DIVISION 2. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Power of the council to establish the planning and zoning commission, § 20. 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 98. 

Sec. 2-81. - Adoption of state laws. 
    All the powers and authority granted to cities by any and all state laws relating to planning and zoning regulations are hereby adopted. 
(Code 1995, § 31.01) 
Charter reference- Power of the council to adopt and modify the zoning plan and zoning map, § 20. 
State Law reference- Municipal zoning authority, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-82. - Established; composition; appointment. 
    A planning and zoning commission is hereby created and established for the city. Such commission shall be composed of seven resident citizens. Such members shall be appointed by the mayor with ratification by the city council. 
(Code 1995, § 31.02; Ord. No. 00-01, § 31.02, 1-25-2000) 
State Law reference- Zoning commission, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.007. 
Sec. 2-83. - Membership; qualifications. 
    The seven regular members of the planning and zoning commission shall be selected at large. The members shall be real property owners and qualified to vote in the city, and shall hold no other position in the city government. 
(Code 1995, § 31.03; Ord. No. 97-22, § 31.03, 5-14-1997; Ord. No. 11-26, 11-22-2011) 
Sec. 2-84. - Term; vacancies. 
    Appointments shall be to the planning and zoning commission each year for a three-year term. Vacancies occurring on the commission shall be filled within 30 days by the city council for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1995, § 31.04) 
Sec. 2-85. - Compensation. 
    Regular members of the planning and zoning commission shall be paid a sum as set forth by ordinance from time to time. 
(Code 1995, § 31.05) 
Sec. 2-86. - Internal organization; management. 
    The mayor shall appoint a chairperson, and the planning and zoning commission shall select a vice-chairperson from its membership, and other such officers as it may deem necessary. Such appointment and election shall be for a period of one year. The commission shall adopt rules for the practical and efficient transaction of business, and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which shall be a public record. 
(Code 1995, § 31.06; Ord. No. 00-01, § 31.06, 1-25-2000) 
State Law reference- Public information, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 552.001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-87. - Meetings. 
    At least one meeting of the planning and zoning commission shall be held each month, and additional meetings may be held from time to time upon the call of the chairperson. 
(Code 1995, § 31.07) 
Sec. 2-88. - Master plan. 
    It shall be the duty of the planning and zoning commission to assist the city council in the development and implementation of the city's master plan. The recommendations of the commission will be through a planning and zoning master plan committee that will function with the council committee to formulate recommendations. 
(Code 1995, § 31.08) 
Sec. 2-89. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission shall have the power to: 
(1)  Promote public interest in, and understanding of, the master plan and planning; 
(2)  Consult and advise with public officials and agencies, public utilities, civic, educational, professional and other organizations and citizens in relation to the protecting or carrying out of the master plan or special planning reports. 
(b)  Upon request, all public officials shall furnish to the commission, within a reasonable time, such available information as it may reasonably require for its work. 
(c)  The commission, its members and employees may enter upon any land and make examinations and surveys in the performance of its functions, and shall place and maintain necessary monuments and marks thereon. 
(d)  The commission shall also perform such other duties that relate to municipal planning as the city council shall prescribe from time to time. 
(Code 1995, § 31.09) 
Sec. 2-90. - Platting board. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall be the platting board of the city, and as such, shall have the control of the platting or subdivision of land within the city, and shall have such authority outside the corporate limits of the city, as permitted by law. 
(Code 1995, § 31.10) 
Charter reference- Platting, § 9. 
Sec. 2-91. - Subdivision and plat regulations. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall recommend to the city council the adoption of rules and regulations governing the platting and subdividing of land. 
(Code 1995, § 31.11) 
Sec. 2-92. - Zoning plan. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall be designated as the zoning commission, and shall recommend a zoning plan to the city council for adoption, and shall recommend or disapprove proposed changes in the plan, subject to the provisions of any existing ordinance covering zoning. 
(Code 1995, § 31.12) 
Secs. 2-93-2-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - AIRPORT BOARD[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Power of the council to operate a municipal airport, § 20. 

Sec. 2-111. - Responsibility; composition. 
    The responsibility for the operation and supervision of the Brownwood Municipal Airport shall be vested in a seven-member board which shall be known as the "Airport Board of the City of Brownwood." 
(Code 1995, § 31.25) 
Sec. 2-112. - Appointment; terms of members; election of officers; rules and regulations. 
(a)  The seven members of the airport board, one of whom shall be a member of the city council, shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council, to serve two-year overlapping terms. The city councilmember of the airport board shall be appointed each year, and all necessary appointments shall be made each January 1. 
(b)  The airport board shall elect a chairperson from its membership and such other officers as it deems necessary. The airport board may make reasonable rules and regulations for its own government in conformity with this division, any amendments thereto, any other applicable city ordinances, the city Charter and the laws of the state. 
(Code 1995, § 31.26) 
Sec. 2-113. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The airport board is hereby authorized to manage and operate the Brownwood Municipal Airport facility, but shall be answerable to the city council in all matters of policy and operation, and subject to its control in all things. 
(b)  The airport board is authorized to: 
(1)  Establish reasonable rules for its operation; 
(2)  Adopt operating policies and procedures; and 
(3)  Employ and supervise necessary operating personnel, including a manager. 
(c)  Through the airport manager, the airport board shall solicit and try to obtain such activities as may be profitable to the airport and the city; however, in no case shall the airport board underwrite any use, and no funds may be borrowed or obligations created by the airport board without the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1995, § 31.27) 
Sec. 2-114. - Budget. 
(a)  The airport board shall submit a proposed budget for each fiscal year to the city council in accordance with budget guidelines prescribed by the city manager. The budget shall contain an estimate of all proposed expenditures, and shall include an estimate of the revenue to be received from the airport operation. 
(b)  All revenues from the airport operation shall be deposited into the airport fund of the city. All expenditures shall be approved by the airport board in such methods as it shall establish, and shall be made from the airport fund of the city in the manner prescribed by the city manager. In no case shall the airport board approve expenditures that have not been budgeted by the city council. 
(Code 1995, § 31.28) 
Sec. 2-115. - Reports to city council. 
    The airport board shall report to the city council on the operations of the airport when requested or on such occasions as it deems desirable. 
(Code 1995, § 31.29) 
Secs. 2-116-2-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TECHNOLOGY BOARD 

Sec. 2-141. - Technology plan. 
    The responsibility to refine, implement and perpetuate a technology plan for the city shall be vested in a seven-member board which shall be known as the "Technology Board of the City of Brownwood." 
(Code 1995, § 31.40) 
Sec. 2-142. - Membership; terms of office; election of officers; rules and regulations; administrative support. 
(a)  The seven members of the technology board, one of whom shall be a member of the city council, shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council, to serve two-year overlapping terms. The city councilmember of the technology board shall be appointed each year, and all necessary appointments shall be made on or before September 1 of each calendar year. 
(b)  The technology board shall elect a chairperson from its membership and such other officers as it deems necessary. The technology board shall develop reasonable rules and regulations for its internal affairs in government in conformity with this division, any amendments thereto, all other applicable city ordinances, the city Charter and the laws of the state. 
(c)  The city staff shall provide administrative support necessary to record and publicize all agendas and minutes of the meetings of the technology board. 
(Code 1995, § 31.41) 
Sec. 2-143. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The technology board shall be comprised of five members. Four members shall be assigned by the city council and one member shall be assigned by the technology board from its membership. The cable television operator may designate a representative of the company to serve as a nonvoting member of the committee. The committee shall have the continuing oversight authority with regard to the cable television operations in the city, and the obligations of the cable television operator for compliance with the terms and conditions of this franchise. 
(b)  The technology board shall be responsible to the city council in all matters of policy and operation, and shall be subject to its control in all things. The technology board shall have the power to form subcommittees, as it deems necessary. The technology board shall report to the city council on the operations of the technology board and the implementation of the technology plan when requested, or on such other occasions as it deems necessary. 
(Code 1995, § 31.42; Ord. No. 02-15, Pt. 1, 3-26-2002)) 
Secs. 2-144-2-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CABLE TELEVISION SERVICE COMMITTEE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Telecommunications, § 98-671 et seq. 

Sec. 2-161. - Membership; meetings; responsibilities. 
(a)  The cable television service committee shall be comprised of the city manager or his designated representative, and three additional members assigned by the city council, and one shall be appointed by the cable operator. The cable television service committee shall have the continuing oversight authority with regard to the cable television operations in the city and the obligations of the cable operator for compliance with the terms and conditions of the franchise. 
(b)  The cable television service committee shall establish a regular schedule for meetings and shall make recommendations, as may be necessary, to the mayor and city council for any necessary action by the council in carrying out its oversight obligations and the administration of the franchise. 
(c)  The authority and responsibility of the cable television service committee shall extend to such matters as rate regulation, customer service requirements, compliance with technical standards and Federal Communications Commission regulations, as well as consideration of any subscriber complaints that are not resolved promptly by the company. 
(d)  The city may delegate such other functions and duties to the cable television service committee under the franchise, as it may deem appropriate. 
(Code 1995, § 92.20) 
Sec. 2-162. - Participation in technology board. 
    The cable television service committee is hereby authorized to be made a part of the city's technology board, with the charge as outlined in this division, to approve and oversee operations and obligations of the cable television company in the city, according to the terms and conditions of the television cable franchise agreement dated November 22, 1994. In addition, the cable television service committee shall interact with, and report to, the technology board to promote and provide technology opportunities for the citizens of the city, in general, and to assist in the implementation of the various elements of the technology plan for the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-30, 7-8-1997) 
Secs. 2-163-2-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - JOINT AIRPORT ZONING BOARD 

Sec. 2-171. - Created. 
    Subject to like provisions being made by the City of Early, Texas, and the commissioners court of the county, by proper order, duly promulgated and entered on their minutes, and as authorized by the provisions of the Airport Zoning Act, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 241.001 et seq., there is hereby created a joint airport zoning board, to be known as the county joint airport zoning board, which board shall have the powers and exercise the duties set forth in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 241.014. 
(Ord. No. 05-23, § 1, 8-23-2005) 
Sec. 2-172. - Membership. 
    The county joint airport zoning board shall be composed of seven members, two members to be appointed by the city council, two members to be appointed by the Early City Council and two members to be appointed by the commissioners court of the county; the seventh member shall be elected by a majority of the members so appointed, and said seventh member shall serve as chairman of the county joint airport zoning board. 
(Ord. No. 05-23, § 2, 8-23-2005) 
Secs. 2-173-2-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - PARK AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-181. - Membership. 
(a)  There is created a six member advisory board which shall assist and advise the park and recreation director, city manager, and the city council on the operation of the city's parks and recreation facilities. The board shall be known as the park and recreation advisory board. 
(b)  The mayor shall appoint the six members to the board. The mayor shall designate one of the appointed members to be the chairman of the board. The mayor's appointments shall be subject to ratification by the city council. The members shall hold office for three-year staggered terms. 
The initial appointments shall be as follows: 
Two appointments for a one-year term; 
Two appointments for two-year terms; and 
Two appointments for three-year terms. 
The chairman shall be one of the initial three-year appointments. 
    All members of the board shall be residents of the city and shall be selected at large. If vacancies occur, such vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointments; however, such terms shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term. Terms of office will run from January 1 through December 31. 
(Ord. No. 07-31, § 1, 12-11-2007; Ord. No. 11-26, 11-22-2011) 
Sec. 2-182. - Rules of procedure. 
    The board is empowered to establish its own parliamentary procedure, provided that such shall not be in conflict with the Charter or other provisions of law. 
(Ord. No. 07-31, § 2, 12-11-2007) 
Sec. 2-183. - Meetings. 
    The board shall meet no less than once each month. Meetings shall be opened to the public, as required pursuant to V.T.C.A., Government Code § 551.001 et seq., and minutes shall be filed with the city secretary and shall be treated as public records. 
    Attendance at meetings. The board may establish its own rules as to the attendance of its members. In furtherance of such, the board may, by a majority vote, request the mayor to remove any member who, in the opinion of the board, misses an unreasonable number of meetings. 
(Ord. No. 07-31, §§ 3, 4, 12-11-2007) 
Sec. 2-184. - Quorum; voting. 
(a)  A quorum at any meeting of the board shall be three voting members of the board, and any vote of the board shall be resolved by a majority vote of the quorum. 
(b)  The chairman shall vote only to break a tie and shall not be considered a voting member of the board. The chairman shall have no veto power. 
(Ord. No. 07-31, § 5, 12-11-2007) 
Sec. 2-185. - Authority to advise. 
    The board is authorized to work with the park and recreation director, city manager and the city council to make recommendations about any matter within their scope of responsibility that it deems beneficial to the city administration, provided that such functions shall not contravene with the Charter or any other law and such shall be considered advisory only. 
(Ord. No. 07-31, § 6, 12-11-2007) 
Sec. 2-186. - Duties; reports. 
    The board shall perform such duties as may be delegated to it by the city council and/or the city manager. They may appoint ad hoc committees to review and recommend changes/improvements within their scope of responsibility. The board shall review the facilities/policies and shall make recommendations in writing to the city manager as to any changes, modifications and other improvements to such facilities/policies. The board shall present a written report to the city council on or before September 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 07-31, § 7, 12-11-2007) 
Secs. 2-187-2-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - MARTIN & FRANCES LEHNIS TRANSPORTATION MUSEUM ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-191. - Membership. 
(a)  The responsibility for the operation and supervision of the Martin & Frances Lehnis Transportation Museum shall be vested in a five member board which shall be called the Martin & Frances Lehnis Transportation Museum Advisory Board. 
(b)  The five members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to ratification by the city council, to serve three-year overlapping terms, running from January 1 to December 31. If vacancies occur, such vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointments, for the remainder of the term being vacated. 
(c)  The members shall be residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-31, 10-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-192. - Rules of procedure. 
    The board is empowered to establish its own parliamentary procedure, provided that such shall not be in conflict with the Charter or other provisions of law. 
(Ord. No. 08-31, 10-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-193. - Meetings. 
(a)  The board shall meet no less than once per quarter. Meetings shall be open to the public, as required pursuant to V.T.C.A., Government Code § 551.001 et seq., and minutes shall be filed with the city secretary and shall be treated as public records. 
(b)  The board may establish its own rules as to the attendance of its members. In furtherance of such, the board may, by a majority vote, request the mayor to remove any member who, in the opinion of the board, misses an unreasonable number of meetings. 
(Ord. No. 08-31, 10-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-194. - Voting. 
(a)  A quorum at any meeting of the board shall be three voting members of the board and any vote of the board shall be resolved by a majority vote of the quorum. 
(b)  The chairman shall be a voting member of the board. 
(Ord. No. 08-31, 10-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-195. - Duties. 
(a)  The boards shall assist and advise the museum curator, city manager and city council on the operation of the museum, especially in the areas of fundraising, grant acquisition, special events and special projects. 
(b)  The board is authorized to work with the museum curator, city manager and the city council to make recommendations about any matter within their scope of responsibility that it deems beneficial to the city administration, provided that such functions shall not contravene with the Charter, or any other law and such shall be considered advisory only. 
(c)  The board shall perform such duties as may be delegated to it by the city council and/or the city manager. They may appoint ad hoc and/or standing committees to review the facilities/policies and shall make recommendations in writing to the city manager as to any changes, modifications and other improvements to such facilities/policies. 
(Ord. No. 08-31, 10-14-2008) 
Sec. 2-196. - Reports. 
    The board shall present a written report to the city council on or before September 1 of each year on the operations of the museum. 
(Ord. No. 08-31, 10-14-2008) 
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS[6] 
Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-197-2-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POLICE AND FIRE 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 2-211. - Civil service. 
    All provisions of the civil service law (V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.001 et seq.), are hereby adopted and incorporated as part of this Code, with respect to city police officers and firefighters, in conjunction with the local civil service commission rules adopted by the city's civil service commission. 
(Code 1995, §§ 32.01, 32.04) 
Sec. 2-212. - Uniforms. 
(a)  Required while on duty. 
(1)  All uniformed police officers and firefighters of the city shall wear a regulation official uniform while on duty. Uniforms shall be of the materials and styles selected by the department and approved by the city manager. 
(2)  The city council may designate one or more members of the police force, and one or more members of the firefighters' force, which may include the chief of each force, who shall not be required to wear the official uniform while on duty. 
(b)  Police officers. The official police officer's uniform shall include a coat, trousers, shirt, duty belt, cap and the necessary badges. 
(c)  Firefighters. The official firefighter's uniform shall include a cap, trousers, shirt, coat and the necessary badges. 
(d)  Shirt as substitute for coat. The city council may designate regulation official shirts for police officers and firefighters. Regulation official shirts may be worn instead of a coat when desired by any police officer or firefighter. 
(e)  Clothing allowance. 
(1)  The plain clothes personnel of the police department, including the chief, juvenile officer and investigative officers, shall be entitled to receive a clothing allowance in such amount as may be fixed from time to time by the city council. Each such officer now serving in a permanent appointed position shall accrue a clothing allowance benefit from September 1, 1991, which shall be payable each March 1 and September 1 thereafter. 
(2)  Should a police officer or firefighter leave the service for any reason after permanent appointment, but before the completion of six months after the receipt of the initial clothing allowance, there shall be withheld from his final earnings an amount equal to the unaccrued portion of the initial clothing allowance. Should a police officer or firefighter leave the service for any reason after the completion of six months after the receipt of the initial clothing allowance, he shall receive a pro rata share payable from his last clothing allowance to his date of termination. 
(f)  Inventory of purchases made. It shall be the responsibility of the chief of police and the fire chief to inventory the initial uniform purchase for each new permanent appointee, and to assure that each member of his department wears the specified uniforms and keeps such uniforms in good repair at all times. 
(Code 1995, § 32.03) 
Secs. 2-213-2-230. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Police Department[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference- Power to establish the city police department, § 13. 
State Law reference- Police force, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 341.003, 341.903. 

Sec. 2-231. - Chief of police. 
(a)  The chief of police shall be the head of the police department of the city. He shall be responsible to the city council for the proper operation of the police department and the enforcement of the laws and ordinances of the city and state. He shall have the power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Establish such rules and procedures to be followed by the police department as may be necessary for proper law enforcement and criminal apprehension. 
(2)  Recommend the appointment and, when necessary for the good of the service, the removal of all officers and employees within the police department within such limits and bounds as prescribed by the civil service statutes and ordinances of the state and the city. 
(3)  Annually, prepare the police department's recommended budget and submit the budget to the city manager for review and inclusion in the total city budget, and be responsible for its efficient administration after adoption. 
(4)  Prepare and submit to the city council, at the end of each month, a report of the activities of the police department during the month, and such other reports as the city council may request. 
(5)  Keep the city council advised on law enforcement within the city, and make such recommendations as may seem desirable to him. 
(6)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the city council which are not inconsistent with the law of the state, nor with the city Charter. 
(b)  The salary of the chief of police shall be fixed by ordinance passed by the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1995, § 32.15(B)) 
Charter reference- Chief of police, §§ 43, 44. 
Secs. 2-232-2-245. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Reserve Police Force 

Sec. 2-246. - Qualifications and standards of training. 
(a)  Members of the reserve police force shall: 
(1)  Be of good moral character; 
(2)  Be at least 21 years of age on the date of appointment; 
(3)  Be a resident of the state; 
(4)  Be physically capable of the duties of a law enforcement officer; 
(5)  Furnish three letters of reference; 
(6)  Hold the minimum basic peace officer certification from an accredited state peace officer training academy; 
(7)  Successfully have completed a state peace officer licensing examination administered by the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education; 
(8)  Not have been found guilty of any felony criminal offense under the state penal code; 
(9)  Consent to drug testing/screening at any time; and 
(10)  Consent to psychiatric evaluation in the event of a 180-day break in service as a state peace officer. 
(b)  Members of the reserve police force shall have the qualifications of an officer as required by the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education, and maintain, at their own expense, required educational programs as mandated by the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education. Instruction programs provided by the city police department shall be made available to the reserve police force membership at no cost, and members of the reserve police force shall demonstrate firearms proficiency on an annual basis, and the results of such proficiency demonstration shall remain in the personnel file of the individual officer. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(A)) 
State Law reference- Police Reserve Force, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.012. 
Sec. 2-247. - Membership. 
    The city council may limit the size of the reserve police force, and the reserve police force shall be composed of not more than 12 members. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(B)) 
Sec. 2-248. - Appointments. 
    The chief of police shall appoint members to the reserve police force with the advice and consent of the city council. Such member shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(C)) 
Sec. 2-249. - Call to service. 
    The chief of police may call the reserve police force into service at any time he considers it necessary to have additional officers to preserve the peace and enforce the law. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(D)) 
Sec. 2-250. - Designation as peace officer. 
    Members of the reserve police force serve as peace officers during the actual discharge of official duties, under guidelines set forth by the chief of police. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(E)) 
Sec. 2-251. - Carrying weapons. 
    An appointment to the reserve police force must be approved by the city council before the person appointed may carry a weapon or otherwise act as a peace officer. After such appointment is approved, the person appointed may carry a weapon only when authorized to do so by the chief of police and only when discharging his duties as a peace officer. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(F)) 
Sec. 2-252. - Action as a supplementary force. 
    Reserve police force officers may act only on a supplementary capacity to the regular police force, and may not assume the full-time duties of regular police officers without complying with the requirements for regular peace officers. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(G)) 
Sec. 2-253. - Oath required. 
    Members of the reserve police force shall subscribe to an oath that he will swear or affirm to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States of America, the state constitution and the ordinances governing the city. He will further swear or affirm that he will carry out the duties of a member of the reserve police force to the best of his ability. Persons taking the oath shall indicate such by signature and/or affirmation. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(H)) 
Sec. 2-254. - Compensation. 
    Members of the reserve police force shall serve without monetary compensation when ordered to active duty by the chief of police or his designee. There shall be no remuneration for the tour of training, nor for service voluntarily performed, unless such compensation is authorized by the chief of police. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(I)) 
Sec. 2-255. - Badges; uniforms; insignia. 
(a)  The chief of police shall prescribe the uniforms, badges and insignia worn by reserve police force personnel, and direct the manner in which they shall be worn or displayed. The city shall furnish reserve police force members with the following: 
(1)  One uniform shirt, with patches and the insignia for the reserve police force; 
(2)  One pair of uniform pants in compliance with departmental standards; 
(3)  One badge bearing the official insignia of the reserve police force; 
(4)  One set of credentials identifying the bearer as a reserve police force officer. 
(b)  Should the reserve police force officer be terminated or otherwise become disassociated with the reserve police force, all assigned equipment, badges, uniforms, insignia and credentials shall be returned to the chief of police within 72 hours of the separation from the department. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(J)) 
Sec. 2-256. - Use of communications systems by officers. 
    Reserve police force officers on duty shall have the same electronic voice (radio) transmission privileges that any full-time officer incorporates in the performance of his duties. Reserve police force officers, at the discretion of the chief of police, may exercise radio privileges while not on duty, if such action assists the department in its obligation to public safety and the preservation of the peace and dignity of the state and city. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(K)) 
Sec. 2-257. - Access to confidential information by officers. 
    Unless otherwise directed by the chief of police, his designee or the police communications supervisor, reserve police force officers shall have access to the Texas Crime Information Computer and National Crime Information Computer (TCIC-NCIC) and the Texas Law Enforcement Telecommunications System (T-LETS) and National Law Enforcement Telecommunications System (N-LETS) communications systems, while on duty or at the discretion of the chief of police or police communications supervisor. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(L)) 
Sec. 2-258. - Required number of service hours per calendar month; service schedule; excused absences; training time. 
    Reserve police force officers shall work a minimum of 16 hours per calendar month, and shall maintain a service schedule prepared by the chief of police or his designee. Excused absences shall be at the discretion of the chief of police or his designee. Training time shall be considered on-duty time, and reserve police force officers shall be credited with service time for training time. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(M)) 
Sec. 2-259. - Authority; power of arrest. 
    While on duty, reserve police force officers are state peace officers, empowered with the same authority as any full-time peace officer, and subject to the same rules and regulations. Reserve police force officers may only make arrests while on duty. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(N)) 
State Law reference- Arrest without a warrant, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. arts. 14.01-14.06; what force may be used, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. arts. 15.24, 15.25; use of deadly force, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 9.51. 
Sec. 2-260. - Prescribed duty weapons. 
    No reserve police force officer will carry a handgun larger than a 0.45 caliber, nor smaller than a nine millimeter, while performing the duties of a reserve police force officer. Reserve police force officers shall carry the weapon that the individual officer has successfully demonstrated proficiency with on a prescribed firing range and course of fire, as set forth by the police department's firearms proficiency officer. All weapons used on duty by reserve police force officers will be registered in the officers' personal equipment file, and proof of legal ownership may be required, at the discretion of the chief of police. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(Q)) 
Sec. 2-261. - Personal equipment. 
    Reserve police force officers shall provide their own duty weapon of an appropriate caliber, ammunition, belts, holsters, handcuffs, associated leather gear and all equipment required that is not supplied by the city. It is the duty of all reserve police force officers to maintain their firearms and equipment in good working order. All equipment is subject to inspection at any time by the chief of police or his designee. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(R)) 
Sec. 2-262. - Suspension. 
    The chief of police may suspend any reserve police force officer for any length of time for any reason, for a violation of the regulations concerning duty or conduct or if the reserve police force officer demonstrates an inability to perform the duties of a reserve police force officer. A suspension is an administrative order and may be issued only by the chief of police. An officer may be temporarily or permanently reassigned in lieu of suspension or termination. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(S)) 
Sec. 2-263. - Termination and dismissal. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to terminate or dismiss any member of the reserve police force at any time. The chief of police may take such action at his own discretion, and the chief of police's decision is final. The terminated or dismissed reserve police force officer shall have no recourse available for reinstatement once the chief of police has reached a final, written decision in the matter. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(T)) 
Sec. 2-264. - Resignation. 
    Reserve police force officers who voluntarily resign their position with the reserve police force unit shall do so in writing, with a minimum of two weeks' advance notice, if possible. If the required notice cannot be honored, as much time as possible should be allowed before the departure becomes effective. Deviation from the requirements of this section may result in an unfavorable performance reference from the department, at the discretion of the chief of police. 
(Code 1995, § 32.16(U)) 
Secs. 2-265-2-300. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - Fire Department[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- Power to establish the city fire department, § 13. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
State Law reference- Municipal fire protection, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 342.011 et seq. 

Sec. 2-301. - Fire chief. 
(a)  Appointment. A chief of the fire department shall be appointed. 
(b)  Duties and powers. The chief of the fire department shall have general supervision and control of the fire department. 
(Code 1995, § 32.25) 
Sec. 2-302. - Police power at fire scenes. 
    The chief and all members of the fire department shall have the police powers at all fires as the police officers of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 32.26) 
State Law reference- Interference with firefighters, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 38.15; following or obstructing fire apparatus, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.407; crossing a fire hose, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.408. 
Sec. 2-303. - Riding on fire apparatus. 
    It is unlawful for any person, other than a member of the fire department of the city, to ride, or attempt to ride, on any vehicle belonging to the fire department at any time while the vehicle is being used by the fire department at the time of a fire or at a practice. 
(Code 1995, § 32.28) 
Secs. 2-304-2-330. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - CITY MANAGER[10] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 2-351. - Attendance at city council meetings; vote. 
    The city manager shall attend all meetings of the city council, and take part in the discussion of matters pertaining to his department, but shall have no vote. 
(Code 1995, § 30.01(A)) 
Sec. 2-352. - Advising city council. 
    The city manager shall from time to time make such suggestions to the city council as he may desire, and he shall keep the city council fully advised as to matters pertaining to his department. 
(Code 1995, § 30.01(B)) 
Sec. 2-353. - Full-time service. 
    The city manager shall give all of his time to the service of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 30.01(C))
