a.  Which has no sign visible from the exterior of the structure and no other advertising that indicates a nude person is available for viewing; 
b.  Where a student must enroll at least three days in advance of the class in order to participate in the class; and 
c.  Where no more than one nude model is on the premises at any one time. 
(e)  It is a defense to prosecution under section 10-142 or 10-173 that each item of descriptive, printed, film or video material offered for sale or rental, taken as a whole, contains serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. 
(Code 1995, § 158.524) 
State Law reference- Misdemeanor authorized, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.010. 
Sec. 10-96. - Injunction. 
    A person who operates, or causes to be operated, a sexually oriented business without a valid license or in violation of section 10-173 is subject to a suit for injunction, as well as prosecution for criminal violations. 
(Code 1995, § 158.525) 
Secs. 10-97-10-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 10-121. - Inspections. 
(a)  An applicant or licensee shall permit representatives of the police department, fire department, department of streets, sanitation and code enforcement services, and the building official to inspect the premises of a sexually oriented business for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the law, at any time it such business occupied or open for business. 
(b)  A person who operates a sexually oriented business or his agent or employee commits an offense if he refuses to permit a lawful inspection of the premises by a representative of the police department at any time it such business is occupied or open for business. 
(c)  The provisions of this section do not apply to areas of an adult motel which are currently being rented by a customer for use as a permanent or temporary habitation. 
(Code 1995, § 158.507(A)-(C)) 
State Law reference- Inspection authorized, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.008. 
Secs. 10-122-10-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-141. - Required. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he operates a sexually oriented business without a valid license issued by the city for the particular type of business. 
(b)  An application for a license must be made on a form provided by the chief of police. The completed application shall contain the following information and shall be accompanied by the following documents: 
(1)  If the applicant is: 
a.  An individual, the individual shall state his legal name and any aliases, and submit satisfactory proof that he is at least 18 years of age; 
b.  A partnership, the partnership shall state its complete name, and the names of all partners, whether the partnership is general or limited, and, if in existence, a copy of the partnership agreement; or 
c.  A corporation, the corporation shall state its complete name, the date of its incorporation, evidence that the corporation is in good standing, the names and capacity of all officers, directors and principal stockholders, and, if applicable, the name of the registered corporate agent and the address of the registered office for service of process. 
(2)  If the applicant intends to conduct the establishment under a name other than the name of the applicant, the establishment's fictitious name and the county of registration under the assumed name or professional name act statutes of the state. 
(3)  Whether the applicant, or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section, has, within the five-year period immediately preceding the date of the application, been convicted of a specified criminal act, and, if so, the specified criminal act involved, the date of conviction and the place of conviction. 
(4)  Whether the applicant, or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section, has had a previous license under this division suspended or revoked, including the name and location of the establishment for which the license was suspended or revoked, as well as the date of the suspension or revocation, and whether the applicant, or any other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section, has been a partner in a partnership or an officer, director or principal stockholder of a corporation whose license under this division has previously been suspended or revoked, including the name and location of the establishment for which the license was suspended or revoked, as well as the date of the suspension or revocation. 
(5)  Whether the applicant, or any other individuals listed pursuant to subsection (b)(1) of this section, holds any other licenses under this division and, if so, the names and locations of such other licensed establishments. 
(6)  The single classification of license for which the applicant is filing. 
(7)  The location of the proposed establishment, including a street address. 
(8)  The names of the employees for the proposed establishment, if known, or, if presently unknown, a statement to that effect. 
(9)  A plan, drawn to appropriate scale, of the proposed licensed premises, indicating the areas to be covered by the license, all windows, doors, entrances and exits and the fixed structural features of the establishment to which the proposed license pertains. The term "fixed structural features" shall include immovable partitions, counters and similar structures that are intended to be permanent. 
(10)  The applicant's mailing address and, if different, a designated return address where all future correspondence from the county may be sent. 
(11)  Any additional information which the planning and zoning commission deems necessary to effectuate the language and purposes of this article. 
(c)  The applicant must be qualified according to the provisions of this division. 
(d)  The fact that a person possesses a valid dancehall license does not exempt the person from the requirement of obtaining a sexually oriented business license. 
(Code 1995, § 158.504) 
Sec. 10-142. - Issuance. 
(a)  The chief of police shall approve the issuance of a license by the city secretary to an applicant within 30 days after receipt of an application unless the chief of police finds one or more of the following to be true: 
(1)  An applicant is under 18 years of age; 
(2)  An applicant or his spouse is overdue in payment to the city of taxes, fees, fines or penalties assessed against or imposed upon the applicant or his spouse in relation to a sexually oriented business; 
(3)  An applicant has failed to provide information reasonably necessary for issuance of the license or has falsely answered a question or request for information on the application form; 
(4)  An applicant or his spouse has been convicted of a violation of a provision of this article, other than the offense of operating a sexually oriented business without a license, within two years immediately preceding the application; 
(5)  Any fee required by this article has not been paid; 
(6)  An applicant has been employed in a sexually oriented business in a managerial capacity within the preceding 12 months and has demonstrated an inability to operate or manage a sexually oriented business premises in a peaceful and law abiding manner, thereby necessitating action by law enforcement officers; 
(7)  An applicant or the proposed establishment is in violation of, or is not in compliance with, sections 10-121, 10-145, 10-172, 10-173 and 10-178-10-183; or 
(8)  An applicant or his spouse has been convicted of a crime: 
a.  Involving: 
1.  Any of the following offenses as described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 43: 
i.  Prostitution; 
ii.  Promotion of prostitution; 
iii.  Aggravated promotion of prostitution; 
iv.  Compelling prostitution; 
v.  Obscenity; 
vi.  Sale, distribution or display of harmful material to a minor; 
vii.  Sexual performance by a child; or 
viii.  Possession of child pornography. 
2.  Any of the following offenses as described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 21: 
i.  Public lewdness; 
ii.  Indecent exposure; or 
iii.  Indecency with a child. 
3.  Sexual assault or aggravated sexual assault as described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 22; 
4.  Incest, solicitation of a child or harboring a runaway child as described in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 25; or 
5.  Criminal attempt, conspiracy or solicitation to commit any of the offenses listed in this subsection (a)(8)a. 
b.  For which: 
1.  Less than two years have elapsed since the date of conviction or release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a misdemeanor offense; 
2.  Less than five years have elapsed since the date of conviction or release from confinement imposed for the conviction, whichever is the later date, if the conviction is of a felony offense; or 
3.  Less than five years have elapsed since the date of the last conviction or release from confinement imposed for the last conviction, whichever is the later date, if the convictions are of two or more misdemeanor offenses, or combination of misdemeanor offenses, occurring within any 24-month period. 
(b)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed has no effect on the disqualification of the applicant or his spouse under subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  An applicant or his spouse who has been convicted of an offense listed in subsection (a)(8)a. of this section may qualify for a sexually oriented business license only when the time period required by subsection (a)(8)b. of this section has elapsed. 
(d)  The chief of police, upon approving issuance of a sexually oriented business license, shall send to the applicant, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of such approval, and state where the applicant must pay the license fee and obtain the license. The chief of police's approval of the issuance of a license does not authorize the applicant to operate a sexually oriented business until the applicant has paid all fees required by this article and obtained possession of the license. 
(e)  If granted, the license must state on its face the name of the persons to whom it is granted, the expiration date and the address of the sexually oriented business. The license must be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance to the sexually oriented business so that it may be easily read at any time. 
(Code 1995, § 158.505) 
Sec. 10-143. - Fees. 
(a)  The annual fee for a sexually oriented business license shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(b)  In addition to the fees required by subsection (a) of this section, an applicant for an initial sexually oriented business license shall, at the time of making application, pay a nonrefundable fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office for the city to conduct a survey to ensure that the proposed sexually oriented business is in compliance with the location restrictions set forth in section 10-173. 
(c)  If an applicant is required by this Code to also obtain a dancehall license for the business at a single location, payment of the fee for the sexually oriented business license shall not exempt the applicant from payment of the fees for the dancehall license. 
(Code 1995, § 158.506) 
Sec. 10-144. - Expiration. 
    Each sexually oriented business license expires one year from the date of issuance, except that a license issued pursuant to a locational restriction expires on the date the exemption expires. A license may be renewed only by making application as provided in section 10-141. Application for renewal should be made at least 30 days before the expiration date, and when made less than 30 days before the expiration date, the expiration of the license will not be affected by the pendency of the application. 
(Code 1995, § 158.508) 
Sec. 10-145. - Transferability. 
    A licensee shall not transfer his license to another, nor shall a licensee operate a sexually oriented business under the authority of a license at any place other than the address designated in the license application. 
(Code 1995, § 158.512) 
Sec. 10-146. - Suspension. 
    The chief of police shall suspend a sexually oriented business license for a period not to exceed 30 days if he determines that a licensee or an employee of a licensee has: 
(1)  Violated or is not in compliance with sections 10-121, 10-145, 10-172, 10-173 and 10-178-10-183; 
(2)  Engaged in excessive use of alcoholic beverages while on the sexually oriented business premises; 
(3)  Refused to allow an inspection of the sexually oriented business premises as authorized by this article; 
(4)  Knowingly permitted gambling by any person on the sexually oriented business premises; 
(5)  Demonstrated an inability to operate or manage a sexually oriented business in a peaceful and law abiding manner, thereby necessitating action by law enforcement officers. 
(Code 1995, § 158.509) 
Sec. 10-147. - Revocation. 
(a)  The chief of police shall revoke a sexually oriented business license if a cause of suspension in section 10-146 occurs and the license has been suspended within the preceding 12 months. 
(b)  The chief of police shall revoke a license if he determines that: 
(1)  A licensee gave false or misleading information in the material submitted to the chief of police during the application process; 
(2)  A licensee or an employee of the licensee has knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances on the premises; 
(3)  A licensee or an employee of the licensee has knowingly allowed prostitution on the premises; 
(4)  A licensee or an employee of the licensee knowingly operated the sexually oriented business during a period of time when the licensee's license was suspended; 
(5)  A licensee has been convicted of an offense listed in section 10-142(a)(8)a., for which the time period required in section 10-142(a)(8)b. has not elapsed; 
(6)  On two or more occasions within a 12-month period, a person committed an offense occurring in or on the licensed premises of a crime listed in section 10-142(a)(8)a., for which a conviction has been obtained, and the person was an employee of the sexually oriented business at the time the offense was committed; 
(7)  A licensee or an employee of the licensee has knowingly allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation or sexual contact to occur in or on the licensed premises. The term "sexual contact" shall have the same meaning as such term is defined in V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 21.01; or 
(8)  A licensee is delinquent in payment to the city for hotel occupancy taxes, ad valorem taxes or sales taxes related to the sexually oriented business. 
(c)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the revocation of the license. 
(d)  Subsection (b)(7) of this section does not apply to adult motels as grounds for revoking the license unless the licensee or employee knowingly allowed the act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation or sexual contact to occur in a public place or within public view. 
(e)  When the chief of police revokes a license, the revocation shall continue for one year and the licensee shall not be issued a sexually oriented business license for one year from the date such revocation became effective. If, subsequent to revocation, the chief of police finds that the basis for the revocation has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date the revocation became effective. If the license was revoked under subsection (b)(5) of this section, an applicant may not be granted another license until the appropriate number of years required under section 10-142(a)(8)b. has elapsed. 
(Code 1995, § 158.510) 
Sec. 10-148. - Appeals. 
    If the chief of police denies the issuance or renewal of a sexually oriented business license, or suspends or revokes a license, the chief of police shall send to the applicant or licensee, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of the action and the right to an appeal. Upon receipt of written notice of the denial, suspension or revocation, the applicant or licensee whose application for a license or license renewal has been denied or whose license has been suspended or revoked has the right to appeal to the state district court. An appeal to the state district court must be filed within 30 days after the receipt of notice of the decision of the chief of police. The applicant or licensee shall bear the burden of proof in court. 
(Code 1995, § 158.511) 
Secs. 10-149-10-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 10-171. - Minors prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for an operator of an adult entertainment establishment, regardless of whether such establishment is licensed under this article, to knowingly, or with reason to know, permit, suffer or allow a person under 18 years of age: 
(1)  Admittance to the establishment. 
(2)  To remain at the establishment. 
(3)  To purchase goods or services at the establishment. 
(4)  To work at the establishment as an employee. 
(Code 1995, § 158.526) 
Sec. 10-172. - Display of sexually explicit material to minors. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if, in a business establishment open to persons under the age of 18 years, he displays a book, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, film or videocassette, the cover of which depicts, in a manner calculated to arouse sexual lust or passion for commercial gain or to exploit sexual lust or perversion for commercial gain, any of the following: 
(1)  Human sexual intercourse, masturbation or sodomy; 
(2)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, the pubic region, buttocks or female breasts; 
(3)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, buttocks or the portion of the female breast below the top of the areola; or 
(4)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, whether covered or uncovered. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the term "display" means to locate an item in such a manner that without obtaining assistance from an employee of the business establishment: 
(1)  It is available to the general public for handling and inspection; or 
(2)  The cover or outside packaging on the item is visible to members of the general public. 
(Code 1995, § 158.523) 
State Law reference- Display of harmful material to a minor, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 43.24. 
Sec. 10-173. - Location. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he operates, or causes to be operated, a sexually oriented business within 1,500 feet of: 
(1)  A church; 
(2)  A public or private elementary or secondary school; 
(3)  A boundary of a residential or historic district, as defined in section 10-91; 
(4)  A public park; 
(5)  The property line of a lot devoted to a residential use, as defined in section 10-91; 
(6)  A hospital; or 
(7)  A licensed child care facility. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he causes or permits the operation, establishment, substantial enlargement or transfer of ownership or control of a sexually oriented business within 1,500 feet of another sexually oriented business. 
(c)  A person commits an offense if he causes or permits the operation, establishment or maintenance of more than one sexually oriented business in the same building or structure, or portion of a building or structure. 
(d)  For the purposes of subsection (a) of this section, measurement must be made in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the nearest portion of the building or structure used as a part of the premises where a sexually oriented business is conducted, to the nearest property line of the premises of a church, public or private elementary or secondary school, hospital or child care facility, or to the nearest boundary of an affected public park, residential district, historic district or residential lot. 
(e)  For the purposes of subsection (b) of this section, the distance between any two sexually oriented businesses must be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the closest exterior wall of the structure in which each business is located. 
(f)  A sexually oriented business fully operating as a conforming use is not rendered a nonconforming use by the location, subsequent to the grant or renewal of the sexually oriented business license, of a church, public or private elementary or secondary school, public park, residential district, historic district, residential lot, hospital or child care facility within 1,500 feet of the sexually oriented business. Such provision applies only to the renewal of a valid license, and does not apply when an application for a license is submitted after a license has expired or has been revoked. 
(Code 1995, § 158.513) 
Sec. 10-174. - Exemption from location restrictions. 
(a)  If the chief of police denies the issuance of a license to an applicant because the location of the sexually oriented business establishment is in violation of section 10-173, then the applicant may, not later than ten calendar days after receiving notice of the denial, file with the city secretary a written request for an exemption from the location restrictions of section 10-173. 
(b)  If the written request is filed with the city secretary within the ten-day limit, the zoning board of adjustment shall consider the request. The city secretary shall set a date for the hearing within 60 days from the date the written request is received. 
(c)  The zoning board of adjustment may, in its discretion, grant an exemption from the location restrictions of section 10-173 if it makes the following findings: 
(1)  The location of the proposed sexually oriented business will not have a detrimental effect on nearby properties or be contrary to the public safety or welfare; 
(2)  The granting of the exemption will not violate the spirit and intent of this article; 
(3)  The location of the proposed sexually oriented business will not downgrade the property values or quality of life in the adjacent areas or encourage the development of urban blight; 
(4)  The location of an additional sexually oriented business in the area will not be contrary to any program of neighborhood conservation, nor will it interfere with any efforts of urban renewal or restoration; and 
(5)  All other applicable provisions of this article will be observed. 
(d)  The zoning board of adjustment shall grant or deny the exemption by a majority vote. Failure to reach a majority vote shall result in denial of the exemption. Disputes of fact shall be decided on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence. The decision of the zoning board of adjustment is final. 
(e)  If the zoning board of adjustment grants the exemption, the exemption is valid for one year from the date of the zoning board of adjustment's action. Upon the expiration of an exemption, the sexually oriented business is in violation of the location restrictions of section 10-173 until the applicant applies for and receives another exemption. 
(f)  If the zoning board of adjustment denies the exemption, the applicant may not reapply for an exemption until at least 12 months have elapsed since the date of the zoning board of adjustment's action. 
(g)  The grant of an exemption does not exempt the applicant from any other provisions of this article, other than the location restrictions of section 10-173. 
(Code 1995, § 158.514) 
Sec. 10-175. - Exterior portions of sexually oriented businesses. 
(a)  An owner or operator of a sexually oriented business commits an offense if he allows the: 
(1)  Merchandise or activities of the establishment to be visible from any point outside the establishment; 
(2)  Exterior portions of the establishment to have flashing lights, or any words, lettering, photographs, silhouettes, drawings or pictorial representations of any manner, except to the extent permitted by this article; or 
(3)  Exterior portions of the establishment to be painted any color other than a single chromatic color, except that this subsection does not apply to an establishment if the following conditions are met: 
a.  The establishment is a part of a commercial multiunit center; and 
b.  The exterior portions of each individual unit in the commercial multiunit center, including the exterior portions of the establishment, are painted the same color or are painted in such a way as to be a component of the overall architectural style or pattern of the commercial multiunit center. 
(b)  Nothing in this section requires the painting of an otherwise unpainted exterior portion of a sexually oriented business. 
(Code 1995, § 158.515) 
Sec. 10-176. - Sign required at entrance. 
    The operator of a sexually oriented business shall maintain at each public entrance at least one conspicuous sign of a size of at least 18 inches in height and 24 inches in width, easily visible and legible to all persons prior to entry into the establishment, which contains a statement to the effect that: 
"This is a sexually oriented business establishment which regularly features  (describe activities or merchandise)  . If nudity or activity of a sexual nature offends you, do not come in. No person under 18 years of age is allowed entry" (if alcoholic beverages are sold on the premises)-"No person under 21 years of age is allowed entry." 
(Code 1995, § 158.507(D)) 
Sec. 10-177. - Primary and secondary signs. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any provision of the state local government code or any other city ordinance, code or regulation to the contrary, the owner or operator of any sexually oriented business or any other person commits an offense if he erects, constructs or maintains any sign for the establishment other than one primary sign and one secondary sign, as provided in this section. 
(b)  A primary sign may have no more than two display surfaces. Each display surface must: 
(1)  Not contain any flashing lights; 
(2)  Be a flat plane, rectangular in shape; 
(3)  Not exceed 75 square feet in area; and 
(4)  Not exceed ten feet in height or ten feet in length. 
(c)  A secondary sign may have only one display surface. The display surface must: 
(1)  Not contain any flashing lights; 
(2)  Be a flat plane, rectangular in shape; 
(3)  Not exceed 20 square feet in area; 
(4)  Not exceed five feet in height or four feet in width; and 
(5)  Be affixed or attached to a wall or door of the establishment. 
(d)  A primary or secondary sign must contain no photographs, silhouettes, drawings or pictorial representations of any manner, and may contain only: 
(1)  The name of the establishment; and/or 
(2)  One or more of the following phrases: 
a.  "Adult arcade"; 
b.  "Adult bookstore or adult video store"; 
c.  "Adult cabaret"; 
d.  "Adult motel"; 
e.  "Adult motion picture theater"; 
f.  "Adult theater"; 
g.  "Escort agency"; or 
h.  "Nude model studio." 
(e)  A primary sign for an adult motion picture theater may contain the phrase "Movie titles posted on premises," in addition to the phrases listed in subsection (d)(2) of this section. 
(f)  Each letter forming a word on a primary or secondary sign must be of a solid color, and each letter must be the same print type, size and color. The background behind the lettering on the display surface of a primary or secondary sign must be of a uniform and solid color. 
(Code 1995, § 158.516) 
Sec. 10-178. - Additional escort agency regulations. 
(a)  An escort agency shall not employ any person under the age of 18 years. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he acts, or agrees to act, as an escort for any person under the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1995, § 158.517) 
Sec. 10-179. - Additional nude model studio regulations. 
(a)  A nude model studio shall not employ any person under the age of 18 years. 
(b)  A person under the age of 18 years commits an offense if he appears in or on the premises of a nude model studio. It is a defense to prosecution under this subsection if the person under 18 years of age was in a restroom not open to public view or persons of the opposite sex. 
(c)  A person commits an offense if he appears, or knowingly allows another person to appear, in a state of nudity in an area of a nude model studio premises that can be viewed from the public right-of-way. 
(d)  A nude model studio shall not place or permit a bed, sofa or mattress in any room on the premises, except a sofa may be placed in a reception room open to the public. 
(e)  An employee of a nude model studio, while exposing any specified anatomical areas, commits an offense if he touches a customer or the clothing of a customer. 
(f)  A customer at a nude model studio commits an offense if he touches an employee who is exposing any specified anatomical areas or touches the clothing of the employee. 
(g)  A licensee or an employee of a nude model studio commits an offense if he permits any customer access to an area of the premises not visible from the manager's station or by a walk through of the premises without entering a closed area, excluding a restroom. 
(Code 1995, § 158.518) 
Sec. 10-180. - Additional adult theater and adult motion picture theater regulations. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he knowingly allows a person under the age of 18 years to appear in or on the premises of an adult theater or adult motion picture theater. 
(b)  A person under the age of 18 years commits an offense if he knowingly appears in or on the premises of an adult theater or adult motion picture theater. 
(Code 1995, § 158.519) 
Sec. 10-181. - Additional adult motel regulations. 
(a)  Evidence that a sleeping room in a hotel, motel or similar commercial establishment has been rented and vacated two or more times in a period of time that is less than ten hours creates a rebuttable presumption that the establishment is an adult motel, as defined in section 10-91. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if, as the person in control of a sleeping room in a hotel, motel or similar commercial establishment that does not have a sexually oriented business license, he rents or subrents a sleeping room to a person and, within ten hours from the time the room is rented, he rents or subrents the same sleeping room again. 
(c)  For purposes of subsection (b) of this section, the term "rent" or "subrent" means an act of permitting a room to be occupied for any form of consideration. 
(Code 1995, § 158.20) 
Sec. 10-182. - Additional adult cabaret regulations. 
(a)  An employee of an adult cabaret, while exposing any specified anatomical areas, commits an offense if he touches a customer or the clothing of a customer. 
(b)  A customer at an adult cabaret commits an offense if he touches an employee who is exposing any specified anatomical areas or touches the clothing of the employee. 
(c)  A licensee or an employee of an adult cabaret commits an offense if he permits any customer access to an area of the premises not visible from the manager's station or by a walk through of the premises without entering a closed area, excluding a restroom. 
(Code 1995, § 158.521) 
Sec. 10-183. - Exhibition of sexually explicit films and videos. 
(a)  A person who operates, or causes to be operated, a sexually oriented business, other than an adult motel, which exhibits on the premises, in a viewing room of less than 150 square feet of floor space, a film, videocassette or other video reproduction which depicts specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Upon application for a sexually oriented business license, the application shall be accompanied by a diagram of the premises, showing a plan thereof, specifying the location of one or more manager's stations and all overhead lighting fixtures, and designating any portion of the premises in which patrons will not be permitted. A manager's station may not exceed 32 square feet of floor area. The diagram shall also designate the place at which the permit will be conspicuously posted, if granted. A professionally prepared diagram, in the nature of an engineer's or architect's blueprint, shall not be required; however, each diagram should be oriented to the north or to a designated street or object, and should be drawn to a designated scale or with marked dimensions sufficient to show the various internal dimensions of all areas of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches. The chief of police may waive the diagram requirement for renewal applications if the applicant adopts a diagram that was previously submitted and certifies that the configuration of the premises has not been altered since the diagram was prepared. 
(2)  The application shall be sworn to be true and correct by the applicant. 
(3)  No alteration in the configuration or location of a manager's station may be made without the prior approval of the chief of police or his designee. 
(4)  It is the duty of the owners and operator of the premises to ensure that at least one employee is on duty and situated in each manager's station at all times that any patron is present inside the premises. 
(5)  The interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view from a manager's station of every area of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose, excluding restrooms. Restrooms may not contain video reproduction equipment. If the premises has two or more manager's stations designated, then the interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view from at least one of the manager's stations of each area of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose. The view required in this subsection must be by direct line of sight from the manager's station. 
(6)  It shall be the duty of the owners, operator and any agents and employees present in the premises to ensure that the view area specified in subsection (a)(5) of this section remains unobstructed by any doors, walls, merchandise, display racks or other materials at all times that any patron is present in the premises, and to ensure that no patron is permitted access to any area of the premises which has been designated as an area in which patrons will not be permitted in the application filed pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(7)  The premises shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted access, at an illumination of not less than one footcandle as measured at the floor level. 
(8)  It shall be the duty of the owners, operator and any agents and employees present in the premises to ensure that the illumination described in subsection (a)(7) of this section is maintained at all times that any patron is present in the premises. 
(b)  A person having a duty under subsections (a)(1)-(8) of this section commits an offense if he knowingly fails to fulfill such duty. 
(Code 1995, § 158.522) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power to regulate animals, public pounds, § 13. 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Health and safety of animals, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 821.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any live vertebrate creature, domestic or wild. 
    Animal control authority means the city animal control officer who has authority over the area where a dog is kept. 
    At large means any animal off the property of its owner and not under the control of a competent person. 
    Dangerous dog means a dog which: 
(1)  Makes an unprovoked attack on a person which causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own; or 
(2)  Commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and such acts cause a person to reasonably believe that the dog will attack and cause bodily injury to such person. 
    Dangerous wild animal has the same meaning as defined in V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.101, a lion, tiger, ocelot, cougar, leopard, cheetah, jaguar, bobcat, lynx, serval, caracal, hyena, bear, coyote, jackal, baboon, chimpanzee, gorilla or any hybrid of animal listed in this definition. 
    Dog means a domesticated animal that is a member of the canine family. 
    Domestic animal means an animal which is naturally tame and gentle, or which, by long association with man, has become thoroughly domesticated and is now reduced to such a state of subjection to his will that such animal no longer possesses a disposition or inclination to escape. 
    Kennel means any place where more than four dogs or cats, or any combination thereof, where the total exceeds four animals over the age of ten weeks, and where such animals are raised, trained, boarded, harbored or kept. 
    Nuisance means any animal or fowl kept, maintained or harbored within the city, which: 
(1)  Has fierce, dangerous or vicious propensities; 
(2)  Has bitten, scratched or otherwise attacked any person, animal or fowl; 
(3)  By loud, unusual or prolonged barking or howling, causes the peace and quiet of any neighbor, neighborhood or occupant of any adjacent premises to be disturbed; or 
(4)  Has repeatedly destroyed or damaged any property. 
    Owner means a person who owns or has custody or control of a dog. 
    Restraint means when an animal is: 
(1)  Confined within a fence or enclosure on the premises of the owner; 
(2)  Fastened or picketed by a lead, rope or chain so as to keep the animal on the premises; 
(3)  Under the control of a person by a leash; 
(4)  On or within a vehicle being driven or parked; 
(5)  At heel beside a competent person and obedient to that person's command. 
    Secure enclosure means a fenced area or structure which is: 
(1)  Locked; 
(2)  Capable of preventing the entry of the general public, including children; 
(3)  Capable of preventing the escape or release of a dog; 
(4)  Clearly marked as containing a dangerous dog; and 
(5)  In conformance with the requirements for enclosure established by the local animal control authority. 
    Vaccination means one injection of rabies vaccine, which has been approved by the U.S. Department of Public Health. 
    Wild animal means an animal of wild nature or disposition so as to require to be reclaimed and made tame by art, industry or education, or which must be kept in confinement to be brought within the immediate control of the owner. 
(Code 1995, §§ 91.01, 91.40(A); Ord. No. 02-22, § 1, 5-14-2002) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.041. 
Sec. 14-2. - Loud noises prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or be in control of any animal which causes unreasonably loud or unnecessary noise, or causes material distress or discomfort to a person of ordinary sensibilities in the immediate vicinity. 
(Code 1995, § 91.04) 
Sec. 14-3. - Animal traps. 
(a)  Placement and baiting. It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to place or place and bait, or to permit the placing or placing and baiting, of any trap designed for trapping animals in any highway, street, alley or other public place within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Setting and baiting of certain traps prohibited. It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to set or bait, or permit the setting, baiting or placing, of any trap designed for trapping animals and commonly known as a "steel jawed trap," "bear trap," "wolf trap" or "coyote trap," within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  Declaration of abandonment; impoundment. Any traps described in this section which are found upon any public property shall be declared to be abandoned traps, and any police officer is authorized and directed to impound such traps and process them as abandoned property in accordance with section 34-145(c). 
(Code 1995, § 91.06) 
Sec. 14-4. - Wild animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to harbor, possess or maintain the following within the city limits: 
(1)  Bats; 
(2)  Skunks; 
(3)  Poisonous reptiles; 
(4)  Foxes and bobcats; 
(5)  Any wild animal whose normal mature weight exceeds 40 pounds; 
(6)  Any dangerous wild animal. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to sell any wild animal within the city limits. 
(c)  The owner shall keep his wild animal under restraint at all times. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to or prohibit the keeping of wild animals by the following: 
(1)  A publicly owned or privately owned zoo, maintained or operated by a nonprofit organization or governmental entity. 
(2)  A publicly maintained or privately maintained circus, traveling show or rodeo, which does not remain in the city for longer than 30 days out of each year. 
(3)  Hospitals, clinics and other premises operated by licensed veterinarians for the care and treatment of animals. 
(Code 1995, § 91.05; Ord. No. 02-22, § 2, 5-14-2002) 
Secs. 14-5-14-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 14-41. - Animal control officer; authority. 
(a)  Appointment. 
(1)  The city manager shall appoint, for a period to be terminated at the city manager's pleasure, a qualified person who shall act in the capacity of animal control officer. It shall be the duty of the animal control officer to see that the provisions of this chapter are enforced. For his services, the animal control officer shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed by the city council. 
(2)  In lieu of the appointment of an animal control officer, the city council may designate such persons as it sees fit to operate the animal shelter or city pound according to the desires of the city council. Such persons shall be directly responsible to the city council. 
(3)  The animal control officer or the persons designated by the city council to run the animal shelter or city pound shall provide, at the expense of the city, sanitary and comfortable quarters and necessary sustenance for animals or fowl impounded pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  Authority. Any person employed as an animal control officer shall have the authority to: 
(1)  Issue citations for violations of this chapter; and 
(2)  Enter upon any and all premises within the city limits to enforce any and all provisions of this chapter, which authority shall be exercised only with reason and good discretion. 
(Code 1995, § 91.65) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-331 et seq. 
Sec. 14-42. - Duties of animal control department and animal control officer. 
(a)  Records. It shall be the duty of the animal control department to keep, or cause to be kept, accurate and detailed records of: 
(1)  Impoundments. The impoundment and disposition of all animals coming into the custody of the animal control department. 
(2)  Bite cases. All bite cases reported to the animal control department and its investigation of such reports. 
(3)  Moneys received. Records shall be kept of all moneys received under this chapter, and such records shall be open to inspection at reasonable times by persons responsible for similar records of the city, and shall be audited by the city auditor in the same manner as other city records which are audited. All moneys shall be turned in daily to the municipal court clerk for deposit in the city depository on the next work day. 
(b)  Monthly reports. The animal control officer shall monthly, or at such times as may be required by the city manager, account to the city for all moneys received by him by virtue of his official duties. At the same time, the animal control officer shall render to the city manager a full statement of all animals or fowl received into the animal shelter during the month, showing the name of the owner, if known, the date of sale, all of the animals or fowl destroyed, and all of the moneys expended by the animal control officer during the month for the maintenance of the pound. The animal control officer shall attach a receipt for all the moneys to the statement. The forms for such reports shall be furnished by the finance director of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 91.66) 
Sec. 14-43. - Interference with animal control department. 
(a)  No person shall interfere with, hinder or molest any agent of the animal control department in the performance of any duty of the agent, or seek or release any animal in the custody of the animal control department or its agents. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the interference alleged consisted only of speech. 
(Code 1995, § 91.03) 
Sec. 14-44. - Violations; citations. 
(a)  (1)  When an animal is found in violation of a provision of this chapter and the ownership of such animal is known to the agent of the animal control department, the animal need not be impounded by the agent. If the owner agrees to sign a citation, the agent may issue a citation, which shall require the person to appear in court within ten days to answer a charge of a violation of this chapter. 
(2)  The owner signing the citation shall only be a promise to appear and is not an admission of guilt. 
(3)  Upon being issued any citation, it shall be unlawful for any person to give the animal control employee a false name or address. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful to fail to appear in municipal court within ten days of the signing of the citation. 
(b)  When an animal is found in violation of a provision of this chapter, and its ownership is known to the agents of the animal control department and the owner cannot be located or refuses to sign a citation, the agent may impound the animal or file a complaint against the owner in municipal court. 
(c)  When an animal is found in violation of a provision of this chapter and its ownership is not known to the agent of the animal control department, the animal shall be impounded. 
(Code 1995, § 91.02) 
Sec. 14-45. - Hearing of nuisance; notice. 
(a)  Authority to hold hearing; order. Upon written complaint wherein any animal or fowl is alleged to be a nuisance, as defined in section 14-1, the municipal court of the city shall have the authority to order and hold a hearing, upon giving notice of such hearing to the owner of any such animal or fowl. A substantial copy of the order for a hearing, detailing the time, date, place and purpose for such hearing, personally delivered or enclosed in a correctly addressed envelope to the owner, postage prepaid and deposited in the United States mail within not less than three days prior to the date of the hearing, shall be deemed sufficient and proper notice. 
(b)  Appearance in court; arrest. 
(1)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter may be arrested upon written complaint. The person shall immediately be taken before the municipal court if he refuses to give his written promise to appear in court. 
(2)  Whenever any such arrested person is not immediately taken before the recorder of the municipal court, the arresting officer shall prepare, in duplicate, a written notice to appear in court. The notice shall contain the name and address of the person, the offense charged, the time and place of the offense and when and where the person shall appear in court. The person must give his written promise to appear in court and may do so by signing, in duplicate, the written notice prepared by the arresting officer. The appearance shall be at least three days from the date of arrest, unless an earlier hearing is demanded. The original of the notice shall be retained by the arresting officer, and a copy thereof shall be delivered to the person, and the officer shall forthwith release the person. 
(3)  Any person willfully violating any part of the written promise to appear in court, given as provided in this section, is guilty of a misdemeanor, regardless of the disposition of the original charge. 
(Code 1995, § 91.67) 
Secs. 14-46-14-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOGS, CATS AND OTHER HOUSEHOLD PETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-81. - Exemptions. 
    Hospitals, clinics and other premises operated by licensed veterinarians for the care and treatment of animals are exempt from the provisions of this article, except where such duties are expressly stated. 
(Code 1995, § 91.30) 
Sec. 14-82. - Restraint of dogs. 
    Every person who owns, keeps or is in charge of a dog shall restrain such dog at all times. 
(Code 1995, § 91.39) 
Sec. 14-83. - Number of dogs and cats permitted. 
    No person shall harbor or keep more than four dogs or cats, or any combination thereof, over ten weeks of age, when the total of such animals exceeds four, except in an animal pound, clinic, hospital or kennel as provided by chapter 94. 
(Code 1995, § 91.31) 
Secs. 14-84-14-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RABIES CONTROL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Rabies control, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.001 et seq. 

Sec. 14-101. - State standards adopted. 
    Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.013, the state board of health's regulations and standards for rabies control are adopted by reference, and incorporated in this division as if set out at length in this section. 
(Code 1995, § 91.50) 
Sec. 14-102. - Rabies vaccination. 
    No person shall own, keep or harbor a dog or cat over the age of four months within the city limits unless the dog or cat has been vaccinated with an antirabies vaccine by a licensed veterinarian, and licensed by the city. The animal shall be vaccinated periodically at one-year intervals from the initial date of vaccination. 
(Code 1995, § 91.32) 
Sec. 14-103. - Designation of local rabies control authority. 
(a)  The city council designates the chief of police to act as the local rabies control authority for the purposes of this division. 
(b)  Among other duties, the local rabies control authority shall enforce: 
(1)  V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 826 and the Texas Board of Health Rules that comprise the minimum standards for rabies control; 
(2)  The ordinances or rules of the City of Brownwood constituting the city's local rabies control program; and 
(3)  The rules adopted by the Texas Board of Health under the area rabies quarantine provisions of V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.045. 
(Ord. No. 08-22, § 1, 7-22-2008) 
Secs. 14-104-14-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSES AND TAGS 

Sec. 14-121. - Furnishing licenses; tag exhibition. 
(a)  The city animal control department will furnish licensed veterinarians who agree to follow the provisions of this article with application forms and license tags for dogs and cats. 
(b)  The metal vaccination tag shall be exhibited on the animal's neck at all times. 
(Code 1995, § 91.33) 
Sec. 14-122. - Licensing requirements. 
(a)  Issuance. Dog and cat license tags shall be issued by the animal control department and authorized licensed veterinarians. 
(b)  Application. A written application for a dog or cat license shall be made upon a printed application form provided by the city, and shall state the name and address of the owner or keeper of the dog or cat, and the name, breed, color, age and sex of the animal being licensed. 
(c)  Fee; conditions. Dog and cat license tags shall be issued after payment to the city council of a license fee, as recommended by the humane society, in an amount established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, for a full year, or any part thereof, and upon meeting of one of the following conditions: 
(1)  Vaccination by a licensed veterinarian with an antirabies vaccine; or 
(2)  Presentation of a written, dated and signed paper certificate issued by a licensed veterinarian showing that such vaccination was given less than three months prior to the date of application for the license. 
(d)  Validity; expiration. The license issued under this division shall be valid for the calendar year in which it is issued, and shall expire on December 31 of such year. 
(e)  Exemptions. The provisions of this division requiring a license for dogs shall not apply to: 
(1)  Dogs brought into the city by nonresidents, when the dogs are not kept in the city for a period of more than 48 hours; 
(2)  Dogs in veterinary hospitals, boarding kennels or licensed breeding kennels; 
(3)  Dogs which are securely confined at all times; or 
(4)  Dogs brought into the city and entered in any dog show or exhibition for the period of time the show or exhibition is held. 
(Code 1995, § 91.34) 
Sec. 14-123. - License expiration notice; annual fee. 
    On or before the expiration date of a license, the proper department of the city may send a notice of expiration to the owner indicated by the records of the city for the annual fee. If the owner has not reported the death of the animal or its removal from the city before the annual fee becomes due, he is liable for the fee currently due. 
(Code 1995, § 91.35) 
Sec. 14-124. - Proof of ownership. 
    The license information shall be kept on permanent file with the city, and a certified copy of the information shall constitute prima facie proof in any court of the ownership of the animal. 
(Code 1995, § 91.36) 
Sec. 14-125. - Citation for failure to pay annual fee. 
    If the owner of a dog or cat has not paid the annual license fee within 30 days of the date such fee is due, the owner of the animal to which the fee applies may be cited in the manner set out in section 14-45. 
(Code 1995, § 91.37) 
Sec. 14-126. - License tag. 
(a)  Provision; placement; identification number; replacements; refunds. 
(1)  Every person who owns, keeps or is in charge or control of a dog or cat within the city shall provide and place a collar or harness on the dog or cat, which shall be worn by the dog or cat at all times when the dog or cat is off the premises of the person, and such person shall attach the metal license tag obtained pursuant to this division to the collar or harness. 
(2)  The dog or cat license tag shall have an identification number stamped on it, which shall be assigned to the animal for the calendar year in which the tag is issued. If the tag is subsequently lost, a replacement tag shall be issued for a fee in an amount as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. No refunds shall be made on any license fee because of the death of the animal or the removal of such animal from the city before the expiration of the license period. 
(b)  Removal. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any metal tag issued under the provisions of this division from any dog or cat without written consent of the owner of the dog or cat. 
(Code 1995, § 91.39) 
Secs. 14-127-14-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DANGEROUS DOGS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Dangerous dogs, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code §§ 822.041-822.047. 

Sec. 14-151. - Owner requirements. 
(a)  Not later than the 30th day after a person learns that he is the owner of a dangerous dog, such person shall: 
(1)  Register the dangerous dog with the animal control authority; 
(2)  Restrain the dog at all times on a leash in the immediate control of a person or in a secure enclosure; 
(3)  Obtain liability insurance coverage or show financial responsibility in an amount of at least $100,000.00 to cover damages resulting from an attack by the dangerous dog causing bodily injury to a person, and provide proof to the animal control authority of the required liability insurance coverage or financial responsibility; and 
(4)  Comply with the applicable regulations, requirements or restrictions for dangerous dogs. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, a person shall learn that he is the owner of a dangerous dog when the owner: 
(1)  Knows of an attack as described in the definition of "dangerous dog," as set forth in section 14-1; 
(2)  Receives notice that a justice court, county court or municipal court has found the dog is a dangerous dog; or 
(3)  Is informed by the animal control authority that the dog is a dangerous dog. 
(c)  If a person reports an incident as described in the definition of "dangerous dog," as set forth in section 14-1, the animal control authority may investigate the incident. If, after receiving the sworn statements of any witnesses, the animal control authority determines the dog is a dangerous dog, it shall notify the owner of such fact. 
(d)  The owner of a dangerous dog who does not comply with subsection (a) of this section shall deliver the dog to the animal control authority not later than the 30th day after the owner learns that the dog is a dangerous dog. 
(e)  Not later than the 30th day after the date the owner is notified that a dog owned by him is a dangerous dog, he may appeal the determination of the animal control authority to a justice or municipal court of competent jurisdiction. An owner may appeal the decision of the justice or municipal court in the same manner as an appeal for other civil cases. 
(Code 1995, § 91.40(B)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code §§ 822.042, 822.0421. 
Sec. 14-152. - Registration. 
(a)  The animal control authority shall annually register a dangerous dog if the owner: 
(1)  Presents proof of: 
a.  Liability insurance or financial responsibility, as required by section 14-151(a)(3); 
b.  Current rabies vaccination of the dangerous dog; and 
c.  The secure enclosure in which the dangerous dog will be kept. 
(2)  Pays an annual registration fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(b)  If an owner of a registered dangerous dog sells or moves the dog to a new address, not later than the 14th day after the date of the sale or move, the owner shall notify the animal control authority for the area in which the new address is located. Upon presentation by the current owner of the dangerous dog's prior registration tag and payment of a fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, the animal control authority shall issue a new registration tag to be placed on the dangerous dog's collar. 
(c)  An owner of a registered dangerous dog shall notify the office in which the dangerous dog was registered of any attacks the dangerous dog makes on people. 
(Code 1995, § 91.40(C)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.043. 
Sec. 14-153. - Unprovoked attacks. 
    A person commits an offense if the person is the owner of a dangerous dog and the dog makes an unprovoked attack on another person outside the dog's enclosure and causes bodily injury to the other person. 
(Code 1995, § 91.40(D)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.044. 
Sec. 14-154. - Defenses to prosecution. 
    It is a defense to prosecution under this division that the person is: 
(1)  A veterinarian, peace officer, person employed by a recognized animal shelter or employed by the state, or political subdivision of the state, to deal with stray animals and has temporary ownership, custody or control of the dog in connection with such position. 
(2)  An employee of the institutional division of the state department of criminal justice or a law enforcement agency, and trains or uses dogs for law enforcement or correction purposes. 
(3)  A dog trainer or an employee of a guard dog company under the Private Security Act, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 1702.001 et seq. 
(Code 1995, § 91.40(E)) 
State Law reference- Defenses, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.046. 
Secs. 14-155-14-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 14-181. - Authorization. 
    The agents of the animal control department are authorized to take up all: 
(1)  Dogs found not to be restrained by their owners; or 
(2)  Cats which do not have a vaccination tag as provided by sections 14-102 and 14-126(a), or found not to be restrained by their owners. 
(Code 1995, § 91.41(A)) 
Sec. 14-182. - Vaccinated dogs. 
(a)  Period of confinement. A dog impounded as authorized in section 14-181 shall be confined in a humane manner for a period of not less than five working days. 
(b)  Notice. Upon impounding a dog found with a current vaccination tag, the agents of the animal control department shall make a reasonable effort to notify the owner that his animal has been impounded and the conditions whereby the owner may regain custody of such animal. 
(Code 1995, § 91.41(B)) 
Sec. 14-183. - Unvaccinated dogs and cats. 
    Dogs or cats without a vaccination tag which are impounded as authorized by section 14-181 shall become the property of the animal control department after the expiration of two working days. If such dogs or cats are unclaimed and unredeemed as provided in section 14-185, they may be disposed of in a humane manner as provided in section 14-187. 
(Code 1995, § 91.41(C)) 
Sec. 14-184. - Redemption. 
(a)  Dogs and cats. The owner shall be entitled to resume the possession of any impounded dog or cat, except as otherwise provided in this section for certain dogs or cats, upon compliance with the provisions of sections 14-102 and 14-126(a) and the payment of the impoundment fees as set forth in section 14-185. 
(b)  Unvaccinated animals over four months of age. Any animal over the age of four months which does not have a current rabies vaccination may not be redeemed until it has been vaccinated. 
(Code 1995, § 91.41(D)) 
Sec. 14-185. - Fees. 
(a)  Any dog or cat impounded under this division may be reclaimed as provided in section 14-184 upon payment of the following fees to the animal control department by the owner, or person taking custody through purchase or adoption: 
(1)  Taking up and impounding each dog, a fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(2)  Taking up and impounding each cat, a fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(3)  Taking care of each dog and cat, a fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(b)  For computation purposes of the charges set forth in subsection (a) of this section, each day shall begin at 12:01 a.m. The full fee shall be charged when the animal is kept for any portion of a day. 
(Code 1995, § 91.41(E)) 
Sec. 14-186. - Removal of animal from animal shelter without permission. 
    It shall be unlawful to remove, or attempt to remove, any impounded animal or fowl from the city animal shelter without the permission of the animal control officer. 
(Code 1995, § 91.70) 
Sec. 14-187. - Donated, unclaimed and impounded animals. 
(a)  Deemed property of animal control. Donated and impounded animals (in the case of an impounded animal, after the requirements of section 14-125 are satisfied and such animal is unclaimed and unredeemed as provided in section 14-184) shall become the property of the animal control department. 
(b)  Powers of department. The animal control department shall have the following powers: 
(1)  Authority to transfer title. The animal control department may transfer title of an animal. In the event of such transfer of title, the person or agency to whom the title is transferred shall pay for such animal's food and care while the animal is in the animal shelter and shall comply with the applicable vaccination provisions. 
(2)  Right to destroy. The animal control department may humanely destroy an animal. 
(3)  Placement in custody of responsible and suitable person. The animal control department may place any animal held at the animal shelter in the custody of a person deemed to be a responsible and suitable owner, who will agree to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(4)  Destruction of donated, sick or injured animals. The animal control department may destroy any animal by a humane method if the animal has been donated to the shelter with the request that it be destroyed, or if the animal is so sick or injured that its cure is considered by the animal control department to be impractical, or if death is imminent, in either of such events, the destruction may be done immediately, without notice of any waiting period. 
(5)  Transfer of title to humane society. The animal control department may transfer title of an animal to any legitimate humane society for purposes of adoption. In the event of transfer and subsequent placement of the animal in the custody of a person deemed to be a responsible and suitable owner, the humane society shall be required to give rabies shots to such animals over the age of four months which are transferred. There shall be no charge for expenses incurred for previous care of an animal, or for the animal and its transfer of title to the humane society. 
(Code 1995, § 91.68) 
Secs. 14-188-14-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LIVESTOCK AND FARM ANIMALS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Estrays, V.T.C.A., Agriculture Code § 142.001 et seq. 

Sec. 14-221. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means all livestock, farm animals and domestic animals, other than dogs, cats or other domesticated household pets. 
(Code 1995, § 91.15) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-222. - Running at large; herding. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or be in control of any livestock and farm animal which runs at large within the city limits, including, but not limited to, horses, mules, cows, sheep, swine, goats, geese, chickens, ducks, rabbits, fowl or any other animal. 
(b)  The driving of herds of such animals along or upon any street, avenue or alley of the city is hereby prohibited. This subsection shall not apply to or prohibit the herding of animals along or upon any street, avenue or alley of the city by: 
(1)  A publicly maintained or privately maintained circus, traveling show or rodeo, which does not remain in the city for longer than 30 days out of each year. 
(2)  Any officer, agent or employee of the federal, state or local government, or agencies thereof, if such herding is done in the performance of his official duties. 
(Code 1995, § 91.16) 
Sec. 14-223. - Keeping of swine. 
(a)  No person who is the owner of any swine, or any person who has any swine under his management or control, shall keep the swine or allow it to remain in any pen or other place within the city. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to or prohibit the keeping of swine by the following: 
(1)  A publicly owned or privately owned zoo, maintained or operated by a nonprofit organization or governmental entity. 
(2)  A publicly maintained or privately maintained circus, traveling show or rodeo, which does not remain in the city longer than 30 days out of each year. 
(3)  Slaughterhouses and livestock auctions. 
(4)  Hospitals, clinics and other premises operated by licensed veterinarians for the care and treatment of animals. 
(5)  A publicly owned agricultural farm maintained or operated by a governmental entity for educational purposes only. 
(Code 1995, § 91.19; Ord. No. 10-13, 7-13-2010) 
Sec. 14-224. - Temporary confinement. 
    If any animal is found upon the premises of any person, the owner or occupant of the premises shall have the right to temporarily confine such animal until he can notify the animal control department. When notified, it shall be the duty of the animal control department to impound such animal as provided in section 14-225. 
(Code 1995, § 91.18) 
Sec. 14-225. - Impoundment. 
(a)  Animals in violation of article. Any peace officer or agent of the animal control department shall take up and impound any animal found in violation of this article. 
(b)  Sale of impounded animals. After having held an animal impounded under the provisions of this article for at least five days, the animal control department shall sell such animal, at private sale, for cash, to the highest bidder, and after deducting all of the expenses of the sale and taking up and keeping of the animal, the balance of proceeds, if any, shall be returned to the owner of the animal. If the owner is unknown, the balance shall be paid into the city treasury. Any time within 30 days after such sale, the owner may apply to the animal control officer and, upon satisfactory proof of his ownership, he shall be entitled to receive the balance of the proceeds, which shall be the money deposited after deducting all of the expenses of the sale and taking up and keeping of the animal, paid into the city treasury on account of such sale. 
(c)  Disposition of impounded animals. If any impounded animal is found to be affected with rabies or seriously injured, or if the animal control officer has determined the animal is not salable, or if the animal cannot be sold as provided in subsection (b) of this section, it shall forthwith be destroyed or otherwise disposed of. All decisions as to the condition or salability of the animal shall be made by the animal control officer, after seeking competent advice, if necessary. 
(d)  Redemption before sale. The owner of any animal not affected with a contagious disease and impounded under the provisions of this section may redeem the animal before it is sold by paying the poundage fees as set out in subsection (g) of this section. 
(e)  Redemption after sale. The owner of any impounded animal which is sold under the provisions of subsection (b) of this section may redeem the animal by paying double the amount paid by the purchaser to him for such animal and his reasonable expenses for keeping the animal, provided that the owner will redeem the animal within 30 days after the date of the sale; otherwise, the animal becomes the absolute property of the purchaser. 
(f)  Records. For at least one year, the animal control department shall keep a record giving the description of all animals impounded, the date of impoundment, date of sale, amount realized for such animal, and name and address of the purchaser. 
(g)  Fees. All fees charged shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(1)  Fees shall be charged on ungulated or hoofed (even-toed and odd-toed) animals, including, but not limited to, horses, cows, sheep, goats, etc., for: 
a.  Taking up and impounding each animal. 
b.  Taking care of each animal after the day of impoundment. 
(2)  For computation purposes of the charges set forth in this subsection (g), each day shall begin at 12:01 a.m. The full fee shall be charged when the animal is kept for any portion of any day. 
(Code 1995, § 91.17)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - FOOD AND FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-07, §§ 1-8, adopted March 13, 2007, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. II, §§ 18-1-18-120, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1995 §§ 94.01, 94.10-94.20, 94.30-94.35; and Ord. No. 02-08 §§ I, II, adopted Feb. 12, 2002. 
State Law reference- Food, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code §§ 431.081-431.084; food service establishments, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 437.001 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-31. - Adoption of Texas Food Establishment Rules. 
    The City of Brownwood adopts by reference the provisions of the current rules by the Texas Board of Health found in 25 Tex. Admin. Code, ch. 229, §§ 161-171 and 173-175 regarding the regulation of food establishments in this jurisdiction, including any future amendments of such rules. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1.A., 3-13-2007) 
Sec. 18-32. - Definitions. 
    Authorized agent or employee means the employees of the regulatory authority. 
    Food establishment means a food service establishment, a retail food store, a temporary food establishment, a mobile food unit, and/or a roadside food vendor. 
    Municipality of Brownwood in this article shall be understood to refer to the City of Brownwood. 
    Regulatory authority means the Brownwood/Brown County Health Department. 
    State rules means the state rules found at 25 Tex. Admin. Code, ch. 229, §§ 161-171 and 173-175. These rules are also known as the Texas Food Establishment Rules. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 1.B., 3-13-2007) 
Secs. 18-33-18-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 18-51. - Review of plans. 
(a)  Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling or conversion shall be submitted to the regulatory authority for review before work is begun. Extensive remodeling means that 20 percent or greater of the area of the food establishment is to be remodeled. The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, equipment arrangement, mechanical plans and construction of materials of work areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The plans and specifications will be approved by the regulatory authority if they meet the requirements of the rules adopted by this article. The approved plans and specifications must be followed in construction, remodeling or conversion. 
(b)  Failure to follow the approved plans and specifications will result in a permit denial, suspension, or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, §§ 4.A., B., 3-13-2007) 
Sec. 18-52. - Administrative process. 
(a)  A notice as required in these rules is properly served when it is delivered to the holder of the permit or the person in charge, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the holder of the permit. A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the regulatory authority. 
(b)  The hearings provided for in these rules shall be conducted by the regulatory authority at a time and place designated by it. Based upon the recorded evidence of such hearing, the regulatory authority shall make final findings, and shall sustain, modify or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing decision shall be furnished to the holder of the permit by the regulatory authority. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, §§ 7.A., B., 3-13-2007) 
Secs. 18-53-18-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS, LICENSES AND CERTIFICATES 

Sec. 18-81. - Permits and exemptions. 
(a)  A person may not operate a food establishment without a permit issued by the regulatory authority. Permits are not transferable from one person to another or from one location to another location, except as otherwise permitted by this division. A valid permit must be posted in or on every food establishment regulated by this article. 
(b)  A food establishment operated solely by a nonprofit organization is exempt from the permitting requirements of this division, but is not exempt from compliance with state rules. The regulatory authority may require any information necessary to determine whether an organization is nonprofit for purposes of this exemption. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, §§ 2.A., B., 3-13-2007) 
Sec. 18-82. - Application for permit and fees. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a food establishment must make a written application for a permit on forms provided by the regulatory authority. The application must contain the name and address of each applicant, the location and type of the proposed food establishment and the applicable fee. An incomplete application will not be accepted. Failure to provide all required information, or falsifying information required may result in denial or revocation of the permit. Renewal of permits are required on an annual basis and the same information is required for a renewal permit as for a initial permit. 
(b)  Prior to the approval of an initial permit or the renewal of an existing permit, the regulatory authority shall inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with state laws and rules. A food establishment that does not comply with state laws and rules will be denied a permit or the renewal of a permit. 
(c)  The following fee schedule applies to permits issued under this division: 
One year permit (January 1-December 31)\$75.00 
Seasonal permits (up to 6 months)\$35.00 
Temporary permits (1 to 5 days)\$20.00 
School cafeterias\$140.00 
(Ord. No. 07-07, §§ 3.A.-C., 3-13-2007) 
Sec. 18-83. - Suspension of permit. 
(a)  The regulatory authority may, without warning, notice or hearing, suspend any permit to operate a food establishment if the operation of the food establishment constitutes an imminent hazard to public health. Suspension is effective upon service of the notice required by section 18-83(b) of this article. When a permit is suspended, food operations shall immediately cease. Whenever a permit is suspended, the holder of the permit shall be afforded an opportunity for a hearing within 20 days of receipt of a request for a hearing. 
(b)  Whenever a permit is suspended, the holder of the permit or the person in charge shall be notified in writing that the permit is, upon service of the notice, immediately suspended and that an opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written request for a hearing is filed with the regulatory authority by the holder of the permit within ten days. If no written request for hearing is filed within ten days, the suspension is sustained. The regulatory authority may end the suspension at any time if reasons for suspension no longer exists. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, §§ 5.A., B., 3-13-2007) 
Sec. 18-84. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The regulatory authority may, after providing opportunity for a hearing, revoke a permit for serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of these rules or for interference with the regulatory authority in the performance of its duties. Prior to revocation, the regulatory authority shall notify the holder of the permit or the person in charge, in writing, of the reason for which the permit is subject to revocation and that the permit shall be revoked at the end of the ten days following service of such notice unless a written request for a hearing is filed with the regulatory authority by the holder of the permit within such ten-day period.
