(b)  If no request for hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the revocation of the permit becomes final. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, §§ 6.A., B., 3-13-2007) 
Sec. 18-85. - Remedies. 
    The regulatory authority may seek to enjoin violations of these rules. 
(Ord. No. 07-07, § 8., 3-13-2007) 
Secs. 18-86-18-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PEDDLERS, ITINERANT VENDORS, TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND VENDORS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-121. - Exercise of police power. 
    This article shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the state and the city for the public safety, comfort, convenience and protection of the city and its citizens, and all of the provisions of this article shall be construed for the accomplishment of such purpose. 
(Code 1995, § 112.01) 
State Law reference- Full power of local self-government, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 51.072. 
Secs. 18-122-18-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ITINERANT MERCHANT, PEDDLER OR VENDOR 

Sec. 18-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Itinerant merchant, vendor or peddler means any person, firm, company, partnership, corporation or association going from house to house or place to place within the city, selling or soliciting orders for goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs, newspapers, magazines or subscriptions to newspapers or magazines. 
    Temporary means any business transacted or conducted in the city for which definite arrangements have not been made for the hire, rental or lease of premises for at least one month, in or upon which such business is to be operated or conducted. 
(Code 1995, § 112.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-142. - Exclusions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or sales agents in the usual course of business; 
(2)  Sales made under authority and by order of law; or 
(3)  Vendors of farm or dairy products raised or grown by such vendors. 
(Code 1995, § 112.03) 
Sec. 18-143. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in any activity defined in section 18-141 without first obtaining a permit from the city. 
(Code 1995, § 112.04) 
Sec. 18-144. - Permit application. 
(a)  Any person desiring to participate in any activity defined in sections 18-141 and 18-171 shall file a written application for a permit prior to the date on which the person intends to sell or solicit in the city. 
(b)  The application shall show the following information: 
(1)  The company that the person represents, including the: 
a.  Company name. 
b.  Field office address, principal official in the field office and such official's telephone number. 
c.  Home office address and telephone number, and the name and title of the principal official in the home office. 
d.  Name, title, mailing address and telephone number of the person in charge of sales in the city or the area, and the city address and telephone number of such person. 
e.  Names of all sales personnel. 
(2)  The name, home address and local address, if any, of the applicant. 
(3)  Such references as the chief of police shall require. 
(4)  The nature of the articles or things which are to be sold or for which orders are to be solicited. 
(5)  Upon any sale or order, whether the applicant shall demand, receive or accept payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery. 
(6)  The period of time which the applicant wishes to peddle, solicit or sell in the city. 
(Code 1995, § 112.05) 
Sec. 18-145. - Term of permit. 
    Each person desiring to participate in any activity defined in sections 18-141 and 18-171 shall obtain a permit annually. 
(Code 1995, § 112.06) 
Sec. 18-146. - Street peddling, solicitation and selling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to peddle, solicit or sell from the streets of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 112.07) 
Secs. 18-147-18-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRANSIENT MERCHANT OR VENDOR 

Sec. 18-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Transient merchant or transient vendor means all persons, firms and corporations, as well as their agents and employees, who are engaged in the temporary or transient business in the city of selling or offering for sale any goods or merchandise, or exhibiting such goods or merchandise for sale or for the purpose of taking orders for sale, and who, for the purpose of carrying on such business or conducting exhibits of such goods or merchandise, either hires, rents, leases or occupies any room or space in any building, structure or other enclosure in the city in, through or from which any goods or merchandise may be sold, offered for sale, exhibited for sale or exhibited for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof. 
(Code 1995, § 112.20) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-172. - Permit required; fee. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any transient vendor to sell, offer for sale, exhibit for sale or for the purpose of taking orders for the sale of any goods or merchandise in the city without first obtaining a permit as provided for in this section. 
(b)  The city shall issue a permit to any transient vendor authorizing the transient vendor to sell, exhibit for sale, offer for sale or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale in the city of his goods or merchandise only after the transient vendor shall have fully complied with all provisions of this division and made payment for the permit as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, and which sum shall be compensation to the city for the services required of the city by this division and to enable the city to partially defray the expenses of enforcing the provisions of this division, provided that: 
(1)  The transient vendor shall make application at least ten days prior to the date of his contemplated sale or exhibit to be held in the city. The application shall be in the form of an affidavit stating: 
a.  The full name and address of the transient vendor; 
b.  The location of the transient vendor's principal office and place of business; 
c.  The names and addresses of the transient vendor's officers, if a corporation, and the partnership name and the names and addresses of all partners, if the transient vendor is a firm. 
(2)  Before a permit shall be issued, the application must be accompanied by a: 
a.  Statement showing the kind and character of the goods or merchandise to be sold, offered for sale or exhibited. 
b.  Certified copy of the Charter, if the transient vendor is a corporation incorporated under the laws of the state. 
c.  Certified copy of the permit to do business in the state, if the transient vendor is a corporation incorporated under the laws of a state other than this state. 
d.  Bond in a sum of not less than $2,000.00, which shall be executed by the transient vendor as principal, with two or more good and sufficient sureties satisfactory to the city. The bond shall be payable to the city for the use and benefit of any person entitled thereto, and conditioned that the principal and surety will pay all damages to a person caused by, arising from or growing out of the wrongful, fraudulent or illegal conduct of the transient vendor while conducting the sale or exhibit in the city. The bond shall remain in full force and effect for the entire duration of the permit, as provided in this division, and two years thereafter. 
(Code 1995, § 112.21) 
Sec. 18-173. - Permit transferability. 
    The permit provided for by this division shall not be transferable, nor give authority to more than one person to sell or exhibit goods or merchandise as an transient vendor, either by agent or clerk or in any way other than his own proper person, but any person having obtained a permit may have the assistance of one or more persons in conducting the sale or exhibit, which persons shall have authority to aid the permittee, but not to act for or without him. 
(Code 1995, § 112.22) 
Sec. 18-174. - Duration of license; display on premises. 
    The permit as provided by this division shall continue so long as the sale or exhibit is continuously held in the city, but in no event shall it continue for more than 40 days from the date of its issuance. Permits shall be prominently displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises where the sale or exhibit is being conducted and shall remain so displayed so long as any goods or merchandise are being so sold or exhibited. 
(Code 1995, § 112.23) 
DIVISION 4. - SOLICITATION OF FUNDS PROHIBITED 

Sec. 18-175. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division the following words have the meaning indicated: 
    Parkway means the area between the curbline of the paved street and the adjacent owner's property line that has been dedicated for public use. 
    Solicit funds or solicitation of funds means to ask, beg, solicit, or plead, whether orally or in a written or printed manner, for money or other items or services of value. 
    Street means the portion of a public street, road, or state highway that is paved, designated, or used for vehicular traffic, plus all areas dedicated to public use for street purposes, including parkways, sidewalks and traffic islands. 
    Traffic island means a barrier with a street to exclude vehicles, designated for the purpose of separating or directing streams of vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 16-20 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
Sec. 18-176. - Solicitation prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a person to solicit funds while located on the following streets: (a) East and West Commerce Street; (b) Main Street and 377 South; (c) Austin Avenue and West Austin Avenue; and (d) Coggin Avenue. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person located on a street to solicit funds from the occupants of any motor vehicle on a street. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a person to solicit funds within 150 feet of any intersection controlled by a traffic light. The distance from the intersection shall be measured from the nearest curbline of the street upon which the traffic light is located to the location of the solicitation of funds. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a person soliciting funds at any time to enter into or remain in the portion of the street designated for vehicular traffic so that their presence impedes the flow of traffic. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for a person to solicit funds on the private property of another. It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section if the solicitation of funds was being conducted on the private property of another with the consent and permission of the owner, manager, or other person in control of the property. 
(Ord. No. 16-20 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
Sec. 18-177. - Exceptions. 
    Section 18-176(1), (2) and (3) shall not apply to: 
(1)  The solicitation of charitable contributions permitted by V.T.C.A. Texas Transportation Code §552.0071 of the provided that (a) the person obtains a written permit from the city's development services department by filing a written application, in a form provided by the city, with the city's development services department not later than the 11 th day before the date the solicitation is to begin; (b) permit applications must be accompanied by a certificate of insurance signed by an agent authorized to bind coverage indicating that the applicant has obtained, at his sole expense, insurance coverage (i) that is written by an insurance company with an A- or better rating by AM Best and that is admitted and licensed to do business in the state; (ii) that is in full force and effect for the duration of the permit period; (iii) that provides $1,000,000.00 of liability coverage per occurrence with no deductible; (iv) that insures the applicant and all persons who will be soliciting; (v) that names the city, its officers, employees, and elected representatives as an additional insured; (vi) that provides that any insurance or self-insurance maintained by the city shall apply in excess of and not contribute with it; and (vii) that is written on an occurrence basis. 
(2)  The solicitation of funds for the benefit of local civic organizations, local youth organizations or other local non-profit corporations, provided that they are not located in the portion of the street designated for vehicular traffic or on a traffic island. 
(Ord. No. 16-20 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
Secs. 18-178-18-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONVENIENCE STORE 

Sec. 18-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Convenience store means any place of business that is engaged in the retail sale of groceries, including the sale of prepared foods, and gasoline and services, and which is regularly open for business at any time between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., and is attended by one employee during such hours. The term "convenience store" does not include a store which is solely or primarily a restaurant. Convenience food stores or grocery stores that are situated within office, condominium, apartment or cooperative buildings shall be exempt from this article, provided the building has a security system providing limited public access or provides a concierge, doorman or security guard at the main public entry during all hours of operation. 
(Code 1995, § 115.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-202. - Purpose. 
    The city council finds that small businesses and automobile-related facilities which offer convenience food, gasoline and other services can become targets of opportunity for theft and violent crimes. The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety and welfare by increasing security for patrons and employees of such businesses by the use of surveillance cameras and other security devices. Surveillance cameras and security devices will assist in deterring crime in and adjacent to such businesses and can provide information to assist the police in investigating crimes that do occur. 
(Code 1995, § 115.01) 
Sec. 18-203. - Enforcement. 
    The city code officers, under the provisions of chapter 26, and all city law enforcement officers are authorized to enforce this article. 
(Code 1995, § 115.21) 
Sec. 18-204. - Noncompliance. 
    Noncompliance with this article shall subject the owner or principal operator of a convenience store to the enforcement procedures and penalties provided for in sections 26-201-26-208, except if noncompliance with this article is corrected within ten days after receipt of the notice of noncompliance, no noncompliance fee shall be assessed. 
(Code 1995, § 115.10) 
Sec. 18-205. - Civil fine. 
    The city may seek the imposition of a civil fine of up to $1,000.00 for a willful and deliberate violation of this article by the owner or principal operator of a convenience store. Each day in violation of this article shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Code 1995, § 115.20) 
Sec. 18-206. - Security devices. 
    Every convenience store shall be equipped with, and continuously maintain, all of the following security devices: 
(1)  A security camera system capable of retrieving an image to assist in the identification and apprehension of a robber. Such camera must be capable of producing a retrievable image on film or tape that can be made a permanent record, and can be enlarged through projection or other means, and which shall be maintained and available to police for a period of five days before reuse or destruction. Cameras required by this section shall be either 35-millimeter surveillance cameras or videotaping surveillance cameras. Such cameras shall be maintained in proper working order at all times during all hours of operation of the business, and shall provide coverage of the register and adjacent customer area. 
(2)  A drop safe or cash management device that provides minimum access to the convenience store's cash receipts. 
(Code 1995, § 115.03) 
Sec. 18-207. - Register amount sign. 
    Every convenience store shall have posted and continuously maintain a conspicuous sign in the convenience store entrance which states that the cash register contains $100.00 or less, or have a cash management program as set forth in section 18-211. 
(Code 1995, § 115.04) 
Sec. 18-208. - Camera surveillance sign. 
    Every convenience store shall have posted and continuously maintain a conspicuous sign in the convenience store entrance which states that the property is under camera surveillance. 
(Code 1995, § 115.05) 
Sec. 18-209. - Maintenance of window signs. 
    Every convenience store shall maintain its window signs so that there is a clear and unobstructed view of the cash register and transaction area. 
(Code 1995, § 115.06) 
Sec. 18-210. - Window tinting. 
    Window tinting on the windows of a convenience store is prohibited if such tinting reduces exterior or interior viewing of the convenience store during the hours of operation to which this article is applicable. 
(Code 1995, § 115.07) 
Sec. 18-211. - Cash management policy. 
    Every convenience store which does not have a drop safe shall institute and continuously maintain a cash management policy, approved by the chief of police, to limit the amount of cash on hand between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Code 1995, § 115.08) 
Sec. 18-212. - Robbery deterrence and safety training programs. 
    Every convenience store shall provide robbery deterrence and safety training to its employees who work between the hours of 9:00 p.m and 6:00 a.m. Such training programs shall be approved by the chief of police. 
(Code 1995, § 115.09) 
Chapter 22 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; emergency services, ch. 30; fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
State Law reference- Texas Disaster Act of 1975, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 22-31. - Director; coordinator; organization. 
(a)  There exists the office of emergency management director of the city, which shall be held by the mayor in accordance with state law. 
(b)  An emergency management coordinator may be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the director. 
(c)  The director shall be responsible for a program of comprehensive emergency management within the city and for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in this article. He may delegate authority for execution of these duties to the coordinator, but ultimate responsibility for such execution shall remain with the directory. 
(d)  The operational emergency management organization of the city shall consist of the officers and employees of the city so designated by the director in the emergency management plan, as well as organized volunteer groups. The functions and duties of this organization shall be distributed among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the emergency management plan. 
(Ord. No. 03-14, § 1, 4-22-2003) 
Charter reference- Mayor as official head of city government, § 17. 
Sec. 22-32. - Powers and duties of director. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the emergency management director shall include the following: 
(1)  Surveying actual or potential hazards which threaten life and property within the city and identifying and requiring or recommending the implementation of measures which would tend to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of such hazards if a disaster did occur. 
(2)  Supervision of the development and approval of an emergency management plan for the city, and recommending for adoption by city council all mutual aid arrangements deemed necessary for the implementation of such plan. 
(3)  Authority to declare a local state of disaster. The declaration may not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven days except by or with the consent of the city council. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing, or terminating a local state of disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the city secretary. 
(4)  Issuance of necessary proclamations, regulations, or directives which are necessary for carrying out the purposes of this article. Such proclamations, regulations, or directives shall be disseminated promptly by means calculated to bring their contents to the attention of the general public and, unless circumstances attendant on the disaster prevent or impede, promptly filed with the city secretary. 
(5)  Direction and control of the operations of the city or county emergency management organization as well as the training of emergency management personnel. 
(6)  Determination of all questions of authority and responsibility that may arise within the emergency management organization of the city. 
(7)  Maintenance of liaison with other city, county, district, state, regional or federal emergency management organizations. 
(8)  Marshaling of all necessary personnel, equipment, or supplies from any department of the city to aid in the carrying out of the provisions of the emergency management plan. 
(9)  Supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements, in cooperation with the representatives of the state and of other local political subdivisions of the state, and the drafting and execution, if deemed desirable, of an agreement with the county and with other municipalities within the county for the countywide coordination of emergency management efforts. 
(10)  Supervision of, and final authorization for, the procurement of all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions which may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency management within the city. 
(11)  Authorizing of agreements, after approval by the city attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other purposes. 
(12)  Surveying the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies, and services which could be used during a disaster, as provided for herein. 
(13)  Other requirements as specified in the state Disaster Act (V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.001 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 03-14, § 2, 4-22-2003) 
Sec. 22-33. - Comprehensive plan. 
    A comprehensive emergency management plan shall be developed and maintained in a current state. The plan shall set forth the form of the organization, establish and designate divisions and functions, assign responsibilities, tasks, duties, and powers, and designate officers and employee to carry out the provisions of this article. As provided by state law, the plan shall follow the standards and criteria established by the state division of emergency management. Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles, and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the state division of emergency management. When approved, it shall be the duty of all departments and agencies to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at all times. The emergency management plan shall be considered supplementary to this article and have the effect of law during the time of a disaster. 
(Ord. No. 03-14, § 3, 4-22-2003) 
Sec. 22-34. - Interjurisdictional program. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized to join with the county judge and the mayors of the other cities in the county in the formation of an interjurisdictional emergency management program of the county and shall have the authority to cooperate in the preparation of an interjurisdictional emergency management plan and in the appointment of a joint emergency management coordinator, as well as all powers necessary to participate in a countywide program of emergency management insofar as said program may affect the city. 
(Ord. No. 03-14, § 4, 4-22-2003) 
Sec. 22-35. - Applicability of regulations. 
    At all times when the orders, rules, and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this article shall be in effect, they shall supersede and override all existing ordinances, orders, rules, and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 03-14, § 5, 4-22-2003) 
Sec. 22-36. - Liability. 
    This article is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health, and safety, and neither the city, the agents and representatives of the city, any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, nor any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with any order, rule, or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons as the result of said activity. Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to the city a license of privilege, or otherwise permits the city to inspect, designate, and use the whole or any part or parts of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending, or practice enemy attack or natural or manmade disaster shall, together with his successors in interest, if any, not be civilly liable for the death of or injury to any person on or about such real estate or premises under such license, privilege or other permission, or for loss of or damage to the property of such person. 
(Ord. No. 03-14, § 6, 4-22-2003) 
Sec. 22-37. - Commitment of funds. 
    No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the city in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this article without prior approval by the city council, and no person shall have any right to bind the city by contract, agreement, or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the city council unless during a declared disaster. During a declared disaster, the mayor may expend and/or commit public funds of the city when deemed prudent and necessary for the protection of health, life, or property. 
(Ord. No. 03-14, § 7, 4-22-2003) 
Sec. 22-38. - Offenses; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article. 
(b)  It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear, carry, or display any emblem, insignia, or any other means of identification as a member of the emergency management organization of the city unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials. 
(c)  Convictions for violations of the provisions of this article shall be punishable by fine not to exceed $2,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 03-14, § 8, 4-22-2003) 
Sec. 22-39. - Limitations. 
    This article shall not be construed so as to conflict with any state or federal statute or any military or naval order, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 03-14, § 10, 4-22-2003) 
Chapter 26 - CODE ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 78; manufactured homes and parks, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Enforcement of municipal ordinances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abatement means any action the city may take on public or private property and any adjacent property as may be necessary to remove or alleviate a nuisance, including, but not limited to, demolition, removal, repair, boarding and securing or replacement of property. 
    Abatement notice means a notice issued by a code enforcement officer which requires a responsible person to abate a public nuisance. 
    Administrative enforcement order means an order issued by the building and standards commission, after a hearing, requiring a responsible person to correct a violation, abate a public nuisance, pay civil penalties and administrative costs or take any other action as authorized or required by this Code and applicable state codes. Such term may also include an order authorizing the city to abate a public nuisance or assess a code enforcement lien. 
    Cash deposit includes certificates of deposit and assigned securities in the form of savings accounts whenever a cash deposit is required as a condition of an application for activity related to a construction project under this Code. 
    City means the area within the territorial city limits and such territory outside of the city over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or Charter provisions, or any law. 
    City manager means the city manager of the City of Brownwood, Texas, or his designee. 
    Code enforcement lien means a lien recorded to collect outstanding civil penalties and administrative costs imposed as part of a cost recovery, administrative or judicial code enforcement action. 
    Code enforcement officer means any person authorized to enforce violations of this Code or applicable state codes. 
    Code enforcement performance bond means a bond posted by a responsible person to ensure compliance with this Code, applicable state codes, a judicial action or administrative enforcement order. 
    Financial institution means any person that holds a recorded mortgage, deed of trust, claim or security interest on a property. 
    Imminent life safety hazard means any condition which creates a present, extreme and immediate danger to life, property, health or public safety. 
    Legal interest means any interest that is represented by a document, such as a deed of trust, quitclaim deed, mortgage, judgment lien, tax or assessment lien, security interest, mechanic's lien or other similar instrument which is recorded with the county clerk. 
    Notice of compliance means a document issued by the city manager representing that a property complies with the criteria set forth in section 26-236. 
    Notice of satisfaction means a document or form, approved by the city manager, which indicates that all outstanding civil penalties and costs have either been paid in full, or the city has negotiated an agreed amount, or a subsequent administrative or judicial decision has resolved the outstanding debt. 
    Notice of violation means a written notice used in abatement and civil penalties actions, prepared by an enforcement official, which informs a responsible person of code violations and of the consequences of the code violations, requires compliance, and contains specific information as required by this Code. 
    Owner means any person who shall have legal or equitable title, and shall include the executor, executrix, administrator, administratrix, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner. 
    Person means any natural person, firm, limited liability company, joint venture, joint stock company, partnership, association, club, company, corporation, business trust, organization, or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of any of such persons, or any other entity which is recognized by law as the subject of rights or duties. 
    Property owner means the record owner of real property, based on the county clerk's and/or county appraisal district's records. 
    Public nuisance means any condition caused, maintained or permitted to exist which constitutes a threat to the public's health, safety and welfare or which significantly obstructs, injures or interferes with the reasonable or free use of property in a neighborhood, community or to any considerable number of persons. 
    Responsible person means a person whom a code enforcement officer determines is responsible for causing or maintaining a public nuisance or a violation of this Code or applicable state codes. Such term includes, but is not limited to, a property owner, tenant or person with a legal interest in or possession of real property. 
    Substandard building means any building, or portion thereof, including any dwelling unit, guestroom, hotel, motel or suite of rooms, or the premises on which such building is located, in which any of the following conditions exist to an extent that endangers the life, limb, health, property, safety or welfare of the public, or the occupants thereof: 
(1)  A "condemned building," under the International Building Code, as defined in such code. 
(2)  Lack of, or not properly operative water closet, lavatory, bathtub or shower in a dwelling unit. 
(3)  Lack of, or not properly operative water closets, lavatories and bathtubs or showers in a motel. 
(4)  Lack of, or not properly operative kitchen sink. 
(5)  Lack of hot and cold running water to plumbing fixtures in a motel. 
(6)  Lack of hot and cold running water to plumbing fixtures in a dwelling unit. 
(7)  Lack of, or improper operation of adequate heating facilities. 
(8)  Lack of, or improper operation of required ventilating equipment. 
(9)  Room and space dimensions less than required by this Code. 
(10)  Lack of required electrical lighting. 
(11)  Dampness of habitable rooms because of faulty weather protection. 
(12)  General dilapidation or inadequate maintenance. 
(13)  Lack of a connection to the required sewage disposal system. 
(14)  Infestation of insects, vermin, bats, birds or rodents. 
(15)  Lack of an adequate roof. 
(16)  Evidence of structural failure. 
    Written includes printed, typewritten, mimeographed, multigraphed, printout by computer, facsimile and items listed in Texas Rules of Evidence, Rule 1001(1). 
(Code 1995, §§ 131.003, 131.602) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-2. - Purpose and intent. 
    The city council finds that the enforcement of this Code and applicable state codes throughout the city and, to the extent permitted by law, within its extraterritorial jurisdiction, is an important public service. Code enforcement and state code enforcement is vital and necessary for the protection of the public's health, safety and quality of life. The city council recognizes that enforcement starts with adopting applicable state statutes and codes and the drafting of precise regulations that can be effectively applied in administrative enforcement hearings and judicial proceedings. The city council further finds that a comprehensive code enforcement system that uses a combination of judicial and administrative remedies is critical to gain compliance with code regulations. The city council further finds that there is a need to establish uniform procedures for administrative enforcement hearings conducted pursuant to this Code and state statutes and codes. It is the purpose and intent of the city council to afford due process of law to any and all persons who are directly affected by any administrative action. Due process of law includes adequate notice, an opportunity to participate in the administrative hearing and an adequate explanation of the reasons justifying the administrative action. Such procedures are also intended to establish a forum to efficiently, expeditiously and fairly resolve issues raised in any administrative enforcement action. The procedures established by these administrative remedies are in addition to any other legal remedy established by law which may be pursued to address code and applicable state code violations. Failure to comply with an administrative code enforcement action may require the city attorney to file a judicial action to gain compliance. 
(Code 1995, § 131.001) 
Sec. 26-3. - Criminal violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any provision or fail to comply with any of the requirements of this Code. A violation of any of the provisions or failure to comply with any of the mandatory requirements of this Code shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable by the maximum fine allowed by law and authorized by state statutes or other provisions of this Code. Each such person shall be charged with a separate offense for each and every day, or portion thereof, during which any violation of any provision of this Code is committed, continued or permitted by such person and shall, upon conviction, be punished accordingly. 
(Code 1995, § 131.007) 
Sec. 26-4. - Civil violations. 
    In addition to any other remedy provided by this Code, any provision of this Code or applicable state law may be enforced by injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction upon a suit brought by the city. As part of a civil action filed to enforce provisions of this Code, a court may assess a maximum civil penalty as allowed by law per violation of this Code or state law for each day during which any person commits, continues, allows or maintains a violation of any provision of this Code or state law. 
(Code 1995, § 131.008) 
Sec. 26-5. - Recovery of civil penalties. 
    The city manager may collect all civil penalties and related administrative costs by the use of all appropriate legal means, including referral to the city attorney, the recordation of a code enforcement lien pursuant to the procedures set forth in this chapter and state law, and the filing of a court action to recover such penalties and costs. 
(Code 1995, § 131.501) 
Secs. 26-6-26-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-41. - Enforcement authority. 
(a)  The city manager or any of the city's designated code enforcement officials, including staff members of the code administration department ("code enforcement officials") shall have the authority and powers necessary to gain compliance with the provisions of this Code, any and all other codes or ordinances of the city and applicable state codes. Such powers include the power to issue notices of violation, issue citations as provided in subparagraph (b), inspect public and private property and use whatever judicial and administrative remedies are available under this Code or applicable state laws. 
(b)  Any code enforcement official shall have the authority to issue citations for any violation of this Code and any and all other codes or ordinances of the city. If the person being cited is not present, the code enforcement official may send the citation to the alleged offender by certified mail, return receipt requested. If a person who receives a citation by personal service or as provided under this subsection fails to appear on the return date of the citation, the court may issue a warrant for the person's arrest for the violation described in the citation. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with a code enforcement official in the performance of his or her duties and enforcement under this section. 
(Code 1995, § 131.002(A); Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, 4-10-2012) 
Secs. 26-42-26-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING AND STANDARDS COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-61 et seq. 

Sec. 26-61. - Purpose. 
    The city council finds that the enforcement throughout the city of this Code and applicable state codes is an important public service and its purpose in adopting V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 54, "Quasi-judicial Enforcement of Health and Safety Ordinances", is to create and establish a building and standards commission and establish a procedure to hear and determine cases concerning alleged violations of ordinances and to seek quasi-judicial enforcement. 
(Code 1995, § 131.201) 
State Law reference- Quasi-judicial enforcement of health and safety ordinances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 54.031-54.044. 
Sec. 26-62. - Created. 
    In accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 54, the city hereby creates a building and standards commission consisting of one, five-member panel to be appointed by the city council for a term of two years. The city council may appoint four alternate members to the commission to serve in the absence of one or more regular members as provided by state law. The building and standards commission shall conduct its activities and enforce this Code, ordinances and the state code and statutes in accordance with the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 54. The procedures established in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 54 are in addition to any and all other legal remedies, criminal or civil, established by law which may be pursued to address violations of this Code or applicable state codes. 
(Code 1995, § 131.202; Ord. No. 10-06, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 10-31, 11-23-2010) 
State Law reference- Building and standards commission, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.033. 
Sec. 26-63. - Powers and duties. 
    The building and standards commission shall have the powers and duties to: 
(1)  Require the reduction in occupancy load of an overcrowded structure or vacation of a structure that is hazardous to the health, safety and welfare of the occupants; 
(2)  Permit the repair of a substandard structure as an alternative to demolition of the structure; 
(3)  Require the demolition of structures found to be substandard; 
(4)  Require the removal of personalty from a structure ordered vacated or demolished. Removal may be accomplished by use of city forces or a private transfer company if the owner of the personalty is not known, the whereabouts of the owner cannot be ascertained or the owner fails to remove the personalty. The building and standards commission may cause any personalty removed to be stored in the care and custody of a bonded warehouse facility. Cost of removal and storage is the responsibility of the owner of the personalty; 
(5)  Require that a vacant structure or vacant portion of a structure constituting a hazard be securely closed and made safe; 
(6)  Grant a variance when, in the opinion of the building and standards commission, a literal interpretation of the city's housing standards regulations would result in an imposition of an unnecessary or unreasonable hardship; and 
(7)  Interpret the provisions of the city's housing standards regulations in a way so as to carry out their intent and purpose and, from time to time, as it deems advisable, make suggestions and recommendations to the city council for improvement of the city's housing standards regulations. 
(Code 1995, § 131.205) 
Sec. 26-64. - Applicability of division. 
    This division applies only to ordinances: 
(1)  For the preservation of public safety relating to the materials or methods used to construct a building or improvement, including the foundation, structural elements, electrical wiring or apparatus, plumbing and fixtures, entrances or exits; 
(2)  Relating to the fire safety of a building or improvement, including provisions relating to materials, types of construction or design, warning devices, sprinklers or other fire suppression devices, availability of water supply for extinguishing fires, or location, design or width of entrances or exits; 
(3)  Relating to dangerously damaged or deteriorated buildings or improvements; or 
(4)  Relating to conditions caused by accumulations of refuse, vegetation or other matter that creates breeding and living places for insects and rodents. 
(Code 1995, § 131.203) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.032. 
Sec. 26-65. - Municipal court proceeding not affected. 
    This division does not affect the ability of a municipality to proceed under the jurisdiction of the municipal court. 
(Code 1995, § 131.204) 
Secs. 26-66-26-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-331 et seq. 

Sec. 26-91. - Authority to inspect. 
    The city manager and any code enforcement officer are authorized to enter upon any property or premises to ascertain whether the provisions of this Code or applicable state codes and statutes are being obeyed, and to make any examinations and surveys as may be necessary in the performance of their enforcement duties. Such duties may include the taking of photographs, samples or other physical evidence. All inspections, entries, examinations and surveys shall be done in a reasonable manner. If an owner, occupant or agent refuses permission to enter or inspect, a code enforcement officer, first authorized by the city manager, may seek an administrative inspection warrant or search warrant as provided for by Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 18.05. 
(Code 1995, § 131.005) 
Secs. 26-92-26-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CODE ADMINISTRATION DEPARTMENT[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-191 et seq. 

Sec. 26-111. - Findings. 
    The city council finds that the enforcement of this Code and applicable state codes throughout the city, and, to the extent permitted by law, within its extraterritorial jurisdiction, is an important public service. Enforcement of this Code and the state code is vital and necessary for the protection of the public's health, safety and quality of life. The city council has adopted applicable state statutes and codes and drafted precise regulations for effectively applying administrative enforcement hearings and judicial proceedings. The city council further finds that a need exists to create a code administration department to implement judicial and administrative remedies critical to gain compliance with code regulations set out in Ordinance No. 97-18, adopted by the city council on May 3, 1997. 
(Code 1995, § 131.701) 
Sec. 26-112. - Code administrator. 
    The city council finds that the code administration department should be managed by the creation of a code administrator position, who shall have the authority and powers necessary to gain compliance with the provisions of this Code, any and all other codes or ordinances of the city and all applicable state codes. In addition to the power to issue notices of violation, to issue citations as provided in section 26-41, inspect public and private property and use whatever judicial and administrative remedies are available under this Code, any other codes or ordinances of the city or applicable state codes, the code administrator shall have supervisory status over positions within the code administration department. 
(Code 1995, § 131.702; Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, 4-10-2012) 
Sec. 26-113. - Staff implementation. 
    The code administration department shall consist of the code administrator, one code official II position and two code official I positions. 
(Code 1995, § 131.703) 
Sec. 26-114. - Procedure. 
    Using provisions established in this chapter, the code administration department shall implement a conscientious, balanced approach to code enforcement in the city. 
(Code 1995, § 131.704) 
Secs. 26-115-26-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - JUDICIAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE REMEDIES[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-181. - Performance bond. 
    As part of any court action, the city has the authority to require a responsible person to post a performance bond to ensure compliance with this Code, applicable state codes and statutes or any judicial action taken under this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 131.009) 
Sec. 26-182. - Judicial abatement. 
    The city has the authority to judicially abate public nuisances by the filing of criminal or civil actions. The city also has the authority to make the expense of the abatement of the nuisance a special assessment or a lien against the property on which it is maintained and a personal obligation against the property owner, if permitted by law. 
(Code 1995, § 131.010) 
Sec. 26-183. - Service of notice of violation. 
(a)  Whenever a notice of violation is required to be given under this Code for enforcement purposes, the notice shall be served by any of the following methods, unless different provisions are otherwise specifically stated to apply: 
(1)  Personal service; 
(2)  Certified mail, postage prepaid, return receipt requested. Simultaneously, the same notice may be sent by regular mail. If a notice that is sent by certified mail is returned unsigned, then service shall be deemed effective pursuant to regular mail, provided that the notice sent by regular mail is not returned; or 
(3)  Conspicuously posting the notice on or in front of the property. The form of the posted notice shall be approved by the city manager. 
(b)  Service of notice by certified or regular mail in the manner described in subsection (a) of this section shall be effective on the date of mailing. 
(c)  The failure of any person with an interest in the property to receive any notice served in accordance with this section shall not affect the validity of any proceedings taken under this Code. 
(d)  The notice requirements in this section do not apply to initial notices of violation which may be sent by regular mail. Service of a notice of violation by regular mail is effective on the date of mailing. 
(Code 1995, § 131.011) 
State Law reference- Notice of proceedings before the Building and Standards Commission, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.033. 
Sec. 26-184. - Proof of service of notice of violation. 
    Proof of service of a notice of violation may be made by the certificate of any officer or employee of the city or affidavit of any person over the age of 18 years. The proof of service shall show that service was done in conformity with this Code or other provisions of law applicable to the subject matter concerned. 
(Code 1995, § 131.012) 
Sec. 26-185. - Constructive notice of recorded documents. 
    Whenever a document is recorded with the county clerk as authorized or required by this Code or applicable state laws, recordation shall provide constructive notice of the information contained in the recorded documents. 
(Code 1995, § 131.013) 
Sec. 26-186. - Furnishing false or incomplete information. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. It is the purpose and intent of the city council that every applicant for city licenses, permits, certificates, employment or other city actions under the provisions of this Code should be required to furnish true and complete information. 
(b)  Prohibited. No person shall willfully make a false statement or fail to report any material fact in any application for a city license, permit, certificate, employment or other city action under the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 131.014) 
Sec. 26-187. - Acts include causing, aiding and abetting. 
    Whenever any act or omission is made unlawful in this Code, it shall include causing, permitting, aiding or abetting such act or omission. 
(Code 1995, § 131.015) 
Sec. 26-188. - Notice of pending administrative enforcement action. 
    The city manager or, at his direction, a code enforcement officer may record with the county clerk a notice against a property which is the subject of an administrative enforcement action pending with the city. Such notice shall be on a form approved by the city attorney, shall describe the property both by street address and legal description, and shall describe the nature of the administrative action and refer to the section of this Code governing the pending administrative action. The cost of recording such notice shall be a charge against the property and the person responsible. 
(Code 1995, § 131.016) 
Secs. 26-189-26-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MINOR VIOLATIONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Alternative procedure for administrative hearing, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.044. 

Sec. 26-201. - Purpose. 
(a)  The city council finds that there is a need for an alternative method of enforcement for violations of this Code and applicable state law. The city council further finds that an appropriate method of enforcement for these violations is a notice of violation program. 
(b)  The procedures established in this division shall be in addition to criminal, civil or any other legal remedy established by law which may be pursued to address violations of this Code or applicable state laws. 
(Code 1995, § 131.401) 
Sec. 26-202. - Notice of violation-Authority; civil penalty. 
(a)  Any person violating any provisions of this Code or applicable state law may be issued a notice of violation by a code enforcement officer, as provided in this division. 
(b)  Each and every day a violation of this Code or applicable state law exists shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(c)  A civil penalty shall be assessed by means of a notice of violation issued by the code enforcement officer at a daily rate determined by the city manager or the building and standards commission, pursuant to the criteria listed in section 26-273, and shall be payable directly to the city. 
(d)  Penalties assessed by means of a notice of violation shall be collected in accordance with the procedures specified in this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 131.402) 
Sec. 26-203. - Same-Procedures. 
(a)  Upon discovering any violation of this Code or applicable state law, a code enforcement officer may issue a notice of violation to a responsible person in the manner prescribed in this division. The notice of violation shall be issued on a form approved by the city manager. 
(b)  If the responsible person is a business, the code enforcement officer shall attempt to locate the business owner and issue the business owner a notice of violation. If the code enforcement officer can only locate the manager of the business, the notice of violation may be given to the manager of the business. A copy of the notice of violation shall also be mailed to the business owner or responsible person in the manner prescribed by section 26-183. 
(c)  If the code enforcement officer is unable to locate the person responsible for the violation, then the notice of violation shall be mailed to the responsible person in the manner prescribed in section 26-183. 
(d)  If no person can be located at the property, then the notice of violation shall be posted in a conspicuous place on or near the property, and a copy subsequently mailed to the responsible person in the manner prescribed by section 26-183. 
(e)  The notice of violation shall be mailed to the responsible person in the manner prescribed by section 26-183. The failure of any person with an interest in the property to receive notice shall not affect the validity of any proceedings taken under this division. 
(Code 1995, § 131.403) 
Sec. 26-204. - Same-Contents. 
(a)  Whenever a code enforcement officer determines that a violation of this Code or applicable state codes or laws exists, the city manager and/or code enforcement officer may issue a notice of violation to a responsible person. The notice of violation shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name of the property's record owner; 
(2)  Street address; 
(3)  Code sections violated or how the sections are violated; 
(4)  A description of the property's condition which violates the applicable codes; 
(5)  A list of necessary corrections to bring the property into compliance; 
(6)  A deadline or specific date to correct the violations listed in the notice of violation; 
(7)  A description of the civil penalties assessed for the violations; and 
(8)  Reference to the potential consequences if the property should remain in violation after the expiration of the compliance deadline, including, but not limited to, criminal prosecution, civil injunction, administrative abatement, civil penalties, revocation of permits, recordation of the notice of violation and withholding of future municipal permits. 
(Code 1995, § 131.404) 
Sec. 26-205. - Appeals. 
    An appeal of a notice of violation shall follow the procedures set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 131.405) 
Sec. 26-206. - Administrative enforcement order. 
(a)  An appeal hearing shall follow the enforcement hearing procedures set forth in section 26-235. 
(b)  As part of the administrative enforcement order, the building and standards commission may reduce, waive or conditionally reduce the penalties or late fees assessed by the notice of violation. 
(c)  The building and standards commission may also impose conditions and deadlines to correct the violations or require payment of any outstanding penalties. 
(d)  The building and standards commission may assess reasonable administrative costs. 
(Code 1995, § 131.406) 
Sec. 26-207. - Penalties. 
(a)  The city manager shall establish policies to assist in the assessment of civil penalties for notices of violation. 
(b)  Payment of the penalty shall not excuse the failure to correct the violation, nor shall such payment bar further enforcement action by the city. 
(c)  All penalties assessed shall be payable to the city. 
(Code 1995, § 131.407) 
Sec. 26-208. - Failure to pay penalties. 
    The failure of any person to pay the civil penalties assessed by a notice of violation within the time specified on the notice may result in the city manager referring the matter to the city attorney to file a claim in a court having jurisdiction over the amount in controversy. Alternatively, the city manager may pursue any other legal remedy to collect the civil penalties as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 131.408) 
Sec. 26-209. - Allocation of administrative penalties. 
    Administrative civil penalties collected pursuant to this chapter shall be deposited in the code enforcement civil penalties fund established pursuant to this chapter (set forth in section 26-311). 
(Code 1995, § 131.409) 
Secs. 26-210-26-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REAL PROPERTY VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 26-231. - Purpose. 
(a)  The city council finds that there is a need for alternative methods of enforcement for violations of this Code and applicable state codes and laws which are found to exist on real property. The city council further finds that an appropriate method of enforcement for such types of violations is the issuance and recordation of notices of violation. 
(b)  The procedures established in this division shall be in addition to criminal, civil or any other remedy established by law which may be pursued to address violations of this Code or applicable state codes and statutes. 
(Code 1995, § 131.420) 
Sec. 26-232. - Notice of violation-Recordation procedure. 
(a)  Once a code enforcement officer has issued a notice of violation to a responsible person and the property remains in violation after the deadline established in the notice of violation, the city manager may record the notice of violation with the county clerk. 
(b)  Before recordation, the city manager shall provide to the responsible person a letter stating that a notice of violation will be recorded unless a written request is filed to appeal, pursuant to the procedures outlined in this division. The letter shall be served pursuant to any of the methods of service set forth in section 26-183. The city manager may also send a courtesy copy of the letter to any applicable financial institution. 
(c)  If the city manager does not receive the written request to appeal pursuant to the procedures set forth in this division, he may record the notice of violation if the violation remains. 
(d)  The recorded notice of violation shall include the name of the property owner's assessor's parcel number, the parcel's legal description and a copy of the latest notice of violation. 
(Code 1995, § 131.421) 
Sec. 26-233. - Same-Service. 
    A copy of the recorded notice of violation shall be served on the responsible person and property owner pursuant to any of the methods of service set forth in section 26-183. 
(Code 1995, § 131.422) 
Sec. 26-234. - Appeal procedure. 
(a)  An appeal of the city manager's letter to record a notice of violation shall follow the procedures set forth in section 26-235. 
(b)  Upon receiving a written appeal, the city manager or his designee shall schedule a hearing before the building and standards commission. The purpose of the hearing is for the responsible person or property owner to state any reasons why a notice of violation should not be recorded. 
(c)  The failure of any person to file an appeal in accordance with this section shall constitute a waiver of the right to an administrative hearing and shall not affect the validity of the recorded notice of violation. 
(Code 1995, § 131.423) 
Sec. 26-235. - Appeal hearing. 
(a)  An appeal hearing shall follow the hearing procedures set forth in this section. 
(b)  At the appeal hearing, the building and standards commission shall only consider evidence that is consistent with the city manager's rules and procedures for administrative enforcement hearings and that is relevant to the following issues: 
(1)  Whether the conditions listed in the notice of violation violate this Code or applicable state codes; and 
(2)  Whether the city afforded the responsible person with due process by adhering to the notification procedures specified in this division. 
(c)  If the building and standards commission affirms the city manager's decision, the city manager may proceed to record the notice of violation. 
(d)  If the building and standards commission determines that recordation is improper, the building and standards commission shall invalidate the city manager's decision to record the notice of violation. 
(Code 1995, § 131.424) 
Sec. 26-236. - Notice of compliance. 
(a)  When the violations listed on the notice of violation have been corrected, the responsible person or property owner may file with the city manager a written request for a notice of compliance on a form provided by the city. 
(b)  Once the city manager receives the request, the city manager or his designee shall reinspect the property within 30 calendar days to determine whether the violations listed on the notice of violation have been corrected and whether all necessary permits have been issued and final inspections have been performed. 
(c)  The city manager shall serve a notice of compliance to the responsible person or property owner in the manner provided in section 26-184, if the city manager determines that: 
(1)  All violations listed in the recorded notice of violation have been corrected; 
(2)  All necessary permits have been issued and finalized; 
(3)  All civil penalties assessed against the property have been paid; and 
(4)  The party requesting the notice of compliance has paid an administrative fee to reimburse the city for all administrative costs. 
(d)  Administrative costs may include costs incurred in the investigation, inspection, reinspection, title search, appeal hearing and any other processing costs associated with the violations specified on the notice of violation. 
(e)  If the city manager denies a request to issue a notice of compliance, he shall serve the responsible person or property owner with a written explanation setting forth the reasons for the denial. The written explanation shall be served by any of the methods of service listed in section 26-183. 
(f)  The city manager's decision to deny a request to issue a notice of compliance constitutes the final decision in the matter and is not appealable. 
(Code 1995, § 131.425) 
Sec. 26-237. - Withholding permits. 
    The city may withhold permits for any alteration, repair or construction pertaining to any existing or new structures or signs on the property, or any permits pertaining to the use and development of the real property or the structure, if a request to appeal has not been timely filed, or after the building and standards commission affirms the city manager's decision to record a notice of violation. The city may withhold permits until a notice of compliance has been issued by the city manager. The city may not withhold permits which are necessary to obtain a notice of compliance or to correct serious health and safety violations. 
(Code 1995, § 131.426) 
Sec. 26-238. - Recordation of notice of compliance; cancellation of recorded notice of violation. 
    The city manager, property owner or responsible person shall record the notice of compliance with the county clerk's office. The recordation of the notice of compliance shall have the effect of canceling the recorded notice of violation. 
(Code 1995, § 131.427) 
Secs. 26-239-26-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ASSESSMENT OF CIVIL PENALTIES 

Sec. 26-271. - Purpose. 
(a)  The city council finds that there is a need for alternative methods of enforcement of this Code and applicable state codes and statutes. The city council further finds that the assessment of civil penalties through an administrative hearing procedure for code violations is a necessary alternative method of code enforcement. 
(b)  The administrative assessment of civil penalties established in this article is in addition to any other administrative or judicial remedy established by law which may be pursued to address violations of this Code or applicable state codes and statutes. 
(Code 1995, § 131.440) 
Sec. 26-272. - Authority; applicability. 
(a)  Any person violating any provision of this Code or applicable state codes or statutes may be subject to the assessment of civil penalties pursuant to the administrative procedures provided in sections 26-273-26-278. 
(b)  Each and every day a violation of any provision of this Code or applicable state codes or statutes exists constitutes a separate and distinct violation. 
(c)  Civil penalties may be directly assessed by a notice of violation issued by a code enforcement officer or affirmed by the building and standards commission. Civil penalties may be recovered by assessment of a code enforcement lien or subsequent legal action brought by the city attorney. 
(d)  Civil penalties for violations of any provision of this Code or applicable state codes and statutes shall be assessed at a daily rate determined by the city manager or the building and standards commission pursuant to the criteria listed in section 26-273. The maximum rate shall be the amount specified in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.017. 
(Code 1995, § 131.441) 
State Law reference- Civil penalty, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.017. 
Sec. 26-273. - Determinations; penalty schedule. 
(a)  In determining the date when civil penalties started to accrue, the city manager may consider the date when the city first discovered the violations as evidenced by the issuance of a notice of violation or any other written correspondence. 
(b)  The assessment of civil penalties shall end when all action required by the notice of violation has been completed. 
(c)  In determining the amount of the civil penalty to be assessed on a daily rate, the city manager may consider some or all of the following factors: 
(1)  Duration of the violation. 
(2)  Frequency or recurrence of the violation. 
(3)  Seriousness of the violation. 
(4)  History of the violation. 
(5)  Responsible person's conduct after issuance of the notice of violation. 
(6)  Good faith effort by the responsible person to comply. 
(7)  Economic impact of the penalty on the responsible person. 
(8)  Impact of the violation upon the city. 
(9)  Hardship on the responsible party. 
(10)  Any other factors that justice may require. 
(d)  The city manager has the authority to establish a penalty schedule to use as a guideline in determining the amount of civil penalties in appropriate cases. The city manager shall also establish procedures for the use of the penalty schedule. 
(Code 1995, § 131.443) 
Sec. 26-274. - Administrative costs. 
    The city manager and/or the building and standards commission are authorized to assess any reasonable administrative costs. Administrative costs may include scheduling and processing of the hearing and all subsequent actions. 
(Code 1995, § 131.444) 
Sec. 26-275. - Failure to comply with notice of violation. 
    The city manager shall request the building and standards commission to establish a date, time and place for the civil penalties hearing when the responsible person fails to comply with the terms of the notice of violation. Failure to comply includes failure to: 
(1)  Pay the assessed civil penalties; 
(2)  Commence and complete corrections by the established deadlines; or 
(3)  Refrain from continuing violations of this Code or applicable state codes. 
(Code 1995, § 131.445) 
Sec. 26-276. - Consideration of evidence. 
    The building and standards commission shall only consider evidence that is relevant to the following issues: 
(1)  Whether the responsible person has caused or maintained a violation of this Code or applicable state codes or statutes that existed on the dates specified in the notice of violation; and 
(2)  Whether the amount of civil penalties assessed by the city manager pursuant to the procedures and criteria outlined in section 26-273 was reasonable. 
(Code 1995, § 131.446) 
Sec. 26-277. - Administrative enforcement order. 
(a)  Once all evidence and testimony are completed, the building and standards commission shall issue an administrative enforcement order which affirms or rejects the notice of violation or modifies the daily rate or duration of the civil penalties, depending upon the review of the evidence. The building and standards commission may increase or decrease the total amount of civil penalties and costs that are assessed by the notice of violation. 
(b)  The building and standards commission may issue an administrative enforcement order that requires the responsible person to cease from violating this Code or applicable state codes and statutes and to make necessary corrections. 
(c)  As part of the administrative enforcement order, the building and standards commission may establish specific deadlines for the payment of penalties and costs and condition the total or partial assessment of civil penalties on the responsible person's ability to complete compliance by specified deadlines. 
(d)  The building and standards commission may issue an administrative enforcement order which imposes additional civil penalties that will continue to be assessed until the responsible person complies with the building and standards commission's decision and corrects the violation. 
(e)  To ensure compliance with the administrative enforcement order, the building and standards commission may schedule subsequent review hearings as may be necessary or as requested by a party to the hearing. 
(Code 1995, § 131.447) 
Sec. 26-278. - Failure to comply with administrative enforcement order. 
(a)  Upon the failure of the responsible person to comply with the terms and deadlines set forth in the administrative enforcement order, the city manager may use all appropriate legal means to recover the civil penalties, administrative costs and obtain compliance with the administrative enforcement order. 
(b)  After the building and standards commission issues an administrative enforcement order, the city manager shall monitor the violations and determine compliance. 
(Code 1995, § 131.448) 
Secs. 26-279-26-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RECOVERY OF CODE ENFORCEMENT PENALTIES AND COSTS 

Sec. 26-311. - Code enforcement civil penalties fund. 
    Civil penalties collected pursuant to this chapter shall be deposited in the code enforcement civil penalties fund as established by the city manager for the enhancement of the city's code enforcement efforts and to reimburse city departments for investigative costs and costs associated with the hearing process that are not paid by the responsible person. Civil penalties deposited in such fund shall be appropriated and allocated in a manner determined by the city manager. The city finance officer shall establish accounting procedures to ensure proper account identification, credit and collection. 
(Code 1995, § 131.502) 
Sec. 26-312. - Notice of satisfaction. 
    Once payment in full is received for the outstanding civil penalties and costs or the amount is deemed satisfied pursuant to a subsequent administrative or judicial order, the city manager shall either record a notice of satisfaction or provide the property owner or financial institution with the notice of satisfaction so they can record the notice with the county clerk's office. The notice of satisfaction shall include the same information as provided for in the original code enforcement lien, and shall cancel the code enforcement lien. 
(Code 1995, § 131.503) 
Sec. 26-313. - Recoupment of expenses. 
    It is the intent of this section that, over a minimum three-year period commencing October 1, 1997, the city shall recover 100 percent of the full cost, including indirect charges, of code enforcement activities from fees derived from code enforcement. It shall be the responsibility of the city manager or his designee to review the code enforcement income at yearly intervals and recommend to the city council the need to increase or decrease code enforcement fees according to the result of such review. 
(Code 1995, § 131.504) 
Secs. 26-314-26-340. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VOLUNTARY CODE COMPLIANCE PROGRAM 

Sec. 26-341. - Purpose; created. 
    Believing that city fear of present code enforcement programs is based in part on the unreasonable fear that people will be forced to meet standards beyond the standards required for health and safety; and believing that the citizens of the city have displayed an earnest desire to preserve the livability of their city and deserve the opportunity to voluntarily meet basic minimum standards for health and safety, there is hereby created a voluntary code compliance program. 
(Code 1995, § 131.601) 
Sec. 26-342. - Certificate of code compliance authorized. 
    The owner of any building within the city, other than an accessory building, may obtain a certificate of code compliance relating to such building by submitting an application to the city manager or his designee. 
(Code 1995, § 131.602) 
Sec. 26-343. - Application. 
(a)  An application for a certificate of code compliance shall be made on the form provided by the city manager or his designee and must be duly signed by the owner. Such application shall state: 
(1)  The street address of such building; 
(2)  The height and number of stories contained in the building; 
(3)  The type of construction used in the building; and 
(4)  The nature of the occupancies of the building. 
(b)  The city manager or his designee may, if needed, request any plans or surveys for multiple dwellings or other additional information or assistance from the owner of any building. 
(Code 1995, § 131.603) 
Sec. 26-344. - Code compliance inspection. 
    Upon proper application for a certificate of code compliance and the payment of the required fees, the city manager or his designee shall cause the general construction, plumbing, electrical and other mechanical installations of the building to be inspected for safety and sanitation. The standards for the code compliance inspection shall be the minimum requirements of the code which are applicable to existing buildings and the inspection will not pertain to nonrequired items or building features, such as, but not limited to, fireplaces, pools, saunas, air conditioners, carpeting and humidifiers. In making the inspection, it shall be assumed that any concealed facilities and installations that are not viewed are adequate, based on the functional operations of the facilities and installations and the condition of the equipment that is viewed. 
(Code 1995, § 131.604) 
Sec. 26-345. - Issuance of certificate of code compliance. 
    Whenever the inspection, made pursuant to a request for a certificate of code compliance, shows the building to be in compliance with the requirements of the code with respect to housing, zoning, general construction, plumbing, electrical and other mechanical installations, based on the present occupancy of the building, the city manager or his designee shall issue a certificate of code compliance, setting forth the result of the inspection, containing the date of the inspection or the date the inspection was concluded, and a statement to the effect that such building complies with the provisions of the code as of the date of the inspection. The certificate shall clearly indicate it is not a guarantee. Such certificate of code compliance shall not be in lieu of or replace the requirement of a certificate of occupancy. 
(Code 1995, § 131.605) 
Sec. 26-346. - Building noncompliance. 
    When the results of the code compliance inspection shall show that the building fails, in any respect, to comply with the provisions of the code, the city manager or his designee shall notify the owner of such failure to comply, and specify where such building fails to comply with the requirements of the provisions of the code. The city manager or his designee shall take the necessary action to secure compliance with the provisions of the code, so that no immediate hazard to health or safety of the occupants is allowed to continue. 
(Code 1995, § 131.606) 
Sec. 26-347. - Fee. 
    The fee for the inspection of the building and issuance of the certificate of code compliance shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 131.607) 
Chapter 30 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses and business regulations, ch. 18; civil emergencies, ch. 22; fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30-1-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Burglar alarm systems, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 214.191-214.197; fire alarm systems, V.A.T.S. Insurance Code, art. 5.43-2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm notification means a notification intended to summon the police or fire department, which is designed either to be initiated purposely by a person or by an alarm system that responds to a stimulus characteristic of unauthorized intrusion or fire. 
    Alarm site means a single premises or location (one street address) served by an alarm system that is under the control of one owner. 
    Alarm system means any mechanical or electrical device which is used to protect buildings or premises from criminal acts or unauthorized entries by warning persons of a crime, unauthorized entry or fire through the emission of a sound or the transmission of a signal or message.
