Such term does not include an alarm installed on a vehicle unless the vehicle is permanently located at a site. 
    Automatic alarm notification means an alarm notification sent over telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a prerecorded voice message, synthesized voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect. 
    Central station means an office to which remote and supervisory signaling devices are connected, where operators supervise the circuits and/or guards are continuously maintained to investigate signals. 
    Chief means the chief of police or fire chief of the city or his authorized representative. 
    False alarm notification means an alarm notification to the police or fire department, when the responding officer finds no evidence of unauthorized intrusion, attempted unauthorized intrusion, robbery, attempted robbery, attempt to take a person hostage or a fire. 
    Local alarm means an alarm system that emits a signal at an alarm site which is audible or visible from the exterior of a structure. 
    Permit holder means the person designated in the application, as required in section 30-61, who is responsible for responding to alarms, giving access to the site, proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees. 
    Person means an individual, corporation, partnership, association, organization or similar entity. 
(Code 1995, § 90.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-32. - Monitoring. 
(a)  The police department of the city will house, monitor and respond to alarm systems for the following types of establishments within the corporate limits of the city: 
(1)  Chartered financial institutions. 
(2)  Drugstores. 
(3)  Health care facilities. 
(4)  Industrial plants with nonannexation contracts. 
(5)  Jewelry stores. 
(6)  Schools. 
(b)  The fire department of the city will house, monitor and respond to alarm systems for the following types of establishments: 
(1)  Chartered financial institutions. 
(2)  Commercial establishments. 
(3)  Health care facilities. 
(4)  Industries. 
(5)  Schools. 
(Code 1995, § 90.02) 
Sec. 30-33. - Applicability; exemptions. 
(a)  This article shall apply to any person who operates, or causes to be operated, an alarm system at any alarm site. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to alarm systems operated by local, state or federal governmental entities and private alarm systems which do not summon the police or fire department by direct connection via an electrical device. 
(Code 1995, § 90.03) 
Sec. 30-34. - Liability; city to be held harmless. 
    The application to the city or its designated agent shall contain a provision that the city shall not be liable for any failure of service or damages, including damages resulting from breaking to gain entrance, which might result from the installation or operation of any receiving station alarm, automatic dialing device or local alarm. All applicants must agree to indemnify the city for all claims, demands, judgments or other liability in a form satisfactory to the city attorney. 
(Code 1995, § 90.04) 
Sec. 30-35. - Violations; penalties. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this article, and any person who violates a provision of this article is guilty of a separate offense for each day, or portion thereof, during which the violation is committed, continued or permitted, and each offense is punishable by a fine as provided in section 1-14. 
(Code 1995, § 90.05) 
Secs. 30-36-30-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 30-61. - Required; application; transferability; false statements. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he operates, or causes to be operated, an alarm system without an alarm permit issued by the chief. A separate permit is required for each alarm system. 
(b)  An initial fee, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, shall be charged for the issuance of each permit. The renewal fee shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(c)  Upon receipt of a completed application form and the required fee, the chief shall issue an alarm permit to an applicant, unless the applicant has failed to pay a service fee assessed under section 30-100 or has had an alarm permit for the alarm system revoked, and the violation causing the revocation has not been corrected. 
(d)  Each permit application must contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the permit holder who will be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees assessed under this article; 
(2)  For each alarm system located at the alarm site, the purpose of the alarm system, such as burglary, robbery, personal hostage or fire; 
(3)  Other information required by the chief which is necessary for the enforcement of this article. 
(e)  Any false statement of a material matter made by an applicant for the purpose of obtaining an alarm permit shall be sufficient cause for refusal to issue a permit. 
(f)  An alarm permit cannot be transferred to another alarm system, except by authorization of the chief. A permit holder shall inform the chief of any change that alters any information listed on the permit application within two business days. No fee will be assessed for any such changes. 
(g)  A permit holder shall cancel a permit for any alarm system which is removed from an alarm site or otherwise ceases to come under the permitting requirements of this division. Cancellation may be accomplished by returning the permit to the chief. 
(h)  All fees owed by an applicant must be paid before a permit may be issued or renewed. 
(Code 1995, § 90.15) 
Sec. 30-62. - Duration and renewal. 
    An alarm permit is issued for one year and must be renewed every year upon submission of an updated application. It is the responsibility of the permit holder to submit an application prior to the permit expiration date. The chief shall determine the first expiration date of a permit. 
(Code 1995, § 90.16) 
Sec. 30-63. - Revocation. 
(a)  The chief shall revoke an alarm permit if he determines that: 
(1)  There is a false statement of a material matter on the application for a permit; 
(2)  The permit holder has violated any part of this article; 
(3)  The permit holder has failed to make payment of a service fee assessed under section 30-100 within 30 days of receiving notice to do so. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he operates an alarm system during the period in which his alarm permit is revoked. 
(Code 1995, § 90.17) 
Sec. 30-64. - Appeal from denial, revocation or suspension. 
(a)  If the chief refuses to issue or renew a permit or revokes a permit, he shall send to the applicant or permit holder, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of his action and a statement of the right to an appeal. Within ten days after receipt of the notice from the chief, the applicant or permit holder may appeal the decision of the chief to the city secretary by written request for a hearing, setting forth the reason for the appeal. The filing of a request for an appeal hearing with the city secretary stays an action of the chief in revoking a permit until the city secretary or his designated representative makes a final decision. If a request for an appeal hearing is not made within the ten-day period, the action of the chief is final. 
(b)  The city secretary shall set a time and place for the hearing, which shall be served upon the applicant or permit holder by certified mail, return receipt requested. The city secretary or his representative shall serve as hearing officer at an appeal and consider evidence by any interested person. The formal rules of evidence do not apply at an appeal hearing. All parties to the hearing shall have the right to present evidence and of cross examination. Within 15 days after the request for an appeal hearing is filed, the hearing officer shall make his decision on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence. The time for hearing an appeal may be extended by agreement of the parties. The hearing officer shall affirm, reverse or modify the action of the chief. The decision of the hearing officer is final as to administrative remedies with the city. 
(Code 1995, § 90.18) 
Secs. 30-65-30-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE 

Sec. 30-91. - Responsibilities. 
(a)  A permit holder shall: 
(1)  Maintain the premises containing an alarm system in a manner that ensures proper operation of the alarm system; 
(2)  Maintain the alarm system in a manner that will minimize false alarm notifications; 
(3)  Respond within 30 minutes, or cause a representative to respond within a reasonable period of time, when requested by the chief, to repair or inactivate a malfunctioning alarm system, provide access to the premises or provide security for the premises; 
(4)  Not manually activate an alarm for any reason, other than occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report; 
(5)  Notify the police department or fire department prior to activation of an alarm for maintenance purposes. 
(b)  A permit holder shall adjust, or cause to be adjusted, the mechanism so that an alarm signal will sound for no longer than 30 minutes after being activated. 
(Code 1995, § 90.30) 
Sec. 30-92. - Yearly inspection; certification. 
    Prior to January 10 of each year, establishments shall make arrangements with their alarm system company to inspect and provide written certification to the city that their alarm system is in proper working order. Failure to provide certification will result in charging for all alarm responses at the rate, per response, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 90.38) 
Sec. 30-93. - Reset required. 
    A permit holder of an alarm system that utilizes a local alarm shall adjust, or cause to be adjusted, the mechanism so that, upon activation, the local alarm will not transmit another alarm signal without first being reset. 
(Code 1995, § 90.31) 
Sec. 30-94. - Indirect reporting. 
    A person who is engaged in the business of relaying alarm notifications to the city shall: 
(1)  Communicate alarm notifications to the city in a manner and form determined by the chief. 
(2)  Comply with the requirements of this article and any rules and regulations promulgated by the chief. 
(Code 1995, § 90.32) 
Sec. 30-95. - Automatic telephone dialing notification. 
    Following the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived (12-11-1990), no permit will be issued for the use of alarm systems using automatic telephone dialing to report an alarm condition directly to the police department by means of a recorded message. 
(Code 1995, § 90.33) 
Sec. 30-96. - Operating instructions. 
    A permit holder shall maintain a complete set of written operating instructions for each alarm system at each alarm site. Special codes, combinations or passwords must not be included in the instructions. 
(Code 1995, § 90.34) 
Sec. 30-97. - Dispatch records. 
(a)  The police or fire dispatcher receiving an alarm notification and/or the officer responding to a dispatch resulting from a burglary, robbery, personal hostage or fire alarm notification shall cause to be recorded in the police or fire information systems such information, as necessary, to permit the chief to maintain records, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Identification of the permit holder; 
(2)  Identification of the alarm site; 
(3)  Dispatcher-received time, dispatch time and officer-arrived-at-scene time; 
(4)  Date of occurrence; 
(5)  Name of permit holder's representative on the premises, if any. 
(b)  The responding police officer or firefighter shall prepare and submit the appropriate reports in regard to any criminal offense, attempt, fire or other incident which contributed to the alarm notification, as determined by the investigation. 
(Code 1995, § 90.35) 
Sec. 30-98. - Performance reviews and consultations. 
(a)  The chief may require a conference with an alarm permit holder to review circumstances of each false alarm if there is reason to believe that an alarm system is not being used or maintained in a manner that ensures proper operation and suppresses false alarms. 
(b)  The permit holder or his representative may request a conference with the chief if there is a belief that an alarm is the result of circumstances beyond the reasonable control of the permit holder. 
(Code 1995, § 90.36) 
Sec. 30-99. - Service fee for false burglar alarm notifications. 
    Except as provided in sections 30-101 and 30-102, the holder of an alarm permit or alarm site, responded to upon call, shall pay a fee for each false burglar alarm notification emitted from an alarm system, as follows: 
(1)  Beginning January 1 of each year, five false alarms will be answered free of charge. 
(2)  Each false burglar alarm in a 12-month period will be billed at the rate, per response, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 90.37(A)) 
State Law reference- False burglar alarm fee, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.197. 
Sec. 30-100. - Service fee for false fire alarm notifications. 
    Except as provided in sections 30-101 and 30-102, the holder of an alarm permit or alarm site, responded to upon call, shall pay a fee for each false fire alarm notification emitted from an alarm system, as follows: 
(1)  Beginning January 1 of each year, three false fire alarms will be answered free of charge. 
(2)  The next three false fire alarms in such 12-month period will be billed at the rate, per response, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(3)  The next three false fire alarms will be billed at the rate, per response, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(4)  Each false fire alarm thereafter will be billed at the rate, per response, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 90.37(A)) 
Sec. 30-101. - Service fee exemption when permit applied for prior to installation. 
    If a person notifies the chief and applies for an alarm permit before a new alarm system is put into service, no service fee will be assessed during the first 60 days after the system is put into service, and alarm notifications during such period will not be counted in determining when a service fee shall be assessed. 
(Code 1995, § 90.37(B)) 
Sec. 30-102. - Service fee exemption for alarm notifications. 
(a)  If the responding police officer or firefighter determines that an alarm notification was caused by unauthorized intrusion, attempted unauthorized intrusion, robbery, attempted robbery, attempt to take a person hostage or fire, including smoke, the notification will not be counted in determining when a service fee will be assessed. 
(b)  An alarm notification will not be counted in determining when a service fee will be assessed if the permittee can prove that the alarm notification was the result of a severe weather condition, such as a tornado, hurricane, earthquake or other weather condition that causes physical damage to the alarm site, or the result of a malfunction in the operation of telephone lines for the transmission of alarm signals. Proof of the malfunction in the operation of telephone lines for the transmission of alarm signals shall be documented in the form of telephone company work orders or time stamped records from the alarm company showing the periods of interrupted service. 
(Code 1995, § 90.37(C), (D)) 
Sec. 30-103. - Late payment of service fee. 
    If a permit holder or alarm site which is responded to by the fire or police department does not timely pay a service fee charge required in this division, the chief shall file a complaint in the proper court to force collection. 
(Code 1995, § 90.37(E)) 
Chapter 34 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 14; rabies control, § 14-101 et seq.; dangerous dogs, § 14-151 et seq.; combustible materials and flammable liquids, § 38-131 et seq.; natural resources, ch. 46; parks and recreation, ch. 50; solid waste, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; utilities, ch. 70; hazardous waste discharge notification, § 70-102(j); buildings and building regulations, ch. 78; International Property Maintenance Code, § 78-71 et seq.; moving buildings, § 78-481 et seq.; floods, ch. 82; manufactured homes and parks, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 94; storage of inflammable and explosive materials; open burning prohibited; fire zone, § 94-256; zoning, ch. 98. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 34-1-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UNSECURED, VACANT STRUCTURES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to condemn dangerous buildings, § 13. 

Sec. 34-31. - Findings. 
(a)  The city council finds and declares that: 
(1)  Structures that are vacant and unsecured or boarded attract vagrants, gang members and other criminals as prime locations to conduct illegal criminal activities. 
(2)  Structures that are vacant and not properly secured are extremely vulnerable to being set on fire by unauthorized persons. 
(3)  Structures that are vacant and unsecured or boarded are a blight and cause deterioration and instability in neighborhoods. 
(4)  Structures that are vacant and unsecured or boarded pose serious threats to the public's health and safety and, therefore, are declared to be public nuisances. 
(b)  Immediate abatement and rehabilitation of the structures set forth in subsection (a) of this section is necessary and can be accomplished by using the judicial or administrative procedures found in this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 97.01) 
Sec. 34-32. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Responsible person means a person whom a code enforcement officer determines is responsible for causing or maintaining a public nuisance or a violation of this Code or applicable state codes. Such term includes, but is not limited to, a property owner, tenant, person with a legal interest in real property or person in possession of real property. 
    Statement of intent means a form filled out by the owner of a boarded structure by a code enforcement officer which contains specific information from the property owner regarding the structure and the owner's plan for its rehabilitation and maintenance. 
    Vacant structure means any structure or building that is: 
(1)  Unoccupied or occupied by unauthorized persons; and 
(2)  Unsecured or boarded. 
(Code 1995, § 97.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-33. - Enforcement authority. 
    Any code enforcement officer authorized by the city manager is authorized to administer and enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 97.03) 
Sec. 34-34. - Enforcement remedies. 
    Violations of this article may be prosecuted as misdemeanors and shall be subject to the fines and administrative penalties as provided in this article. The city manager may also seek injunctive relief and civil penalties in the district court or pursue any administrative remedy provided in articles III and IV of chapter 26. 
(Code 1995, § 97.04) 
Sec. 34-35. - Duty to remove waste, rubbish and debris from interior of structure. 
    It is unlawful for any responsible person in charge or control of any structure to fail to remove any waste, rubbish or debris from the interior of the structure. 
(Code 1995, § 97.06(A); Ord. No. 02-03, pt. 1, 1-8-2002) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 54. 
Sec. 34-36. - Duty to remove waste, etc., from yards. 
    It is unlawful for any responsible person in charge or control of any structure to fail to remove any waste, rubbish, debris or excessive vegetation from the yards surrounding the structure to the edge of a paved street or alley or to the centerline of any undeveloped or unpaved street or alley. 
(Code 1995, § 97.06(B); Ord. No. 02-03, pt. 1, 1-8-2002) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 54. 
Sec. 34-37. - Duty to lock, barricade or secure doors, windows and openings. 
    It is unlawful for any responsible person in charge or control of any vacant structure to fail to lock, barricade or secure all doors, windows and other openings. 
(Code 1995, § 97.06(C)) 
Sec. 34-38. - Administrative abatement procedures. 
(a)  Whenever a code enforcement officer or the city manager determines that a vacant and unsecured structure exists within the city, an abatement notice and order may be sent to the responsible person, directing abatement by cleaning and securing or boarding. Boarding shall be done pursuant to the standards established in section 34-39. 
(b)  The code enforcement officer shall follow the administrative abatement procedures provided in articles III and IV of chapter 26. 
(c)  If the responsible person does not comply with the abatement notice and order, and no appeal is filed, the city may: 
(1)  Clean and board the unsecured, vacant structure; and 
(2)  Recover all costs pursuant to the procedures set forth in articles III and IV of chapter 26. 
(d)  If the city boards the structure, all barricade materials supplied by the city shall become the property of the responsible person, upon payment of all costs to the city. 
(Code 1995, § 97.07) 
Sec. 34-39. - Boarding standards. 
    Except as provided in subsection (8) of this section, the responsible person or the city shall board a vacant structure in accordance with the following specifications and requirements: 
(1)  Remove all waste, rubbish or debris from the interior of the structure; 
(2)  Remove all waste, rubbish, debris or excessive vegetation from the yards surrounding the vacant structure; 
(3)  Boarding shall be as specified in the city property maintenance code listed in chapter 78 of this Code; 
(4)  Post the premises. One or more signs shall be posted at or near each entrance to the structure and on fences or walls, as appropriate. The signs shall remain posted until the structure is either lawfully occupied or demolished. Signs shall contain the following information: 
DO NOT ENTER 
It is unlawful to enter or occupy this building or premises or to remove or deface this notice. 
(Brownwood Municipal Code) 
City of Brownwood, Texas 
Trespassers will be prosecuted 
(5)  In lieu of requiring the responsible person to board a structure as set forth above, the city manager may allow the responsible person to board the vacant structure in a manner which the city manager determines adequately prevents unauthorized entry or vandalism, or deterioration from the elements. In any event, a responsible person shall post the premises as set forth in subsection (7) of this section. 
(Code 1995, § 97.08; Ord. No. 11-30, § 4.B, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 34-40. - Unlawful entry or occupancy; interference with notice. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to enter or occupy any structure or premises which has been posted pursuant to section 34-39(7), except to repair or demolish the structure under a proper permit or for a purpose authorized by the owner. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to remove or deface any notice posted pursuant to section 34-39(7) until the required repairs or demolition have been completed or a certificate of occupancy has been issued in accordance with appropriate provisions of the building code as adopted in section 78-31. 
(Code 1995, § 97.09) 
Sec. 34-41. - Continuous abatement authority. 
(a)  If a vacant structure previously abated by the responsible person or the city pursuant to a notice and order again becomes unsecured and open to unauthorized entry, the city may, without further notice to the responsible person, proceed to abate the nuisance and recover costs as provided for in this article. 
(b)  If the yards surrounding a vacant structure again contain debris, rubbish, waste or excessive vegetation, the city may, without further notice to the responsible person, proceed to abate the nuisance and recover costs as provided for in this article. 
(c)  The building and standards commission may issue an administrative enforcement order that would give the city continuous abatement authority to: 
(1)  Abate a vacant structure which again becomes unsecured and open to unauthorized entry; or 
(2)  Abate the yards surrounding a vacant structure if the yards again contain debris, rubbish, waste or excessive vegetation. 
The building and standards commission may establish notice requirements, as may be reasonable. 
(Code 1995, § 97.10) 
Sec. 34-42. - Abatement costs. 
(a)  Abatement costs shall include the cost to perform the actual work and the city's cost to administer any abatement. 
(b)  Once the abatement is complete, the city shall recover all abatement costs by all remedies allowed by this Code or state codes and statutes. 
(Code 1995, § 97.11) 
Sec. 34-43. - Continuous public nuisances. 
    Any vacant structure that was originally secured by the responsible person's voluntary actions or pursuant to judicial or administrative order may be declared a permanent public nuisance by the city if the structure continues to remain open and unsecured on a periodic basis, thereby requiring additional reinspections and resecuring of the structure. The city may seek demolition of the continuous public nuisance by seeking a court order or follow any of the administrative abatement procedures found in this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 97.12) 
Sec. 34-44. - Statement of intent. 
(a)  The city shall create and make available a form entitled "Statement of Intent," to be completed by the owner of a vacant structure. 
(b)  The owner of a vacant structure shall complete the information required on the standard statement of intent and submit the statement of intent to the city manager within 30 days of the date the city manager determines that the structure became boarded. 
(c)  The city manager shall determine whether a submitted statement of intent is complete, and may require an owner to provide more complete information. 
(d)  The statement of intent shall include: 
(1)  Information as to the expected period of vacancy; 
(2)  A plan for regular maintenance during the period of vacancy; and 
(3)  A plan and timeline for the lawful occupancy, rehabilitation or demolition of the vacant structure. 
(e)  It is unlawful to: 
(1)  Fail to file a statement of intent within the time period specified in subsection (b) of this section; or 
(2)  File a statement of intent which does not comply with the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1995, § 97.13) 
Secs. 34-45-34-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WEEDS AND EXCESSIVE GROWTH OF VEGETATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal power over weeds or other unsanitary matter, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.004; additional authority to abate dangerous weeds, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.008. 

Sec. 34-81. - Maximum growth. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person having supervision or control of any lot, tract, parcel of land, or portion thereof, within the corporate limits of the city, to the edge of a paved street or alley or the centerline of any undeveloped or unpaved street or alley, occupied or unoccupied, improved or unimproved, to suffer or permit grass, weeds or brush that is uncultivated to grow to a height greater than 12 inches on such lot, tract, or parcel of land, five acres or less in size, within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  On tracts of land more than five acres, it shall be unlawful to suffer or permit grass, weeds and brush in excess of 12 inches in height to grow uncultivated within 100 feet of the edge of a paved street or alley or the centerline of any undeveloped or unpaved street or alley within the corporate limits of the city or within 100 feet on either side of any lot that is occupied by a residence or business. 
(Code 1995, § 99.01; Ord. No. 02-03, pt. 2, 1-8-2002) 
Sec. 34-82. - Notice of violation. 
(a)  When any violation of this article is found to exist, a notice by letter will be sent to the owner of the property in question. The notice may be given as follows: 
(1)  Personally to the owner, in writing; 
(2)  By letter addressed to the owner at the owner's address as recorded in the appraisal district records of the appraisal district in which the property is located; or 
(3)  If personal service cannot be obtained, by: 
a.  Publication of the notice at least once; 
b.  Posting the notice on or near the front door of each building on the property to which the violation relates; or 
c.  Posting the notice on a placard attached to a stake driven into the ground on the property to which the violation relates. 
(b)  If the city mails a notice to a property owner in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, and the United States Postal Service returns the notice as refused or unclaimed, the validity of the notice is not affected and the notice is considered to have been delivered. 
(c)  In a notice provided under this section, the city may inform the owner by regular mail and a posting on the property, or by personally delivering the notice, that if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses a danger to the public health and safety on or before the first anniversary of the date of the notice, without further notice, the city may correct the violation at the owner's expense and assess the expense against the property. If a violation covered by a notice under this subsection occurs within the one-year period, and the city has not been informed, in writing, by the owner of an ownership change, then the city, without notice, may take any action permitted by subsections (a)(1) and (2) of this section, and assess the expenses as provided by V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.007. 
(d)  Upon the giving of the annual notice, no further notice shall be required pursuant to this article. 
(e)  The notice of violation shall contain the following statements: 
(1)  "You are required to maintain your property so as to keep grass, brush and weeds at a height of less than 12 inches; 
(2)  "If you fail to do so, the city will enter upon your property and mow, or have it mowed, at 30-day intervals, during such annual growing season; 
(3)  "You have seven days from the date of this notice to correct the violation; and 
(4)  "Tall weeds are a breeding ground for rats and mice, and are a source of fuel for many fires. Please help us clean up Brownwood." 
(Code 1995, § 99.02) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.006. 
Sec. 34-83. - Action upon failure of owner to mow. 
    In addition to court action, the city may enter upon the property found in violation of this article and mow, or have the property mowed, at 30-day intervals, during such annual growing season if the owner fails to mow the property. 
(Code 1995, § 99.03) 
Sec. 34-84. - Assessment of city's expenses; billing. 
    Expenses incidental to the action taken by the city to correct any condition coming under the provisions of this article, which includes a service charge to cover administration costs, plus a penalty charge as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, shall be assessed against the owners of all outstanding interests in the lot or parcel of land involved. An itemized bill of such costs shall be mailed by the city to each such owner if the owner's address is known. 
(Code 1995, § 99.04) 
Sec. 34-85. - Action upon nonpayment of bill. 
    If the bill for the city's expenses in correcting any condition coming under the provisions of this article, including the administrative and penalty charges, shall remain unpaid for a period of 30 days after the date of the mailing of the bill, the city shall file a statement of the bill as provided in section 34-86. 
(Code 1995, § 99.05) 
Sec. 34-86. - Statement of expenses; lien. 
(a)  The mayor, city health authority or city official designated by the mayor shall file with the county clerk a statement of expenses in correcting any condition coming under the provisions of this article. The lien statement shall state the name of the owner, if known, and the legal description of the property. The lien attaches upon the filing of the lien statement with the county clerk. 
(b)  The lien obtained by the city council is security for the expenditures made and interest accruing at the rate of ten percent on the amount due from the date of payment by the city. 
(c)  The lien is inferior only to: 
(1)  Tax liens; and 
(2)  Liens for street improvements. 
(d)  The city council may bring a suit for foreclosure in the name of the city to recover the expenditures and interest due. 
(e)  The statement of expenses, or a certified copy thereof, is prima facie proof of the expenses incurred by the city in doing the work or making the improvements. 
(f)  The remedy provided by this section is in addition to the remedy provided by V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.005. 
(g)  The city council may foreclose a lien on property under this section in a proceeding relating to the property brought under V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 33, subch. E (V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 33.91 et seq). 
(Code 1995, § 99.05) 
State Law reference- Assessment of expenses, lien, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 342.007. 
Sec. 34-87. - Administrative citation. 
    In addition, this article may be enforced pursuant to the notice of violation in section 26-201. 
Secs. 34-88-34-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - JUNKED, WRECKED, ABANDONED PROPERTY[4] 
Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 34-121-34-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ABANDONED PROPERTY OTHER THAN MOTOR VEHICLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Unclaimed property, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 18.17. 

Sec. 34-141. - Public nuisance declared; impoundment authorized; exemptions. 
(a)  Any personal property, other than a motor vehicle, which is placed, left standing, parked, erected or lying in violation of any ordinance, the city Charter or any state law, or which is left unattended for more than 48 continuous hours in or on any public street, alley, sidewalk, public property or public place in the city, or which is placed, left standing, parked, erected or lying in or on any public street, alley or sidewalk in such a manner as to substantially interfere with, obstruct or constitute a barrier to vehicular or pedestrian traffic is declared a public nuisance. When any such property is found by a police officer or city code enforcement officer, it shall be removed, or caused to be removed, summarily to the police pound or any other place of impoundment designated by the city manager. 
(b)  Trash receptacles and newspaper and magazine vending machines on public sidewalks shall not be deemed obstructions under this section. 
(Code 1995, § 95.01) 
Sec. 34-142. - Notice of impoundment. 
    Within ten days after any personal property is impounded under this division, the impounder shall notify the owner of such property and all lienholders, if their names and addresses are known, that such property has been impounded. 
(Code 1995, § 95.02) 
Sec. 34-143. - Lien on impounded property. 
    A lien for all costs incurred in the impounding, storing and advertising for sale of personal property pursuant to this division shall exist and inure to the benefit of the person actually impounding such property. Such lien shall be prior and superior to all other liens of every kind, except liens for ad valorem taxes, and the impounder may retain possession of such property until all costs are paid and may sell the property as provided in this division. 
(Code 1995, § 95.03) 
Sec. 34-144. - Redemption of impounded property. 
    The owner or any person legally entitled to possession of any impounded personal property, as provided for in this division, may redeem the property by: 
(1)  Paying to the impounder, before sale, the applicable fees set out in section 34-143; 
(2)  Paying to the buyer at the sale double the amount paid by him for such personal property, and any reasonable expenses incurred by him for keeping the property, provided that the property shall be redeemed from the buyer within 30 days after the date of the sale, excluding the date of sale, otherwise title to the property shall become absolute in the buyer. 
(Code 1995, § 95.04) 
Sec. 34-145. - Sale of unredeemed property. 
(a)  When any personal property, other than motor vehicles, is not redeemed within 30 days after being impounded, the property may be sold in the manner designated by the city manager. 
(b)  Before selling any personal property as provided for in this section, the impounder shall post two notices thereof, one at the county courthouse door and one at the city hall, and shall cause a copy of such notice to be published once a week for two consecutive weeks in a daily newspaper published in the city, and the date of the first publication shall be at least 14 days prior to the day of the sale. The notice of sale shall: 
(1)  Describe the impounded property; 
(2)  State that the property is unredeemed; 
(3)  State that the property will be sold; 
(4)  Designate the place, manner and time and date of the sale, which shall not be less than 14 days from the date of the first posting of such notice. 
(c)  When any impounded property is not redeemed by the date and time designated in the notice of sale, the impounder shall sell such property in the manner designated by the city manager, and execute a bill of sale of such property to the purchaser thereof, provided that the impounder shall execute or deliver only a conditional bill of sale until the title of the buyer has become absolute by an expiration of a period of 30 days, exclusive of the day of sale, without being redeemed by the owner of the impounded property. 
(Code 1995, § 95.05) 
Sec. 34-146. - Disposition of proceeds of sale. 
    After deducting the fees to which the impounder is entitled pursuant to section 34-147, the impounder shall hold the balance of the proceeds of such sale, if any, to pay to the owner of the property. If the owner fails to call for such proceeds within 30 days, the proceeds shall belong to the impounder. 
(Code 1995, § 95.06) 
Sec. 34-147. - Impoundment fees and charges. 
    The fees established by this article shall be charged and shall be paid to an impounder pursuant to the provisions of this article (see section 34-143). 
(Code 1995, § 95.07) 
Secs. 34-148-34-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ABANDONED MOTOR VEHICLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 66. 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.001 et seq. 

Sec. 34-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned motor vehicle means a vehicle that: 
(1)  Is inoperative and over five years of age, and is left unattended on public property for more than 48 hours; 
(2)  Has illegally remained on public property for a period of more than 48 hours; 
(3)  Has remained on private property for more than 48 hours without the consent of the owner or person in control of the property; 
(4)  Has been left unattended for more than 48 hours on the right-of-way of a designated county, state or federal highway; or 
(5)  Has been left unattended for more than 24 hours on the right-of-way of a turnpike project constructed and maintained by the state turnpike authority or a controlled access highway. 
State Law reference- Similar definition, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.002. 
    Chief of police means the chief of police, his designee or any duly commissioned police officer. 
    Code enforcement officer means any person authorized to enforce violations of this Code or applicable state codes. 
    Inoperable motor vehicle means a motor vehicle subject to registration pursuant to the Texas Certificate of Title Act, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 501, that does not have lawfully affixed thereto an unexpired license plate, or a motor vehicle that cannot be started, driven, operated, steered and stopped, under its own power and without causing damage to the vehicle, because of mechanical failure, breakdown or disrepair or because it has been wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled. 
(Code 1995, § 95.10) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-172. - State law adopted. 
    The provisions of V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 683 are hereby adopted by reference to establish a comprehensive and uniform procedure for the impounding, storage and sale of abandoned motor vehicles within the city. 
(Code 1995, § 95.12) 
State Law reference- Notice, seizure, auction or disposal, storage fees, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.011 et seq. 
Sec. 34-173. - Leaving inoperable motor vehicle unattended. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, place or allow an inoperable motor vehicle to remain on any public street, alley, sidewalk, highway or public property within the city for a period of more than 48 continuous hours, and the presence of such inoperable motor vehicle upon any such public street, alley, sidewalk, highway or public property after the expiration of such 48-hour period is hereby declared unlawful and to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1995, § 95.11) 
Sec. 34-174. - Authority to impound; administrative procedures established. 
    The city manager is authorized to provide, by contract or otherwise, for the impounding, storage and disposition of abandoned motor vehicles and shall establish such administrative procedures as he deems necessary for the securing of proof of abandonment, collection of fees, distribution of proceeds of sale or redemption, giving of notices and impounding and sale of abandoned and junked motor vehicles, consistent with this article and the Texas Litter Abatement Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 365. 
(Code 1995, § 95.13) 
Sec. 34-175. - Interference with impoundment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally interfere with or attempt to prevent the physical impounding of any junked or abandoned motor vehicle by the chief of police or any code enforcement officer pursuant to this article or the Texas Litter Abatement Act. 
(Code 1995, § 95.14) 
Sec. 34-176. - Notice required prior to impoundment. 
    At least 48 hours prior to impounding any abandoned motor vehicle, whether such vehicle is on public or private property, a code enforcement officer or police officer of the city shall securely affix a visible, dated, brightly colored notice of abandonment to such vehicle, and a record of the date and time such notice was affixed shall be maintained by the chief of police or the code enforcement officer, as the case may be. If the motor vehicle is subsequently impounded as abandoned, proof that the motor vehicle was not removed from the public or private property after the visible notice of abandonment was attached to the vehicle shall be prima facie proof in any court that the: 
(1)  Vehicle was left unattended and abandoned for the period of time between the affixing of the notice and the impounding of the motor vehicle; and 
(2)  Owner of such vehicle caused, allowed, suffered and permitted the motor vehicle to remain at the place where such motor vehicle was impounded for the period of time between the affixing of the notice and the impounding of the motor vehicle. 
(Code 1995, § 95.15) 
Sec. 34-177. - Impoundment, storage and other fees. 
(a)  The fees established by this section shall be charged by, and paid to, the director of finance, his designee or the person engaged by the city to impound and store abandoned motor vehicles, if upon, upon redemption of an abandoned motor vehicle, or out of the proceeds of the sale of such motor vehicle, if the motor vehicle is not redeemed. 
(b)  The fees established for service rendered under the provisions of this article shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 95.16) 
Sec. 34-178. - Notice of sale at public auction. 
    Any motor vehicle not redeemed as provided by law shall be sold at public auction in the manner provided by the city manager. Before selling any such motor vehicle, a code enforcement officer or the chief of police shall post two notices of the sale, one at the county courthouse and one at city hall, and shall cause a copy of such notice to be published in a daily newspaper in the city at least ten days prior to the date of sale. The notice shall describe the year, make and model of the impounded motor vehicle to be sold, state that the motor vehicle is unredeemed and is being sold at public auction under reserve pursuant to the Texas Litter Abatement Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 365.001 et seq., and state the time, date, place and manner of the sale. The notice shall further state that the failure of the owner and the lienholder to exercise their rights to reclaim any vehicle within the time provided constitutes a waiver by the owner and lienholder of all rights, title and interest in the vehicle and their consent to the sale of the abandoned motor vehicle at a public auction. The notice shall also state that the Texas Litter Abatement Act provides that the purchaser of the motor vehicle shall take title to the motor vehicle free and clear of all liens and claims of ownership, and is entitled to register the purchased vehicle and receive a certificate of title. Such notice may contain multiple listings of abandoned motor vehicles. Failure to give notice required by this section, in whole or in part, shall not affect the sale of such motor vehicle, it being the intention of the city council that the procedures set forth in this section for giving notice of the sale shall not be a precondition of the sale, but merely a means of advertising the sale to potential bidders. The impounder may establish a minimum bid for the sale of any motor vehicle offered for sale pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1995, § 95.17) 
Sec. 34-179. - Recordkeeping requirements. 
    A code enforcement officer, the chief of police or his designee shall maintain records containing: 
(1)  A description of each motor vehicle impounded, by the year, make and model of each vehicle; 
(2)  The date and time of such impoundment; 
(3)  The date notices of impoundment are advertised or mailed to holders and owners of record and the return receipts from such mailings; 
(4)  The date the motor vehicles are redeemed or sold; 
(5)  The amount realized for each motor vehicle at such sale; 
(6)  The amount of fees to which the impounder is entitled pursuant to this division; 
(7)  The names and addresses of the owners and holders, if known; 
(8)  The names and addresses of the buyers; 
(9)  The names and addresses of the garage keepers, if any, entitled to recover charges for servicing, storing or repair of the motor vehicles, upon redemption or sale, and the amount of such charges; and 
(10)  Any further information the city manager may deem necessary. 
(Code 1995, § 95.18) 
Secs. 34-180-34-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - JUNKED VEHICLES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 66. 
State Law reference- Junked vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.071 et seq. 

Sec. 34-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Junked vehicle means any motor vehicle as defined in V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.071. 
(Code 1995, § 95.10) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-202. - Public nuisance declared. 
    Junked vehicles are detrimental to the welfare of the general public, tending to reduce the value of private property, invite vandalism, create fire hazards, constitute an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors, and are detrimental to the economic welfare of the city and state by producing urban blight which is adverse to the maintenance and continuing development of the city, and such vehicles are declared to be a public nuisance and subject to abatement as provided in this division. 
(Code 1995, § 95.30) 
Sec. 34-203. - Responsibility of owners and occupants of real property. 
    The owner or occupant of any real property within the city shall keep such property free of, and shall not permit or suffer the presence of, any junked vehicles on such property. 
(Code 1995, § 95.31) 
Sec. 34-204. - Notice to abate nuisance. 
(a)  Whenever any junked vehicle is located on any private property in violation of this division, a code enforcement officer or the chief of police shall order the owner or the occupant of the premises whereon such public nuisance exists, the last known registered owner of the nuisance and each lienholder of record of the nuisance to abate or remove the nuisance. Such order shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  State the nature of the public nuisance and that it must be removed and abated within ten days after service of notice; 
(3)  State that a request for a hearing to determine whether or not the motor vehicle is a junked motor vehicle must be made to the municipal court clerk, either in person or in writing, and without the requirement of bond, before expiration of the ten-day period; and 
(4)  State that if no request for a hearing is received before the expiration of the ten-day period, it shall be conclusively presumed that the vehicle is a junked vehicle. 
(b)  Such notice shall be served in accordance with section 26-183, to the owner or the occupant of the private premises whereupon such public nuisance exists, the last known registered owner of the nuisance and each lienholder of record of the nuisance. 
(c)  If the post office address of the last known registered owner of the nuisance is unknown, notice may be placed on the nuisance or, if the owner is located, the notice may be personally delivered. 
(d)  If the notice is returned undelivered, action to abate the nuisance shall be continued to a date not earlier than the 11th day after the date of the return of the notice. 
(Code 1995, § 95.32(A)) 
Sec. 34-205. - Order to abate or remove. 
(a)  Whenever any junked vehicle is located on public property or a public right-of-way within the city in violation of this division, a code enforcement officer or the chief of police shall order the owner or occupant of the public premises or of the premises adjacent to the public right-of-way whereupon such public nuisance exists, the last known registered owner of the nuisance and each lienholder of record to abate or remove the nuisance. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  State the nature of the public nuisance and that it must be removed and abated within ten days after service of the notice; 
(3)  State that a request for a hearing to determine whether or not the motor vehicle is a junked motor vehicle, as defined in section 34-201, must be made to the municipal court clerk, either in person or in writing, and without the requirement of bond, before the expiration of the ten-day period; and 
(4)  State that if no request for a hearing is received before the expiration of the ten-day period, it shall be conclusively presumed that the vehicle is a junked vehicle. 
(b)  Such notice shall be served in accordance with section 26-183, to the owner or the occupant of the private premises or occupant of the private premises adjacent to the public right-of-way whereupon such nuisance exists, the last known registered owner of the nuisance and each lienholder of record of the nuisance. 
(c)  If the post office address of the last known registered owner of the nuisance is unknown, notice may be placed on the nuisance or, if the owner is located, the notice may be personally delivered. 
(d)  If the notice is returned undelivered, action to abate the nuisance shall be continued to a date not earlier than the 11th day after the date of the return of the notice. 
(Code 1995, § 95.32(B)) 
State Law reference- Notice, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.075. 
Sec. 34-206. - Visible notice to be placed on junked vehicles. 
(a)  At the time a junked vehicle is located by a code enforcement officer or the chief of police on either occupied or unoccupied private or public property or a public right-of-way, in addition to any other notices required in this division, a visible notice, brightly colored, but of a color different from the color used for notices of abandonment, shall be securely affixed to such vehicle. Such notice shall: 
(1)  State that the vehicle is a public nuisance and it must be removed and abated within ten days from the date on such notice; 
(2)  State that a request for a hearing to determine whether or not the motor vehicle is a junked motor vehicle, as defined in section 34-201, must be made to the municipal court clerk, either in person or in writing, and without the requirement of bond, before the expiration of the ten-day waiting period; 
(3)  State that if no request for a hearing is received before the expiration of the ten-day period, it shall be conclusively presumed that the vehicle is a junked vehicle as defined under state law and city ordinance; and 
(4)  State the date the notice was affixed. 
(b)  Affixing the notice as set out in this section shall not be a condition of requirement precedent to any proceeding or official action to abate such public nuisance, and such proceeding or action shall not be rendered void or voidable, nor in any way affected by failure to affix the visible notice prescribed in this section. 
(c)  If the ten-day period set out on the visible notice is different from the period of time prescribed in any other notice served as provided for in this division, then official action or proceedings to abate such public nuisance shall not be commenced until after the expiration of both periods of time. 
(Code 1995, § 95.33) 
Sec. 34-207. - Right to hearing. 
(a)  The owner or occupant of any premises on which a junked vehicle is located may, within ten days after service of a notice to abate the nuisance, request the municipal court clerk of the city, either in person or in writing, and without the requirement of a bond, that a date and a time be set when he may appear before the judge of the municipal court for a hearing to determine whether or not the motor vehicle is a junked motor vehicle. 
(b)  The judge of the municipal court shall hear any case brought before the court, as set out in this section, and shall determine, by a preponderance of the evidence, whether or not the motor vehicle is a junked motor vehicle and in violation of this division. Such hearing shall not be criminal in nature, and shall be as summary as due process and orderly procedure allows. Upon finding that such motor vehicle is in violation of this division, the judge of the municipal court shall order such defendant to remove and abate such nuisance within ten days, which period of time is reasonable. If the defendant shall fail and refuse to abate or remove the nuisance within ten days, the judge of the municipal court may issue an order directing a code enforcement officer or the chief of police to have the nuisance removed, and a code enforcement officer or the chief of police shall take possession of such junked vehicle. The order shall include the vehicle's description, the current vehicle identification number and license plate number of the vehicle, if available at the time. 
(c)  Notice of any hearing set under this section shall be delivered to a code enforcement officer or the chief of police. 
(Code 1995, § 95.34) 
State Law reference- Hearing, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.076. 
Sec. 34-208. - Authority to abate when vehicle owner cannot be found. 
    If there is a junked motor vehicle, as defined in section 34-201, on a premises that is occupied or unoccupied, and: 
(1)  Neither the owner nor the occupant of the premises can be found and notified to remove the junked vehicle; or 
(2)  The notice required by section 34-207(c) is returned undelivered by the U.S. Post Office and ten days after the return of such notice the nuisance has not been abated; 
then, upon a showing of such facts to the judge of the municipal court, the court may issue an order directing a code enforcement officer or the chief of police to have the junked vehicle removed and a code enforcement officer or the chief of police shall take possession of such junked vehicle and remove it from the premises. 
(Code 1995, § 95.35) 
Sec. 34-209. - Abatement upon noncompliance by owner with notice to abate. 
    If a person served with an order, pursuant to the provisions of this division, does not request a public hearing and either fails or refuses to comply with the order of the municipal court within the ten-day period after service thereof, as provided in this division, a code enforcement officer or the chief of police shall take possession of the junked motor vehicle and remove it from the premises. 
(Code 1995, § 95.36) 
Sec. 34-210. - Notice of impoundment to state. 
    Notice shall be given to the state department of public safety that a junked vehicle has been impounded within five days after the removal of the junked motor vehicle, as provided in this division, identifying the vehicle, or part thereof, impounded. 
(Code 1995, § 95.37) 
State Law reference- Notice to state, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.074(b)(3). 
Sec. 34-211. - Disposition of impounded vehicles. 
    The chief of police or a code enforcement officer shall dispose of all impounded junked vehicles in a manner as the city manager may designate, consistent with state law, provided such vehicle shall not be reconstructed or made operable. Disposal may be by removal or sale, with or without competitive bidding, to a scrapyard or demolisher. 
(Code 1995, § 95.38) 
State Law reference- Junked vehicle disposal, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.078. 
Sec. 34-212. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Antique vehicle means a passenger car or truck that is at least 25 years of age. 
    Motor vehicle collector means a person who: 
(1)  Owns one or more antique or special interest vehicles; and 
(2)  Acquires, collects or disposes of an antique or special interest vehicle, or part thereof, for personal use to restore and preserve such vehicle for historic interest. 
    Special interest vehicle means a motor vehicle of any age that has not been changed from the original manufacturer's specifications and, because of its historic interest, is being preserved by a hobbyist. 
(b)  Nonapplicability. The provisions of this division shall not apply to: 
(1)  A vehicle, or part thereof, which is completely enclosed within a building, in a lawful manner, where it is not visible from the street or other public or private property; 
(2)  A vehicle, or part thereof, which is stored or parked, in a lawful manner, on private property in connection with the business of a licensed vehicle dealer or a junkyard; or 
(3)  Unlicensed, operable or inoperable antique and special interest vehicles stored by a collector on his property, provided that the vehicles and the outdoor storage areas are maintained in such a manner that they do not constitute a health hazard and are screened from ordinary public view by means of a fence, rapidly growing trees, shrubbery or other appropriate means. 
(Code 1995, § 95.39) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.077. 
Sec. 34-213. - Filing of complaint. 
    A complaint shall be filed in the municipal court if a person maintains a public nuisance, as defined under the provisions of this division, and the nuisance is not removed and abated, and a hearing is not requested within the ten-day period provided in this division. If a person is found guilty of maintaining a public nuisance, the person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and the court shall order removal and abatement of the nuisance. 
(Code 1995, § 95.40) 
State Law reference- Misdemeanor authorized, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.073. 
Secs. 34-214-34-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NOISE[8] 

Footnotes: 

Sec. 34-241. - Findings, purpose and intent. 
    The city finds and declares that: 
(1)  Inadequately controlled noise presents a growing danger to the health and welfare of the residents of the city; 
(2)  The making and creating of disturbing, excessive, or offensive noises within the jurisdictional limits of the city is a condition which has persisted, and the level and frequency of occurrences of such noises continue to rise; 
(3)  The making, creation, or continuance of such excessive noises, which are prolonged or unusual in their time, place, and use, affect and are a detriment to the public health, comfort, convenience, safety, welfare, and prosperity of the residents of the city; 
(4)  Every person is entitled to an environment in which the noise is not detrimental to his life, health, or enjoyment of property; and 
(5)  The necessity, in the public interest, for the provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained and enacted is declared to be a matter of legislative determination and public policy, and it is further declared that the provisions and prohibitions hereinafter contained and enacted are in pursuance of and for the purpose of securing and promoting the public health, comfort, convenience, safety, welfare, prosperity, peace, and quiet of the city and its inhabitants. 
(Code 1995, § 96.01) 
Sec. 34-242. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, and definitions of technical terms not defined as follows shall be obtained from the American National Standard Acoustical Terminology, SI 1-1960 (ANSI S1.1-1960) (R-1976): 
    Average sound level means a sound level typical of the sound levels at a certain place during a given period of time, averaged by the general rule of combination for sound levels, as set forth in American National Standard Specifications for Sound Level Meters, SI 4-1971 (ANSI S1.4-1971). The term "average sound level" is also called "equivalent continuous sound level." 
    Community noise equivalent level means an average sound level during a 24-hour day, obtained after addition of five decibels to sound levels in the evening from 7:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m., and after addition of ten decibels to sound levels in the night before 7:00 a.m. and after 10:00 p.m. 
    Construction equipment means any tools, machinery, or equipment used in connection wih construction operations, including all types of "special construction" equipment, as defined in pertinent sections of the state transportation code, when used in the construction process of any construction site, regardless of whether such construction site is located on-highway or off-highway. 
    Decibel means a unit measure of sound (noise) level. 
    Disturbing, excessive, or offensive noise means any sound or noise conflicting with the criteria or levels set forth in this chapter. 
    Emergency work means work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, work required to protect persons or property from imminent exposure to danger of damage, or work by public or private utilities when restoring utility service. 
    Motor vehicles means any and all self-propelled vehicles, as defined in the state transportation code, specifically including, but not limited to, minibikes and go-carts. 
    Noise level or sound level means, in decibels, the quantity measured with a sound level meter, as defined herein, by use of the "A" frequency weighting and "fast" time averaging unless some other time averaging is specified. 
    Sound amplifying equipment means any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice, music, or any other sound. The term "sound amplifying equipment" shall not be construed as including standard automobile radios, when used and heard only by occupants of the vehicle, warning devices on authorized emergency vehicles, or horns or other warning devices on other vehicles used only for traffic safety purposes. 
    Sound level meter means an instrument for the measurement of sound, including a microphone, an amplifier, an attenuator, networks at least for the standardized frequency weighting "A," and an indicated instrument having at least the standardized dynamic characteristic "fast," as specified in American National Standard Specifications for Sound Level Meters, SI 4-1971 (ANSI S1.4-1971), or its successor. 
    Sound truck means any motor vehicle or other vehicle, regardless of motive power, whether in motion or stationary, having mounted thereon or attached thereto any sound amplifying equipment. 
(Code 1995, § 96.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-243. - Regulations for use of sound trucks. 
    Noncommercial use of sound trucks in the city with sound amplifying equipment in operation shall be subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The only sounds permitted are music and human speech. 
(2)  Operations are permitted between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. at and during public events and affairs of interest to the general public. 
(3)  Sound amplifying equipment shall not be operated unless the sound truck upon which such equipment is mounted is operated at a speed of at least ten miles per hour, provided that whenever said truck is stopped or impeded by traffic, where stopped by traffic, such sound amplifying equipment shall not be operated for longer than one minute at each stop. 
(4)  Sound shall not be issued within 100 yards of hospitals, schools, nursing homes, churches, or courthouses. 
(5)  No sound truck with its amplifying device in operation shall be operated within the central business district of the city. 
(6)  The human speech and music amplified shall not be obscene, lewd, indecent, or slanderous. 
(7)  The volume of sound shall be controlled so that said volume is not unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing, or a nuisance to persons within the area of audibility and so that the volume of sound shall not exceed an "A" weighted sound level of 65 decibels on the "slow" scale at a distance of 50 feet from the sound amplifying equipment, as measured by a sound level meter which meets American National Standard ANSI S1.4-1983, or its successor. 
(8)  No sound amplifying equipment shall be operated unless the axis of the center of any sound reproducing equipment used shall be parallel to the direction of travel of the sound truck; provided, however, that any sound reproducing equipment may be so placed upon said sound truck as to not vary more than 15 degrees either side of the axis of the center of the direction of travel. 
(9)  No sound truck with its amplifying device in operation shall be driven on the same street past the same point more than twice in a period of one hour. 
(10)  It shall be unlawful to operate a noncommercial sound truck in violation of these regulations. 
(Code 1995, § 96.03) 
Sec. 34-244. - General prohibitions. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person operating or controlling a motor vehicle in either a public or private place within the city to operate any sound amplifier which is part of or connected to any radio, stereo receiver, compact disc player, cassette tape player, or other similar device in the motor vehicle in such a manner that, when operation, it is audible at a distance of 30 feet, or such that, when operated, causes a person to be aware of the vibration accompanying the sound at a distance of 30 feet from the source. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued within the limits of the city any disturbing, excessive, or offensive noise which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of normal sensitivities residing in the area. 
(c)  The characteristics and conditions which should be considered in determining whether a violation of the provisions of this section exists should include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The level of the noise; 
(2)  Whether the nature of the noise is usual or unusual; 
(3)  Whether the origin of the noise is natural or unnatural; 
(4)  The level of the ambient noise; 
(5)  The proximity of the noise to sleeping facilities; 
(6)  The nature and zoning of the area from which the noise emanates and the area where it is received; 
(7)  The time of day or night the noise occurs; 
(8)  The duration of the noise; and 
(9)  Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent, or constant. 
(Code 1995, § 96.04) 
Sec. 34-245. - Disturbing, excessive, or offensive noises. 
    The following activities, among others, are declared to cause disturbing, excessive, or offensive noises in violation of this section and are unlawful: 
(1)  Horns, signaling devices, etc. Unnecessary use or operation of horns, signaling devices, or other similar devices on automobiles, motorcycles, or any other vehicle. 
(2)  Radios, television sets, phonographs, loudspeaker amplifiers, and similar devices. 
a.  Uses restricted. The use or operation of any sound production or reproduction device, radio receiving set, musical instrument, drums, phonograph, television set, loudspeaker and amplifier, or other similar machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, or comfort of any reasonable person of normal sensitivity in any are of the city is prohibited. This shall not apply to any participant in a licensed parade or to any person who has been otherwise duly authorized by the city to engage in such conduct. 
b.  Prima facie violations. Any of the following shall constitute evidence of a prima facie violation of this section: 
1.  The operation of any such sound production or reproduction device, radio receiving set, musical instrument, drum, phonograph, television set, machine, loudspeaker and sound amplifier, or similar machine or device between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 30 feet from the building, structure, or vehicle in which it is located. 
2.  The operation of any sound amplifier which is a part of or connected to any radio, stereo receiver, compact disc player, cassette tape player, or other similar device, when operated in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of 30 feet and when operated in such a manner as to cause a person to be aware of vibration accompanying the sound at a distance of 30 feet from the source. 
c.  Enforcement of prima facie violations. 
1.  Any peace officer who encounters evidence of a prima facie violation of this section is empowered to confiscate and impound as evidence any or all of the components amplifying or transmitting the sound. 
2.  Any peace officer who encounters evidence of a prima facie violation of this section, when the components amplifying or transmitting the sound are attached to a vehicle, may impound the vehicle as containing evidence of a criminal offense, when the amplifying and/or transmitting components cannot be readily removed from the vehicle without damaging the components or vehicle. 
(3)  Animals. 
a.  The keeping, maintenance, or permitting to be kept or maintained, upon any premises owned, occupied, or controlled by any person, of any animal which, by any frequent or long-continued noise, shall cause annoyance or discomfort to a reasonable person of normal sensitiveness in the vicinity. 
b.  The noise from any such animal that disturbs two or more residents residing in separate residences adjacent to any part of the property on which the subject animal is kept or maintained, or three or more residents residing in 
Sec. 34-246. - Burglar alarms. 
Sec. 34-247. - Violations; additional remedies; injunctions.
