Chapter 38 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 2-301 et seq.; civil emergencies, ch. 22; emergency services, ch. 30; fire prevention for oil and gas; identification signs, § 46-131; use of fire hydrants, § 70-282; buildings and building regulations, ch. 78; fire suppression systems, § 78-291; fire hydrants, § 78-292; storage of inflammable and explosive materials; open burning prohibited; fire zone, § 94-256. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Arson reward. 
    The city hereby offers a standing or continuous reward of $250.00 for the arrest and conviction of any person who shall, at any time, commit or attempt to commit the offense of arson within the city limits. 
(Code 1995, § 93.02) 
State Law reference- Arson, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.02. 
Sec. 38-2. - False fire alarm. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely give an alarm of fire. 
(Code 1995, § 93.04) 
State Law reference- False alarm or report, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.06. 
Sec. 38-3. - Burning of trash and the like. 
(a)  Within fire limits. It shall be unlawful for any person to burn or attempt to burn paper, combustible material, or trash of any kind, character, or description within the fire limits of this city in any manner or by any means whatsoever, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Outside fire limits. It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of any building, premises, vacant lot, or enclosure in the city and outside of the fire limits to burn or attempt to burn leaves, papers, or trash of any kind, character, or description at the building, premises, vacant lot, or enclosure in any manner other than in an iron, brick, stone, or metal receptacle, or incinerator. If, in the opinion of the fire marshal, dangerous conditions exist, he may order the discontinuance of burning provisions until such dangerous conditions have been eliminated. 
(Code 1995, § 93.05; Ord. No. 97-20, 5-14-1997) 
Secs. 38-4-38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY OF BROWNWOOD FIRE CODE 

Sec. 38-31. - International Fire Code adopted. 
    A certain document, one copy of which is on file in the office of the City of Brownwood Code Administrator, being marked and designated as the International Fire Code, 2009 edition, including all chapters and appendices except appendix A as published by the International Code Council be and is hereby adopted as the Fire Code of the City of Brownwood, for regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, material and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said International Fire Code on file in the office of the code administrator are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the following additions, insertions, if any prescribed in section 38-32. 
(Code 1995, § 93.01(A); Ord. No. 05-10, § 1(E), 3-22-2005; Ord. No. 07-19, § 1.E., 7-24-2007; Ord. No. 11-30, § 1.I., 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 38-32. - Local amendments to the International Fire Code. 
    The following sections of the International Fire Code adopted by reference in section 38-31 are hereby revised: 
(1)  Section 101.1. Insert: "City of Brownwood." 
(2)  Section 109.3. Insert: "misdemeanor"; "$500.00"; "N/A" 
(3)  Section 111.2. Insert: "$50.00"; "$500.00" 
(4)  The following shall hereby be adopted as an amendment and supplement to appendix D, "Fire Apparatus Access Roads," of the International Fire Code: 
a.  The marking of fire lanes on private property, devoted to public use, shall be designated by the fire marshal and chief of police with a list of designated fire lanes on file in the office of the city secretary. 
b.  No fire lane shall be designated unless it is constructed of concrete, asphalt or other hard surface material. 
c.  Fire lanes must be marked with conspicuous signs which state "FIRE LANE - NO PARKING" in four-inch letters painted at 20-foot intervals on a contrasting background stripe, continuous or broken, along the perimeter of the entire fire lane. 
d.  The expense and responsibility of marking fire lanes shall be borne by the property owner. 
e.  No person may mark a private drive in a way which gives it the appearance of being a fire lane unless the fire marshal has, in writing, designated that drive a fire lane as described in this section. 
f.  Fire lanes may not be closed or abandoned without written permission of the fire marshall. 
g.  A person may not park, place, allow, permit, or suffer to be parked or placed or to remain unattended an unauthorized vehicle or similar obstruction in a fire lane. 
h.  If an unauthorized vehicle or similar obstruction is found parked or unoccupied in a fire lane, it is hereby declared a public nuisance, and the fact that it is parked, unattended, or unoccupied in a way which obstructs a fire lane is proof that the registered owner violated this subsection. 
i.  The records of the Texas Department of Transportation, Motor Vehicle Division, showing the name of the person to whom a vehicle license is issued is sufficient proof of ownership for the purpose of this Code. 
j.  If any obstruction is found in a fire lane, the fire marshal or any other police officer may issue a citation for the violation, and he may have the obstruction removed or towed to any suitable site. The property may be redeemed by payment of the towage and storage charges in the same manner as any vehicle impounded. 
k.  A citation may not be voided by the redemption of the property from the suitable site, nor may the violator be relieved of any penalty assessed by a judge of the municipal court for a violation of any provision of this subsection. 
To the extent that the terms of this amendment may conflict with the terms of the International Fire Code, the amendments shall supersede and control over the terms of the International Fire Code. 
(Code 1995, § 93.01(D); Ord. No. 05-10, § 2(E), 3-22-2005; Ord. No. 06-07, § 2, 2-28-2006; Ord. No. 07-19, § 2.E., 7-24-2007; Ord. No. 11-30, § 1.I., 12-13-2011) 
Secs. 38-33-38-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE MARSHAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-331 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 417.009. 

Sec. 38-61. - Office created. 
    The office of city fire marshal is hereby created. The fire marshal shall report directly to the city manager. Such office shall be filled by the appointment of the city manager, with the approval of the city council. The fire marshal shall be properly qualified for the duties of such office. The fire marshal's salary shall be set by the city manager. 
(Code 1995, § 93.20) 
Sec. 38-62. - Investigation of fires; records. 
(a)  The fire marshal shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring within the city by which property has been destroyed or damaged, and shall especially make investigation as to whether such fire was the caused intentionally, carelessly or accidentally. Such investigation shall begin within 24 hours of the occurrence of such fire, not including Sunday. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall keep in his office a record of all fires, together with all facts, statistics and circumstances, including the origin of the fires and the amount of the losses, which may be determined by the investigation required by this section. 
(Code 1995, § 93.21) 
State Law reference- Investigation of fires, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 417.007. 
Sec. 38-63. - Testimony; power of arrest; furnishing information to prosecuting attorney. 
    Where further investigation is necessary in the opinion of the fire marshal, he shall take, or cause to be taken, the testimony, on oath, of all persons supposed to be cognizant of any facts or to have means of knowledge in relation to the matter under investigation, and shall cause the testimony to be reduced to writing. If the fire marshal shall be of the opinion that there is evidence sufficient to charge any person with the crime of arson, the attempt to commit the crime of arson, conspiracy to defraud, another offense related to the matter under investigation or criminal conduct in connection with such fire, such officer shall cause such person to be lawfully arrested and charged with such offense, and shall furnish to the proper prosecuting attorney all such evidence, together with the names of witnesses and all of the information obtained by such officer, including a copy of all pertinent and material testimony taken in the case. 
(Code 1995, § 93.22) 
State Law reference- Powers of the fire marshal, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 417.007. 
Sec. 38-64. - Summoning witnesses; administering oaths. 
(a)  The fire marshal shall have the power to summon witnesses before him to testify in relation to any matter which is, by the provisions of this article, a subject of inquiry and investigation, and may require the production of any book, paper or document deemed pertinent to such inquiry and investigation. 
(b)  The fire marshal is hereby authorized and empowered to administer oaths and affirmations to any person appearing before him as a witness. 
(Code 1995, § 93.53) 
State Law reference- Powers of the fire marshal, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 417.007. 
Sec. 38-65. - Failure of witness to appear, testify, etc. 
    Any witness who refuses to be sworn, to appear or testify, or who disobeys any lawful order of the fire marshal, or who fails or refuses to produce any book, paper or document touching any matter under examination, or who is guilty of any contemptuous conduct during any of the proceedings of the fire marshal in the matter of an investigation or inquiry, after being summoned to give testimony in relation to any matter under investigation, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and it shall be the duty of the fire marshal to cause all such offenders to be prosecuted. 
(Code 1995, § 93.54) 
Sec. 38-66. - Privacy of investigations; separation of witnesses. 
    All investigations held by or under the direction of the fire marshal may, in the fire marshal's discretion, be private, and persons other than the persons required to be present may be excluded from the place where such investigation is held, and witnesses may be kept separate and apart from each other and not allowed to communicate with each other until they have been examined. 
(Code 1995, § 93.55) 
Sec. 38-67. - Right of entry. 
    The fire marshal shall have the authority, at any time, to enter a building or premises at which a fire is in progress or has occurred and is under the control of law enforcement or fire service officials to investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of the fire. If control of the building or premises has been relinquished, such entry must be in compliance with search and seizure law and applicable federal law. 
(Code 1995, § 93.56) 
State Law reference- Right of entry, V.T.C.A., Government Code §§ 417.007, 417.008. 
Sec. 38-68. - Removal of violating conditions; appeals; reports to state fire marshal. 
(a)  Upon the complaint of any person having an interest in any building or adjacent property, and without any complaint, the fire marshal shall have a right, at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of examination, to enter into and upon all buildings and premises within the city. The fire marshal shall enter and is entitled, at any time, to enter any mercantile, manufacturing or public building, place of amusement or place where public gatherings are held, or any premises belonging to such building or place, and make a thorough examination. It shall be the fire marshal's duty, monthly or more often, to enter upon and make, or cause to be entered and made, a thorough examination of all mercantile, manufacturing and public buildings, places of amusement or places where public gatherings are held, together with the premises belonging to such buildings and places. Whenever the fire marshal shall find any building or other structure which, for want of repair, by reason of age or dilapidated condition or for any cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is situated so as to endanger other buildings or property, or so occupied that fire would endanger persons or property in such building or other structure, and whenever the fire marshal shall find an improper or dangerous arrangement of stoves, ranges, furnaces or other heating appliances of any kind, including chimneys, flues and pipes with which such appliances may be connected, or a dangerous arrangement of lighting devices or systems, or a dangerous or unlawful storage of explosives, compounds, petroleum, gasoline, kerosene, dangerous chemicals, vegetable products, ashes, combustibles, flammable refuse and materials, or other conditions which may be dangerous in character or liable to cause or promote fire or create conditions dangerous to the firefighters or occupants, the fire marshal shall order such dangerous conditions to be removed or remedied, and such order shall be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant of the building or premises. However, if the owner or occupant deems himself aggrieved by such order, he may appeal to the building and standards commission within five days, and the building and standards commission shall investigate the cause of the complaint and unless, by the authority of the building and standards commission, the order is revoked, such order shall remain in force and be forthwith complied with by such owner or occupant. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall report all existing hazardous conditions to the state fire marshal, as may be required, together with a separate report on each fire in the city during the month. 
(Code 1995, § 93.57) 
State Law reference- Examination and correction of dangerous conditions, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 417.008. 
Secs. 38-69-38-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIREWORKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of fireworks and fireworks displays, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2154.001 et seq. 

Sec. 38-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fireworks means any article, device, substance or combination of substances designed for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, regardless of its name or form of construction. Such term shall include, but not be limited to, the items known as firecrackers, cherry bombs, Roman candles, torpedoes, skyrockets and any other substance or thing of whatever form of construction that contains any explosive or flammable compound or substance which explodes, rises into the air, travels laterally or fires projectiles into the air, and which are commonly known as fireworks. For the purposes of this article, the term "fireworks" shall not include sparklers, Pharaoh's serpents, toy pistols, toy guns or other devices that use paper or plastic caps, model rockets and model rocket motors which are designed, sold and used for the purpose of propelling recoverable aero models and novelties and trick noisemakers; however, the discharge of any item expressly excluded from the applicability of this article shall not be subject to noise abatement and control regulations chapter of this Code. 
(Code 1995, § 93.03; Ord. No. 00-28, pt. 1(A), 9-12-2000) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 38-102. - Sales. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale or exhibit for sale any fireworks of any character within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 93.03; Ord. No. 00-28, pt. 1(B), 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 38-103. - Discharge. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge, or cause to be discharged, any fireworks within the corporate limits of the city; however, a professional fireworks exhibition performed by a licensed and insured pyrotechnic operator who has obtained a public display permit from the state fire marshal may be permissible, if the display and display site are approved by the city fire marshal. 
(Code 1995, § 93.03; Ord. No. 00-28, pt. 1(C), 9-12-2000) 
Secs. 38-104-38-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS AND FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Flammable liquids, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 753.001 et seq. 

Sec. 38-131. - Storage of combustible materials; burn permits. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to accumulate, store or stack on any premises within the corporate limits of the city more than 500 square bales or 20 round bales of hay to the stack, and if more than one stack is created, each stack shall be located not less than 50 feet from any other stack. It shall also be unlawful to accumulate, store or stack, or permit to be accumulated, stored or stacked, on any premises within the corporate limits of the city more than 100 cubic yards of grass, loose cotton, cotton burrs, paper, shavings or any other bulky combustible matter or material. 
(b)  Combustible materials in excess of the limits established in subsection (a) of this section shall be stored in a fireproof building, the roof of which shall be constructed of noncombustible material. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to burn or destroy the combustible matter mentioned in subsection (a) of this section within the corporate limits of the city, except in an incinerator, the specifications of which shall meet the approval of the city council. If the city council shall approve the specifications of the incinerator, it will then cause the proper permit to be issued. 
(Code 1995, § 93.06) 
Sec. 38-132. - Self-service gasoline stations. 
    Self-service gasoline stations shall comply with all rules and regulations of the state commission on fire protection issued pursuant to V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 753.001 et seq., and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1995, § 93.07) 
Sec. 38-133. - Mobile service units. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile service unit means a vehicle, tank truck or other mobile device from which flammable liquids used as motor fuels may, as an act of retail sale, be dispensed in the fuel tank of a motor vehicle parked on an off-street parking facility or public property; that is, a mobile gasoline filling station which either parks or roams around on the parking lot of a shopping center, or public property, and from which the driver or operator makes sales of gasoline to shoppers whose vehicles are parked. 
(b)  Operation prohibited. From and after the date of final passage and publication of this section (8-3-1971), it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a mobile service unit within the city. 
(Code 1995, § 93.08) 
State Law reference- Mobile service units, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 753.002. 
Chapter 42 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 66. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Discharging firearms. 
(a)  The term "firearms," for the purposes of this section, shall be defined as provided in the state penal law. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to discharge any firearm of any description within the city. 
(c)  A person may discharge a shotgun loaded with birdshot only (no larger than four-shot loads) under the following circumstances: 
(1)  On a tract of land comprised of 50 contiguous acres or larger, located in an A-1 agricultural district; 
(2)  Provided that the person shall not discharge the shotgun within 300 feet of a residence located on an adjacent tract of land; and 
(3)  Provided that the person shall not discharge the shotgun so that its shot travels on, over, or across an adjacent tract of land. 
(Code 1995, § 130.02; Ord. No. 02-55, §§ I, II, 11-12-2000) 
Sec. 42-2. - Variance permitting discharge of firearms within city limits. 
    From and after the date of final passage of Ordinance No. 97-49 (12-9-1997), the county 4-H youth members shall be allowed to use the county youth barns as an area to practice shooting skills under a controlled and supervised atmosphere, and such variance shall be a legally existing variance permitting discharge of firearms in the city. 
(Code 1995, § 131.002(B)) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit discharge of firearms within city limits, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.001. 
Sec. 42-3. - Defacing and destroying property of another. 
    It shall be unlawful to deface or destroy the property of another. 
(Code 1995, § 130.03) 
State Law reference- Criminal mischief, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.03; damaging or destroying property of another, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.04; graffiti, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.08. 
Sec. 42-4. - Regulation of smoking in city facilities. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City facilities means any enclosed or indoor facility owned, operated or managed by the city and shall expressly exclude any open air nonenclosed facility such as pavilions at city parks. 
Notice means the posting of a sign at the entrance way of city facilities or other conspicuous locations therein so as to be readily observable by a reasonably observant person. 
Smoke or smoking means the possession of burning tobacco, weeds, or other plant product. 
(b)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in city facilities. 
(c)  Defenses. It is a defense to prosecution hereunder that the city facility in which the offense takes place does not have prominently displayed therein a reasonably sized notice that smoking is prohibited in the facility and that an offense is punishable by fine not to exceed the maximum established by this section. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person who shall do any act or thing prohibited by the terms of this section or in any way violate the provisions thereof shall be fined not less than $25.00 or more than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 03-29, §§ I-IV, 8-7-2003) 
Secs. 42-5-42-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ILLEGAL SMOKING MATERIALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-29, § 2, adopted Nov. 9, 2010, set out provisions intended for use as ch. 43, §§ 43-1-43-7. For purposes of classification and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as ch. 42, art. II, §§ 42-41-42-47. 

Sec. 42-41. - Definitions. 
    Illegal smoking material shall mean any substance, however marketed, which can reasonably be converted for smoking purposes whether it is presented as incense, tobacco, herbs, spices or any blend thereof if it includes any of the following chemicals or a comparable chemical: 
(1)  Salvia divinorum or salvinorin A; all parts of the plant presently classified botanically as salvia divinorum, whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, any extract from any part of such plant, and every compound, manufacture, salts, derivative, mixture or preparation of such plant, its seeds or extracts; 
(2)  2-[(1R, 3S)-3-hydroxycyclohexyl]-5-(2-methyloctan-2-yl) phenol (also known as CP47, 497) and homologues; 
(3)  (6aS, 10aS)-9-(hydroxymethyl)-6, 6-dimethyl-3-(2-methyloctan-2-yl)-6a, 7, 10, 10a-tetra-hydrobenzo [c]chromen-1-ol (also known as HU-211 or Dexanabinol); 
(4)  1-pentyl-3-(1-naphthoyl) indole (also known as JWH-018); 
(5)  1-butyl-3-(1-naphthoyl) indole (also known as JWH-073); or 
(6)  1-pentyl-3-(4-methoxynaphthoyl) indole (also known as JWH-081). 
Products containing some or all of the above substances are currently being marketed under the following commercial names: "K-2", "K-2 Summit", "K-2 Sex", "Genie", "Dascents", "Zohai", "Sage", "Spice", "Ko Knock-Out 2", "Spice Gold", "Spice Diamond", "Yucatan Fire", "Solar Flare", "Pep Spice", "Fire N' Ice", "Blaze" "Red X Dawn" and "Salvia Divinorum". 
Any product containing any of the chemical compounds set forth above shall be subject to the provisions of this article, regardless of whether they are marketed under alternative names. 
    Illegal smoking material paraphernalia shall mean any paraphernalia, equipment or utensil that is used or intended to be used in ingesting or inhaling illegal smoking materials and may include, but is not limited to: 
(1)  A metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipe with or without a screen, permanent screen, hashish head, or punctured metal bowl; 
(2)  A water pipe; 
(3)  A carburetion tube or device; 
(4)  A smoking or carburetion mask; 
(5)  A chamber pipe; 
(6)  A carburetor pipe; 
(7)  An electric pipe; 
(8)  An air-driven pipe; 
(9)  A chillum; 
(10)  A bong; or 
(11)  An ice pipe or chiller. 
    Person shall mean an individual, a group of two or more individuals, proprietorship, corporation, partnership, wholesaler, association or other legal entity, or any licensed or unlicensed business. 
(Ord. No. 10-29, § 2, 11-9-2010) 
Sec. 42-42. - Illegal smoking materials and illegal smoking material paraphernalia: Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to prohibit the purchase, sale, offer for sale, delivery, or gift of illegal smoking materials as defined herein within the city limits of the City of Brownwood, and to prohibit the possession or use of illegal smoking materials and illegal smoking material paraphernalia within the city limits of the City of Brownwood. Any form of delivery, including, without limitation, a simple gift constitutes a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-29, § 2, 11-9-2010) 
Sec. 42-43. - Purchase, sale, delivery, offer or gift. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase, sell, offer for sale, deliver or to give any illegal smoking material to any person. 
(Ord. No. 10-29, § 2, 11-9-2010) 
Sec. 42-44. - Possession or use of illegal smoking materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in their possession or to use, inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body illegal smoking materials within the corporate limits of the City of Brownwood. 
(Ord. No. 10-29, § 2, 11-9-2010) 
Sec. 42-45. - Possession or use of illegal smoking material paraphernalia. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in their possession any illegal smoking material paraphernalia with the intent to use it, to ingest, inhale or otherwise consume or introduce into the human body illegal smoking material. It is a violation of this article, if a person is found in possession of illegal smoking material paraphernalia and appropriate forensic testing is done on the paraphernalia showing traces of illegal smoking material present on the paraphernalia. 
(Ord. No. 10-29, § 2, 11-9-2010) 
Sec. 42-46. - Affirmative defenses to prosecution. 
(a)  It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution for a violation of this article if the use of the illegal smoking material is at the direction or under a prescription issued by a licensed physician or dentist authorized to prescribe controlled substances within the State of Texas. 
(b)  It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under the terms of this article if an individual charged with a violation can provide proper and complete historic documentation that the use of such materials is a portion of a religious undertaking or activity of a religious denomination in which they have long-standing historic membership supported by documentation from clergy or spiritual leader recognized by the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 10-29, § 2, 11-9-2010) 
Sec. 42-47. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(b)  Every act in violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Unless otherwise specifically set forth herein, an allegation and/or evidence of culpable mental state is not required for the proof of an offense of this article. 
(d)  The penal provisions imposed under this article shall not preclude the City of Brownwood from filing suit to enjoin the violation of this article. The city retains all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant to local, state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 10-29, § 2, 11-9-2010) 
Secs. 42-48-42-70. - Reserved. 
Chapter 46 - NATURAL RESOURCES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 46-1-46-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OIL AND GAS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Oil and gas, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 52.001 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-31. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the "Oil and Gas Ordinance of the City of Brownwood, Texas," and may be cited as such. 
(Code 1995, § 114.01) 
Sec. 46-32. - Rules of interpretation; definitions. 
(a)  Technical words. All technical or oil and gas industry words or phrases used in this article and not specifically defined shall have the meaning customarily attributable to such words or phrases by prudent operators in the oil and gas industry. 
(b)  Titles of officials. When the title of any city official is used in this article, it shall include any duly authorized representative. 
(c)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Curbline means the line established by the city for a particular street. 
    Gathering lines means all pipelines operated as an incident to the development and operation of oil and/or gas fields and secondary recovery projects. 
    Lease means any tract of land subject to an oil, gas and mineral lease or other oil and gas development contract, or any unit composed of several tracts and leases, but operated as one lease, and any tract of land in which the minerals are owned by an operator or a person holding under them, but which, due to the free royalty ownership is developed and operated as a separate tract, but such term shall not mean any tract of land conveyed or used for pipeline right-of-way purposes. 
    Permittee means the person to whom a permit is issued for the drilling, completion and operation of a well and/or the construction, installation and operation of any pipeline facility under this article, and his heirs, legal representatives, successors and assigns. 
    Person means an individual, firm, company or corporation. 
    Pipeline means trunkline pipelines, gathering lines and discharge lines, as defined in this subsection, but not when used as part of the terms "gathering lines" and "trunkline pipelines." 
    Right-of-way means all public rights-of-way or streets or other public property within the city. 
    Street means any street, highway, sidewalk, alley, avenue, recessed parking area or other public right-of-way, including the entire right-of-way. 
    Trunkline pipeline means common carrier pipelines and other main pipelines not included in the definition of "gathering lines," expressly including their rights-of-way, as defined and established by instruments of record in the office of the county clerk. 
    Well means any hole or bore to any sand, formation, strata or depth for the purpose of producing any oil, gas or liquid hydrocarbon or used as an injection well for secondary recovery, or any of them. 
(Code 1995, § 114.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 46-33. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Work done in new developments of the city by utility and street contractors, under and in conformity with chapter 94, is exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Work done by the city or under city contract and under directions of the city is exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Work done by public utility companies which operate under a current franchise from the city is exempt from the bond and insurance provisions of this article when such work is done with their own personnel, but such exemption does not apply to contractors doing work for the public utility company. 
(d)  Work done by plumbers who are qualified and bonded with a valid permit from the city inspection department is exempt from the bond and insurance provisions of this article, but must comply with the balance of this article. 
(e)  No permit for construction within a public right-of-way shall be issued unless the written application is accompanied by the necessary plans and descriptions, and submitted to the oil and gas inspector and approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1995, § 114.04) 
Sec. 46-34. - Federal and state laws applicable. 
    Any violation of state law or any rules, regulations or requirements of any state or federal regulatory body having jurisdiction in reference to drilling, completing, equipping, operating, producing, installing, maintaining or abandoning any oil and/or gas well, pipeline or related appurtenance, equipment or facility, or in reference to firewalls, fire protection, blowout protection, safety protection or convenience of persons or property shall also be a violation of this article and shall be punishable in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 114.19) 
Sec. 46-35. - Codes, tests and standards of performance references. 
    All references in this article to ASA or USAS codes, tests or standards of performance are hereby eliminated, and ANSI codes, tests and standards of performance are hereby substituted for all such references. 
(Code 1995, § 114.26) 
Sec. 46-36. - Violations; penalties; fines; forfeitures; revocation of permit; application for reissuance. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of this article, irrespective of whether or not the verbiage of each section of this article contains the specific language that such violation or failure to comply is unlawful and is an offense. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate any provision of this article or any provision of a permit issued pursuant to this article, or who shall fail to comply with the terms of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be fined in any sum as provided for in section 1-14. 
(c)  The violation of each separate provision of this article and such permit shall be considered a separate offense, and each day's violation of each separate provision thereof shall be considered a separate offense. 
(d)  In addition to such penalties, it is further provided that the city council, at any regular or special session or meeting thereof, may, provided ten days' notice has been given to the permittee that revocation is to be considered at such meeting, revoke or suspend any permit issued under this article and under which operations are being conducted, if the permittee has violated any provision of such permit or this article. 
(e)  If the permit is revoked, the permittee may make application to the city council for reissuance of such permit. 
(Code 1995, § 114.99) 
Secs. 46-37-46-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 46-61. - Oil and gas inspector. 
(a)  Appointment; duties. The director of public works shall be the oil and gas inspector, and it shall be his duty to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Appeal of enforcement decision. Any person who may be aggrieved by any ruling, order and/or decision of the oil and gas inspector shall have the right of appeal to the city council from such ruling, order or decision; provided, however, that any such appeal must be taken, if at all, within ten days immediately following the filing of such rule, order or decision in the records of the office of the oil and gas inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 114.03) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-331 et seq. 
Sec. 46-62. - Equipment inspections. 
    All equipment necessarily incidental to the production of oil or gas within the city limits shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the appropriate qualified oil and gas inspector, building inspector, electrical inspector, fire and safety inspector, etc. 
(Code 1995, § 114.22) 
Sec. 46-63. - Annual inspections of wells required; inspection fees. 
    Each producing well, pumping unit, water flood pump and injection well, together with their associated equipment (tankage, separators, structures, fencing, landscaping, etc.), regulated by this article, shall be inspected annually by the oil and gas inspector for the purpose of conformance to the various regulations. If any nonconformance is found, the permittee will be immediately notified of the violation, in writing, and the permittee shall begin to institute proceedings to come into full compliance with this article. The annual inspection fee for each site upon which a facility covered by this article is located shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, and such fee shall be paid by the permittee. 
(Code 1995, § 114.20) 
Sec. 46-64. - Loss of well control; duty of operator; authority of oil and gas inspector; lien for city expenditures. 
    In the event of loss of control of any well, the operator shall immediately take all reasonable steps to regain control of such well, regardless of any other provision of this article, and shall notify the oil and gas inspector, as soon as practicable, after receipt of notice by his employees of the occurrence of such loss of well control endangering persons or property. If and when the oil and gas inspector certifies, in writing, to the city secretary that, in his opinion, danger to persons or property exists because of such loss of well control (briefly describing the danger) and the operator is not taking, or is unable to take, all reasonable necessary steps to regain control of such well, the oil and gas inspector may employ any well control expert or other contractor or supplier of special services, or may incur any other expenses for labor or material which the oil and gas inspector deems necessary to regain control of such well. The city shall have a valid lien against the interest in the well of all working interest owners who have voluntarily joined in the drilling of such well, to secure payment of any expenditure made by the city pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1995, § 114.23) 
Sec. 46-65. - Geophysical work employing underground explosives, thumper, vibroseis and other techniques. 
(a)  No geophysical work employing underground explosives will be permitted any place within the city limits at any time. Other geophysical systems employing the thumper, vibroseis or other techniques not employing explosives will be permitted upon proper application and payment of an application fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(b)  Such application shall include the following: 
(1)  The date of the application. 
(2)  The name of the applicant. 
(3)  The address of the applicant. 
(4)  A statement of the proposed commencement and completion dates. 
(5)  A map or plat outlining the areas proposed to be covered by the survey. 
(6)  Compliance with section 46-94 concerning an indemnification bond and public liability insurance coverage. 
(Code 1995, § 114.25) 
Secs. 46-66-46-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 46-91. - Required; issuance; authority to drill and install. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person, acting either for himself or as agent, employee, independent contractor or servant for any other person, to drill any well or install any trunkline pipeline, or water and/or gas repressurizing or injection facility within the city limits without a permit having first been issued by the authority of the city council in accordance with the terms of this division. 
(b)  When a permit has been issued for the drilling of a well, the permit shall constitute sufficient authority for drilling, operation, production, gathering of production, maintenance, repair, reworking, testing, plugging and abandonment of the well and the construction and use of all facilities reasonably necessary or convenient in connection therewith, including gathering lines and discharge lines, by the permittee and its employees, agents and contractors, provided that any such authorized activities shall be in compliance with all applicable provisions of this article and shall not be in conflict with any of the conditions and provisions contained in the permit. However, a new or supplemental permit shall be obtained before such well may be deepened below the geological formation in which it was originally completed and before it may be used for repressurizing or injecting water or gas. 
(c)  When a permit has been issued for the installation of any trunkline pipeline or water and/or gas repressurizing or injection facility, the permit shall constitute sufficient authority for the construction, operation, maintenance, conversion of existing wells to injection wells (in the case of a water and/or gas repressurizing or injection facility), repair and abandonment of such facility and for all facilities reasonably necessary or convenient in connection therewith (including gathering lines), by the permittee and its employees, agents and contractors, provided that the authorized activities are in compliance with all of the provisions of this article and are not in conflict with any of the conditions and provisions contained in the permit. 
(d)  No permit or filing fee will be required for any well, pipeline and water and/or gas repressurizing or injection facility, and such other facilities as may be covered by this article existing within the city limits at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived (8-4-1982), or which are in existence at the time the land upon which such facilities are situated is annexed to the city, but the oil and gas inspector shall inspect such facilities, and if he is satisfied that such facilities can be operated in a manner that will ensure public safety, he shall issue a certificate, in writing, that such facilities conform to such public safety requirement; provided, however, that the operator of any such facilities coming within the provisions of this subsection shall, within four years of January 1, 1983, or the date that the premises upon which the facilities are located is annexed into the city limits, take all necessary steps required for such facilities to comply with this article. If any such facilities do not conform with the provisions of this article within such period of time, the operator of such facilities shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article, which shall be punishable by a fine as described in section 46-36. It is further provided that if any such existing facilities coming within the provisions of this subsection are abandoned or relocated for any reason, any new facilities constructed or established to replace such facilities must comply with all provisions of this article. 
(e)  No permit shall authorize the drilling of more than one well, or the installation of more than one trunkline pipeline or more than one water and/or gas repressurizing or injection facility. 
(Code 1995, § 114.40) 
Sec. 46-92. - Application; filing fee. 
(a)  Every application for a permit to drill a well or install a water and/or gas repressurizing or injection facility or trunkline pipeline shall be in writing, signed by the applicant or by a person duly authorized to sign on his behalf, and it shall be filed with the city secretary. In case the permit is requested for the purpose of drilling a well or reentering and drilling to a deeper formation, the application shall be accompanied by a filing fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, which shall be payable to the city by cash, cashier's check or certified check. 
(b)  A separate application shall be required for each well, trunkline pipeline and water and/or gas repressurizing or injection facility. The application shall include full information, including the following: 
(1)  The date of the application. 
(2)  The name of the applicant. 
(3)  The address of the applicant. 
(4)  The proposed site of the well (including proposed location of gathering lines), trunkline pipeline or water and/or gas repressurizing or injection facility, including: 
a.  Name of the lease owner, where applicable. 
b.  Accurate description of the land. 
c.  Location with respect to property lines, right-of-way boundaries and grades, where applicable. 
(5)  The type of derrick to be used, if any. 
(6)  The proposed depth of the well, when applicable. 
(7)  The detailed explanation of operating pressures of all pipelines and facilities. 
(8)  The location of compressor, pressure control or safety devices, with an explanation of operating characteristics of each. 
(9)  The name of the persons to be notified in case of an emergency. 
(c)  The application to install any pipeline with pressures in excess of 250 pounds per square inch (psi) should include details and specifications of the safety provisions and equipment. 
(Code 1995, § 114.41) 
Sec. 46-93. - Issuance and denial. 
(a)  Within 60 days after the filing of the application for a permit to drill a well or install a trunkline pipeline or a water flooding, gas injection or any primary or secondary recovery system for the production of oil, gas and condensate, the city council shall determine whether or not the application complies, in all respects, with the provisions of this article, and if it is in compliance, the city council shall then fix the amount of the principal of the bond and insurance provided for in this division, and issue a permit for the drilling of the well or the installation of the facilities applied for. Each permit shall: 
(1)  Have incorporated in the permit, by reference, all of the provisions of this article, with the same force and effect as if this article were copied verbatim in the permit. 
(2)  Specify the location of the proposed well, injection facility and all pipelines, with particularity to lot number, block number, name of addition or subdivision, section line or other available correct legal description. 
(3)  Contain and specify that the term of the permit shall be for a period of one year from the date of the permit and until such time as the permittee has permanently abandoned the operation of the well or facility for which the permit was issued. 
(4)  Contain and specify such other terms and provisions as may be necessary in a particular case to accomplish the purposes of this article. 
(5)  Specify the total depth to which the well (if any) may be drilled, not exceeding the proposed depth. 
(6)  Contain and specify that no actual operation shall be commenced until the permittee shall file and have approved an indemnity bond in the designated principal amount as determined by the city council, or has complied with this article. 
(b)  Such permit, in duplicate originals, shall be signed by the inspector, and prior to delivery to the permittee, shall be signed by the permittee, with one original to be retained by the city and one by the permittee, and, when signed, shall constitute the permittee's drilling and installation license, as well as the contractual obligation of the permittee to comply with the terms of such permit, bond and this article. 
(c)  If the permit is refused, or the applicant notifies the city council, in writing, that he does not elect to accept the permit as tendered and wishes to withdraw his application, or the bond of the applicant is not approved, or the applicant notifies the city council, in writing, that he wishes to withdraw his application, then, upon the happening of such an event, the cash deposit filed with the application to drill a well shall be returned to the applicant, except that an amount as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office shall retained by the city from such deposit as a processing fee. 
(d)  (1)  In determining whether to grant or deny any application for a permit required by this article and in determining the conditions and provisions to be contained in any such permit, the city council shall include the following factors in its consideration: 
a.  Whether the proposed facility will comply with all provisions of this article. 
b.  Whether the proposed facility will conflict with the comprehensive plan for physical development of the city. 
c.  Whether specific sites have been designated on plats of the property in the area concerned for such oil and gas facilities as are the subject of the application. 
d.  Whether, for any reason, the proposed facility will constitute a hazard to property or persons. 
(2)  In acting on any such application, the city council shall determine whether the application complies, or is consistent, with the criteria set forth in subsection (d)(1) of this section as of the time of the granting or denying of the permit and not as of the time of the making of the application for such permit. 
(3)  Once a permit has been granted by the city council, any subsequent change of conditions not under the control of the permittee shall not require any action on the part of the permittee to improve or change his existing facilities to comply with the provisions of this article before the change of conditions; however, this does not apply to facilities which are actually abandoned or relocated for whatever reason, in which case, such relocated facilities must comply with all provisions of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 114.42) 
Sec. 46-94. - Bond and insurance required; amounts; exceptions. 
(a)  Filing. If a permit or certificate of compliance is issued by the city council or the oil and gas inspector, under the terms of this article for the drilling of a well, installation of a trunkline pipeline, water flooding project or gas injection project, no actual operations shall be commenced until the permittee shall file a bond and certificate of insurance with the city secretary, as follows: 
(1)  Bond. 
a.  A bond in the principal sum as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, but not to be less than $25,000.00. The bond shall be executed by a reliable insurance company authorized to do business in the state, as surety, and the applicant as principal, running in the city for the benefit of the city and all persons concerned, conditioned that the permittee will comply with the terms and conditions of this article in the drilling and operation of the well, water flooding project, gas injection or operation of any pipeline. 
b.  Such bond shall become effective on or before the date such bond is filed with the city secretary, and shall remain in force and effect for at least a period of six months subsequent to the expiration of the term of the permit issued. In addition, the bond will be conditioned that the permittee will: 
1.  Promptly pay all legally imposed fines, penalties and other assessments imposed upon him by reason of his breach of any of the terms, provisions and conditions of this article; 
2.  Promptly restore the streets and sidewalks and other public property of the city which may be disturbed or damaged in the operations to their former condition; 
3.  Promptly clear all premises of all litter, trash, waste and other substances used, allowed or occurring in the operations; 
4.  After abandonment or completion, grade, level and restore such property to the same surface conditions, as nearly as possible, as existed when operations were first commenced; 
5.  Indemnify and hold the city harmless from any and all liability growing out of or attributable to the granting of such permit. 
If, at any time, the city council shall deem any permittee's bond to be insufficient for any reason, the city council may require the permittee to file a new bond. 
c.  If, after completion of a producing well, gas injection well, water injection well or any facility or pipeline for which a bond is required by this article, the permittee has complied with all provisions of this article, such as removing derricks, clearing the premises, erecting fences, etc., he may apply to the city council to have the bond reduced to a sum of not less than $10,000.00 on each well or facility for the remainder of the time the well produces or the facility is operated without reworking. During a major well workover or in-hole remedial operations requiring the use of a rotary rig and/or high pressure injection equipment (deepening, cementing, bracing, reperforating, etc.), the amount of the bond shall be increased to the original amount. A trunkline pipeline installation shall not be considered to be completed until the lines have been tested and in operation for a period of 30 days. 
(2)  Insurance. 
a.  In addition to the bond required in subsection (a)(1) of this section, the permittee shall carry a policy of standard comprehensive public liability insurance, including contractual liability covering bodily injuries and property damage, naming the permittee and the city, with an insurance company authorized to do business in the state. Such policy, in the aggregate, shall provide for the following minimum coverages: 
1.  Bodily injuries, $200,000.00 per person, and $500,000.00 per accident. 
2.  Property damage, $300,000.00. 
b.  The permittee shall file certificates of insurance with the city secretary, as required in subsection (a)(2)a. of this section, and shall obtain the written approval of such certificates of insurance by the inspector, who shall act thereon within ten days from the date of such filing. The insurance policy shall not be canceled without written notice to the city secretary at least ten days prior to the effective date of such cancellation. If such insurance policy is canceled, the permit granted shall terminate, and the permittee's right to operate under such permit shall cease until the permittee files additional insurance, as provided in this section. If, after completion of a well, water flooding project, gas injection project or pipeline, the permittee has complied with all of the provisions of this article, such as removing derricks, completion of the pipelines, clearing the premises, etc., he may apply to the inspector to have such insurance policy reduced, as follows: 
1.  Bodily injuries, $100,000.00 per person, and $300,000.00 per accident. 
2.  Property damage, $100,000.00 for the remainder of the time such well produced without reworking. During reworking operations the amount of the insurance policy shall be increased to the original amount. 
(b)  Exceptions. The city council may elect to make an exception to the requirements of subsection (a) of this section when, in its opinion, the intent and purpose for the requirements of the bond and insurance can be assured by any of the following: 
(1)  Acceptance of a guaranty of indemnity to the city in lieu of a bond, and a plan of self-insurance in the case of financially responsible operators. 
(2)  Acceptance of a blanket bond and a single policy of insurance to cover all operations of the permittee within the city limits. 
(3)  Application of bond and insurance requirements acceptable to the city council. 
(Code 1995, § 114.05) 
Sec. 46-95. - Final report. 
    Within 30 days after completion of any well, the permittee shall file a final report in the office of the oil and gas inspector, which shall include the casing program actually utilized in the well. The final report shall specify any changes in the location or depth of the well and any other variation from the terms of the permit. The final report shall specify the perforated interval, and include information pertaining to other perforations, if any. 
(Code 1995, § 114.24) 
Sec. 46-96. - Suspension and cancellation. 
    If the permittee fails to comply with any provision of this article, the oil and gas inspector shall issue a written notice to the permittee of the nature of the noncompliance, stating such reasonable time necessary to gain compliance. After the lapse of such reasonable time, the city council may suspend the permit for a period of time or cancel the permit. 
(Code 1995, § 114.43) 
Sec. 46-97. - Supplemental permit for deep drilling. 
(a)  Once any well has either been completed as a producer or abandoned as a dry hole, it shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to drill the well to a deeper geological formation than that reached in the prior drilling operations without the permittee obtaining a supplemental permit after filing a supplemental application with the city secretary, specifying the: 
(1)  Condition of the well and the casing. 
(2)  Proposed depth to which the well will be deepened. 
(3)  Proposed casing program to be used in the connection with the proposed deepening operations. 
(b)  If the inspector is satisfied that such well may be deepened with the same degree of safety as existing in the original well, a supplemental permit may be issued to the permittee, without an additional filing fee, authorizing the deepening and operation of the well for such specified depth as applied for, provided that the derrick and drilling equipment have not been removed from the drill site. In any deeper drilling or any deeper completion of any deeper production operations, the permittee shall comply with all provisions contained in this article and applicable to the drilling, completion and operation of a well. 
(c)  If the operator has removed the derrick and drilling equipment from the location, the supplemental permit shall comply with the requirements specified in this division for a permit. 
(Code 1995, § 114.44) 
Secs. 46-98-46-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 46-121. - Proximity of facilities to streets, roads, highways and alleys. 
    No oil or gas well, permanent compressor station, water flood station, separator or tank battery covered by this article shall be located closer than 150 feet to any street, road, highway or alley, whether such street, road, highway or alley is existing, platted or dedicated, without the written permission of the city council. 
(Code 1995, § 114.06) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58. 
Sec. 46-122. - Proximity of facilities to structures, buildings and grounds. 
(a)  No well shall be drilled, no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled, nor shall a storage tank be located closer than 150 feet to any residence or commercial building without the applicant having first secured the written permission of the city council. 
(b)  No high pressure gas injection well, or compressor used in conjunction with a gas injection well, shall be located closer than 150 feet to any residential, commercial or industrial structure, school or other public building or public grounds, except by permission of the city council. In exceptional cases, for reasons of safety, the city council may require that any such facility shall be located at a greater distance than 150 feet to any such structure, building or grounds. 
(c)  No residential, commercial or industrial structure, other than structures necessary to operate the pipeline, shall be erected or moved to a location closer than 30 feet to any pipeline transporting gas when the pipeline operating pressure is greater than 250 pounds per square inch (psi) unless a greater or lesser distance is recommended by the then applicable ANSI code. 
(d)  The area of the city limits defined as Brownwood Regional Airport, which property is owned by the city, is exempt from all provisions of this section. Any compliance provisions required will be implemented with a city council approved contract, on a case-by-case basis. 
(Code 1995, § 114.07) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 78. 
Sec. 46-123. - Derrick and rig; watchman. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to use or operate, in connection with the drilling or reworking of any well within the city limits, any wooden derrick or steam powered rig, and all engines shall be equipped with adequate mufflers approved by the oil and gas inspector. No person shall permit any drilling rig or derrick to remain on the premises or drilling site for a period longer than 60 days after completion or abandonment of the well. From the start of erection of a derrick, mast or ginpole, until the well is abandoned and plugged, or completed as a producer and enclosed with a fence as provided in this division, the permittee shall keep a watchman on duty on the premises, at all times, when other workmen of the permittee are not on such premises. 
(Code 1995, § 114.08) 
Sec. 46-124. - Slush pits. 
    Steel slush pits shall be used in connection with all drilling and reworking operations. Such pits and contents shall be removed from the premises and drilling site within 30 days after completion of the well. No earthen slush pits shall be used. 
(Code 1995, § 114.09) 
Sec. 46-125. - Operations and equipment; practices; standards. 
(a)  All drilling and operations performed by a permittee under this article at any well shall be conducted in accordance with the practices of a reasonable and prudent operator. All casings, valves, blowout preventers, drilling fluids, tubing, bradenheads, Christmas trees and wellhead connections shall be of a type and quality consistent with the practices of a reasonable and prudent operator. Setting and cementing casing and running drill stem tests shall be performed in a manner and at a time consistent with the practice of a reasonable and prudent operator. Each permittee under this article shall observe and follow the regulations of the state railroad commission. 
(b)  All operations relative to the design, installation, maintenance and operation of pipelines shall conform to the requirements of this article, applicable ANSI codes and standards of performance of the reasonable and prudent operators of the trades involved. 
(c)  All pipelines constructed shall be of all new pipe and shall comply with ANSI specifications. 
(d)  Valves shall be installed on all pipelines at such locations and spacing to safely and adequately control the operation of the line and to minimize the quantity of gas, oil or water that would be released from the line in case of the failure or rupture of the line. The types and locations of all valves shall be indicated on a plan layout and approved by the oil and gas inspector. 
(e)  Electric motors shall be used to drive all gas compressors, pumping units and/or water flood pumps in the oil and gas operations, and all electrical installations and equipment shall conform to city ordinances and the appropriate national codes. 
(f)  The type and location of pipeline location markers shall be approved by the oil and gas inspector and the removal of any pipeline marker without the express permission of the oil and gas inspector shall constitute a violation of the provisions of this article. 
(g)  The pipelines crossing certain thoroughfares, designated by the oil and gas inspector, shall be cased and vented in accordance with the accepted practice of the pipeline industry. 
(h)  The delivery to or removal of equipment or material from the drill site shall be limited to the hours between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., except in cases of emergency. No pipe racking outside the derrick will be permitted during the hours between 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., except in cases of emergency. All lighting shall be shielded and directed to confine the direct rays to the drill site. 
(Code 1995, § 114.10) 
Sec. 46-126. - Cleanliness and sanitation. 
    The premises shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition which is satisfactory to the health officer and the oil and gas inspector of the city. The permittee shall take reasonable precautions to prevent any mud, wastewater, oil, slush or other waste matter from flowing into the alleys, streets, lots or leases within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 114.11) 
Sec. 46-127. - Motive power for operations. 
    Electric motors shall be used to drive all pumping units, gas compressors and transfer operations. No electric power shall be generated on the location. All electrical installations and equipment shall conform to city ordinances and the appropriate national codes. 
(Code 1995, § 114.12) 
Sec. 46-128. - Storage tanks and separators. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to use, construct or operate any crude oil storage tanks in connection with any producing well within the city limits, except for two low type tanks for oil storage, not exceeding 500 barrels' capacity for each well connected to such tanks, and constructed and maintained so as to be vaportight and properly vented. A permittee may use, construct and operate a steel conventional separator, and such other approved tank and appurtenances as are necessary for treating oil with each of such facilities, which shall be constructed and maintained so as to be vaportight. Each oil or gas separator shall be equipped with both a regulation pressure relief safety valve and a bursting head. All such tanks shall be placed aboveground upon a suitable earth or concrete pad. 
(b)  The use of a central tank battery is permitted as long as not more than two tanks, as specified in subsection (a) of this section, are used for each well connected to the battery. 
(c)  The tanks shall be enclosed within a conventional type fire wall, constructed of compacted earth. Sufficient water shall be used during the firewall construction to assure adequate compaction. 
(d)  The firewall enclosing the tanks shall have a minimum capacity equal to two times the volume of the enclosed tanks. 
(e)  The top or crown of the firewall shall have a normal height of three feet above normal ground elevation. The location of the tank site shall be approved by the city oil and gas inspector. 
(f)  The tanks shall be recessed within the firewall and enclosed to a depth that will assure the tanks of being practically sight clear, when viewed from outside of the fenced enclosure. 
(g)  The separators shall be installed in a manner that will assure they are practically sight clear, when viewed from outside the fenced enclosure. 
(Code 1995, § 114.13) 
Sec. 46-129. - Fences. 
(a)  Any person who completes any producing well shall have the obligation to enclose such well, together with its surface facilities, by a substantial fence, six feet high and properly built to ordinarily keep persons and/or animals out of the enclosure. All gates and exitways shall be kept locked, at all times, except when the permittee or his employees are inside the enclosure. In a developed residential area, the permittee will be obligated to landscape and maintain the appearance of the site to conform to the surrounding residential area. In noncongested residential areas, the oil and gas inspector may designate the type of fencing to be erected. However, if the surrounding area subsequently develops into a residential neighborhood, the permittee will be obligated to conform to the residential landscaping, fencing and appearance. 
(b)  The compressor unit, water flood pump unit and/or injection well location shall be enclosed on all sides by a minimum six-foot chainlink fence, with two strands of barbed wire along the top, and properly built to keep persons and/or animals out of the enclosure. The fence shall have a minimum of two gates or exitways located on opposite sides of the enclosure. The gates or exitways shall be kept locked, at all times, except when the permittee or his employees are inside the enclosure. In a developed residential area, the permittee will be obligated to landscape, solar screen and maintain the appearance of the site to conform to the surrounding area. 
(c)  In addition to the fence requirements set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the compressor unit or water flood pump unit shall be enclosed by a noncombustible structure which is constructed in a manner to reduce the noise of operation and minimize the hazards to the surrounding area. The design of the structure shall be approved by the oil and gas inspector prior to erection. 
(d)  Except where the site is located in an industrial or manufacturing zone, the well site, tank site, tank battery site, pump station site or compressor site shall not be used for the storage of pipe, equipment or materials, except during the drilling or servicing of the well, pipeline, tank, pump station or compressor station. 
(Code 1995, § 114.14) 
Sec. 46-130. - Operations to be conducted in manner to eliminate nuisances. 
    All oil, and drilling and production operations shall be conducted in a manner to eliminate, as far as practicable, dust, noise, vibration or noxious odors, and shall be in accordance with the reasonable and prudent practices incidental to exploration for, drilling for, and production of oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances. 
(Code 1995, § 114.15) 
Sec. 46-131. - Fire prevention; identification signs. 
(a)  Any permittee engaged in the drilling or operation of an oil and/or gas well or the operation of any facility used in conjunction with the production of oil and/or gas within the corporate limits of the city shall take reasonable precautions to prevent gas from escaping into the air, and shall not flare or burn gas or oil from any pipe stack, pit or any similar means within the corporate limits of the city, provided that gas may be burned for a limited time, when necessary, to complete any oil and/or gas well upon the original completion or recompletion of workover jobs upon oil and/or gas wells, as long as such burning does not constitute a fire hazard to the property of others within the vicinity of such oil and/or gas well. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to operate a well for oil and/or gas without a four-inch header being laid over the top of the tank and a 21/2-inch line extending from the tank battery to a point designated by the oil and gas inspector. The manner and method provided for connection at such point shall be determined by the fire department of the city so that foamite or other chemicals may be pumped through such line and the header of the tanks into such tanks to extinguish fires in the tanks. 
(c)  Emergency firefighting apparatus and supplies, subject to approval by the fire department of the city, shall be maintained on the drilling site, at all times, during the drilling operations and on the site of each compressor used for gas injection operations. 
(d)  The permittee shall place a sign at each well location or site to identify the well. 
(Code 1995, § 114.16) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
Sec. 46-132. - Abandonment and plugging. 
    Whenever any well is abandoned, it shall be the obligation of the permittee and the operator of the well to comply with the regulations of the state railroad commission in connection with the abandonment and plugging of a well. A copy of the plugging and abandonment form shall be furnished to the oil and gas inspector. 
(Code 1995, § 114.17) 
Sec. 46-133. - Saltwater. 
    The permittee shall take reasonable precautions for the disposal of all saltwater and other impurities which he may bring to the surface so as not to contaminate the potable water supply, present or prospective, or injure surface vegetation. 
(Code 1995, § 114.18) 
Sec. 46-134. - Landscaping. 
    The land surrounding any well or surface facility, which is required to be landscaped by any of the provisions of this article, shall be planted and maintained with grass, plants or shrubs during such drilling and production operations, but only to the extent reasonably compatible with the general status of the surfaces in the vicinity. The entire controlled drill site shall be adequately landscaped, except for the portions occupied by any required structure, appurtenance or driveway, and all such landscaping shall be maintained in a good condition, at all times. 
(Code 1995, § 114.21) 
Sec. 46-135. - Operations in residential areas. 
    All operations will be maintained in a manner that will minimize dust, noxious odors, vibrations and other offensive conditions to the surrounding residential area. Any aboveground facility which is located within or immediately adjoining any subdivided area where ten percent of the lots or subdivided tracts within a one-half-mile radius are improved with residential structures or located within one-half mile of any school or public building shall be considered to be within a developed residential area. 
(Code 1995, § 114.22) 
Sec. 46-136. - Excavations; operating gauge pressure for gathering and flow lines; pipeline testing; as-built plot plans; cover and backfill; construction in rights-of-way; emergency repairs. 
(a)  Permission required. No permittee shall make any excavation for any purpose or construct any lines for conveyance of fuel, water or minerals on, under or through the streets and alleys of the city without the express written permission of the oil and gas inspector, and then only in strict compliance with ordinances of the city; provided, however, that emergency repairs may be made without such permission when, in the good faith opinion of the permittee, the delay required to obtain written permission would involve a hazard to persons or property. 
(b)  Maximum operating gauge pressure and location of gathering and flow lines. The gathering and flow lines installed in the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of transporting oil, gas or water in conjunction with the operation of any well, tank, tank battery, or injection or gathering system are hereby limited to a maximum operating gauge pressure of 250 pounds per square inch (psi) unless otherwise specifically approved by the oil and gas inspector. The location of any such gathering and flow lines, if not specified in the permit, must be specifically approved by the oil and gas inspector. 
(c)  Testing. Pipelines shall be tested prior to being placed in service. 
(d)  As-built plot plans required. The companies responsible for any and all pipelines installed within the corporate limits of the city are hereby required to furnish to the city, for a permanent record with the city, an as-built plot plan showing the location of all of the companies' facilities. 
(e)  Cover and backfill. 
(1)  All pipelines within the corporate limits of the city, other than the utility lines of the city and the franchised distribution system of Lone Star Gas Company, designed or utilized to transport oil, gas or water in connection with the production and transportation of oil and/or gas or for repressurizing operations shall be installed with the minimum of cover or backfill specified by the then applicable ANSI code for such pipelines. 
(2)  The oil and gas inspector is authorized to approve a lesser cover or specify a greater cover or backfill in special cases when, in the opinion of the oil and gas inspector, such variation is advisable and/or will not increase the degree of hazard. 
(f)  Construction in right-of-way. The requirements for construction in public rights-of-way must conform to such ordinances of the city regulating such construction. 
(g)  Effects on existing streets. The digging up, breaking, excavating, tunneling, undermining, breaking up, damaging of any street as defined in section 46-31, or leaving any earth, other material or obstruction upon any street shall not be permitted unless such person shall first have obtained written permission from the city engineer; provided, however, that emergency repairs may be made without such permission when, in the good faith opinion of the permittee, the delay required to obtain the written permission would involve a hazard to persons or property. 
(Code 1995, § 114.45) 
Chapter 50 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Maintenance and improvement of parks and squares, § 11. 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34; natural resources, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58. 
State Law reference- Municipal parks, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 306.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Area parks and facilities means parks and facilities located away from neighborhoods, and mainly used for reunions, meetings and large gatherings. Such parks and facilities have the same rules and applicable ordinances, but they also have exceptions with proper permits being filed. The following are considered area parks and facilities in the city: 
(1)  Fabis Park. 
(2)  Festival Park. 
(3)  Riverside Park. 
    Motorized sport vehicle means any such vehicle propelled by a motor that can be ridden or driven, including three-wheelers, four-wheelers, motorcycles, motorbikes, go-carts and dune buggies. This definition does not prohibit motorized conveyances for city maintenance vehicles or handicapped persons, such as motorized wheelchairs. 
    Neighborhood parks and facilities means parks and facilities close to neighboring residences or premises. The following are considered neighborhood parks and facilities in the city: 
(1)  Allcorn Park. 
(2)  Bunin Park. 
(3)  Camp Bowie Sport Complex. 
(4)  Cecil Holman Park. 
(5)  Center Park. 
(6)  Coggin Park. 
(7)  Gladys Seward Park. 
(8)  Kiwanis Park. 
(9)  Ledbetter Park. 
(10)  Margaret and Stuart Coleman Plaza. 
(11)  Mayes Park. 
(12)  Memorial Park. 
(13)  Snyder Park. 
(14)  Taber Park. 
(15)  Thomason Park. 
(16)  Trigg Park. 
(17)  Wiggins Park. 
    Vehicle shall mean any wheeled conveyance, whether motor-powered, animal-drawn or self-propelled. This term shall include any trailer in tow of any size, kind or description. This term shall not include baby carriages, bicycles and vehicles in the service of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 100.03; Ord. No. 08-38, § I, 10-28-2008; Ord. No. 18-12 , § 1, 5-22-2018) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 50-2. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide rules and regulations for the use of, and conduct in, the parks and recreation areas of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 100.01) 
Sec. 50-3. - Applicability. 
    This chapter shall apply in all parks and recreation facilities under the jurisdiction of the city, unless expressly exempted. 
(Code 1995, § 100.02) 
Secs. 50-4-50-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 50-31. - Permits.
