    Permits for special events in area parks and recreation facilities shall be obtained by application to the city manager or his designee. 
(Code 1995, § 100.08) 
Sec. 50-32. - Emergency closure. 
    In the case of emergency or at the discretion of the city manager, the director of parks and recreation or his designee, may order any portion of the parks or parkways closed to the public, if the public interest requires such closure. 
(Code 1995, § 100.10; Ord. No. 08-13, § II, 6-10-2008) 
Sec. 50-33. - Posting signs. 
    Appropriate signs shall be posted to notify the public of the park regulations set forth in this chapter, provided that failure to notice or read the signs shall not constitute a defense to any charge of violating this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 100.11) 
Secs. 50-34-50-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK RULES 

Sec. 50-61. - Nuisances. 
    It shall be an unlawful act for any person to omit to perform a duty, or suffer or permit any condition or thing to be or exist, which: 
(1)  Injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; 
(2)  Offends decency; 
(3)  Is offensive to the senses; 
(4)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs, tends to obstruct or renders dangerous, for its intended use, any public or private street, highway, sidewalk, stream, creek, waterway, ditch or drainage; or 
(5)  Essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property, or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others. 
(Code 1995, § 110.04(A)) 
Sec. 50-62. - Noise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or person to violate the noise regulations set forth in chapter 34, article V. 
(Code 1995, § 100.04(B)) 
State Law reference- Criminal mischief, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.03; graffiti, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 28.08; litter, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 356.001 et seq. 
Sec. 50-63. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    Alcoholic beverages shall be prohibited in parks, except by special permit pursuant to section 6-62. 
(Code 1995, § 110.04(E)) 
Sec. 50-64. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to use loud, obscene, vulgar or indecent language, or swear, curse, yell or shriek in a manner calculated to disturb persons present. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person in a neighborhood or area public park or recreation facility to: 
(1)  Mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with or displace or remove any building, bridge, table, bench, fireplace, railing, paving, paving material, water line or other public utility, or part or appurtenance thereof, sign, notice or placard, whether temporary or permanent, monument, stake, post or other boundary marker, or other structure or equipment, facility or park property, or appurtenance whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(2)  Throw, discharge or otherwise place, or cause to be thrown, discharged or placed, in the water of any fountain, pond, lake, stream or other body of water in or adjacent to any park, or any tributary, stream, storm sewer or drain flowing into such water, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of such water. 
(3)  Take into, carry through or put into any park any rubbish, refuse, garbage or other material. Such refuse and rubbish shall be deposited in the provided receptacles. Where receptacles are not provided, all such rubbish or refuse shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(4)  Hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, pursue, chase, tease, shoot or throw objects at any animal, wildlife or bird; or remove or have in such person's possession any wild animal, or the eggs, nest or young of any bird; however, snakes known to be poisonous may be killed on sight. 
(5)  Walk a domestic animal without a leash. The owner or person having custody of such domestic animal shall be responsible for removal of any animal feces. 
(Code 1995, § 100.04(F)) 
Sec. 50-65. - Disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in an area park or recreation facility to: 
(1)  Camp or stay overnight in vehicles or trailers at any place except areas designated for such camping or staying overnight. 
(2)  Enter an area posted as "closed to the public". 
(3)  Engage in threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent language or any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to breach the public peace. 
(4)  Fail to produce and exhibit any permit they claim to have, upon request of any authorized person who shall desire to inspect the permit for the purpose of enforcing compliance with any ordinance or rule. 
(5)  Unreasonably disturb or interfere with any person or party occupying any area or participating in any activity under the authority of a permit. 
(6)  Set off any fireworks. 
(Code 1995, § 100.06) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.01. 
Sec. 50-66. - Closing hours. 
    No person shall be in any area park and recreation facility during the hours that the park is closed, as posted, except for designated camping areas. 
(Code 1995, § 100.07) 
Sec. 50-67. - Operation, standing or parking of vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation facility to: 
(1)  Drive any vehicle on any area other than the paved park roads (or designated park roads if not paved) or parking areas, or such areas as may, on occasion, be specifically designated as temporary areas. 
(2)  Park a vehicle any place other than on a designated parking area. 
(3)  Leave a vehicle standing or parked in established parking areas or elsewhere in the park during hours when the park areas are closed. 
(4)  Use any park area, including parking places, for the repair or cleaning of any vehicle, except in an emergency. 
(5)  Violate any of the traffic laws of the state or any of the traffic ordinances of the city, all of which shall apply in full force and effect in all parks. 
(6)  Fail to obey any traffic-control device indicating speed, direction of travel, caution, stopping, standing, parking or other instructions designed to promote traffic-control safety. 
(7)  Drive or operate a vehicle at a speed in excess of the speed limit posted. 
(8)  Operate a motorized sport vehicle, unless authorized by the city manager, or authorized by the city council in park areas specifically designated and marked by appropriate signage for such use. Motorcycles, legal for street use, and golf carts may be operated on paved park roads (or the designated park roads if not paved) only. 
(Code 1995, § 100.05; Ord. No. 18-12 , § 1, 5-22-2018) 
Sec. 50-68. - Prohibition of dogs in the Bert V. Massey, II Sports Complex and the Brownwood Soccer Complex. 
(a)  Dogs, regardless of whether they are leashed, unleashed or carried, are prohibited in the Bert V. Massey, II Sports Complex during the April 1 to August 31 time period only. 
(b)  Dogs, regardless of whether they are leashed, unleashed or carried, are prohibited in the fenced area of the Brownwood Soccer Complex while league sanctioned soccer games and tournaments are being played by Soccer-4-Fun, the Centex Soccer Association and other leagues (or any successor leagues or associations). 
(c)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, (i) guide dogs aiding a totally or partially blind persons or otherwise incapacitated person shall be permitted in the Bert V. Massey, II Sports Complex and the Brownwood Soccer Complex; and (ii) dogs, provided that they are on a leash at all times, may be on the designated portion of the walking trail located in the Bert V. Massey, II Sports Complex. 
(Ord. No. 03-13, § I(100.61), 4-22-2003; Ord. No. 11-12, 6-14-2011; Ord. No. 17-02 , § I, 1-10-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-02 , § I, adopted Jan. 20, 2017, amended § 50-68 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Prohibition of dogs in the Bert V. Massey, II Sports Complex" to "Prohibition of dogs in the Bert V. Massey, II Sports Complex and the Brownwood Soccer Complex," as set out herein. 
Sec. 50-69. - Riverside Park. 
(a)  The City Council of the City of Brownwood has determined that the back portion of Riverside Park, behind the house and the west side of the park, should be closed at dusk to discourage misuse of the park, including loitering, littering and other nuisance. 
(b)  The City Council of the City of Brownwood has determined that it would be in the best interest of the City of Brownwood residents to close the back portion of Riverside Park, behind the house and the west side of the park, from dusk to 7:00 a.m. Signs stating park hours shall be posted permanently in the park. 
(c)  Said hours may be extended during any such program or event following pre-approval by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 09-29, 12-8-2009) 
Chapter 54 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34; duty to remove waste, rubbish and debris from interior of structure, § 34-35; duty to remove waste, etc., from yards, § 34-36; natural resources, ch. 46; utilities, ch. 70; buildings and building regulations, ch. 78; manufactured homes and parks, ch. 86. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Refuse means all nonputrescible wastes. 
    Solid waste means all putrescible wastes, except sewage and body wastes, including vegetable and animal offal and carcasses of dead animals, but excluding recognizable industrial byproducts, and including all such substances from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
(Code 1995, § 50.01) 
Sec. 54-2. - Uncollected solid waste declared nuisance. 
    Fermenting, putrefying, or odiferous solid waste in containers which have not been collected due to failure to pay solid waste fees or for not being placed in proper containers shall be declared a nuisance. 
(Code 1995, § 50.02) 
Sec. 54-3. - Discontinuance of water service for nonpayment. 
    If solid waste collection charges are not paid within such time as the city council may establish, water service to the premises shall be discontinued. 
(Code 1995, § 50.03) 
Sec. 54-4. - Permit required for collection. 
    No person shall collect solid waste or refuse who does not possess a permit from the sanitary supervisor. Such permit shall be issued only upon the payment of an annual permit fee set by the sanitary supervisor and city manager and after the sanitary supervisor has been satisfied that the licensee is capable of complying with the requirements of this chapter. The permit may be revoked when deemed necessary to the public welfare by the sanitary supervisor. 
(Code 1995, § 50.04) 
Secs. 54-5-54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 54-31. - Solid waste, trash to be kept from scattering. 
    It shall be the duty of every person occupying or having under his control any premises in this city to prevent all solid waste, trash, and refuse from spreading or scattering over the premises, over adjacent premises, or over or into any street, sidewalk, alley, gutter, or drain. 
(Code 1995, § 50.15) 
Sec. 54-32. - Containers to be used; specifications. 
    No owner, tenant, or lessee of any public or private premises shall permit to accumulate upon his premises any solid waste or refuse, except in covered containers approved by the sanitary supervisor. Such containers shall be constructed in such manner as to be strong, not easily corrodible, rodentproof, and insectproof, and shall have a capacity of not more than 30 gallons. The size of containers shall be designated by the sanitary supervisor and city manager. Containers shall be kept covered at all times except when refuse is being deposited therein or removed therefrom. 
(Code 1995, § 50.16) 
Sec. 54-33. - Preparation of certain items for collection. 
    Boxes, papers, trees, and odd articles shall be prepared for collection by being crushed or bundled in lengths not to exceed five feet and not to exceed 50 pounds in weight. 
(Code 1995, § 50.17) 
Sec. 54-34. - Separate containers required for individual disposal. 
    In case solid waste and one or more types of refuse are disposed of separately, separate containers may be required by the solid waste supervisor. 
(Code 1995, § 50.18) 
Sec. 54-35. - Placement for collection; maintenance. 
    No solid waste or refuse shall be collected by any authorized agency or person unless it is placed and maintained as designated by the sanitary supervisor. All containers should be placed in an alley or other place convenient for trucking, and the place and hour of collection shall be designated by the sanitary supervisor. All empty containers shall be disinfected with a suitable disinfectant and removed from the alley or other loading place without unnecessary delay. 
(Code 1995, § 50.19) 
Sec. 54-36. - Collection charge. 
    The solid waste, trash, and refuse collection rate shall be set by the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1995, § 50.20) 
Sec. 54-37. - Disposal of solid waste and refuse. 
    The disposal of solid waste and refuse in any quantity by any individual, householder, or establishment in any place, private or public, within the city limits or within 5,000 feet outside the city limits shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1995, § 50.21) 
Sec. 54-38. - Disposal methods. 
(a)  All disposal of solid waste and refuse shall be by one of the following methods: 
(1)  Incineration; 
(2)  Landfill and cover; 
(3)  Sanitary landfill; or 
(4)  Dumping ground designated by the city or an authorized representative approved by the city and county health officers. 
Such methods shall include the maximum practicable rodent, insect, and nuisance control at the place or places of disposal. 
(b)  The carcasses of dead animals shall be disposed of as directed by the sanitary supervisor. 
(Code 1995, § 50.22) 
Sec. 54-39. - Temporary collection stations. 
(a)  There shall be only private household waste, save and except food or animal waste shall not be permitted; yard waste and large items from private residences disposed of in the container. 
(b)  There shall be no disposal of material by commercial businesses in the container. Such commercial material shall be carried to the city landfill for disposal. 
(c)  There shall be no tires placed in the container. 
(d)  There shall be no littering or spilling of waste material around the container. 
(e)  There shall be no waste placed in the container from commercial haulers who are hauling from private households. 
(Code 1995, § 50.23) 
Secs. 54-40-54-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SANITARY LANDFILL 

Sec. 54-71. - Use regulations. 
(a)  Private use of the city sanitary landfill shall be extended only to citizens of the city and to city utility customers residing outside city limits who have made contractual arrangements with the city utility department. 
(b)  Use and fees shall be applied in accordance with ordinances passed by the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1995, § 50.35) 
Sec. 54-72. - Fees. 
    Fees shall be determined by the utility rate ordinance which is on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 50.36) 
Chapter 58 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Maintenance and improvement of streets, sidewalks and public ways, §§ 11, 12, 20; power over obstructions and encroachments, § 11. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance or resolution dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing, vacating, etc., any street or public way saved from repeal, § 1-8(5); peddlers, itinerant vendors, transient merchants and vendors, § 18-121 et seq.; environment, ch. 34; natural resources, ch. 46; proximity of oil and gas facilities to streets, roads, highways and alleys, § 46-121; parks and recreation, ch. 50; traffic and vehicles, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 70; vehicles for hire, ch. 74; buildings and building regulations, ch. 78; moving buildings, § 78-481 et seq.; floods, ch. 82; manufactured homes and parks, ch. 86; signs, ch. 90; subdivisions, ch. 94; design standards for streets, § 94-122; required improvements for streets, § 94-162; zoning, ch. 98; telecommunications, § 98-671 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal streets, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 311.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Street acceptance. 
    Any streets which are or have been delineated as such, on any of the general or official maps of the city, whether in the old town proper or any addition thereto, or which have been donated to the public as such, or which have been acquired by condemnation, long use, or otherwise, whether named or described, are hereby accepted and declared to be the public streets, avenues, and alleys of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 98.002) 
Sec. 58-2. - Discharge of water, wastewater and other substances on streets and alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful to cause water, wastewater or any other substance to be discharged on any of the streets or alleys of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 98.003) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 70. 
Sec. 58-3. - Parade permit required. 
    All parades upon the streets and alleys of the city are hereby expressly prohibited unless a permit for the parade has been obtained from the city manager. Parade permits shall designate the time for the parade, the length of time the parade may occupy the streets and alleys, the place where the parade may form and the route the parade shall take or follow during its progress. An applicant for a parade permit may request a hearing before the city council to appeal a denial of his permit application. 
(Code 1995, § 98.004; Ord. No. 08-13, § III, 6-10-2008) 
Sec. 58-4. - Gas pipelines. 
    All pipelines for the distribution of gas, or any other commodity, laid in the streets or alleys of the city shall be located and laid under the direction and supervision of the city engineer. 
(Code 1995, § 98.065) 
Sec. 58-5. - Temporary closure of streets and alleys. 
(a)  In case of emergency or at the discretion of the city manager, the city manager or his designee, may order any street or alley, or portion thereof, closed to the public if the public interest requires such closure. 
(b)  The city manager may temporarily close a street or alley, or a portion thereof, for a public event. An application for a temporary street closure must be completed and filed with the city manager. An applicant for a street closure may request a hearing before the city council to appeal a denial of his street closure permit application. 
(Ord. No. 08-13, § III, 6-10-2008) 
Secs. 58-6-58-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR WORK 

Sec. 58-31. - Manner of work; cleanliness of premises. 
    All work done under the provisions of this chapter shall be done or performed in a good, workmanlike manner. The work shall not be accepted or approved by the city until the premises thereof have been cleaned and cleared of all debris, trash, and rubbish which may have accumulated during the work. 
(Code 1995, § 98.020) 
Sec. 58-32. - Parking lots, driveways and similar areas. 
(a)  Performance bond required prior to start of construction. Before engaging in the business of construction of driveways, parking lots and other similar areas with asphalt or other similar construction material, all such persons shall give a performance bond in the sum of $5,000.00, or an amount commensurate with the anticipated cost of the project, with an acceptable surety company, payable to the city, to be approved by the city council, and conditioned that all work done by such persons shall be done in a good and workmanlike manner in accordance with city ordinances. 
(b)  Construction permit required. A permit for construction shall be obtained from the city engineer before the construction and/or paving of any driveway, parking lot or similar area. The permit shall be on a form prescribed by the city engineer. 
(c)  Curb and gutter installation. No driveway, parking lot or similar area shall be constructed or paved without proper curb and gutter being installed at all streets adjoining the property which construction is being placed upon. The city engineer shall set grades and lines for the curb and gutter. 
(d)  Indemnification. Such person shall indemnify the city and the property owner with whom he contracted, or any person, for all damages resulting from his negligence, the violation of any city ordinance or unskilled work done by himself or his employees. 
(e)  Injunctive relief. In addition to the penalty for a violation of this article, the indemnity right set out in subsection (d) of this section, the city shall also reserve the right to file for injunctive relief from the proper court to prevent a contractor from doing business within the city in the construction of driveways, parking lots and other similar construction after a violation of the provisions set out in this section until the violations are corrected at the contractor's own expense. 
(Code 1995, § 98.021) 
Secs. 58-33-58-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS, STREET CUTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Trench safety, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 756.021 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 58-61-58-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 58-81. - Required. 
    Before any roadway, alley or other public right-of-way in the city is cut or excavated, an application shall be filed and a construction permit for breaking the ground surface shall be obtained from the city engineer or his designee. 
(Code 1995, § 98.040) 
Sec. 58-82. - Obligation; deposit. 
    Before any street cut permit shall be granted, the person applying for such permit shall sign an obligation to pay the city for the cost of repairing the street or alley, and all broken portions thereof, and to place such street or alley in as good of a condition as it was prior to such penetration, and upon demand by the city, a deposit may be required in an amount as may be determined by the city, guaranteeing the repair of the street or alley. 
(Code 1995, § 98.041) 
Sec. 58-83. - Excavation requirements. 
(a)  All excavations shall be kept to a minimum depth, and the trenches shall be no wider than necessary to perform the excavation operation. The paving breaks shall be made in such a manner that the cut is straight and smooth, so that adjacent material is left undisturbed. 
(b)  Excavations for utility lines shall be adequate to assure no less than two feet of cover over such lines. The utility lines will be properly bedded and tamped to assure adequate compaction. Valve boxes shall be used on all valves, and shall be brought flush with the surface. 
(Code 1995, § 98.042) 
Sec. 58-84. - Backfilling. 
(a)  Procedure. All trenches or excavations shall be backfilled by one of the following methods: 
(1)  Dirt streets, dirt alleys, and unimproved parkways. All excavations within a street right-of-way and not under an improved surface shall be backfilled by tamping in six-inch horizontal layers or by ponding. The excavation shall be finished flush with the natural ground, and all surplus material shall be removed from the site. 
(2)  Gravel on all-weather-improved but not paved roads and alleys. All excavations under improved, but not paved, roads and alleys shall be backfilled within a reasonable time with select material by tamping in six-inch horizontal layers, or by ponding up to within eight inches of the surface. Select base material shall be tamped and finished flush with the natural grade. Muck and other poor materials shall be removed and replaced with select material. Care shall be taken to assure the optimum water content during tamping operations. 
(3)  Paved and hard-surfaced streets and alleys. The contractor may select one of the following procedures: 
a.  All excavated material shall be removed from the site and replaced with sand to a point eight inches below the existing surface. The sand shall be capped with six inches of concrete. 
b.  All excavated material shall be removed from the site and replaced with select material stabilized with Portland cement or with lime. If soil is used, it shall be stabilized with two sacks of cement or lime per cubic yard of material. If sand and gravel or chat is used, it shall be stabilized with one sack of cement per cubic yard of material. The backfill material shall be mixed in a concrete mixer. Water may be added in the mixer or may be added as the material is tamped into place. 
c.  The backfill may be replaced with select material tamped in six-inch horizontal layers to a point ten inches below the surface. The remaining ten inches shall be stabilized with Portland cement or with lime, as outlined in subsection (a)(3)b of this section. Should the contractor elect to use this method, he shall furnish a certificate signed by a competent engineer that the material has been properly placed and tamped. The owner shall be responsible for any failure of this excavation for a period of 12 months from the date of completion of the repairs. The fact that the city performs the finishing repairs shall not relieve the owner of responsibility for the base failure. 
(b)  Use of bonding and sealing material. The backfill in paved streets or alleys shall be finished flush with the surface with a two-inch surface of plant mixed asphaltic concrete. The backfill shall be properly sealed with a tack coat of RC 2 or similar material to assure bonding and sealing of the excavation. The premix shall be raked, tamped, and rolled into place. 
(c)  Responsibility for maintenance; billing. Should the contractor or owner elect to place the premix on the completed backfill, he shall be responsible for maintenance of the patch for 12 months. Should the city perform the finishing with premix, the owner will be billed at the current rate per square foot of surface replaced in the premix. 
(Code 1995, § 98.043) 
Sec. 58-85. - Correction of work. 
    Within 12 months of any excavation, if the city should be required to correct any work performed by an owner or contractor, such correction shall be made and billed to the owner or contractor responsible, on the basis of cost, plus 25 percent, for the correction. 
(Code 1995, § 98.044) 
Secs. 58-86-58-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VISIBILITY TRIANGLE 

Sec. 58-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Street gutter flow line means the street gutter flow line of the curb adjacent to and bordering upon each restricted area. If there is no such curb, height restrictions shall be based upon the actual level of the paved or used portion of the public street adjacent to and bordering upon each restricted area. 
(Code 1995, § 98.066(E)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-122. - Composition of restricted area. 
(a)  All of the portion of land lying within a triangular-shaped area on each street corner within the city shall comprise a restricted area, whether the land is privately-owned, unpaved or untraveled street right-of-way property, subject to the exceptions set forth in section 58-125, and shall be described by metes and bounds, as follows: 
Beginning at the precise corner of the intersection point of the curbs of each of the two streets intersecting forming each corner and extending 20 feet along each such curbline from the curb intersection point, and the third side is determined by the drawing of a straight line from the ends of such 20-foot extensions, as more fully portrayed in the following diagram:   
(b)  Where no curbs are in existence at the street intersections, the 20-foot lines shall coincide with the central flow line of the ditches paralleling the curbed streets. The central flow line shall be determined by the city engineer. 
(Code 1995, § 98.066(A)) 
Sec. 58-123. - Walls, fences, etc. 
    No person shall erect or maintain any wall, fence or other structure within any restricted area to a height greater than three feet from the street gutter flow line, except utility poles. 
(Code 1995, § 98.066(B)) 
Sec. 58-124. - Plant materials. 
(a)  No person shall plant, grow or maintain any plant, hedge, shrub or other growth in any restricted area or street right-of-way to a height greater than three feet from the street gutter flow line, except trees, as provided for in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(b)  Any tree planted, grown, and maintained in any restricted area or street right-of-way shall not have branches or foliage extending from the trunk thereof at a height lower than 101/2 feet from the surface of the property on which the tree is located. 
(c)  No tree, shrub, vine, palm or similar plant of any description or kind shall be grown, maintained or cultivated in such a manner that any portion thereof overhangs or obtrudes upon or over any street or highway in the city, unless there is a full 12-foot clearance between the surface of all portions of the street or highway and the overhanging tree, shrub, limb, vine, palm or plant. 
(Code 1995, § 98.066(C), (D), (G); Ord. No. 02-38, § 1, 8-27-2002) 
Sec. 58-125. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply only to zoned sections of the city requiring construction on lots in such zoned sections to be set back from the property line of each lot. 
(Code 1995, § 98.066(F)) 
Sec. 58-126. - Violations; notice; abatement. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the director of public works, or such other person as may be designated by the city council, that when it shall come to his knowledge that any obstruction, nuisance or traffic hazard, as set forth in this article, exists, to notify the owner of the property on which the violation exists, by certified mail, of the obstruction, nuisance or traffic hazard which is in contravention of the city ordinance, and to request that the obstruction, nuisance or traffic hazard be remedied or removed, as deemed necessary by the notifying official. The owner of the property so notified shall have ten days, as stipulated in the notice, to remedy or remove the obstruction, nuisance, traffic hazard or violation. 
(b)  If the violation has not been abated by the owner of the property within the time allowed, the director of public works may cause the violation to be abated. The officer charged with the abatement of the violation shall have the right, at reasonable times, to enter into or upon the property to investigate or cause the removal of the obstruction, nuisance or traffic hazard, in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1995, § 98.066(H), (I)) 
Secs. 58-127-58-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STREET RENTAL CHARGE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Gross receipts tax, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 182.025. 

Sec. 58-161. - Imposed. 
    On or before the day set forth each year in the ordinance granting any franchise within the city, every person occupying or using the streets, highways, easements, alleys, parks or other public places in the city with gas mains, pipes and other fixtures for the distribution of gas shall annually pay to the city, as a condition of the further privilege of such occupancy, a rental charge equal to two percent of the gross receipts received by the person from gas sold and delivered to residential and commercial consumers at residential and commercial rates within the corporate limits of the city for the preceding year. 
(Code 1995, § 98.080) 
Sec. 58-162. - Report of gross receipts. 
    All persons using or maintaining any gas pipelines, pipes and other fixtures in any of the streets, highways, easements, alleys, parks or other places within the corporate limits of the city shall, on or before the day set forth each year in the ordinance granting such franchise within the city, file a sworn report with the city showing the gross receipts from gas sold and delivered to residential and commercial consumers at residential and commercial rates by such persons within the corporate limits of the city for the preceding year ending June 30. 
(Code 1995, § 98.081) 
Sec. 58-163. - Examinations of books and records. 
    The city council may, at a reasonable time, have the books and records of any person rendering the report required in section 58-162 to be examined by a representative of the city to ascertain whether the report is accurate, but nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the city from ascertaining such facts by any other method. 
(Code 1995, § 98.082) 
Sec. 58-164. - Receipt for payment. 
    Upon receipt of the rental charge imposed in this article by the city, the city secretary shall deliver a receipt to the person paying the charge. The receipt shall authorize the person to use and occupy the streets, highways, easements, alleys, parks and other public ways of the city in carrying on his business for 12 months from the date fixed in the ordinance granting the franchise for such year. 
(Code 1995, § 98.083) 
Sec. 58-165. - Charge not a tax. 
    The rental charge imposed by this article is made for the privilege now enjoyed by the persons upon whom the charge is imposed for using the streets, easements, alleys and other public ways of the city in the conduct of their business, and the charge is additional to all ad valorem and franchise taxes and all taxes of every nature against such persons. 
(Code 1995, § 98.084) 
Sec. 58-166. - Relief not granted from other laws. 
    Nothing contained in this article is intended to relieve any person of any condition, restriction or requirement imposed by any law or ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 98.085) 
Sec. 58-167. - Franchise not granted; right to cancel privileges and refund. 
    This article does not grant a franchise to any utility or person to use the streets, easements, alleys and other public ways, and shall never be construed to do so by the courts or otherwise. The city reserves the right to cancel the privileges granted under this article and refund the unearned rentals paid to the city. 
(Code 1995, § 98.086) 
Sec. 58-168. - Right to adopt restrictions and regulations. 
    The city hereby reserves the right to put into effect, at any time, other restrictions and regulations as to the erection and maintenance of gas mains, pipes and other appurtenances in the streets, easements, alleys and other public ways of the city and, from time to time, to require such gas mains, pipes and other property, equipment and fixtures to be removed on such terms as the city may deem proper. 
(Code 1995, § 98.087) 
Secs. 58-169-58-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NUMBERING OF BUILDINGS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 78. 

Sec. 58-201. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Curbline means the line established by the city for a particular street. 
    Owner means an individual, firm, company or corporation holding legal fee title of a dwelling or structure. 
    Right-of-way means all public rights-of-way, streets or other public property within the city. 
    Street means any street, highway, sidewalk, alley, avenue, recessed parking area or other public right-of-way, including the entire right-of-way. 
(b)  Titles of city officials. When the title of any city official is used in this article, it shall include any duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1995, § 98.115) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-202. - Building identification inspector. 
(a)  The building official of the city shall be the building identification inspector, and it shall be his duty to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The building official shall file complaints with the municipal court of the city, as necessary, to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 98.116) 
Sec. 58-203. - Building identification. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility and duty of the owner of any building, dwelling, home, house or apartment, residential or commercial, public or private, to place outdoors thereon the proper street number and/or apartment number in conformity with the following requirements: 
(1)  All numbers shall not be less than four inches high, except apartment complexes, and shall be located in a place on the building which is plainly visible from the curbline of the adjacent primary street or right-of-way. 
(2)  Each separate building of an apartment complex and each individual apartment shall be marked with not less than three-inch high outdoor reflective apartment numbers on each adjacent frontage street or right-of-way and at all entrances and exits to adjacent parking areas. 
(3)  All numbers affixed to any building shall be of a contrasting color to the background on which such numbers are affixed. 
(b)  Curb markings of street addresses or apartment numbers shall not be in lieu of building identification numbers required under this article. 
(Code 1995, § 98.117) 
Sec. 58-204. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any owner to violate or fail to comply with any provision of this article, irrespective of whether or not the verbiage of each section in this article contains the specific language that a violation or failure to comply is unlawful and is an offense. Any owner who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or who fails to comply with the terms of the provisions of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall, upon conviction, be fined as set forth in section 1-14. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to willfully deface, injure or remove any number required under this article, except a person shall have the right to remove a number when altering or changing the building, and then such number shall be temporarily placed at another location on the building where it will conspicuously show from the street. Any person violating this subsection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall, upon conviction, be fined as set forth in section 1-14. 
(Code 1995, § 98.118)

Footnotes:

Sec. 62-31. - Homestead exemption to persons 65 years of age or older. 
(a)  From and after January 1, 1984, $15,000.00 of the assessed value of residence homesteads, as defined by law, of persons who have attained the age of 65 years on or before January 1 of the year for which the exemption is claimed shall be exempt from city ad valorem taxes; provided, however, that where the ad valorem tax has heretofore been pledged for the payment of any debt, the taxing officers of the city shall have authority to continue to levy and collect the tax against the homestead property at the same rate as the tax so pledged until the debt is discharged, if the cessation of the levy would impair the obligation of the contract by which the debt was created. 
(b)  In order to secure the benefit of the exemption, the owner shall comply with provisions of V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.43. 
(Code 1995, § 34.02) 
State Law reference- Taxable property, V.T.C.A., Tax Code §§ 11.01, 11.02; residence homestead exemption, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13; application for exemption, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.43. 
Sec. 62-32. - Residence homestead tax freeze for elderly and disabled people. 
(a)  Definitions . 
    Disabled. Has the same meaning as set forth in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13(m)(1), as it currently exists or may be amended. 
    Residence homestead. Has the same meaning as set forth in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13(j)(1), as it currently exists or may be amended. 
    Tax Code . The Texas Tax Code as it currently exists or may be amended. 
(b)  There is hereby created and established a tax freeze on the amount of ad valorem taxes imposed by the city on residence homesteads of individuals age 65 or older and/or who are disabled, which shall be governed by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.261. 
(Ord. No. 15-04 , § 1, 2-10-2015)

Sec. 62-61. - Levied. 
    There is hereby levied and shall be collected from every person pursuing any occupation taxed by the general laws of the state, or which may be so taxed, an annual occupation tax equal in each instance to one-half the state occupation tax, which tax shall be paid annually in advance, except where otherwise provided by state law, in which event, such tax may be paid as provided by the state law. 
(Code 1995, § 34.20)

Footnotes:

Sec. 62-91. - Telecommunications services tax. 
(a)  Authorization. A tax is hereby authorized on all telecommunications services sold within the city. For purposes of this section, the sale of telecommunications services is consummated at the location of the telephone or other telecommunications device from which the call or other communication originates. If the point of origin cannot be determined, the sale is consummated at the address to which the call or other communication is billed. 
(b)  Repeal of telecommunications exemption. The application of the telecommunications exemption provided for in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210(a) and (b) is hereby repealed by the city as authorized by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210(b). 
(c)  Rate. The rate of tax imposed by this section shall be the same as the rate imposed by the city for all other local sales and use taxes as authorized by the state legislature. 
(Code 1995, §§ 34.30-34.32)

ARTICLE V. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Tax assessor, § 82; tax collector, § 82. 
State Law reference- Hotel occupancy tax, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.001 et seq. 

Sec. 62-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consideration means the cost of a room, sleeping space, bed or dormitory space or the facility in a hotel, and shall not include the cost of food served or personal services rendered to the occupant not related to cleaning and readying such room or space for occupancy, nor any tax assessed for occupancy thereof by any other governmental agency. 
    Hotel means any building in which members of the public obtain sleeping accommodations for a consideration. Such term includes a hotel, motel, tourist home, tourist house, tourist court, lodginghouse, inn, roominghouse or bed and breakfast. Such term does not include: 
(1)  A hospital, sanitarium or nursing home; or 
(2)  A dormitory or other housing facility owned or leased and operated by an "institution of higher education" or a "private or independent institution of higher education," as such terms are defined in V.T.C.A., Education Code § 61.003, used by the institution for the purpose of providing sleeping accommodations for persons engaged in an education program or activity at the institution. 
    Occupancy means the use or possession, or right to the use or possession, of any room, space or sleeping facility in a hotel, for any purpose. 
    Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses or possesses, or has a right to the use or possession of, any room, sleeping space or facility in a hotel, under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract or agreement. 
    Permanent resident means a person who has the right to use or possess a room in a hotel for at least 30 consecutive days, as long as there is no interruption of payment for such period. 
    Person means any individual, company, corporation or association owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel. 
    Quarterly period means a regular quarterly period corresponding to the period which tax reports are filed with the state comptroller. 
(Code 1995, § 34.45) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 62-122. - Levied; rate. 
    There is hereby levied in the city, or within its extraterritorial jurisdiction, a tax of seven percent of the price paid for a room at a hotel which costs $2.00 or more each day and is ordinarily used for sleeping. The tax shall apply to every person who, under a lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract or agreement, pays for the right to use or possess a room that is in a hotel in accordance with the terms of V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.001 et seq. 
(Code 1995, § 34.46(A)) 
Sec. 62-123. - Exemptions; refunds. 
(a)  No tax shall be imposed under this article upon a: 
(1)  Permanent resident. 
(2)  Corporation or association organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational purposes, no part of the net earnings of which enures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual. 
(3)  United States governmental entity described in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 156.103(a). 
(4)  Person who is described by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 156.103(d). 
(b)  A state governmental entity described in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 156.103(b) shall pay the tax imposed by this article, but is entitled to a refund of the tax paid. 
(c)  A person who is described in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 56.103(c) shall pay the tax imposed by this article, but the state governmental entity with whom the person is associated is entitled to a refund of the tax paid. 
(Code 1995, § 34.46(B), (C)) 
State Law reference- Tax authorized exemptions, V.T.C.A., Tax Code §§ 351.002, 351.006. 
Sec. 62-124. - Refund claims. 
(a)  To receive a refund of the tax paid under this article, the governmental entity entitled to the refund must file a refund claim on a form provided by the city, containing the information required by the city. The comptroller, by rule, shall prescribe the form that must be used and the information that must be provided. 
(b)  A governmental entity may file a refund claim with the city under this article only for each calendar quarter for all reimbursements accrued during the quarter. The city may adopt an ordinance to enforce this section. 
Sec. 62-125. - Failure to comply. 
    If any person shall fail to collect the tax imposed by this article, or fail to file a report as required by the state, or fail to tax as imposed in this article, when such report or payment is due, or shall file a false report, then such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed the maximum punishment authorized by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.001 et seq. In addition, such person who fails to remit the tax or violates the reporting provisions imposed by the state and this article, within the time required, shall forfeit an additional 15 percent of such tax, plus the delinquent taxes shall draw interest at the maximum rate permitted by law, and in such event, such person shall be liable to the city for reasonable attorney's fees incurred in the collection of the tax or in compliance with V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 351. 
(Code 1995, § 34.47) 
State Law reference- Misdemeanor authorized, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.004. 
Sec. 62-126. - Filing of reports; payment of tax. 
    On the last day of the month following each quarter, every person required in section 62-127 to collect the tax imposed in this article shall file a report with the city showing the consideration paid for all rooms or sleeping space occupancies in the preceding quarter, the amount of tax collected on such occupancies and any other information the city may reasonably require. Such persons shall pay the tax due on such occupancies at the time of filing such report. 
(Code 1995, § 34.48) 
State Law reference- Use and allocation of revenue, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.101 et seq. 
Sec. 62-127. - Authority to make rules and regulations; access to books and records. 
    The city shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are necessary to effectively collect the tax levied in this article, and, upon reasonable notice, shall have access to books and records necessary to enable the city to determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this article and the amount of taxes due under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1995, § 34.49) 
Secs 62-128-62-160. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY

DIVISION 2. - COIN-OPERATED MACHINES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses and business regulations, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Coin-operated machines, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.001 et seq. 

Sec. 62-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coin-operated machine means any kind of machine or device operated by or with a coin or other United States currency, metal slug, token, electronic card or check, including a music, skill or pleasure coin-operated machine. 
    Music coin-operated machine means any kind of coin-operated machine, including a phonograph, piano or graphophone, which: 
(1)  Dispenses music or is used to dispense music; 
(2)  Is operated by inserting a coin, metal slug, token or check; and 
(3)  Is not an amusement machine designed exclusively for a child. 
    Operator means a person who exhibits or displays, or permits to be exhibited or displayed, a coin-operated machine in the city in a place of business that is not owned by the person. 
    Owner means a person who owns a coin-operated machine in the city. 
    Service coin-operated machine means any kind of machine or device, including a pay toilet or telephone, that dispenses only a service. Such term does not include a machine or device that dispenses merchandise, music, skill or pleasure. 
    Skill or pleasure coin-operated machine means any kind of coin-operated machine that dispenses, or is used, or capable of being used, to dispense or afford amusement, skill or pleasure, or is operated for any purpose other than for dispensing only merchandise, music or a service. Such term: 
(1)  Includes a marble machine, marble table machine, marble shooting machine, miniature racetrack machine, miniature football machine, miniature golf machine, miniature bowling machine, billiard or pool game, or a machine or device that dispenses merchandise or commodities or plays music in connection with or in addition to dispensing skill or pleasure; and 
(2)  Does not include an amusement machine designed exclusively for a child. 
(Code 1995, § 111.01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.002. 
Sec. 62-182. - Imposed; rate. 
(a)  The city does hereby impose an occupation tax on a coin-operated machine. 
(b)  The rate of the tax may not exceed one-fourth of the rate of the tax imposed under V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.401(b). 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.401. 
Sec. 62-183. - Exempt machines. 
    This division does not apply to: 
(1)  A stamp vending machine; 
(2)  A service coin-operated machine; or 
(3)  If subject to an occupation or gross receipts tax, a: 
a.  Gas meter; 
b.  Food vending machine; 
c.  Confection vending machine; 
d.  Beverage vending machine; 
e.  Merchandise vending machine; or 
f.  Cigarette vending machine. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.004. 
Sec. 62-184. - Corporation and association exemption. 
    This division does not apply to: 
(1)  A corporation or association owning, leasing or renting a music, skill or pleasure coin-operated machine if the: 
a.  Corporation or association is organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable, educational or benevolent purposes; 
b.  Corporation's or association's net earnings do not inure to the benefit of a private shareholder or individual; and 
c.  Corporation or association owns, leases or rents the coin-operated machine: 
1.  For the corporation's or association's exclusive use; and 
2.  To further a purpose of the corporation or association. 
(2)  A corporation or association exempt under this section if the assessment of the tax is prohibited by other law. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.005. 
Sec. 62-185. - Private ownership exemption. 
    An individual who owns a music, skill or pleasure coin-operated machine for personal use and amusement in the individual's private residence is not required to obtain a license or pay a tax under this division. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.006. 
Sec. 62-186. - Common carrier exemption. 
    A person subject to regulation by the state railroad commission is not required to obtain a license under this division if the person, in the course of his business, transports or stores a music, skill or pleasure coin-operated machine not owned by him. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.007. 
Sec. 62-187. - Owner and exhibitor exemption. 
    A person who owns or exhibits a coin-operated machine is exempt from the licensing and recordkeeping requirements of this division if the person: 
(1)  Operates or exhibits the coin-operated machine only on the premises occupied by the person and in connection with the person's business; 
(2)  Does not own a coin-operated machine subject to the tax imposed under this division and located on the business premises of another person; and 
(3)  Does not have a direct or indirect financial interest in the music, skill or pleasure coin-operated machine industry, except for ownership of the coin-operated machine operated or exhibited on the premises occupied by the person. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.008. 
Sec. 62-188. - Sealing authorized; release fees. 
    The city may: 
(1)  Seal a coin-operated machine if the tax imposed is not paid; and 
(2)  Charge a fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office for the release of a sealed coin-operated machine. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2153.453. 
Chapter 66 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Abandoned motor vehicles, § 34-171 et seq.; junked vehicles, § 34-201 et seq.; miscellaneous offenses, ch. 42; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; vehicles for hire, ch. 74; traffic control signs, § 90-174. 
State Law reference- Rules of the Road, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code chs. 541-600; general penalty, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.401. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Obstruction of traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, drive or propel a vehicle in a manner so as to block or obstruct the traffic on any street or alley within the city. 
(Code 1995, § 71.02) 
Sec. 66-2. - Obstruction of intersections and crosswalks. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle the driver is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1995, § 71.03) 
Sec. 66-3. - Turns restricted. 
(a)  The city council shall determine the intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right turn, left turn or U-turn, and shall place proper signs at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event, such hours shall be plainly indicated on the signs or may be removed when such turns are permitted. Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right turn, left turn or U-turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such signs. 
(b)  No driver of any vehicle shall make a U-turn at any intersection within the city where a traffic control signal light is suspended and operating. 
(Code 1995, § 71.04) 
Sec. 66-4. - Funeral processions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not a part of a funeral procession to ride or drive a vehicle or walk through or across a funeral procession, or to obstruct the funeral process, or any part thereof. 
(Code 1995, § 71.08) 
Sec. 66-5. - Maximum load on bridges and culverts. 
(a)  The city council shall designate, from time to time, the maximum tonnage permitted on specific bridges located on the city streets, and may forbid the use of any bridge or culvert to any vehicle which, by reason of the weight of the vehicle and its load, would tend to rapidly deteriorate or destroy the bridge or culvert. Notices stating the maximum weight permitted shall be posted at any bridge or culvert sought to be protected. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle, the tonnage of which exceeds the tonnage permitted for any bridge or culvert as set out by the posting of a sign at or near any bridge or culvert in the city, to drive such excessively weighted vehicle across the bridge or culvert. 
(Code 1995, § 71.09) 
Sec. 66-6. - Vehicles on public property. 
    No person shall drive or operate a motor vehicle or otherwise move a vehicle on publicly owned property, except on areas maintained and designated as roads, streets, highways or parking areas for vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1995, § 71.10) 
Sec. 66-7. - Unmuffled compression release engine brakes prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to activate or engage, or to have activated or engaged, any compression release engine braking system in the city limits, unless such engine braking system is connected to a lawful muffler which is adequate to and does prevent the emission of noise which is louder than normal and lawful engine operating noise. Violation of this section shall be punishable in addition to any violation of any other law, ordinance, or regulation governing lawful muffler or sound-muffling systems. As used in this section, the term "compression release braking system" means any engine retarding brake system which alters the normal compression of the engine, thereby converting the engine into an air compressor for the purpose of braking without the use of wheel brakes. 
(b)  Appropriate signs shall be posted at entrances to the city and at other locations determined by the chief of police to be reasonable in order to give notice of the prohibition of the use of compression release engine brakes. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine in an amount not to exceed $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § I(71.11), 5-25-2004) 
Sec. 66-8. - Driving of vehicles on public property. 
    No person shall drive or operate a motor vehicle or otherwise move said vehicle on the publicly owned property except to areas maintained and designated as roads, streets, highways or parking areas for vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 86-49, 10-28-1986) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 86-49 adopted Oct. 28, 1986, amended the Code by adding a new § 17-28; however, said provision has been redesignated as § 66-8, at the editor's discretion, for purposes of maintaining Code format and for purposes of allowing future expansion of the Code. 
Secs. 66-9-66-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING, PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Off-street parking and loading requirements, § 98-631 et seq. 

Sec. 66-41. - Unlawful standing and parking. 
    No person shall allow, suffer or permit any vehicle registered in his name to stand or be parked in, on or upon any street in the city in violation of any of the ordinances of the city regulating the standing or parking of vehicles. 
(Code 1995, § 72.01) 
Sec. 66-42. - Prima facie evidence of parking violation. 
    When any person is charged with having parked or left standing a vehicle on any street in the city at a place on the street where parking of vehicles is prohibited, or with parking such vehicle on a street in a manner which violates the designated manner of parking a vehicle, or with parking a vehicle for a length of time in excess of the time allowed in the space where the vehicle was parked, proof that the vehicle was, at the date of the alleged offense, owned by the person charged with the offense, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the vehicle was parked or left standing at the place charged by the owner, but the owner shall have the right to introduce evidence to show that the vehicle was not parked by him as charged in the complaint. 
(Code 1995, § 72.02) 
State Law reference- Offense by person owning or controlling a vehicle, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.302. 
Sec. 66-43. - Designation of parking zones. 
    The city council shall designate zones in which parking may be prohibited or limited and which are on file in the city secretary's office. It shall be unlawful to park in such zones, except in compliance with posted signs. 
(Code 1995, § 72.03) 
Sec. 66-44. - Parking of unused cars for storage, repair or sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any unused car in any street or alley for the purpose of storage, repair or sale. 
(Code 1995, § 72.04) 
Sec. 66-45. - Commercial vehicles. 
(a)  Prohibitions and limitations. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person or any owner to leave, park or stand any truck tractor, road tractor, truck trailer, semitrailer or any other commercial motor vehicle with a rated capacity in excess of one ton, according to the manufacturer's classification, upon any public street, alley, parkway, boulevard or public place within or adjacent to any area zoned as a single-family residential district, two-family residential district, multiple-family residential district or mobile home district, as established in chapter 98. This subsection shall not prevent the parking or standing of such vehicles in such zoned areas for the purpose of expeditiously loading and unloading passengers, freight or merchandise. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person or owner to leave, park or stand any mobile home, motor home, travel trailer, boat trailer, stock trailer or any other type of trailer upon any public street, alley, parkway or boulevard abutting real property not his own within any area zoned as a single-family residential district, two-family residential district, multiple-family residential district or mobile home district, as established in chapter 98. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant, or his invited guest, owning or occupying real property abutting a portion of any public street, alley, parkway or boulevard within any single-family residential district to leave, park or stand any mobile home, motor home, travel trailer, boat trailer, stock trailer or any other type of trailer on the portion of any public street, alley, parkway or boulevard abutting the real property owned or occupied by such owner or occupant for a continuous period of time longer than 72 hours within any calendar year, or for such owner or occupant to permit, allow or suffer any such mobile home, motor home, travel trailer, boat trailer, stock trailer or any other type of trailer owned by such owner or occupant, or his invited guest, to remain parked or standing on the portion of any public street, alley, parkway or boulevard abutting the real property owned or occupied by the owner or occupant for any continuous period of time longer than 72 hours within any calendar year. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person or owner to leave, park or stand any truck tractor, road tractor, trailer, semitrailer, bus or any other commercial motor vehicle, or any house trailer, boat trailer, stock trailer or any other type of trailer upon any public street, alley, parkway or boulevard in such a manner as to block the flow of traffic upon the public street, alley, parkway or boulevard. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person or owner, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., except Sundays and city holidays, to leave, park or stand any truck tractor, road tractor, truck trailer, semitrailer or other commercial vehicle in any alley situated within the central business district for a continuous period of time longer than 30 minutes. 
(b)  Exceptions. The provisions in subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Street construction, maintenance and repair. Street construction, maintenance and repair trucks, rollers and implements. 
(2)  Public service utilities. Truck equipment, trailers and vehicles used by public service utility companies engaged in repairing or extending public service utilities. 
(3)  Buses. Motorbuses, when taking on or discharging passengers at the customary bus stops. 
(4)  Loading zones. All other vehicles designated in subsection (a) of this section, when actually parked at a designated loading zone in the areas of limited parking where loading zones are designated. 
(5)  Emergency repairs. Any vehicle defined or designated in subsection (a) of this section developing a mechanical defect after such vehicle has commenced to run, en route, making it unsafe to proceed further, and in such event, it shall be lawful to stand or park the vehicle during the time necessary to make emergency repairs. 
(Code 1995, § 72.05) 
Sec. 66-46. - Parking in alleys in business district. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in any alley within the business district. 
(Code 1995, § 72.06) 
Sec. 66-47. - Overnight parking at Brownwood Coliseum. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person having the possession, direction, operation or control of any vehicle of whatever character to leave such vehicle parked and unattended, after 12:00 midnight of any day, upon the parking lot located at the Brownwood Coliseum or the parking lot controlled by the Brownwood Coliseum and located at the intersection of Carnegie and Baker Streets. 
(b)  The manager of the Brownwood Coliseum, however, shall have the power to issue permits to permit overnight parking for vehicles operated by persons leasing the Brownwood Coliseum. Such permits shall be valid for 24 hours prior to the date of the first performance and for 24 hours after the last performance and utilization of such facility. 
(Code 1995, § 72.07) 
Sec. 66-48. - Parking areas. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parking area means a privately owned or publicly owned accessway or parking area commonly used by the general public, without charge, and maintained for the convenience of customers, clients or patrons of one or more business establishments or public offices. 
(b)  Prohibited uses of motor vehicles. No person in control or possession of a motor vehicle in a parking area may: 
(1)  Accelerate or race the motor of a vehicle so as to cause a loud noise in a manner calculated to disturb the persons present; 
(2)  Bring a motor vehicle to a sudden start or stop, or blow the horn of the vehicle, when there is no necessity for the protection of a person or property, in such a manner calculated to disturb the persons present; or 
(3)  Hold a race or contest for speed with another motor vehicle without the written consent of the parking area owner or his authorized representative. 
(c)  Prohibited acts. No person in a parking area may: 
(1)  Fight with another person; 
(2)  Use loud, obscene, vulgar or indecent language, or swear, curse, yell or shriek in such a manner calculated to disturb the persons present; 
(3)  Throw any object which is capable of causing bodily harm or property damage at another person or property with the intent to injure or damage; 
(4)  Congregate with another person, or loiter after entering the premises, and willfully refuse to leave after having been notified to leave by the owner or the person in possession and control of the premises or his agent. 
(d)  Littering prohibited. No person may throw or deposit any trash, litter or other waste on a parking area. 
(Code 1995, § 92.08) 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.01. 
Sec. 66-49. - Private off-street disability parking spaces. 
(a)  Private off-street disability parking spaces, which are exclusively for vehicles which display the distinguishing license plates, specially designated symbols, tags or other devices issued to disabled veterans and other persons with disabilities pursuant to state or federal law, shall have the dimensions and markings required by prevailing state and federal standards. Such stalls or spaces shall be designated by posting appropriate signage, at the owner's expense. Appropriate signage shall include any sign in or immediately adjacent to and visible from each stall or space, consisting of wording or symbols, or a combination thereof, which conveys to a person of ordinary intelligence that the stalls or spaces indicated are reserved for persons with disabilities. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle not displaying a distinguishing license plate symbol, tag or device issued to persons with disabilities pursuant to state or federal law to stop, stand, park or leave standing such vehicle in any space designated for the exclusive use of persons with disabilities pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Any vehicle not displaying the proper license plate, tag or device may be towed from a disability parking space designated by subsection (a) of this section, at the expense of the owner of such vehicle, and may be impounded until towing and storage charges are paid. 
(d)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine as provided in section 1-14. Repeat offenders shall be subject to higher fines in accordance with applicable state law. 
(Ord. No. 00-14, pt. 1, 3-28-2000) 
Sec. 66-50. - Loading zones. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Loading zone means a space or section of the street next to the curb which has been set aside for the exclusive use of loading and unloading persons, supplies and merchandise. 
(b)  Designation and utilization. The city council shall cause loading and unloading spaces or loading zones to be designated for the convenience and regulation of the traffic in the city within the areas in which it regulates parking for any designated period of time. Such loading zones as the city council may from time to time designate shall be clearly marked, and shall be used only for loading and unloading. Such zones are for the convenience of all persons needing loading and unloading facilities in the block in which such zone is located, and are not for the exclusive use of any one person. Any person having control of a vehicle, and who shall park such vehicle in any zone designated as a loading zone for a period of time longer than 15 minutes before or 15 minutes after the time when such vehicle is actually in the process of loading or unloading, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1995, § 72.09) 
Sec. 66-51. - Authority to impound. 
    The police department shall have the authority to impound any vehicle parked in violation of the provisions of this article, and shall tow such vehicle from the location. Such vehicle shall be impounded until the owner or person in charge of such vehicle shall pay the applicable towing and impounding fees for release of the vehicle. 
(Code 1995, § 72.10)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Permit required for extension or alteration of mains. 
    Any extension or alteration of any fixture or connection with the water or sewer mains must be done under a permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1995, § 51.01) 
Sec. 70-2. - Access to premises for inspection. 
    The city manager, health officer, director of utilities or any other city officer shall have access to any part of the premises of a city water consumer, at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of examining anything connected with the waterworks or sewers of the city. 
(Code 1995, §§ 51.02, 52.02) 
Sec. 70-3. - Determination of rates. 
    The rates for the sale of water and sewer service shall be determined by the city council and are on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 51.03)

ARTICLE II. - SANITARY SEWER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-31. - Toilet access required upon city property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to camp, reside, live upon or conduct any business whatsoever upon any place, public or private, within the corporate limits of the city or on any other property belonging to the city, whether within the city limits or not, where there is no toilet accessible to persons camping, residing, living upon or conducting a business on such property. 
(Code 1995, § 52.01) 
Secs. 70-32-70-50. - Reserved.

Sec. 70-51. - Required. 
(a)  All structures located in the city and intended for human habitation or occupancy, containing sinks, toilets, bathtubs, urinals or other waste discharging devices, situated on a lot, the lot line of which is within 100 feet of any public sewer, shall be connected to the public sewer. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with this section. 
(Code 1995, § 52.15) 
Charter reference- Power to require connection to the sanitary sewer and water systems, §§ 13, 20. 
Sec. 70-52. - Separate connections required; exception. 
    Every building shall be separately and independently connected with the main or lateral sewer, except when otherwise ordered or allowed by the city manager. 
(Code 1995, § 52.16) 
Sec. 70-53. - Taps. 
    No person, except the director of utilities or his authorized agent, shall tap any sewer main belonging to the city. 
(Code 1995, § 52.18(D)) 
Sec. 70-54. - Responsibility for costs. 
    The cost of installing a sanitary flush toilet, tapping costs and costs connecting to the public sewer system shall be borne by the owner of the property on which the improvement is to be located. 
(Code 1995, § 52.19)
