Charter reference- Power to provide for a water system, §§ 13, 20. 

Sec. 70-271. - Connection required. 
    All structures intended for human habitation or occupancy, situated on a lot, the lot line of which is within 100 feet of any public water supply, shall be connected to the public water supply. 
(Code 1995, § 53.34) 
Sec. 70-272. - Water meters required. 
    Water sold to city consumers shall be metered. 
(Code 1995, § 53.45) 
Sec. 70-273. - Water meter ownership, control and maintenance; consumer responsibility; meter access. 
(a)  All water meters shall be owned or controlled and kept in repair by the city; however, any damage done to the case of a meter, meter connections or the dial or working parts of the meter, which shows evidence of having been either carelessly or maliciously handled, shall be paid for by the consumer, and until the cost or expense of repairing such damage has been paid by the consumer, the water shall be cut off, and all water service withheld from such consumer. The consumer shall further be held responsible for the upkeep of such meter, other than the ordinary wear and tear from water running through the meter. 
(b)  City personnel must have access to read and maintain water meters. It is unlawful to block, impair or impede meter access. It is unlawful for any person to store or maintain any goods, merchandise, material, or refuse, or install equipment over any water meter in use on any water meter connection of the city. It is unlawful to park a motor vehicle over, upon, or in such a manner as to prevent access to any water meter, gate valve, or other appliance in use on any water meter connection of the city regardless of whether such city property is located on public or private property. It is unlawful to restrain a dog in an area adjacent to, or near, a water meter which would make it hazardous to the meter reader's health and safety to access the water meter in use on any water meter connection of the city. Whenever it is necessary to enter a building to read the meter or work on the water connections, a safe passageway must be maintained by the occupant of the premises, free and clear of obstructions from the entrance of the building to the meter. Shrubs and landscaping shall not obstruct reading of the meter. Any obstructions may be trimmed or removed by the city, including the towing of any vehicle, and the owner or occupant of the premises may be charged the service fees and costs to remove any obstructions as prescribed in the city's annual utility rate ordinance, a copy of which is maintained in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 53.46; Ord. No. 13-31, § 1, 9-24-2013) 
Sec. 70-274. - Deposit. 
    When application for water service is made, a cash deposit shall be made in an amount as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. Such deposit shall guarantee the payment of all charges for utilities and related expenses. Such deposit shall be returned to the customer at any time written notice is given of the intention to discontinue water service, less any amount due under such account. 
(Code 1995, § 53.15) 
Sec. 70-275. - Right to shut off; liability for damages; shared stop boxes. 
(a)  The city reserves the right to shut off any consumer's water, at any time, without notice, for the purpose of making repairs, for scarcity of water or any other unavoidable cause, and the city shall not be liable for damages in any case. 
(b)  In all cases where water consumers shall negligently allow water to waste, the water of such consumer may be cut off by the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  In all cases where water is supplied to several consumers from one connection, with the supply controlled by one stop box, and the city has contracted with only one of such consumers, such consumer shall be responsible for any failure on the part of the other consumers to comply with all regulations relative to water service. 
(Code 1995, § 53.16) 
Sec. 70-276. - Authority for service charge for unauthorized turn-on of disconnected meter. 
    The city is authorized to impose a service charge, as established by the utility rate ordinance on file in the city secretary's office for installing a meter cutoff device, upon the unauthorized turn-on of water which has been disconnected for nonpayment. 
(Code 1995, § 53.17) 
State Law reference- Theft of service, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 31.04. 
Sec. 70-277. - Main and pipe extensions. 
    No person, except the director of utilities, shall extend any city water main or pipe. 
(Code 1995, § 53.30) 
Sec. 70-278. - Cost of line extensions. 
    The cost of all water line extensions shall be borne by the person requesting such extension, except for cost recovery policies established by the city council from time to time. 
(Code 1995, § 53.30(C)) 
Sec. 70-279. - Applications for service. 
    Persons desiring to obtain water service shall submit an application, in writing, to the city manager on a form furnished by the city manager for such purpose. Such application shall give the lot and block number, and the street and house number to be connected, and shall provide that neither the city waterworks, nor any employee thereof, shall be responsible for any damage by water or other damage resulting from defective plumbing, broken or faulty service or water mains, or any condition of the water itself, or any substance that may be mixed with or be in the water delivered to the consumer. Such application shall further state the purposes for which water is required, and shall fully describe each fixture on the premises attached to such service. 
(Code 1995, § 53.31) 
Sec. 70-280. - Interference with mains and standpipes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with any water main or standpipe. 
(Code 1995, § 53.32) 
Sec. 70-281. - Customer cutoff valves. 
    Water consumers shall be required to install a customer cutoff valve, at their own expense, in water pipes on their property. No water shall be supplied to such customer unless the customer cutoff valve is installed. 
(Code 1995, § 53.33) 
Sec. 70-282. - Use of fire hydrants. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except authorized city employees, to take water from fire hydrants on the city water system without obtaining a special permit as set forth in this section. 
(b)  A permit may be obtained by placing the prescribed deposit at the utility office of city hall. Upon receipt of such deposit, the applicable meter and fittings will be issued by the director of utilities' office in the service center. 
(c)  The contractor or person securing the permit will be responsible for the meter, valve, fittings and hydrant. If repairs are needed on a meter, valve or hydrant, due to misuse or freezing, the contractor or person securing the permit will be billed for the repair. Should the meter, valve and/or fittings be stolen, the deposit will be forfeited. 
(d)  The contractor or person securing the permit may move a meter to various locations, but when such meter is moved, the water office at city hall must be notified. Failure to notify the water office of such move shall cause the cancellation of the permit. 
(e)  If a connection is made on a faulty hydrant, a report of the faulty hydrant will be made to the water office at city hall. 
(f)  Meters will be read as required, and the contractor or permit holder will be billed for water used, and be responsible for all water taken through the meter. The monthly rate, by volume, shall be in accordance with the rate set out in the water charge rate ordinance in effect at that time. 
(g)  (1)  The procedure for securing water from a fire hydrant will be to open the fire hydrant to the full open position by use of the operating nut, at the beginning of each day. The valve will be used for base use and filling tanks. At the termination of the day, the operating nut on the fire hydrant will be completely closed. Should violations of this procedure be observed, the permit holder will be notified of the violation. Should the permit holder not comply in correcting the violation, the city will terminate the permit and remove the meter, valve and fitting from the hydrant, and the deposit will be forfeited. 
(2)  At the termination of a permit, the meter, valve, fittings and wrench will be returned to the city. The meter will be read and checked by the water department personnel for possible damage. After final billing for water consumption, and meter and valve repairs have been paid, the city will refund the balance of the deposit for the permit. 
(Code 1995, § 53.05) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
Sec. 70-283. - Water conservation and drought contingency plan. 
(a)  A water conservation and drought contingency plan for the city (the "2018 Plan"), entitled Water Conservation and Drought Contingency Plan 2018 attached [to the ordinance from which this section derives] as exhibit A, is hereby adopted and incorporated in this section by reference as if set out herein. The provisions of the 2018 Plan are hereby ordained and enacted, and are expressly made a part of this section. The 2018 Plan is on file in the city secretary's office. 
(b)  No person or entity shall knowingly or intentionally allow the use of water from the city for residential, commercial, institutional, industrial, agricultural, governmental, recreational, wholesale, or any other purpose in a manner contrary to any provision of the 2018 Plan, or in an amount in excess of that permitted by the drought response stage in effect at the time pursuant to action taken by the city manager or his/her designee, in accordance with provisions of the 2018 Plan. 
(c)  Any water customer who violates the 2018 Plan is guilty of and may be charged with a misdemeanor and, upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00. Each day that one or more of the provisions in the 2018 Plan is violated shall constitute a separate offense. Proof of a culpable mental state is not required for a conviction of an offense under this section. If a person is convicted of three or more distinct violations of the 2018 Plan, the city manager or his/her designee shall, upon due notice to the customer, be authorized to discontinue water service to the premises where such violations occur. Services discontinued under such circumstances shall be restored only upon payment of a re-connection charge, hereby initially established at $35.00 but may be amended by the city's annual fee ordinance, and any other costs incurred by the city in discontinuing service. In addition, suitable assurance must be documented with the city manager or his/her designee that the same action shall not be repeated while the 2013 Plan is in effect. Compliance with the 2018 Plan may also be sought through injunctive relief in the district court. 
(d)  The following employees of the city, police officers and code enforcement officers, may issue a citation to a person he/she reasonably believes to be in violation of the plan and/or this section. The alleged violator shall be served a copy of the citation. Service of the citation shall be complete upon delivery of the citation to the alleged violator, to an agent or employee of a violator, or to a person over 18 years of age who is a member of the violator's immediate family or is a resident of the violator's residence. The alleged violator shall appear in municipal court to enter a plea of guilty or not guilty for the violation of the plan. If the alleged violator fails to appear in municipal court, a warrant for his/her arrest may be issued. A summons to appear may be issued in lieu of an arrest warrant. 
(e)  A city code enforcement officer, police officer, or other official designated by the city manager or his/her designee, may issue a written notice of violation to a person or entity he/she reasonably believes to be in violation of this plan. For subsequent violations following written notice: 
(1)  The city may issue a citation (Class C misdemeanor); 
(2)  The city may install a flow restricting device in the line to limit the amount of water which will pass through the meter in a 24-hour period. The city may charge the customer for the actual cost of installing and removing the flow restricting device, not to exceed $50.00, such amount may be amended by the City's annual fee ordinance; 
(3)  The city may discontinue service at the meter pursuant to paragraph (c) for a period of seven days, or until the end of the calendar month, whichever is less. The normal reconnect fee of the utility will apply for restoration of service. 
(f)  Any person in apparent control of the property where a violation occurs or originates shall be presumed to be the violator, and proof that the violation occurred on the person's property shall constitute a rebuttable presumption that the person in apparent control of the property committed the violation, but any such person shall have the right to show that he/she did not commit the violation. Parents shall be presumed to be responsible for violations of their minor children and proof that a violation, committed by a child, occurred on property within the parents' control shall constitute a rebuttable presumption that the parent committed the violation, but any such parent may be excused if he/she proves that he/she had previously directed the child not to use the water as it was used in violation of the 2018 Plan and that the parent could not have reasonably known of the violation. 
(Code 1995, § 33.10; Ord. No. 12-10, §§ 2, 3, 6-12-2012; Ord. No. 13-25, § 2, 3, 8-13-2013; Ord. No. 18-14 , § 3, 7-10-2018) 
Chapter 74 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power to regulate vehicles for hire, § 20. 
Cross reference- Businesses and business regulations, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; traffic and vehicles, ch. 66. 
State Law reference- Power to license, fix the charges and fares, and regulate vehicles for hire, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.073. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL VEHICLES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency medical services, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 773.001 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Attendant means a trained and/or qualified individual who is responsible for the operation of an ambulance and the care of the patients, whether or not the attendant also serves as the driver. 
    Attendant driver means a person who is qualified as an attendant and a driver. 
    Emergency medical service has the meaning as defined in V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 773.003 and, in addition, shall expressly include any non-emergency transfer services provided by an emergency medical vehicle. 
    Emergency medical vehicle has the meaning as defined in V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 773.003 and, in addition, shall expressly include any such vehicle used for non-emergency transfer services. 
    License means a license of public convenience and necessity. 
    Non-emergency transfer services shall mean any circumstance in which a patient is transported by an emergency medical vehicle under circumstances which are or have been represented to be of a non-emergency nature. 
(Code 1995, § 113.01; Ord. No. 11-16, § 2, 9-6-2011) 
Sec. 74-32. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any emergency medical vehicle or emergency medical service, or the driver or attendant of any emergency medical vehicle which is: 
(1)  Rendering assistance to patients in case of a major catastrophe or emergency with which the licensed emergency medical vehicles of the city are unable to cope; 
(2)  Transporting a patient who is picked up from a location beyond the limits of the city and transported to a location within the city; 
(3)  Transporting a patient who is picked up from a location beyond the limits of the city and transported to a location beyond the limits of the city and only incidentally passing through the city; or 
(4)  Transporting a patient picked up from a hospital or clinic within the limits of the city and transported to a location beyond the limits of the city, provided that the emergency medical vehicle or emergency medical service initially transported the patient to the same hospital or clinic and is making a return trip. 
(5)  Rendering emergency medical services to citizens of the city pursuant to a contract entered into by and between Brown County and/or the City of Brownwood and an emergency medical services provider for the provision of such services. 
(6)  Providing mutual aid to the emergency medical services provider who contracts with Brown County and/or the City of Brownwood to provide emergency medical services to the citizens of the city (the "contracted provider"), provided such mutual aid is requested by the contracted provider. 
(Code 1995, § 113.02; Ord. No. 11-16, § 2, 9-6-2011; Ord. No. 16-01 , § 2, 1-12-2016) 
Secs. 74-33-74-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 74-51. - Required. 
    No person shall operate an emergency medical vehicle or emergency medical service upon the streets of the city without first obtaining a license of public convenience and necessity from the city council. No license shall be granted until after the publication of a notice and public hearing under the procedures set forth in this division. 
(Code 1995, § 113.03(A)) 
Sec. 74-52. - Exception. 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to any emergency medical vehicle operated by any agent or employee of the federal or state government, or an agency thereof, if the service is done in the performance of such agent's or employee's official duties. 
(Code 1995, § 113.03(B)) 
Sec. 74-53. - Applications. 
    Every application for a license required by this division shall be in writing, signed and sworn by the applicant, and shall be filed with the city. The application shall be on a form provided by the city and shall contain the following: 
(1)  If the applicant is a corporation, or proposes or intends to do business as a corporation, the application shall contain: 
a.  The corporate name. 
b.  The place and date of incorporation. 
c.  The names and addresses of the incorporators. 
d.  The names, addresses and corporate titles of all corporate officers. 
e.  The name and address of the corporate registered agent. 
f.  The names and addresses of all persons owning or otherwise holding as much as ten percent of any corporate stock. 
(2)  If the applicant is a partnership or association, or proposes or intends to do business as a partnership or association, the application shall contain: 
a.  The name of the partnership or association. 
b.  The names and addresses of all partners or associates, whether limited or general. 
(3)  If the applicant is a private person or sole proprietor, the application shall contain: 
a.  The applicant's name and address. 
b.  Any trade or other fictitious name under which the applicant does, or proposes to do, business. 
(4)  The number of vehicles the applicant proposes to operate, together with a description of each vehicle, when available, including the make, model, year of manufacture, state license number for the current year, motor and chassis number, and the length of time the vehicle has been in use. 
(5)  The location and description of the places from which it is intended the vehicle shall be operated. 
(6)  Verification that a copy of the applicant's state emergency medical vehicle license has been filed with the city prior to operation. 
(7)  A schedule of the proposed rates to be charged by the applicant. 
(8)  Copies of all insurance policies required under this division, a certificate of insurance evidencing that policies are in force or a binding agreement to obtain coverage prior to the commencement of service. 
(9)  A complete and up-to-date financial statement of the applicant, partnership, every partner or associate, and, if the applicant is a corporation, a complete and up-to-date balance sheet of the corporation. 
(10)  A complete list of the names and addresses of all persons employed by the applicant, whether full-time or part-time. 
(11)  Such other information as the city shall determine to be reasonably necessary to a fair determination of the applicant's qualifications to operate an emergency medical service in the city. 
(Code 1995, § 113.03(C)) 
Sec. 74-54. - Public hearing; notice given to the applicant and public. 
    Within 30 days after the receipt of an application for a license under this division, the city council shall cause a public hearing to be held concerning the application. Notice of the hearing shall be given, in writing, to the applicant and all persons holding licenses for emergency medical service in the city. Notice shall be given to the public by publication in a newspaper published in the city, not less than ten days prior to the date of the public hearing. 
(Code 1995, § 113.03(D)) 
Sec. 74-55. - Ascertaining public convenience and necessity. 
    In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the licensing of a proposed emergency medical service, the city council shall consider: 
(1)  Whether the public is, at the time, adequately served; 
(2)  The financial responsibility of the applicant; 
(3)  The number, kind and type of equipment to be operated by the applicant; 
(4)  A schedule of rates proposed to be charged; 
(5)  Whether the safe use of the streets by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be preserved; and 
(6)  Such other facts as the city council shall consider relevant. 
(Code 1995, § 113.03(E)) 
Sec. 74-56. - Prerequisites to issuance. 
    The city council shall not grant any license under this division unless it finds that: 
(1)  The public convenience and necessity require the proposed emergency medical service for which the application has been submitted, and that service would not adversely affect total emergency medical service to the people of the city, nor the overall quality thereof. 
(2)  The applicant has procured or submitted a binding agreement to provide emergency medical vehicles and equipment, complying with the standards required in this article. 
(3)  The applicant has procured or submitted a binding agreement to secure insurance, as required by this division. 
(4)  The applicant and all attendants, drivers and attendant drivers are fit and proper persons to conduct the proposed emergency medical service. 
(5)  All the requirements of this article, all other applicable ordinances of the city and state laws have been met by the applicant. 
(Code 1995, § 113.03(F)) 
Sec. 74-57. - Conditional licenses. 
(a)  License subject to compliance with division. A conditional license may be granted subject to the applicant complying with all of the conditions of this division, but any applicant granted a conditional license who has not fulfilled all of the conditions of this division shall not go into operation until all of the conditions are fulfilled and all of the information required by this division has been filed with the city secretary. 
(b)  Expiration. All conditional licenses granted subject to the fulfillment of the conditions of this division shall expire and be null and void if the applicant has not complied with all conditions in ten days from the date of the issuance of the license. 
(c)  Reapplication. If the conditions are not met in ten days, the applicant must reapply to the city council for a new license. 
(d)  Request to consider applicant compliance. Should a question arise as to the applicant's compliance with this division, where a license has been granted subject to certain conditions being met, the applicant may request a hearing before the city council, which shall consider the applicant's license and may revoke or grant the license if the applicant has complied with all of the conditions of this division. 
(e)  Failure to meet conditions for reissuance. An applicant who previously has been given a conditional license subject to meeting certain conditions and has failed to meet the conditions will not be issued another conditional license, subject to the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1995, § 113.04) 
Sec. 74-58. - Insurance requirements. 
(a)  Minimum coverage. An applicant for a license required by this division shall file with his application an insurance policy, to be approved by the city attorney, providing insurance coverage for each and every emergency medical vehicle owned, operated and/or leased by the applicant for injury to or death of persons in accidents resulting from any cause for which the owner of the vehicle would be liable on account of any liability imposed on him by law, regardless of whether the emergency medical vehicle was being driven by the owner, his agent or lessee, and against damage to the property of another, including personal property under similar circumstances, in sums as may be approved by the city attorney or the minimum amount as prescribed by the state torts claim act or applicable statute. 
(b)  Continuance after recovery. Every policy of insurance shall continue to the full amount of such policy, notwithstanding any recovery thereon, and the liability of the insurer shall not be affected by the insolvency or bankruptcy of the assured. The policy shall run to the city for the benefit of any and all judgment creditors. 
(c)  Coverage period. Every insurance policy required under this section shall extend for the period to be covered by the license applied for, and the insurer shall be obliged to give not less than 30 days' written notice to the city and the assured before any cancellation or termination of the policy earlier than its expiration date, and the cancellation or other termination of any policy shall automatically revoke and terminate the licenses issued for the emergency medical vehicles covered by the policy, unless another insurance policy complying with the provisions of this section shall be provided and be in effect at the time of such cancellation or termination. 
(Code 1995, § 113.05) 
Sec. 74-59. - Revocation or suspension. 
(a)  Every license issued under this division shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the city council when it shall appear that: 
(1)  The operator has failed or neglected to render the full service authorized by his license. 
(2)  The operator has been convicted of a felony or any criminal offense involving moral turpitude. 
(3)  The license was obtained by an application in which any material fact was omitted or stated falsely. 
(4)  The operator has persisted in permitting his vehicles to be operated in violation of any law. 
(5)  The operator has failed to comply with, or willfully or knowingly violated, any of the provisions of this article. 
(6)  The operator has given or allowed a rebate commission or any reduced rate discount not provided for in the established rates. 
(7)  The operator or his agent has induced, or sought to induce, a change of destination to or from a hospital or other place specified by the person hiring the emergency medical vehicle. 
(8)  The operator or his agent has knowingly received any payment, favor or gratuity from any mortuary operating in the city for the purpose of inducing any person transported by the operator or his agent to utilize the services of the mortuary, and no emergency medical vehicle operator shall engage in or have any financial interest in a mortuary service. 
(9)  The operator allows his insurance, as provided for in this division, to be canceled, withdrawn or terminated. 
(10)  The operator allows his vehicles or equipment to become damaged, deteriorated or unclean to the extent that it is unfit for public use, in the judgment of the city. 
(b)  Proceedings for the revocation or suspension of a license shall be undertaken by the city council in the same manner as proceedings for issuance of a license. All complaints shall be referred to the city manager, who shall cause an investigation to be made prior to any action for revocation or suspension, and the city secretary shall give ten days' notice thereof, by certified mail, to the operator holding the license that the action will be considered at a certain date, which shall not be less than 30 days from the date of the notice. The city council shall thereupon undertake to consider the complaint and either revoke or suspend the license or dismiss the complaint. 
(Code 1995, § 113.06) 
Secs. 74-60-74-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 74-81. - Qualifications of attendants. 
    Attendants shall have qualifications as required by the state department of health. 
(Code 1995, § 113.07) 
Sec. 74-82. - Provision of 24-hour service. 
(a)  Certification and licensing by the state department of health required. No person within the city shall operate any emergency medical vehicle upon the public streets of the city unless and until the emergency medical vehicle has been certified and licensed for such usage by the state department of health. 
(b)  License holder to provide emergency medical service. Every license holder shall be required to provide immediate emergency medical service 24 hours a day, each and every day. 
(Code 1995, §§ 113.08, 113.09) 
Sec. 74-83. - Prompt service required. 
    Every call for emergency medical service shall be answered promptly. Patients shall be loaded and transported without being subjected to unreasonable delays. 
(Code 1995, § 113.10) 
Secs. 74-84-74-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TAXICABS AND LIMOUSINES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- State mandate to license, control and regulate taxicabs, including establishment of safety and insurance requirements, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.004. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Limousine service means service which is chartered or reserved by the customer well in advance of the time the service is rendered. 
    Taxicab and limousine mean all vehicles which transport passengers for hire, except only the classes of vehicles which are specifically excluded by section 74-122. 
    Taxicab service means service which is rendered in prompt response to the receipt of a request for such service from the customer. Such requests are typically received in one of the following ways: 
(1)  By telephone, in which case a dispatcher forwards the customer's request to a taxicab driver via two-way radio as soon as a taxicab vehicle is available to respond. 
(2)  By direct contact, in which case the customer communicates directly with the driver of a taxicab waiting at a motel, hotel, airport, bus terminal or similar location. 
(3)  By direct contact, in which case a customer hails or flags down a passing taxicab. 
(Code 1995, § 113.20) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-122. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Emergency medical services. 
(2)  Automobile or truck leasing operations in which the leased or rented vehicle is driven by the customer or his agent. 
(3)  Vehicles operating under a permit or certificate of the state railroad commission or the Federal Interstate Commerce Commission. 
(4)  Vehicles owned or operated by motels, hotels and other businesses for transporting their guests or employees. This article shall apply, however, to other companies or individuals providing such service under a contract with the motels, hotels or other businesses. 
(5)  Transportation of people where the taxicab or limousine is licensed by another governmental entity from a point outside the city to a destination inside the city if the taxicab or limousine leaves the city without receiving a passenger inside the city. 
(Code 1995, § 113.21) 
Sec. 74-123. - Rates and fares. 
(a)  All meter rates and fares shall be established by the taxicab service. 
(b)  Each taxicab operated in the city shall have affixed thereto at a location in plain view of any passenger therein a placard setting out the meter rates and fares for taxicab service. The rates and fares shall be readily visible to and legible by any occupant of such taxicab and, at a minimum, must be posted on each window of the taxicab where passengers enter the taxicab and on the inside compartment of the taxicab in prominent locations for all passengers to see. 
(c)  The rate of fare for trips made by taxicabs shall be determined by an approved taximeter. It shall be unlawful for any permit holder, owner, operator or driver of any taxicab to operate or allow or cause to be operated or driven any taxicab on the streets of the city unless the same is equipped with a taximeter approved by the city and calibrated for the computation of fares at the posted rates as provided herein. It shall be the duty of every permit holder, owner, operator or driver using any taximeter to keep the same accurate at all times, and the failure to do so shall constitute a violation of this article. All taximeters shall be subject to inspection at any time by the city. 
(d)  Nothing in this section precludes a permit holder, owner, operator or driver of any taxicab from agreeing to make a flat rate charge for a trip to a destination, provided that such flat rate is either agreed to in writing with the passenger or responsible paying party or the flat rate is established prior to trip commencement and the rate is not in excess of the maximum meter rate as posted. 
(Code 1995, § 113.25; Ord. No. 06-02, § I, 1-10-2005) 
Secs. 74-124-74-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 74-141. - Required. 
    No person shall operate or dispatch, or cause to be operated or dispatched, a taxicab or limousine without being properly licensed by the city under the procedures set forth in this division. 
(Code 1995, § 113.22(A)) 
Sec. 74-142. - Classifications; fee. 
(a)  Type of license. Licenses shall be issued under this division in three classifications: 
(1)  Operating license. The operating license classification shall authorize the operation of one or more vehicles which are owned or controlled by the licensee, provided that each vehicle has a vehicle permit as set forth in division 3 of this article, and each driver thereof has a driver's permit as set forth in division 4 of this article. 
(2)  Dispatching license. The dispatching license classification shall authorize the operation of a dispatch service, which receives requests for taxicab service by telephone or other means and then forwards the request by two-way radio to a taxicab. 
(3)  Combined operating/dispatching license. The combined operating/dispatching license classification shall authorize both of the activities described in subsections (a)(1) and (2) of this section. 
(b)  Prescription, refund of fee. The fee for any such license shall be as prescribed by city council from time to time and on file in the city secretary's office. No portion of the fee shall be refunded if the license is terminated. 
(Code 1995, § 113.22(B)) 
Sec. 74-143. - Applications. 
    Every application for a license required by this division shall be in writing, signed and sworn by the applicant, and filed with the city manager. The application shall be on a form provided by the city manager and shall contain the following: 
(1)  All classifications of licenses. 
a.  If the applicant is a corporation, or proposes or intends to do business as a corporation, the application shall contain: 
1.  The corporate name. 
2.  The place and date of incorporation. 
3.  A certificate of corporate existence and of good standing. 
b.  If the applicant is a partnership or association, or proposes or intends to do business as a partnership or association, the application shall contain: 
1.  The name of the partnership or association. 
2.  The names and addresses of all partners or associates, whether limited or general. 
c.  If the applicant is a private person or sole proprietor, and proposes or intends to do business as a private person or sole proprietor, the application shall contain: 
1.  The applicant's name and address. 
2.  Any trade or other fictitious name under which the applicant does, or proposes to do, business. 
d.  Any other information that the city manager or city council considers necessary for implementation or enforcement of the regulations set forth in this article. 
(2)  Additional requirements. 
a.  For operating or combined operating/dispatching licenses. 
1.  The number of vehicles the applicant proposes to operate, together with a description of each such vehicle, when available, including the make, model, model year and state license plate number. 
2.  Copies of all insurance policies required under this division, a certificate of insurance evidencing that such policies are in force or a binding agreement to obtain coverage prior to commencement of service. 
b.  For dispatching or combined operating/dispatching licenses. 
1.  The location and telephone numbers of all offices from which dispatching operations will be conducted. 
2.  A description of the system by which calls for service will be transmitted to individual taxicabs or limousines, including all two-way radio frequencies to be used, along with corresponding FCC license numbers. 
(Code 1995, § 113.22(C)) 
Sec. 74-144. - Insurance requirements. 
(a)  Minimum coverage. 
(1)  Operating and combined operating/dispatching licenses. Applicants for operating or combined operating/dispatching licenses shall furnish evidence of vehicle liability insurance currently in effect as part of their application. Evidence of such insurance shall be in the form of a properly executed certificate of insurance or a certified copy of the insurance policy, and shall be written through an insurance company approved by the city attorney. The insurance shall clearly evidence coverage for each and every vehicle to be licensed or permitted, and shall provide coverage for personal injury and property damage, and types and amounts of coverage with minimum limits set by the city council. The policy shall include a requirement that 30 days' advance written notice of cancellation or material change of such policy be provided to the city manager. Minimum amounts notwithstanding, the city reserves the right to increase the minimum required insurance to be effective 90 days after notice is sent to a holder of a license. 
(2)  Taxicabs. 
a.  Type. Comprehensive auto, or business auto, liability insurance, covering all owned/leased vehicles and all hired vehicles. 
b.  Amount (limits of liability). State minimum amounts, as prescribed by the state board of insurance. 
(3)  Limousines. 
a.  Type. Comprehensive auto, or business auto, liability insurance, covering all owned/leased vehicles and all hired vehicles. 
b.  Amount (limits of liability). State minimum amounts, as prescribed by the state board of insurance. 
(b)  Policy to comply with change in state standards. Should the state board of insurance adopt changes to policies of insurance required by this section, the holder of a license shall be required, on issuance of the next policy, to comply with the newly adopted insurance standards. 
(Code 1995, § 113.22(D)) 
State Law reference- Minimum coverage amounts, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 601.072. 
Sec. 74-145. - Assignability. 
    Licenses shall be issued to a person and shall not be assignable. 
(Code 1995, § 113.22(E)) 
Sec. 74-146. - Terms. 
    The term of all licenses shall be for 24 months. 
(Code 1995, § 113.22(F)) 
Sec. 74-147. - Revocation and suspension. 
(a)  Every license issued under this division shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the city manager for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The operator has been convicted of a felony or any criminal offense involving moral turpitude. 
(2)  The license was obtained by an application in which any material fact was omitted or stated falsely. 
(3)  The operator has persisted in permitting his vehicles, drivers and/or dispatching operation to be operated in violation of any law. 
(4)  Failure to pay city, school, county or water district ad valorem taxes on any property the applicant uses in connection with taxicab or limousine service. 
(5)  The operator has failed to comply with any of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  If the city manager determines that grounds exist for revocation of a license, the licensee shall be notified of the revocation, in writing, by certified mail, stating the reasons for the revocation, the effective date of the revocation, and that the licensee has the right to appeal. The licensee may appeal the revocation to the city council by filing written notice of appeal with the city secretary within ten days of receipt of the revocation. Otherwise, the decision of the city manager is final and nonappealable. 
(Code 1995, § 113.22(G, H)) 
Secs. 74-148-74-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - VEHICLE PERMIT 

Sec. 74-171. - Required. 
    No taxicab or limousine shall be operated within the city until a vehicle permit for the vehicle has been issued by the city manager. Vehicle permits shall be issued only to applicants who possess a valid operating or combined operating/dispatching license. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(A)) 
Sec. 74-172. - Classifications. 
    Vehicle permits shall be issued in the following two classifications: 
(1)  Limousine only permit. The limousine only permit classification shall permit the vehicle to be used for limousine service only. 
(2)  Taxicab permit. The taxicab permit classification shall permit the vehicle to be used either for limousine service or taxicab service. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(B)) 
Sec. 74-173. - Fees. 
    The annual fee for either classification of vehicle permit shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. Fees for permits issued for less than a full year shall be prorated, except that the minimum fee shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. The fee is not refundable if the permit is canceled or revoked prior to expiration of the permit. Permit documents which are lost or destroyed may be replaced upon payment of a fee as established by the city council from time to time and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(C)) 
Sec. 74-174. - Applications. 
    Every application for a vehicle permit under this division shall be in writing, signed and sworn by the applicant, and shall be filed with the city manager. The application shall be on a form provided by the city manager and shall contain the following: 
(1)  For either classification of vehicle permit: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
b.  If the applicant is a corporation, the corporate name, place of incorporation, address and telephone number. 
c.  If the applicant is a partnership, the name of the partnership, and the names, addresses and telephone numbers of all partners. 
d.  The number of the applicant's operating or combined operating/dispatching license. 
e.  The make, model, body style, model year and color of the vehicle. 
f.  The number and expiration date of the state license plate number and state vehicle inspection sticker. 
g.  The vehicle identification number. 
h.  The owner of the vehicle, if different than the applicant. 
(2)  For a taxicab permit, a description of the electric identification sign. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(D)) 
Sec. 74-175. - Vehicle requirements. 
    Vehicles must meet the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  For either class of vehicle permit, the vehicle shall: 
a.  Conform to all minimum safety standards as required by the state. 
b.  Display the city permit inside the vehicle at a place visible to the occupants. 
c.  Have a taximeter of a size and design approved by the city. The taximeter shall be accurate to the extent that measured mileage or waiting time is not more than five percent incorrect to the prejudice of the passenger. 
(2)  For taxicab permits only, the vehicle shall: 
a.  Display the permit number on the outside of the vehicle at the rear and on both front doors, in letters not less than 21/2 inches high. Letters shall be in a color which contrasts with the color of the vehicle so as to be clear and legible. 
b.  Have an electrically illuminated sign on the top of the vehicle to identify the operator of the vehicle. 
c.  Have an accurate, calibrated odometer. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(E)) 
Sec. 74-176. - Vehicle inspections. 
    No permit shall be issued or reinstated until the vehicle has been inspected by the police department. The police department shall complete an inspection checklist form provided by the city and certify that the vehicle has fully complied with all requirements on such checklist. Vehicles shall be reinspected and recertified every 12 months. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(F)) 
Sec. 74-177. - Transferability; fee. 
    Vehicle permits may be transferred from one vehicle to another only upon application to the city manager. A nonproratable fee, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, shall be charged. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(G)) 
Sec. 74-178. - Term; expiration; renewal. 
    The term of all vehicle permits shall not be for more than one year, with expiration on January 31. Renewals shall be applied for in the same manner as specified in this division for the original permit. Renewal permits may be issued during the month of January, and shall expire on January 31 of the following year. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(H)) 
Sec. 74-179. - Revocation. 
    A vehicle permit issued under this division may be revoked if: 
(1)  The permit was obtained by an application in which any material fact was omitted or stated falsely. 
(2)  The permit holder has failed to comply with the provisions of this article or has persisted in permitting his vehicle to be operated in violation of any law. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(I)) 
Sec. 74-180. - Suspension. 
    Every vehicle permit issued under this division shall be suspended by the city manager if the vehicle has ceased to comply with the requirements as set forth in sections 74-174 and 74-175. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(J)) 
Sec. 74-181. - Revocation or suspension proceedings. 
    If the city manager determines that grounds exist for revocation or suspension of a permit, the permit holder shall be notified of the revocation or suspension, in writing, by certified mail, stating the reasons for, and effective date of, the revocation or suspension, and that the holder of the permit has the right to appeal the revocation or suspension to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal with the city secretary within ten days. Otherwise, the revocation or suspension is final and nonappealable. In addition, the chief of police may confiscate the permit document. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(K)) 
Sec. 74-182. - Reinstatement of suspended permit; fee. 
    Vehicle permits suspended because of failure to comply with the requirements of section 74-174 may be reinstated as soon as the vehicle is brought back into compliance with section 74-174. Application for reinstatement shall be made, in writing, to the city manager on a form provided by the city manager. The nonproratable fee for reinstatement shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 113.23(L)) 
Secs. 74-183-74-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - REGULATIONS AND STANDARDS FOR DRIVERS 

Sec. 74-201. - Driver's permit required. 
    No person shall drive a taxicab or limousine within the city unless such person has a valid driver's permit as provided for under this division. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(A)) 
Sec. 74-202. - Requirements. 
    Applicants for a driver's permit under this division must possess a valid state driver's license of the appropriate classification. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(B)) 
Sec. 74-203. - Application. 
    Every application for a driver's permit shall be, in writing, signed and sworn by the applicant and shall be filed with the city manager. The application shall be on a form provided by the city manager and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, residence address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  Previous addresses of the applicant for the past three years. 
(3)  Height, weight, eye color, hair color, race, sex and other physical characteristics useful in identifying the applicant and in distinguishing the applicant from other persons. 
(4)  Number, classification and expiration date of the applicant's state driver's license. 
(5)  All traffic violations of the applicant during the last five years. 
(6)  Details concerning all previous felony convictions of the applicant, if any. 
(7)  Two nonreturnable color photographs of the applicant. Such pictures shall be approximately two inches by three inches and shall show a front, head/shoulders view, of sufficient clarity for positive identification. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(C)) 
Sec. 74-204. - Grounds for refusal to issue permit. 
    The chief of police shall recommend approval or disapproval of a driver's permit application under this division. Recommendation for disapproval shall be made if the applicant's past criminal or traffic record indicates unfitness for driving a taxicab or limousine. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(D)) 
Sec. 74-205. - Term of permit; expiration; renewal; renewal fee. 
    The term of all permits under this division shall be for not more than one year, and shall expire on January 31. Renewals shall be applied for in the same manner as specified in this division for the original permit. Renewal permits may be issued during the month of January, and shall expire on January 31 of the following year. Permit documents which are lost or destroyed may be replaced upon payment of a fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(E)) 
Sec. 74-206. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for driver's permits shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. Fees for permits issued after January 31 shall be prorated, except that the minimum fee shall be as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. No portion of the fee shall be refunded if the permit is terminated prior to expiration. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(F)) 
Sec. 74-207. - Display of permit; removal or substitution of photograph. 
    No person shall drive a taxicab or limousine within the city unless a copy of the driver's permit issued by the city is displayed at a conspicuous place inside the vehicle in view of the passengers. The identification photograph affixed to the permit by the city shall not be removed or substituted. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(G)) 
Sec. 74-208. - Revocation. 
    Every driver's permit issued under this division shall be subject to revocation by the chief of police for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The permit was obtained by an application in which any material fact was omitted or stated falsely. 
(2)  The permit holder has been convicted of a felony or any crime or offense involving moral turpitude. 
(3)  The permit holder's traffic record has become unfit for driving a taxicab or limousine, in the opinion of the chief of police. 
(4)  The permit holder has altered, forged or counterfeited, or possesses an altered, forged or counterfeited, driver's license, badge, sticker, emblem or permit required by law. 
(5)  The permit holder has failed to comply with the provisions of this article or has persisted in permitting his vehicle to be operated in violation of the law. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(H)) 
Sec. 74-209. - Suspension. 
(a)  Every driver's permit issued under this division shall be subject to suspension by the chief of police if the permit holder is charged with any felony or crime involving moral turpitude. The suspension may take effect at the time the charges are filed under the state penal code and may remain in effect until final disposition of the charges. 
(b)  Every driver's permit issued under this division shall be subject to suspension by the city manager if the driver fails to comply with the regulations set forth in this division. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(I)) 
Sec. 74-210. - Notification of suspension or revocation; appeal. 
    The driver shall be notified of the suspension or revocation of his driver's permit either by certified mail or a personally delivered written notice. The notice must include the reason for suspension or revocation and a statement that the driver has the right to appeal such suspension or revocation to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal with the city secretary within ten days of receipt of the notice of suspension or revocation. Otherwise, the suspension or revocation is final and nonappealable. 
(Code 1995, § 113.24(J)) 
Secs. 74-211-74-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TOWING SERVICES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Tow truck regulation, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 643.201. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-241. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief of police means the chief of police for the city or his designee. 
    Consent towing service or consent tow means any towing of a motor vehicle initiated by the owner or operator of the vehicle or a person who has possession, custody or control of the vehicle. Such term does not include the tow of a motor vehicle initiated by a peace officer investigating a traffic accident or a traffic incident that involves the vehicle. 
    Motor vehicle means every device in or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, except devices moved only by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks, and shall include trailers, semitrailers and motorcycles. 
    Nonconsent towing service or nonconsent tow means any towing of a motor vehicle that is not a consent tow. 
    Owner means any person who holds the legal title of a motor vehicle, has the legal right of possession thereof or the legal rights of such vehicle. 
    Person means an individual person, firm, corporation or association. 
    Street means any public street, alley, public place, square or highway within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Wrecker means any motor vehicle used for the purpose of towing or removing disabled or wrecked motor vehicles from the streets upon the request of the city. 
    Wrecker business means the business of towing or removing disabled or wrecked motor vehicles off the streets of the city. 
    Wrecker company means any person engaged in the wrecker business. 
    Wrecker rotation list means the rotation list of companies prepared and used as provided in section 74-315. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 1, 6-26-2001) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-242. - Article cumulative. 
    This article shall be cumulative of all laws of the state and the United States governing the subject matter of this article. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 14, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 74-243. - Interpretation and construction. 
    This article does not require any person, repair company or wrecker company to obtain any permit or limit any fees charged, except such persons, businesses and companies that voluntarily obtain a permit and meet the standards provided in this article in order to receive requests from the city for towing vehicles and/or placement on the wrecker rotation list. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 15, 6-26-2001) 
Secs. 74-244-74-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 74-261. - Tow truck committee. 
    There is hereby created a tow truck committee, which shall be referred to as the "committee," for the purposes of this article. The committee shall be composed of the chief of police or a police officer designated by the chief of police, the city manager or a city employee designated by the city manager, and three citizens. The three citizen committee members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to city council approval, to serve one-year terms. One of the citizen committee members shall be an owner of a wrecker business or employed by such business. The remaining two citizen committee members shall not be in the wrecker business. Subsequent terms of the citizen committee members shall be for two years. Appointments to the committee shall be made in June of each year. The tow truck committee shall have the power to suspend or revoke a wrecking company's permit or otherwise discipline a wrecking company for violations of this article. The tow truck committee's authority as provided in this section does not preclude the prosecution of a violation of this article in the city's municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 12(intro. ¶), 6-26-2001) 
Cross reference- Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-61 et seq. 
Sec. 74-262. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person shall have the right to appeal any decision of the tow truck committee to the city council by making a written request to the city manger. Such request must be filed with the city secretary within 15 days after such person has been notified of the decision of the tow truck committee. 
(b)  No person shall have any right to appeal for relief to any court in regard to any matter covered by this article until after such person has exhausted the appeal procedure provided for in this section. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 12(a), (b), 6-26-2001) 
Secs. 74-263-74-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT 

Sec. 74-281. - Application; fees. 
    Every wrecker company desiring to qualify to provide nonconsent towing services to the city and to be placed on the wrecker rotation list to provide nonconsent towing services at the request of the city shall make written application for a permit to the chief of police upon a form provided for such purpose. Such permit application shall contain the name, address, telephone number, number and types of wrecker equipment operated and the owner of the business. The applicant shall name all employees of the wrecker company who will be driving the wreckers and will furnish the chief of police with the employees' addresses, drivers' license numbers and telephone numbers. When filed, every application shall be sworn to by the applicant and accompanied by a fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, which fee is to cover inspection and permit charges, and shall not be returned to the applicant. The permit fee shall cover the permit fees for one wrecker per wrecker company, and an additional fee, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, shall be submitted for each wrecker that will provide nonconsent towing services, and such fees shall not be returned to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 2, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 74-282. - Issuance requirements. 
    Upon payment of the permit fees stated in section 74-281, the chief of police shall issue a permit for wrecker companies to be eligible to provide nonconsent towing services at the request of the city, and shall issue a permit for all wreckers of such wrecker companies providing such services only if the following requirements are met: 
(1)  Every wrecker proposed to be used by the applicant shall comply with the following minimum requirements: 
a.  Each wrecker shall be no less than one-ton dual in size, and be equipped with booster brakes. 
b.  Each wrecker shall be equipped with a power- or hand-operated winch and winch line, with a factory rated lifting capacity of not less than four tons, single line capacity. 
c.  Each wrecker shall carry the following standard equipment: 
1.  Tow bars; 
2.  Safety chains; 
3.  Fire extinguisher (minimum five-pound, class B or C); 
4.  Wrecking bars; 
5.  Brooms; 
6.  Shovel; 
7.  Axe; and 
8.  Amber color flashing ray light, mounted at the highest practical point on the vehicle. 
(2)  The applicant shall procure, and keep in full force and effect, a policy of public liability and property damage insurance issued by a casualty insurance company in the standard form approved by the state, with the insured provisions of the policy including the city as an additional insured, and the coverage provision insuring the public from any loss or damage that may arise to any person or property by reason of the operation of a wrecker of such company, and providing that the amount of recovery on each wrecker shall be in limits of not less than the following: 
a.  For damages arising out of bodily injury or death, such limits shall meet the state minimum requirements for wreckers as set by the state department of transportation. 
b.  For injury to or destruction of property, such limits shall meet the state minimum requirements for wreckers as set by the state department of transportation. 
(3)  A copy of the policy of insurance, or a certificate of insurance issued by the insurer, shall be obtained and filed with the city secretary. 
(4)  The owner of the wrecker for which such permit or license is sought shall render the wrecker for ad valorem taxation, and all taxes due and owing on such vehicle shall have been paid to the city. 
(5)  Proof shall be provided that the owner of the wrecker has a storage facility located a distance of not greater than five miles from the city limits, which shall be licensed by state law as suitable for the protection of stored motor vehicles and fenced as required by applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 3, 6-26-2001) 
State Law reference- Minimum coverage amounts, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 601.072. 
Sec. 74-283. - Additional permits required; display; unlawful service; transferability; duplicates; expiration. 
(a)  In addition to a permit authorizing a person to engage in nonconsent towing services at the request of the city, a permit shall also be issued for each wrecker owned by the permittee and authorized to provide such service. 
(b)  Each permit for a wrecker shall be securely affixed to the inside of the windshield of the wrecker. 
(c)  No wrecker shall provide service to the city in response to a request by the city police department, be placed or remain on the wrecker rotation list, or perform any nonconsent towing services unless a permit has been issued to the owner of such wrecker pursuant to this article. 
(d)  No permit shall be transferable, and if such permit is lost or destroyed a charge for a duplicate shall be made as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(e)  Every permit shall expire at 12:00 midnight on December 31 of the calendar year in which the permit is issued. 
(f)  No wrecker company shall provide nonconsent towing services at the request of the city without the permits issued pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 4, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 74-284. - Revocation. 
    Any of the permits defined in this division may be revoked by the tow truck committee established under section 74-261 for the violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 5, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 74-285. - Operation without valid and current permit. 
    No wrecker company shall provide nonconsent towing services in response to a request for wrecker services from the city or in response to a notice resulting from being on the wrecker rotation list unless a valid and current permit for such wrecker has been issued for such vehicle by the chief of police, and no person shall operate a wrecker on the public streets of the city for such purposes unless the permit duly issued to such wrecker is posted on the windshield of such wrecker as provided in section 78-283(b). 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 6, 6-26-2001) 
Secs. 74-286-74-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 74-311. - Towing charges. 
(a)  A wrecker owner is hereby authorized to collect fees, as established by the city council in its annual fee ordinance on file in the city secretary's office, for the following nonconsent towing services: 
(1)  Regular towing charge (for vehicles not requiring the use of a heavy-duty wrecker during regular business hours only, Monday-Friday 8:00 a.m.-5:00 p.m.). An additional surcharge may be imposed during afterhours on holidays or weekends. 
(2)  Additional charge when towing dolly is used. 
(3)  Mileage fee per mile (roundtrip). 
(4)  Additional charge if drive line must be dropped. 
(5)  Additional charge if wheel and tire must be changed. 
(6)  Additional charge if winch required (per 50 feet). 
(7)  Additional charge to upright a vehicle. 
(8)  Additional charge to pull axle prior to tow. 
(9)  Clean up. 
(10)  Additional charge for any other necessary labor, chargeable in 15-minute increments, such time and labor charges not to accrue until after wrecker has been on the scene for 30 minutes or longer (not to include delays for police investigations). 
(b)  The fees for services set forth in subsection (a) of this section and in the amounts established by the city council in the annual fee ordinance, which may be amended, shall be all inclusive, and there will be no additional towing charges to a motor vehicle owner. Towing fees for a heavy-duty wrecker, when required, are not regulated by this section. However, any preservation and notification fees provided by this law may be applied. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 13, 6-26-2001; Ord. No. 04-23, § 1, 6-8-2004; Ord. No. 13-30, § 1, 9-24-2013) 
Sec. 74-312. - Following emergency vehicles. 
    No person in a motor vehicle shall follow any ambulance or police car traveling on a public street in response to the report of an automobile collision or accident for the purpose of following such ambulance or police car to the location of the collision or accident. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 7, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 74-313. - Location of traffic accidents. 
    No person shall drive a wrecker, or other motor vehicle used in the business of towing motor vehicles, to the scene or site of a traffic accident or collision on the streets of the city unless such person has been called to the scene by the police department or the owner of a motor vehicle involved in the accident, provided that when it is necessary to prevent death or bodily injury to any person involved in an accident or collision, the prohibition of this section shall be inapplicable. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 8, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 74-314. - Solicitations at accident scene. 
    No person shall solicit business at the scene of any traffic accident or collision on a public street in a manner which disrupts, impedes or otherwise interferes with the flow of traffic or the provision or conduct of police, fire or emergency medical services. Proof of the presence of any person engaged in the wrecker business, or any wrecker or motor vehicle owned or operated by any person engaged in the wrecker business, at or near the scene or site of a wreck, accident or collision on any public street in the city within one hour after the occurrence of such wreck, accident or collision shall be a violation of this section, except when such person or wrecker has been called to the scene of such accident or collision by the police department or owner. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 9, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 74-315. - Wrecker rotation list; failure to respond to a call. 
(a)  If the owner of a vehicle involved in an accident or collision is physically unable or refuses to designate the wrecker company desired, the investigating officer shall immediately communicate such fact to the police department headquarters. The police department or its authorized designee shall keep a master list (known as the "wrecker rotation list") of all wrecker companies which meet the requirements of section 74-282. Upon receiving the first communication, the police officer receiving such communication at the police department headquarters shall call the wrecker company in line on the wrecker rotation list to tow the disabled vehicle and remove such vehicle from the city streets. On each succeeding communication of the inability or refusal of the owner to designate a wrecker company, the next wrecker company on the list shall be called, and proper rotation of each such call shall be made on the master list. 
(b)  If a wrecker company fails to respond to a call on two consecutive instances or more than twice in any six-month period, the wrecker company's permit shall then be subject to suspension and/or revocation and removal from the wrecker rotation list, as determined by the tow truck committee. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 10, 6-26-2001) 
Sec. 74-316. - Wrecker recommendation by police officer. 
    No police officer investigating or present at the scene or site of any wreck, accident or collision on a public street shall, directly or indirectly, either by word, gesture, sign or otherwise, recommend to any person the name of any particular person engaged in the towing or wrecker service or repair business; nor shall any such police officer influence, or attempt to influence, in any manner, the decision of any person in choosing or selecting a towing, wrecker or repair service, provided that any police officer, in the exercise of his discretion as a police officer, may direct that any vehicle, whether towed by a company selected by the owner of the vehicle or from the wrecker rotation list, shall be taken by the driver of the tow truck or wrecker towing the vehicle directly to the pound or a place approved by the chief of police and held at such place until properly released; however, this section shall not be interpreted as preventing any police officer from making any recommendation to a member of his immediate family. 
(Ord. No. 01-12, § 11, 6-26-2001) 
Subpart B - LAND USE REGULATIONS 
Chapter 78 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Amendments to regulatory codes. 
    Amendments to regulatory codes adopted by reference in this chapter, which, from time to time, are adopted and published by the organizations or agencies referred to in this chapter or amended, from time to time, by the city by ordinance, shall be effective in the city at the time the amendments are placed on file in the office of the city secretary. 
(Code 1995, § 150.06) 
Sec. 78-2. - Fire limits. 
    The fire limits of the city shall be as shown and indicated on the official map of the fire zones on file in the office of the city secretary. 
(Code 1995, § 150.15) 
Charter reference- Power of the council to designate and regulate fire limits, § 20. 
Secs. 78-3-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY OF BROWNWOOD BUILDING CODE[2]

(9)  Section 302.7. Add Section 302.7.1 - Trailers. 
1.  Trailers shall not be used as storage buildings unless wheels, axles, jack stands and landing gear have been removed and it is secured to an appropriate foundation and anchored to the ground in a manner specified by the City of Brownwood Building Code. A permit shall be required as it would for any other structure and it must meet all applicable building code requirements. 
2.  Trailers shall be maintained in a manner which permits their designed use; i.e., currently registered, inspected and legally operable on the roads of the state. 
3.  A loaded trailer that has been located on the same property for 90 or more days shall be considered a storage unit and will be subject to the foregoing and all applicable requirements of the City of Brownwood Building Code. Successive 90 day periods shall be separated by no less than 30 days during which the trailer is not located on the property. 
4.  Job Trailers shall: 
a.  Be installed in full compliance with all of the locally adopted codes and ordinances related to occupancy; e.g., building, plumbing, electric, mechanical, etc. when being used at a work site. 
b.  Be occupied for office use only and not as residential quarters. 
c.  When stored at a non-working site be, at a minimum, maintained in good condition and appropriately secured to the ground in accordance with the locally adopted codes. Job trailers may be indefinitely stored at a non-working site provided all the foregoing provisions are complied with. 
(10)  Section 302. 
1. In this instance "front yard" shall be that portion of land between the front property line and the structure's front wall furthest from said property line excluding porches and other unconditioned spaces." 
2.  Add Section "302.11 A motor vehicle or trailer shall not be parked on a public sidewalk or greenway; i.e., the portion of land between a property line and the edge of a street or face of a raised curb."

(12)  Section 602.3. Insert: "January 1 - December 31"
