Sec. 78-214. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-30, § 4.D.h.iii., adopted Dec. 13, 2011, deleted § 78-214, which pertained to water heating equipment and derived from Ord. No. 01-07, § I, adopted 3-13-2001. 
Sec. 78-215. - Fees. 
    The permit and inspection fees, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, shall be paid to the city before the issuance of a permit and before any work is started. Plumbing contractors licensed and bonded to do work in the city may, upon approved credit, place a deposit with the city for such permits. Plumbing contractors with a deposit may call by telephone for a permit. If, at anytime during the month, permit costs exceed the deposit on file with the city by the plumbing contractor, the plumbing contractor must immediately pay the difference. If such event happens two months in succession, the plumbing contractor must increase his deposit or go on cash on deliver (COD), which shall be at the sole discretion of the plumbing code official. 
(Ord. No. 00-34, § 153.02, 10-10-2000) 
Sec. 78-216. - Bond required. 
    Before any person shall engage in the business of plumbing in the city, such person shall possess a valid state license and deposit a good and sufficient bond with the city, in the sum set by the city council by resolution and on file in the city secretary's office, conditioned that the person engaged in the plumbing business will faithfully observe all of the laws pertaining to plumbing, and that the city shall be indemnified and saved harmless from all claims arising from accidents and damages of any character caused by the negligence of the person engaged in the plumbing business, or by any other inadequate work done either by himself or his agents or employees. 
(Ord. No. 00-34, § 153.03, 10-10-2000) 
Secs. 78-217-78-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL AND PREVENTION 

Sec. 78-241. - Violations; penalties; sanctions; review and revocation of certified tester's registration. 
(a)  A person who violates any portion of this division is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, is punishable, as set forth in applicable law, for each act of violation and each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued or permitted. 
(b)  In addition to proceeding under authority of section 78-282(1), the city is entitled to pursue all other criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of statutes or other ordinances against a person committing any violation of this article, including injunction and civil penalties. 
(c)  In addition to sanctions provided for by this article, the city is entitled to exercise sanctions provided for by other ordinances of the city. 
(d)  A certified tester's registration may be reviewed and revoked by the city if it is determined that the tester has: 
(1)  Falsely, incompletely or inaccurately made assembly reports; 
(2)  Used inaccurate gauges; 
(3)  Used improper testing procedures; or 
(4)  Created a threat to public health or the environment. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(H)(4)-(6), 11-28-2000) 
Secs. 78-242-78-260. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 78-261. - Responsibility; backflow prevention assembly installation inspections and tests. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the city manager or his designated representative or employees. 
(b)  The city shall inspect and initially test, or cause to be inspected or tested, all backflow prevention assemblies installed pursuant to the requirements of this article. For new facilities, permanent water service shall not be provided until all backflow prevention assemblies have been tested and are operational. Except in cases where testing of backflow prevention assemblies must be delayed until the installation of internal production or auxiliary equipment, the city shall not approve a certificate of occupancy until backflow prevention assemblies have been tested and are operational. The city shall not be liable for damage caused to a backflow prevention assembly as a result of such inspection or testing. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(H)(1), (2), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-262. - Offenses. 
    A person commits an offense: 
(1)  If there is failure to maintain backflow prevention assemblies in compliance with this article. 
(2)  If there is failure to comply with a repair order issued by the city. 
(3)  If backflow from the premises owned, operated, managed or under the control of such person enters the public water supply system. 
(4)  If there is a failure to pay any fees required by this article. 
(5)  By violating any section of this article. 
(6)  If disconnected or discontinued water service to a premises under this article is reinstated, except as directed by the city. 
(7)  If such person is in charge of a facility and allows an unregistered tester to perform testing work at the establishment. 
(8)  By testing a backflow prevention assembly within the city without being registered with the regulatory authority. 
(9)  By testing a backflow prevention assembly within the city without being certified by the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (TNRCC). 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(H)(3), 11-28-2000) 
Secs. 78-263-78-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - STANDARDS 

Sec. 78-281. - Right-of-way installations of backflow prevention assemblies. 
(a)  No person shall install or maintain a backflow prevention assembly upon or within any city right-of-way, except as follows: 
(1)  A backflow prevention assembly required by the city may be installed upon or within any city right-of-way only if the owner proves to the city that there is no other feasible location for installation of the assembly; such installation will not interfere with traffic or utilities; and a permit is obtained from the city for such installation. The city retains the right to approve the location, height, depth, enclosure and other requisites of the backflow prevention assembly prior to the installation. 
(2)  All permits and inspections required by this Code to perform work in a right-of-way shall be obtained. 
(3)  The backflow prevention assembly shall be installed below or flush with the surrounding grade, except when it is not practical to install the backflow prevention assembly in such manner. Any backflow prevention assembly, or portion thereof, which extends above the ground shall be located no closer than 18 inches to the face of the curb. 
(4)  The city shall not be liable for any damage done to, or caused by, a backflow prevention assembly installed in the right-of-way. 
(5)  A property owner shall, at the request of the city and at the owner's expense, relocate a backflow prevention assembly which encroaches upon any city right-of-way when such relocation is necessary for street or utility construction or repairs for purposes of public safety. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he fails to relocate a backflow prevention assembly located in or upon any city right-of-way after receiving a written order from the regulatory authority. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(A), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-282. - When backflow prevention assembly required. 
(a)  The backflow prevention assembly protection which is required under this article shall be any of the duly nationally recognized and authorized backflow prevention assemblies listed in the state-approved plumbing code, or as determined by the regulatory authority prior to installation. Each backflow prevention assembly must have been approved by the regulatory authority prior to installation. Failure to obtain such approval prior to installation of the backflow prevention assembly failing to meet final approval by the regulatory authority. The city shall determine the type and location of the backflow prevention assembly to be installed within the service area of the city. A backflow prevention assembly will be required in, but not limited to, each of the following: 
(1)  Where the nature and intent of any activity on the premises, or the materials used in the connection with any activity on the premises, or materials stored on the premises could contaminate or pollute the potable water supply. 
(2)  A premises which has any one or more cross connections and the cross connections are protected by an atmospheric vacuum breaker device (AVB). 
(3)  Where internal cross connections are present that are not correctable. 
(4)  Where intricate plumbing arrangements are present which make it impractical to ascertain whether a cross connection exists. 
(5)  Where there is unduly restricted entry so that inspections for cross connections cannot be made with sufficient frequency to assure that the cross connections do not exist. 
(6)  Where installation of an approved backflow prevention assembly is deemed to be necessary to accomplish the purpose of this article, in the judgment of the city. 
(7)  When an appropriate cross connection survey report form has not been filed with the public works/plumbing/water utilities department of the city, upon request of the city. 
(8)  Where a fire suppression system is connected to the city's water system. 
(9)  All new construction, if deemed necessary in the customer service inspection. The type of assembly required will be determined by the degree of hazard. 
(10)  Any used water return system. 
(11)  All multistory buildings or any building with a booster pump or elevated storage tank. 
(b)  If a point-of-use assembly has not had the testing or repair done as required by this article, a premises isolation assembly will be required. 
(c)  When a building is constructed on a commercial premises, and the end use of such building is not determined or could change, a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly may be installed at the service connection that supplies water for domestic use. 
(d)  If it is determined that additions or alterations have been made to the plumbing system without obtaining the proper permits, premises isolation may be required. 
(e)  Retrofitting will be required on all high hazard connections and wherever the city deems it necessary. 
(f)  All backflow prevention assemblies installed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be installed in a manner designed to facilitate ease of inspection by the city. Any currently installed backflow prevention assemblies which are located in inaccessible locations, or where the tester is subject of physical danger, shall be relocated to approved locations following current national guideline standards. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(B), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-283. - Inspection and testing of backflow prevention assemblies. 
(a)  All backflow prevention assemblies shall be inspected and tested, or caused to be inspected and tested, by the city in each of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Immediately after installation; 
(2)  Whenever the backflow prevention assembly is moved; 
(3)  A minimum of once a year; 
(4)  Prior to reoccupancy of a premises that has been vacated and unoccupied for one year; 
(5)  Immediately after repairs. 
(b)  All backflow prevention assembly testing shall be performed by a state certified backflow prevention assembly tester, approved by the regulatory authority. 
(c)  Duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification are entitled to enter any public or private property at any reasonable time for the purpose of enforcing this section. Persons and occupants of the premises which are provided water service by the city, either directly or indirectly, shall allow the city or its representatives ready access at all reasonable times to all parts of the premises for the purpose of inspection, testing, records examination or the performance of any of their duties. Where persons or occupants of premises have security measures in force which would require proper identification and clearance before entry into the premises, the persons and occupants of the premises shall make necessary arrangements with their security guard so that, upon presentation of suitable identification, personnel from the city will be permitted to enter, without delay, for the purpose of performing their specific responsibilities. 
(d)  The city is not liable for damage to a backflow prevention assembly which may occur during testing or inspection. 
(e)  A water use survey may be conducted at any establishment located in the city which is served by a public water supply or provides water to the public. Upon determination that the establishment falls under the provisions of this section and requires a backflow prevention assembly, a notice to abate the condition or to install the proper backflow prevention assembly shall be issued. 
(f)  It is the responsibility of the person who owns or controls property to have all backflow prevention assemblies tested in accordance with this section. 
(g)  All results from backflow prevention assembly testing by a certified backflow prevention assembly tester shall be placed on a form that may be purchased by the tester from the city for a fee as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, or may use an approved identical form. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(C), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-284. - Customer service inspections. 
(a)  Pursuant to the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (TNRCC) water system regulations, a customer service inspection for cross connection control shall be completed by the city prior to providing continuous water service: 
(1)  To a newly constructed facility or previously nonexisting premises. 
(2)  To a building or premises after any material improvement. 
(3)  To any facility or premises after any correction or addition to the plumbing of such facility or premises. 
(4)  When the city deems it necessary. 
(b)  Permanent water service shall not be supplied to a newly construction facility until after the customer service inspection is complete. 
(c)  Temporary water service which poses a potential cross connection threat to the potable water supply shall be protected by an approved backflow prevention assembly. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(D), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-285. - Backflow prevention assembly installation guidelines and requirements. 
(a)  Generally. To ensure proper operation and accessibility of all backflow prevention assemblies, the following national guideline requirements shall apply to the installation of such assemblies: 
(1)  Backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed in accordance with the current Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (TNRCC) rules and the regulations set forth in this section. The backflow prevention assembly installer must obtain the required plumbing permits and have the installation inspected by the city. 
(2)  At facilities which require a backflow prevention assembly to be installed at the point of delivery of the water supply, such installation must be before any branch in the line and on private property located just inside the boundary between the city right-of-way and the landowner's property. The city may specify other areas for installation of the backflow prevention assembly. Backflow prevention assemblies that must be installed or are located on the city right-of-way are the responsibility of the business or entity that the water line is serving. 
(3)  The backflow prevention assembly must be protected from freezing and other severe weather conditions. 
(4)  All backflow prevention assemblies shall be of a type and model approved by the city. 
(5)  All vertical installations of backflow prevention assemblies must have prior approval by the city. 
(6)  Backflow prevention assemblies that are larger than four inches and installed more than five feet above the floor level must have a suitable platform for use by testing or maintenance personnel. 
(7)  Bypass lines are prohibited. Pipefittings which could be used for connecting a bypass line must not be installed. 
(8)  Premises where an uninterrupted water supply is critical should be provided with two backflow prevention assemblies installed in parallel. Such assemblies should be sized in a manner so that either assembly will provide the maximum flow required. 
(9)  Lines should be thoroughly flushed prior to installation. A strainer with blowout tapping may be required ahead of the backflow prevention assembly. 
(10)  All facilities that require continuous, uninterrupted water service and a backflow prevention assembly must make provisions for the parallel installation of assemblies of the same type so that testing, repair and maintenance can be performed. 
(11)  The property owner assumes all responsibility for any damages resulting from installation, operation and/or maintenance of a backflow prevention assembly. The owner shall be responsible for keeping backflow prevention assembly vaults reasonably free of silt and debris. 
(12)  Upon completion of installation of a backflow prevention assembly, the city shall be notified and all backflow prevention assemblies must be inspected and tested. All such assemblies must be registered with the city and shall provide the date of installation, manufacturer, model, type, size, serial number and initial test report. 
(b)  Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assemblies (RPs). Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assemblies may be utilized at premises where substance is handled that would be hazardous to the health if introduced into the potable water system. The RP is normally used in locations where an air gap is impractical. The RP shall be effective against both backsiphonage and backpressure. 
(1)  RPs must be sized to provide an adequate supply of water and pressure for the premises being served. Flow characteristics are not standard. The manufacturerer's specifications shall be consulted for specific performance data. 
(2)  The RP must be readily accessible for testing and located in an area where water damage to a building or furnishings would not occur from relief valve discharge. The property owner assumes all responsibility for any damage caused by water discharge from a RP. An approved air gap shall be located at the relief valve orifice of RPs. 
(3)  No part of a RP shall be submerged in water or installed in a location subject to flooding. RPs are typically installed above grade in well drained areas, but may be installed below grade (ground level) if a boresight drain to daylight is provided. The drain shall be of an adequate capacity to carry the full rated flow of the RP and shall be screened on both ends. 
(4)  Enclosures shall be designed for ready access and sized to allow for the minimum clearances established in subsection (b)(5) of this section. Removable protective enclosures are typically installed on the smaller assemblies. Daylight drain ports must be provided to accommodate full pressure discharge from the RP. 
(5)  RPs which are two inches and smaller shall have at least a six-inch clearance on both sides and on top of the assembly, and a 12-inch clearance below and behind the assembly. All RPs larger than two inches on the test cock side, and the relief opening shall be at least 12 inches, plus nominal size of the assembly above the floor or highest possible water level. Headroom of six feet is required in vaults without a fully removable top. A minimum access opening of 36 inches is required on all vault lids. 
(6)  All RPs must be tested in accordance with this article. Tests are the responsibility of the assembly owner. The owner must notify the city upon installation of any backflow prevention assembly. 
(7)  Variances from the specifications of this subsection (b) will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. Any deviation from such specifications must have prior written approval of the city. 
(c)  Reduced pressure principle detector backflow prevention assemblies (RPDAs). Reduced pressure principle detector backflow prevention assemblies may be utilized in all installations requiring a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly and detector metering. 
(1)  RPDAs shall comply with the installation requirements applicable for reduced pressure principle backflow assemblies (RP) as set forth in subsection (b) of this section. 
(2)  The line size and bypass RP assemblies must each be tested. A separate test report for each assembly must be completed by the certified tester. 
(d)  Double check valve backflow prevention assemblies (DCs). Double check valve backflow prevention assemblies may be utilized at premises where a substance is handled that would be objectionable but not hazardous to health if introduced into the potable water system. 
(1)  DCs must be sized to provide an adequate supply of water and pressure for the premises being served. Manufacturer's specifications shall be consulted for specific performance data. 
(2)  Premises where an uninterrupted water supply is critical should be provided with two DCs installed in parallel. Such assemblies should be sized in a manner so that either assembly will provide the minimum water requirements, while the two together will provide minimum flow requirements. 
(3)  DCs shall be readily accessible, with adequate room for testing and maintenance. DCs may be installed below grade, provided all test cocks are fitted with brass pipe plugs. All vaults shall be well drained, constructed of suitable materials and sized to allow the minimum clearance established in subsection (d)(4) of this section. 
(4)  DCs two inches and smaller shall have at least a six-inch clearance below and on both sides of the assembly, and if located in a vault, the bottom of the assembly shall not be more than 24 inches below grade. All DCs larger than two inches shall have a minimum clearance of 12 inches on the backside, 24 inches on the test cock side and 12 inches below the assembly. Headroom of six feet is required in vaults without a fully removable top. A minimum check valve assembly shall be installed so that the checks are horizontal and the test cocks face upward. The clearance standards set forth in this subsection apply to all DCs installed in vaults, enclosures and meter boxes. 
(5)  Vertical installations of DCs are allowed only on sizes up to and including four inches, which meet the following requirements. 
(6)  All DCs must be tested in accordance with this article. Tests are the responsibility of the assembly owner. The owner must notify the regulatory authority upon installation of any backflow prevention assembly. 
(7)  Variances from the specifications set forth in this subsection (d) will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. Any deviation must have prior written approval of the city. 
(e)  Double check detector backflow prevention assemblies (DCDAs). Double check detector backflow prevention assemblies may be utilized in all installations requiring a double check valve assembly and detector metering. 
(1)  DCDAs shall comply with the installation requirements applicable for double check valve assemblies (DCs) as set forth in subsection (d) of this section. 
(2)  The in-line and bypass DC assemblies must each be tested. A separate test report for each assembly must be completed by the certified tester. 
(f)  Pressure vacuum breaker backflow prevention assemblies (PVBs). Pressure vacuum breaker backflow prevention assemblies may be utilized for point-of-use protection only where a substance is handled that would be objectionable but not hazardous to health if introduced into the potable water system. PVBs protect against backsiphonage only, and shall not be installed where there is a potential for backpressure. 
(1)  PVBs shall be installed a minimum of 12 inches above the highest downstream piping. 
(2)  PVBs shall not be installed in an area subject to flooding or where damage would occur from water discharge. 
(3)  PVBs shall be readily accessible for testing and maintenance, with a minimum clearance of 12 inches all around the assembly. 
(4)  All PVBs must be tested in compliance with this article. Tests are the responsibility of the assembly owner. 
(5)  Variances from the specifications set forth in this subsection (f) will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. Any deviation must have prior written approval of the city. 
(g)  Spill resistant pressure vacuum breaker backflow prevention assemblies (SVBs). Spill resistant pressure vacuum breaker backflow prevention assemblies may be utilized in all installations requiring a pressure vacuum breaker. SVBs shall comply with the installation requirements applicable for pressure vacuum breaker backflow prevention assemblies as set forth in subsection (f) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(E), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-286. - Responsibilities. 
(a)  Property owners. It is the responsibility of all property owners and/or persons in charge of any premises to abide by the conditions of this article and comply with the following: 
(1)  Pay all costs associated with this article and the purchase, installation, testing and repair of backflow prevention assemblies. 
(2)  Install and maintain all backflow prevention assemblies in accordance with this article and acceptable industry practices. 
(3)  All commercial establishments shall cause to have all backflow prevention assemblies on their premises tested annually. Such testing must be conducted by a certified cross connection tester who is registered with the city. 
(4)  Maintain all backflow prevention assemblies in proper working order at all times, including repair, as required. 
(5)  Maintain all backflow prevention assemblies in a manner which allows them to be tested by a method that has been approved by the regulatory agency. 
(6)  Maintain on the premises, for a minimum of three years, all records related to backflow prevention assembly installation, testing and repair. 
(b)  Commercial establishments. All commercial establishments shall cause to have all backflow prevention assemblies on their premises tested annually. Such testing must be conducted by a certified cross connection tester who is registered with the city. 
(c)  Certified backflow prevention assembly testers. Certified backflow prevention assembly testers shall comply with the following: 
(1)  Annually register with the city and pay the required fee. 
(2)  Maintain testing equipment in proper working condition and calibration. 
(3)  Maintain the design of operation characteristics of an assembly. 
(4)  Ensure that devices are tested according to accepted industry practice and Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (TNRCC) regulations. 
(5)  Enter required testing data, including test gauge serial numbers, on the cross connection test form obtained from or approved by the city. 
(6)  Report test results to the regulatory authorities within three days of testing. 
(7)  Provide a copy of the completed test report to the property owners and/or persons in charge of any premises. 
(8)  Maintain testing and/or repair records for a minimum of three years. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(F), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-287. - Backflow prevention assembly testers. 
    Only approved Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission (TNRCC) licensed backflow prevention assembly testers can test backflow prevention assemblies in the city. Testers must: 
(1)  Register annually with the city; 
(2)  Provide proof of TNRCC certification; 
(3)  Provide proof that testing equipment is able to maintain a calibration of plus or minus two-tenths psig accuracy; and 
(4)  Pay an annual nonrefundable tester registration fee. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(G), (N), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-288. - Multiple service connections. 
    Any premises requiring multiple service connections for adequacy of supply and/or fire protection will be required to install a backflow assembly on each of the service lines to the premises. The type of assembly will be determined by the degree of hazard that could occur in the event of an interconnection between any of the buildings and/or systems on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(I), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-289. - Residential service connections. 
    Any person who owns or controls any residential property which has been determined to have an actual or potential cross connection will be required to eliminate such actual or potential cross connection or have an approved backflow assembly installed in accordance with this division. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(J), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-290. - Rental properties. 
    Any person who owns or controls rental property is responsible for the installation, testing and repair of all backflow prevention assemblies on the property. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(K), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-291. - Fire suppression systems. 
(a)  All new installations of fire suppression systems which utilize the city's potable water supply shall have backflow prevention devices installed and approved according to the degree of hazard. 
(b)  An approved double check detector backflow prevention assembly (DCDA) or reduced pressure detector assembly (RPDA) shall be the minimum protection for fire sprinkler systems using piping material that is not approved for potable water use and/or that does not provide for a periodic flow-through during each 24-hour period, unless a variance has been issued, in writing, from the city. A RPDA must be installed if any solution other than the potable water can be introduced into the sprinkler system. 
(c)  It is the responsibility of all property owners and persons in charge of any premises to abide by the conditions of this article. In the event of any changes to the plumbing system, it is the responsibility of the property owners to notify the regulatory authority. All costs associated with this article and the purchase, installation, testing and repair of a DCDA or RPDA device is the responsibility of the property owner and persons in charge of any premises. 
(d)  Upon the approved installation of a DCDA or RPDA, a cross connection test report, completed by a licensed fire line tester, must be sent to the attention of the city, and shall include the information required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(L), 11-28-2000) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
Sec. 78-292. - Fire hydrants. 
(a)  An approved double check device backflow prevention assembly (DCDA) or reduced pressure detector assembly (RPDA) shall be the minimum protection for fire hydrant water meters which are being used for a temporary water supply during any construction or other use which would pose a potential hazard to the public water supply. A RPDA must be installed if any solution, other than the potable water, can be introduced into the system. 
(b)  It is the responsibility of all persons engaging in the use and rental of a fire hydrant water meter to abide by the conditions of this article. All fire hydrant water meter rentals shall meet the current requirements as provided by the city. 
(c)  Only the city fire hydrant water meters with approved backflow prevention assemblies are allowed to be used within the city limits. 
(d)  A refundable deposit is required to ensure the return to the city of all water meter and backflow prevention assemblies. Failure to return the assemblies can result in the forfeiture of the deposit and/or enforcement action being taken against the responsible party pursuant to section 78-241. 
(e)  All nonapproved fire hydrant meters which are found to be in use in the city will be confiscated and enforcement action shall be taken against the responsible party pursuant to section 78-261. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(M), 11-28-2000) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
Sec. 78-293. - Lawn irrigation systems. 
    All permits, issued by the building inspection department, shall be required for all lawn irrigation system installations. Installation requirements must comply with the current city plumbing code or guidelines for the appropriate device found in this article. Interconnections of the potable water supply with an alternate water source is prohibited unless appropriate backflow protection is installed. High hazard backflow protection devices must be installed if any mechanical injection stations are used within the irrigation system. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(O), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-294. - Mobile units. 
    The connection of a mobile unit to any potable water system is prohibited unless such connection is protected by an air gap or approved backflow prevention assembly. Prior approval and annual device testing of any backflow prevention assembly must be received from the city before connecting to any potable water system. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(P), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-295. - Required forms. 
    The following forms shall be required: 
(1)  Certificate. 
(2)  Backflow prevention assembly test and maintenance report. 
(3)  Customer service agreement. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(Q), 11-28-2000) 
Sec. 78-296. - Hazard assessments and assembly selections. 
    Hazard assessments and backflow prevention assembly selections shall be performed in accordance with Title 30 TAC Chapter 290 and Texas Commission on Environmental Quality regulations published from time to time by that agency. 
(Ord. No. 00-42, § 153.01.01(R), 11-28-2000; Ord. No. 11-30, § 4.D.h.4., 12-13-2011) 
Secs. 78-297-78-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - CITY OF BROWNWOOD ELECTRICAL CODE[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 70. 
State Law reference- Adherence to the National Electrical Code, 2001 edition, required, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 214.214. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-331. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Apprentice electrician means any person other than a master electrician or journeyman electrician who, as his principal occupation, is engaged in learning and assisting in the installation of electrical work, is licensed by the city, and works under the supervision of a licensed master electrician or journeyman electrician. 
    Control electrician means a person who engages in or works at the installation, maintenance or repair of AC or DC electrical controls. 
    Electrical work means any work related to or involving the furnishing of labor, equipment, appliances or materials, or the performance of any operation in connection with electrical installations, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Power and lighting systems, secondary services, distribution panels, lighting panels, conduits, junction boxes, pull boxes, outlets, feeders, subfeeders, wiring devices, service fittings, lighting fixtures, lamps, etc. 
(2)  All power and control wiring and any other electrical installations incidental to any equipment furnished by any other contractors, owners or their agents. 
    Electrician's apprentice means any person, other than a master or journeyman electrician, who, as his principal occupation, is engaged in learning and assisting in the installation of electrical work under the personal, constant supervision of a master or journeyman electrician. 
    Installation means any electrical work of any nature performed on, in or near any premises. 
    Journeyman electrician means any person licensed by the city who, under the supervision of a master electrician, engages in, or works at the actual installation, alteration, repair, service, and renovation of electrical work, and who has successfully fulfilled the examinations and requirements as set out in this chapter. 
    Legal entity has the same meaning as the term "person," as defined in section 1-2. 
    Maintenance electrician means a person who is employed by one single person, firm or organization to maintain and repair existing electrical installations on properties within the city owned by such person, firm or organization, and does not otherwise engage himself as either a master or journeyman electrician. 
    Master electrician means any person licensed by the city who is skilled in the planning, superintending, and practical installation, repair, and service of electrical work, who secures permits for electrical work, who is knowledgeable about the codes, ordinances, or rules and regulations governing those matters, who, alone or through a person or persons under his supervision, performs electrical work, and who has successfully fulfilled the examinations and requirements as set out in this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 151.02; Ord. No. 02-41, § 1, 8-27-2002) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-332. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Fire, police and traffic signal installations installed and maintained by the city and state department of transportation. 
(2)  Electric light, heat and power companies, and telephone and telegraph companies operating under a state charter and state laws or a franchise from the city in the operation, installation, maintenance, removal, repair or replacement of equipment and facilities of any kind or character which are necessary to, or a part of, the companies' production, operation, distribution or transmission systems. 
(3)  Manufacturers of electrical equipment carrying on reasonable electrical experiments with materials and products within the confines of their own premises, provided that the electrical inspector may, when he deems it necessary for the general welfare, inspect such premises and all installations therein, and the electrical inspector may require the manufacturer to make whatever changes he believes necessary for the protection of public life and property. 
(4)  All installations for the illumination of public grounds, ways, alleys or parks, and other exterior areas which also are owned and maintained by an electric light, heat and power company operating under a franchise from the city, or have been installed by or for such company, or are placed upon easements of such company, and have all lights installed upon poles, with no more than four lights on any one pole, and the poles shall not be closer together than 50 feet on any one tract of land. 
(5)  Any bona fide homeowner personally installing electrical conductors or equipment within his own home, provided that the owner shall: 
a.  File approved plans and specifications with the electrical inspector, which shall satisfy the electrical inspector as to such person's ability to install electrical wiring; 
b.  Apply for and secure a permit; 
c.  Pay the required fees; 
d.  Do the work in accordance with this article; and 
e.  Apply for an inspection and receive a certificate of approval. 
Personal installation by an owner under this subsection shall be by himself, for himself, on his homestead premises, without compensation, and no person shall be employed to assist him, in any way, on such work. No homeowner shall be issued a permit under the provisions of this subsection more frequently than once every two calendar years, except for additions or repairs. 
(Code 1995, § 151.01) 
Sec. 78-333. - Compliance with National Electrical Code. 
    A certain document, one copy of which is on file in the office of the City of Brownwood Code Administrator, being marked and designated as the National Electric Code, 2011 edition, including all Chapters and Appendices as published by the National Fire Protection Association, be and is hereby adopted as the Electrical Code of the City of Brownwood, for regulating and governing the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of electrical systems as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said National Electric Code are hereby referred to adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article. 
(Code 1995, § 151.03; Ord. No. 07-22, § 1, 8-28-2007; Ord. No. 08-33, §§ 1, 3, 10-14-2008; Ord. No. 11-30, § 1.J., 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 78-334. - Changes or deviations from provisions. 
    Means of appeal shall be as provided in Article XIII of this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 151.04; Ord. No. 11-30, § 1.J., 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 78-335. - Master electrician to supervise wiring. 
    All wiring within the city shall be done under the supervision of a master electrician, except as otherwise provided. 
(Code 1995, § 151.05) 
Sec. 78-336. - Connections between service and control. 
    No master, journeyman or maintenance electrician shall make any connection between the point of service and the work to be served until the electrical inspector has inspected and approved the work. 
(Code 1995, § 151.07) 
Secs. 78-337-78-360. - Reserved.

DIVISION 4. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 78-421. - Permit required. 
    No person shall begin any electrical installation or any work of installing, erecting or altering material, wiring fixtures or any other apparatus to be used for the generation, transmission or utilization of electricity for light, heat or power in or on any building or premises in the city without first securing a permit for such installation or work. 
(Code 1995, § 151.35) 
Sec. 78-422. - Permit application. 
    Homeowners and master electricians shall make application to the city development services department for a permit required by this division. 
(Code 1995, § 151.36) 
Sec. 78-423. - Issuance of permit. 
    After payment of the required inspection fees, the city development services department shall issue to the applicant a permit under this division for the proposed work. If other than homeowners apply for a permit, the permit will be issued to a master electrician only, unless prior arrangements have otherwise been made, in writing. 
(Code 1995, § 151.37) 
Sec. 78-424. - Expiration of permit. 
    If a building has not received and passed a final inspection within 60 days after completion of the building, the permit shall expire and may be renewed only after a fee in the amount of the original permit fee has been paid. However, the permit may be extended for a reasonable length of time, without charge, if application for an extension has been made to the office of the electrical inspector before the expiration of the permit. 
(Code 1995, § 151.38) 
Sec. 78-425. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-30, § 4.D.i, adopted 12-13-2011 deleted § 78-425 which pertained to permit for temporary service and derived from the Code of 1995, § 151.39. 
Sec. 78-426. - Inspection fees. 
    Upon application for a permit under this division, the inspection fees shall be paid by the applicant to the city as prescribed in the fee schedule passed by the city council from time to time and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 151.40; Ord. No. 11-30, § 4.D.i, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 78-427. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-30, § 4.D.i, adopted 12-13-2011 deleted § 78-427 which pertained to baseboard heating and derived from the Code of 1995, § 151.41. 
Sec. 78-428. - Notice of readiness for inspection. 
    Permit holders and other persons whose installations are ready for inspection shall allow the electrical inspector's office 24 hours, Sundays and holidays excluded, before proceeding with the installation. 
(Code 1995, § 151.42) 
Secs. 78-429-78-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ELECTRICAL STANDARDS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 70. 

Sec. 78-451. - Wiring methods. 
    In addition to the requirements of section 78-333, all wiring shall be as follows: 
(1)  Any new buildings built for commercial use and any existing building being remodeled that is to be used for any type of commercial purposes shall have all wiring in and/or on the building enclosed in National Electrical Code approved conduit, and: 
a.  Any existing building which is to be used for commercial purposes shall have the service entrance brought up to code and any additions or changes to the electrical system shall be installed according to the NEC. 
b.  All electrical installations or alterations done in or on any building which is to be used for commercial purposes shall be done by a master electrician licensed in the city. 
c.  Existing businesses will be excepted from subsection (1)a. of this section unless a permit is issued for any electrical additions or alterations, at which time the existing business shall comply with subsections (1)a. and (1)b. of this section. 
(2)  Any structure containing three or more living units shall be wired in NEC-approved conduit or shall have a fire wall approved by the International Building Code separating it from all other units. 
(3)  Electrical grounding systems shall consist of any type of wiring that is allowed by the NEC, except grounding systems shall not be attached to any plumbing pipes. 
(4)  Armored cable wiring, open wiring on insulators and concealed knob and tube wiring methods shall not be used. 
(5)  No grounding conductor run separately shall be smaller than No. 14 AWG. 
(6)  All buildings in the fire zone of the city shall be wired in NEC-approved conduit. 
(7)  In all construction, no electric wiring smaller than No. 14 AWG on 15 amp breakers shall be used in accordance with the 2011 National Electrical Code, as may be amended. 
(8)  Service masts which support service drops shall be made of a minimum size of two-inch trade size rigid steel electrical conduit. In addition, mast supports (guying or other suitable supports) to support the tension of the service drop cable is required if the service drop attachment is more than five feet above the roofline. 
(9)  The use of aluminum wire as a service/feeder conductor is permitted so long as the requirements of the 2011 National Electrical Code Table 310.15(B), as may be amended, are followed. 
(10)  Apprentice electricians shall perform electrical work only under the direct supervision of a licensed master or journeyman electrician. An apprentice electrician found doing any electrical work by themselves will be subject to the general penalties provided for in this Code. If the unsupervised apprentice electrician is working for a master electrician, the master electrical is held equally liable. 
(Code 1995, § 151.55; Ord. No. 11-30, § 4.D.i, 12-13-2011; Ord. No. 17-03 , § 1, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 78-452. - Minimum wiring standards for residential rehabilitation. 
(a)  Application to owner-occupied residences. The following standards shall apply to installations and alterations of the electrical system of owner occupied existing residences: 
(1)  Services. All service equipment shall meet NEC requirements. No service conductor shall be smaller than No. 2 AWG. 
(2)  Circuits. Wiring methods not presently approved by this article may remain if they are in a safe condition and not disturbed in any manner other than by reconnection to an electrical panel, provided also that such systems were legal at the time of original installation. 
(b)  Moved into or relocated buildings. All buildings moved into or relocated within the city shall be required to be in total compliance with NEC requirements and this article. The same requirements apply to residences being rehabilitated for sale or use as rental property. 
(Code 1995, § 151.56) 
Sec. 78-453. - General regulations. 
(a)  Pull chain switches shall not be installed over sinks or lavatories, regardless of the wiring method used. 
(b)  Scuttle holes shall be located and all recessed panels, fixtures or heater cans and other outlet boxes shall be in place for the rough-in inspection, unless otherwise excepted by the electrical inspector. 
(c)  If the wiring of a building is covered, in any manner, before the rough-in inspection is made, the wiring shall be uncovered or tests shall be made to ensure the proper functioning of the circuits. 
(d)  All plans for commercial and industrial construction, educational and institutional facilities, and apartment buildings shall show the following, as minimum requirements: 
(1)  A floor plan locating all electrical outlets, lighting fixtures and panel locations. 
(2)  A lighting fixture schedule showing type, location and wattage. 
(3)  A single line riser diagram showing conduit and wire size, beginning at the service entrance and continuing through the main and distribution panels. Fuse or breaker size shall be shown. 
(4)  A notation shall be placed on the riser diagram showing the planned total electrical load, in amperage, to be provided. 
Plans which are not required to be certified by a professional engineer shall be signed by a licensed master electrician. 
(e)  All panels and switches shall be properly labeled and indexed for circuit and equipment control identification. 
(f)  All wiring in space enlargements or additions to buildings shall consist of entirely new circuits. 
(Code 1995, § 151.58; Ord. No. 11-30, § 4.D.i, 12-13-2011) 
Secs. 78-454-78-480. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - MOVING BUILDINGS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-481. - Article not to be construed to repeal, amend or supersede other ordinances. 
    No provision of this article or the ordinance adopting this article shall be construed to repeal, amend or supersede any ordinance, or provision thereof, relating to moving buildings. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(A)) 
Secs. 78-482-78-500. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS AND LICENSES 

Sec. 78-501. - Permit required; exceptions. 
(a)  Permit required. 
(1)  Before any house, building or structure of any kind, over the maximum loaded height of 14 feet, maximum width of eight feet, six inches, or maximum length of 65 feet, is moved over or along any street, highway, alley or public way in the city, the person proposing to do such moving shall first secure a permit from the building official authorizing the applicant to move such house, building or other structure. 
(2)  Each individual house, building or other structure moved under the terms of this article shall require the issuance of a separate permit. 
(3)  Any person may submit an application form at city hall for a moving permit, and upon approval of the travel route, may request a waiver up to, but not to exceed, 16 feet maximum loaded width upon approval of the building official. 
(b)  Exceptions. The following do not require a moving permit from the building inspection department: 
(1)  A house, building or other structure of any kind originating outside the city limits and only passing through the city on a state highway or interstate highway. 
(2)  Transporting mobile homes. 
(3)  A structure built on-site for the express purpose of being relocated to another site, and which does not exceed a loaded height of 14 feet, a width of 12 feet or a maximum loaded length of 65 feet. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(B), (C)) 
Sec. 78-502. - Permit application. 
    Before a permit is granted under this division, the owner of the property shall furnish a statement, in writing, upon forms furnished by the building inspection department, authorizing the moving of a structure and the name of the mover. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(D)) 
Sec. 78-503. - Approval of route. 
    No person shall move any house, building or structure of any kind over, along or across any street, highway, alley or public way unless such route is expressly approved and a permit issued by the building official. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(E)) 
Sec. 78-504. - Notice to utility companies; removal and replacement of utility wires. 
(a)  Before a permit authorizing any proposed move or relocation is issued under this division, and before the move is begun, if the height of the house, building or structure is over 15 feet, the permittee shall notify each utility company which has wires, poles or other instruments used as an electrical generating, transmission or distribution system, or as a communication system, located on, over or across any street in the city along, over or across which the proposed moving operation is routed. 
(b)  Within 48 hours (excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays) after the permittee shall have notified any such utility company of the issuance by the building official of a permit for the moving of a house, building or other structure, the utility company shall cut, move and repair all wires, cables, poles or other instruments necessary to be altered in the furtherance of the proposed moving operation. 
(c)  The permittee requesting the services on the part of the utility companies shall pay a sum of money, in cash, to each utility company which shall be sufficient to defray the actual expense of performing any such services, including all repairs necessary to restore such utilities as they were, provided that no charge shall be made to the permittee for the removal or replacement of wires across streets, alleys or other public ways lower than the required minimum height set up by the electrical ordinances of the city. 
(d)  Such payment may be required by the utility companies in advance. It shall be the duty of each utility company to make all necessary repairs and alterations set forth in this section in a safe and workmanlike manner and restore its utility system to a safe condition. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(F)) 
Sec. 78-505. - License and bond required. 
(a)  No person, except a licensed mover, shall move any house or building within the city, and every such person shall obtain an annual license before engaging in such occupation. Such license shall be in an amount as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. The license shall not be granted until the person applying for such license has given a bond to the city, as approved by the city secretary, in an amount as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, and executed by a surety company duly authorized to transact such business in the state. 
(b)  The bond shall be conditioned that the principal will: 
(1)  Pay any damages which may accrue to persons, as well as the city, on account of moving such houses or structures along and across the public streets, alleys and highways, and damages to the water and sewer lines of the city, whether the damage is inflicted by the principal, his agents or employees; 
(2)  Save and keep the city harmless against all liabilities, judgments, costs and expenses which may, in any way, accrue against the city in consequence of granting a license or permit under this division; and 
(3)  Strictly comply with the conditions of his permit or license, this article and any other ordinances of the city. 
(c)  Any person sustaining damage because of the moving of a house or structure may, with the consent of the city council, sue on such bond without joinder of the city as plaintiff. 
(d)  The bond shall be filed in the office of the city secretary. 
(e)  Any person who sells structures for the express purpose of being relocated to another site is excepted from the license and bond requirements. Proof of state required liability insurance is to be provided to the office of the city secretary. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(G)) 
Sec. 78-506. - Fees. 
    Fees shall be assessed as established by the city council, by resolution, and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(H)) 
Sec. 78-507. - Ad valorem taxes. 
    No permit shall be issued to move any house, building or other structure from any location until the applicant furnishes the building official with certificates from the county appraisal district indicating the status of ad valorem taxes on the property. Any delinquent property taxes will have to be addressed to the satisfaction of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(I)) 
Sec. 78-508. - Issuance of permit. 
    The building official shall grant the issuance of a permit under this division when all of the facts, information and approvals required by this division have been furnished by the permit applicant. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(J)) 
Sec. 78-509. - Appeal of denial. 
(a)  Should the building official refuse to issue any permit under this division, the applicant shall have the right of appeal to the city council. The applicant desiring such appeal shall file a written appeal with the city secretary within 15 days of the denial of a permit, which shall include a brief statement of the reasons for the appeal and a detailed statement of facts supporting the appeal. Upon the expiration of the 15-day period without a written appeal being filed with the city secretary as provided in this subsection, the denial shall become final. 
(b)  Any applicant who is dissatisfied with the denial of a permit by the city council may appeal to any district court, which shall determine whether or not the decision of the city council was supported by substantial evidence. The appeal shall not stay the effect of the decision appealed from unless the court to which the appeal is taken shall so order. Upon expiration of the 15-day period without an appeal having been perfected as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the ruling of the city council shall become final. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(L)) 
Secs. 78-510-78-530. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 78-531. - Certain work required. 
    At the time that any house, building or other structure is removed from a property by moving or razing, the owner of the property shall complete the following work, as evidenced by the owner's signature on a no fee additional work agreement: 
(1)  Remove all floor slabs, foundations, footings, sidewalks, fences and posts; 
(2)  Clear and remove all loose tree limbs, appliances and other trash, weeds, tall grass and other debris within 25 feet of the building perimeter; 
(3)  Fill in all holes or depressions remaining at the building site, and level the area to facilitate future mowing maintenance; 
(4)  Mow the grass; 
(5)  After coordination with the plumbing inspector, plug all sewer lines with concrete; and 
(6)  Complete all of the requirements of subsections (1)-(5) of this section within 30 days of the actual moving or completion of razing of the house, building or structure from the property. 
(Code 1995, § 150.16(K)) 
Secs. 78-532-78-560. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - SATELLITE DISH ANTENNAS 

Sec. 78-561. - Conflict requirements. 
    Whenever the requirements of this article are at a variance with the requirements of the general law or any other lawfully adopted rules, regulations or ordinances, the more restrictive requirement or the requirement imposing the higher standards shall govern. 
(Code 1995, § 150.17(E)) 
Sec. 78-562. - Nonconforming uses. 
    By the passage of the ordinance from which this article is derived, no presently illegal use shall be deemed to be legalized, and such use shall remain a nonconforming use. 
(Code 1995, § 150.17(F)) 
Sec. 78-563. - Permit required; fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install a satellite dish antenna without first securing a building permit, and the fee for such permit shall be as established by the city council, by resolution, and on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1995, § 150.17(C)) 
Sec. 78-564. - Installation in residential districts. 
    Satellite dish antennas located in residential districts shall meet the following conditions for installation: 
(1)  Such antennas shall not be located in the front or side yards, and shall be installed so that the closest point on the satellite dish antenna is not less than two feet from any property line. 
(2)  Installation on the roof is permitted, provided that the total height of the structure and the antenna does not exceed the district height restriction as set forth in chapter 98. 
(3)  All antennas shall be installed according to the manufacturer's specifications, and a building permit shall be required for each installation. 
(Code 1995, § 150.17(A)) 
Sec. 78-565. - Installation in commercial districts. 
    Satellite dish antennas located in commercial districts shall meet the following conditions for installation: 
(1)  All permanent installations shall: 
a.  Require a building permit; 
b.  Be installed according to manufacturer's requirements; and 
c.  Meet appropriate setbacks as set forth in chapter 98. 
(2)  All antennas, whether for sales and service or permanent installation, shall be located in a manner that: 
a.  Will not interfere with pedestrian or vehicular movement; 
b.  Shall not be a visual obstruction to traffic; or 
c.  Will not eliminate required parking spaces. 
(Code 1995, § 150.17(B)) 
Sec. 78-566. - Variances. 
    The city council may grant a variation in the yard or setback requirements for satellite dish antennas whenever a property owner can show that a strict application of the terms of this article will impose unusual and practical difficulties or particular hardship upon him due to an irregular shape of the lot or topographical or other conditions, but only when the city council is satisfied that a granting of such variation will not merely serve as a convenience to the property owner, but will alleviate a demonstrable and unusual hardship or difficulty so great as to warrant such variation, and, at the same time, the surrounding property will be properly protected and the general welfare will not be interdicted. 
(Code 1995, § 150.17(D)) 
Sec. 78-567. - Civil remedies. 
    If any satellite dish antenna is erected, constructed, reconstructed, altered, repaired, converted or maintained in violation of the terms of this article, the city, in addition to imposing the penalties provided for in section 1-14, may institute any appropriate action or proceedings in court to prevent the unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, repair, conversion or use, and restrain, correct or abate the violation, and the criminal penalties provided under this section shall not preclude the city from invoking civil remedies given to the city by law in such cases. Such actions and proceedings shall be cumulative of and in addition to the penalties prescribed for such violation. 
(Code 1995, § 150.17(G)) 
Secs. 78-568-78-580. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - UNIFIED BOARD OF APPEALS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-30, § 3, adopted Dec. 13, 2011, enacted provisions designated as Ch. 78, Art. XII. To avoid duplicate Articles and to facilitate indexing, said provisions have been redesignated as Ch. 78, Art. XIII. 

Sec. 78-581. - Unified board of appeals established. 
    In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by code officials relative to the application and interpretation of the codes listed in [ch. 78, Arts. II-X, and ch. 38, Art. II] (hereinafter referred to as "the codes") there shall be and is hereby created a unified board of appeals (hereinafter referred to as "the board"). 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 3, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 78-582. - Ex officio members. 
    The City of Brownwood Code Administrator and/or a city staff member designated thereby, shall serve as ex officio members of the board. Ex officio members shall have the right to debate issues but not make motions, vote or hold office of chair or vice chair. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 3, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 78-583. - Procedures. 
    The board shall utilize the "Guide to Parliamentary Procedure" as adopted by the Brownwood City Council on November 12, 1996 for conducting its business and shall render all decisions and findings in writing. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 3, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 78-584. - Application for appeal. 
    Any person shall have the right to appeal a decision of the code official to the board of appeals. The application for appeal shall be filed on a form obtained from the City of Brownwood code administrator within 20 days after appellant was notified of the official's decision. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 3, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 78-585. - Powers and duties of the board. 
(a)  The board shall have no authority to waive the requirements of the adopted codes. 
(b)  Hearing of all appeals from rulings or actions of the city Code officers by persons aggrieved thereby who shall have followed the procedures for an appeal as provided in this article. 
(c)  The board may issue non-binding advisory opinions as to the true intent of the codes or rules adopted thereunder and make written recommendations and suggestions to the city council for the improvement, enforcement and administration of the codes. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 3, 12-13-2011) 
Sec. 78-586. - Membership of the board. 
    The board of appeals shall consist of five members appointed by the mayor, and approved by the city council, as follows: one for five years, one for four years, one for three years, one for two years and one for one year. Thereafter, each new member shall serve for five years or until a successor has been appointed. 
(a)  Qualifications. The board of appeals shall consist of five individuals, one from each of the following professions or disciplines: 
(1)  Registered design professional who is a registered architect or engineer with structural experience; or a builder or superintendent of building construction with at least ten years experience, five years of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(2)  Registered design professional with mechanical engineering experience; or a licensed mechanical tradesman licensed and possessing at least ten years experience, five years of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(3)  Registered design professional with electrical engineering experience; or a licensed Master Electrician possessing at least ten years experience, five years of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(4)  Registered design professional with plumbing engineering experience; or a licensed Master Plumber possessing at least ten years experience, five years of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(5)  Citizen at large. Mayoral appointment of a citizen representing the public consumer of the services regulated by the adopted codes. 
(b)  Alternate members. The mayor shall appoint, subject to approval of the city council, at least one alternate for each board position. Alternates shall sit when regular members are not available. 
(c)  Chairman. The board shall annually select one of its members to serve as chair person. A vice chair person shall also be elected to serve when the chair person cannot. 
(d)  Disqualification of member. A member shall not hear an appeal in which that member has a conflict of interest as defined under V.T.C.A. Local Government Code ch. 171. 
(e)  Secretary. The chief administrative officer shall designate a qualified clerk to serve as secretary to the board. The secretary shall file a detailed record of all proceedings in the office of the chief administrative officer. 
(f)  Member compensation. Members shall not be compensated. 
(g)  Appeal. Any person dissatisfied with any ruling, order or decision of a city Code officer, his authorized representative or other officer in the enforcement of this article may appeal such ruling, order or decision to the unified board of appeals. The person desiring to appeal shall file a written appeal in the office of the code administrator within 15 days of any ruling, order or decision appealed from, which shall include a brief statement of the reasons for the appeal and a detailed statement of the facts supporting the appeal. Upon the expiration of the 15-day period without a written appeal being filed with the code administrator as provided in this subsection, the order, ruling or decision by the Code officer, his authorized representative or any other officer in the enforcement of this article shall become final. 
(h)  Investigation; stay of order appealed from. Upon the filing of an appeal pursuant to the provisions of subsection (h) of this section, the code administrator, if he has not already done so, shall personally investigate the facts upon which the order, ruling or decision appealed from is based. If, in the opinion of the code administrator, based upon such personal investigation, the facts warrant a stay of the effect of the order, ruling or decision appealed from, pending a determination of the appeal by the unified board of appeals, the code administrator may order such stay. 
(i)  Hearing by unified board of appeals. 
(1)  Upon receipt of an appeal as provided in subsection (h) of this section, the code administrator shall notify the chairperson of the unified board of appeals. The appeal shall be heard no later than 15 days after receipt of the appeal. Upon filing of the appeal, the appellant shall be notified of the time and place of the appeal hearing. When five members are not present to hear an appeal, either the appellant or the appellant's representative shall have the right to request a postponement of the hearing. 
Prior to the hearing, the code administrator shall furnish each member of the unified board of appeals with a copy of the written appeal, a copy of the order or ruling appealed from, a copy of the section of the order involved in the appeal, and any other facts pertinent to the appeal. 
(2)  The unified board of appeals shall try the appeal de novo, and the hearings shall be public. The appellant or his representatives and the Code officers shall be granted the opportunity to be heard. Any other person whose interest may be affected may be granted the opportunity to be heard. Such evidence as is pertinent may be introduced by either party. The unified board of appeals may adopt rules of procedure as it deems appropriate for the conduct of the hearing. The chairperson of the board shall administer the oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses for the purposes of the hearing. 
(j)  Decisions of the board; records. A concurring vote of the majority of the members of the unified board of appeals present shall be necessary to reverse or modify rulings, orders or decision of the authority appealed from. All decisions of the board shall be in writing. The board shall keep clear and detailed minutes of all proceedings, including its decision, the reasons for such decision and the vote of each member participating in the decision. Immediately following the board's decision, the record shall be filed in the office of the code administrator and shall be a public record. Notice of the board's decision shall be properly furnished to the appellant, his representatives or any other person who has filed a written entry of appearance and the Code officer. 
(k)  Appeals from decisions of the board. A person desiring to appeal a decision of the unified board of appeals shall, within 15 days after a decision of the board is rendered, appeal to any district court of the county. The court shall determine constitutional issues, questions of law and whether or not the decision of the unified board of appeals was supported by substantial evidence. The appeal shall not stay the effect of the decision appealed from unless the court from which the appeal is taken shall order such stay. Upon the expiration of the 15-day period without an appeal having been perfected as provided in this subsection, the ruling of the unified board of appeals shall become final and nonappealable. 
(Ord. No. 11-30, § 3, 12-13-2011) 
Chapter 82 - FLOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34; natural resources, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; utilities, ch. 70; buildings and building regulations, ch. 78; manufactured homes and parks, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 94; zoning, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Flood Control and Insurance Act, V.T.C.A., Water Code § 16.311 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 82-1-82-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-30. - Statutory authorization. 
    The Legislature of the State of Texas has in the Flood Control Insurance Act, V.T.C.A., Texas Water Code § 16.315, delegated the responsibility of local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to minimize flood losses. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, 7-14-2009) 
Sec. 82-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Appeal means a request for a review of the city planner/building official's interpretation of any provision of this article or a request for a variance. 
    Appurtenant structure means a structure which is on the same parcel of property as the principal structure to be insured and the use of which is incidental to the use of the principal structure. 
    Area of shallow flooding means a designated AO zone on the city's flood insurance rate map (FIRM), with base flood depths range from one to three feet. Such conditions occurs where a clearly defined channel does not exist, the path of flooding is unpredictable and indeterminate, and velocity flow may be evident. 
    Area of special flood hazard means the land in the floodplain within the city subject to a one percent or greater chance of flooding in any given year. 
    Base flood means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
    Base flood elevation (BFE) means the elevation shown on the flood insurance rate map (FIRM) and found in the accompanying flood insurance study (FIS) for zones A, AE, AH, A1-A30 or AR, that indicates the water surface elevation resulting from the flood that has a one percent chance of equaling or exceeding that level in any given year (also called the base flood). 
    Basement means any area of the building having its floor subgrade (below ground level) on all sides. 
    Critical feature means an integral and readily identifiable part of a flood protection system, without which the flood protection provided by the entire system would be compromised. 
    Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations. 
    Elevated building means a nonbasement building built: 
(1)  In the case of a building in zones A1-30, AE, A, A99, AO, AH, B, C, X and D, to have the top of the elevated floor, or in the case of a building in zones V1-30, VE or V, to have the bottom of the lowest horizontal structure member of the elevated floor: 
a.  Elevated above the ground level by means of pilings, columns (posts and piers) or shear walls parallel to the floor of the water; and 
b.  Adequately anchored so as not to impair the structural integrity of the building during a flood of up to the magnitude of the base flood. 
(2)  In the case of zones A1-30, AE, A, A99, AO, AH, B, C, X and D, also, a building elevated by means of fill or solid foundation perimeter walls with openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movement of floodwaters. 
(3)  In the case of zones V1-30, VE or V, also, a building otherwise meeting the definition of an "elevated building," even though the lower area is enclosed by means of breakaway walls if the breakaway walls meet the standards of 44 CFR 60.3(e)(5) of the National Flood Insurance Program regulations. 
    Existing construction and existing structure mean, for the purposes of determining rates, structures for which the start of construction commenced before the effective date of the flood insurance rate map (FIRM) or before January 1, 1975, for the FIRMs effective before such date. 
    Flood and flooding mean a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the: 
(1)  Overflow of inland or tidal waters. 
(2)  Unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Flood boundary-floodway map (FBFM) means an official map of the city, issued by the Federal Insurance Administration, where the areas within the boundaries of special flood hazards have been designated as zone A. 
    Flood insurance rate map (FIRM) means the official map of the city on which the Federal Insurance Administration has delineated both the areas of special flood hazards and the risk premium zones applicable to the city. 
    Flood insurance study means the official report provided by the Federal Insurance Administration. The report contains flood profiles, the water surface elevation of the base flood, as well as the flood boundary-floodway map. 
    Flood protection system means the physical structural works for which funds have been authorized, appropriated and expended and which have been specifically constructed to modify flooding in order to reduce the extent of the areas within the city subject to a special flood hazard and the extent of the depths of associated flooding. Such a system typically includes hurricane tidal barriers, dams, reservoirs, levees or dikes. Such specialized flood modifying works are those constructed in conformance with sound engineering standards. 
    Floodplain and flood-prone area mean any land area susceptible to being inundated by water from any source. See the definition of Flood . 
    Floodplain management means the operation of an overall program of corrective and preventive measures for reducing flood damage, including, but not limited to, emergency preparedness plans, flood control works and floodplain management regulations. 
    Floodway means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than a designated height. 
    Functionally dependent use means a use which cannot perform its intended purpose unless it is located or carried out in close proximity to water. Such term includes only docking facilities, port facilities that are necessary for the loading and unloading of cargo or passengers, and ship building and ship repair facilities, but does not include long-term storage or related manufacturing facilities. 
    Habitable floor means any floor usable for the purpose of working, sleeping, eating, cooking or recreation, or a combination thereof. A floor used for storage purposes only is not a habitable floor. 
    Highest adjacent grade means the highest natural elevation of the ground surface, prior to construction, next to the proposed walls of a structure. 
    Levee means a manmade structure, usually an earthen embankment, designed and constructed in accordance with sound engineering practices to contain, control or divert the flow of water so as to provide protection from temporary flooding. 
    Levee system means a flood protection system consisting of a levee and associated structures, such as closure and drainage devices, which are constructed and operated in accordance with sound engineering practices.
