    A-frame sign means a stationery outdoor sign with two faces attached at one surface on each face to form a triangle with one side parallel to the grade, which sign is often used to advertise fuel prices. 
    Animation means the presentation of pictorials or graphics in a progression of frames which give the illusion of motion, including moving objects, moving patterns or bands of light, or expanding or contracting shapes. 
    Average grade means the grade of the finished ground level at the midpoint of each exterior surface of a sign, or a structure if the sign is attached to the structure. 
    Awning sign, canopy sign and marquee sign mean a projecting sign attached to, hung from or painted on a canopy or covered structure, which extends beyond the building line or property line. 
    Back-to-back sign means a structure with two parallel signs with their faces oriented in opposite directions, located not more than ten feet apart. A back-to-back sign shall constitute one off-premises sign. 
    Billboard means any freestanding sign or a sign that is attached to or part of a building, and is an off-premises sign. 
    Building official means the designated authority for enforcement of this chapter. 
    Candelas means a unit of luminous intensity, defined as the amount of luminous flux (total luminous power emitted from a source and expressed as lumens) per unit solid angle in a given direction. 
    Community service sign means any sign which solicits support for, or advertises, a nonprofit community use or social institution. Such signs may include, but shall not be limited to, seasonal holidays, such as Christmas or Easter, school activities, charitable programs or religious activities. 
    Crown of street means the highest point of grade elevation of a cross section of a street, usually at a point approximately on the centerline of a street. 
    Cultural facilities means establishments, such as museums, art galleries, public libraries, botanical and zoological gardens, and theaters of the performing arts, which, although they may charge an admission fee, are essentially nonprofit and principally funded through public expenditures, grants and donations. 
    Dissolve/fade means a mode of message transition on an electronic billboard or electronic message sign accomplished by varying the light intensity or pattern, where the first message gradually reduces intensity or appears to dissipate to the point of not being legible and the subsequent message gradually appears or increases intensity to the point of legibility. 
    Electronic billboard means an off-premises sign which permits light to be turned on or off periodically or which is operated in a way whereby light is turned on or off periodically, including any illuminated sign in which such illumination is not kept stationary or constant in intensity and color at all times when such sign is in use, including an LED (light emitting diode) or digital sign that varies in intensity or color. An electronic billboard does not include a sign located within the right-of-way that functions as a traffic control device and that is described and identified in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MLJTCD), as amended and approved by the Federal Highway Administration as the national standard. 
    Electronic message sign means an on-premises sign which permits light to be turned on or off periodically or which is operated in a way whereby light is turned on or off periodically, including any illuminated sign in which such illumination is not kept stationary or constant in intensity and color at all times when such sign is in use, including an LED (light emitting diode) or digital sign that varies in intensity or color. 
    Electronic message sign/large means an on-premises electronic message sign that exceeds 30 square feet in size. 
    Electronic message sign/small means an on-premises electronic message sign that does not exceed 30 square feet in size. 
    Erect means to construct, build, raise, assemble, place, affix, attach, create, paint, draw or in any way bring into being or establish. 
    Flashing means a sign containing an intermittent or blinking light source, or which gives the illusion of intermittent or blinking light by means of animation, or an externally mounted intermittent light source. 
    Floodway means the channel of a stream and adjacent land areas which are required to carry and discharge the floodwaters and flood flows of any river or stream associated with the regulatory flood. (Refer to floodway boundary and floodway maps which identify special flood hazard areas resulting from a scientific and engineering report entitled "The Flood Insurance Study for the City of Brownwood".) 
    Frame means a complete, static display screen on the entire face of an electronic billboard or electronic message sign. 
    Frame effect means a visual effect applied to a single frame to transition from one message to the next. 
    Freestanding sign means any sign which is not attached to, or on the walls, face or exterior of, a building, except as provided in the definition of a "Standard roof sign". 
    Glare means an effect created when an illumination source shines with sufficient brightness to cause discomfort, distract attention, or lead to the reduction or loss of visibility or visual function of the public. 
    Hanging sign means a sign which is suspended over a sidewalk, street or other public right-of-way. An overhanging sign may or may not be a projecting sign. 
    Height means the vertical distance between the highest part of the sign or its supporting structure, whichever is higher, and that point on the crown of the street which is used to establish the setback of the sign, as setback is hereinafter defined. For signs located 200 feet or further from a street, height shall be considered to be the vertical distance between the highest part of the sign or its supporting structure, whichever is higher, and the highest adjacent grade. The term "highest adjacent grade", for the purpose of this definition, means the highest natural elevation of the ground surface prior to construction next to the structural support of the sign. 
    Historic building or structure means any building or structure which is officially designated as historically or architecturally significant by a unit of the local, state or federal government. 
    Home occupation sign means any nonilluminated nameplate sign which does not exceed one square foot in area. 
    Lumens means the luminous flux emitted per unit solid angle from a uniform point source whose luminous intensity is one candela. 
    Major thoroughfare means each street designated as a thoroughfare on the thoroughfare plan, including all existing and proposed streets shown on the major street plan adopted by the city council. 
    Moving video shall mean the use of live action footage shot with a video camera or similar device which is sized to fit and be displayed by an electronic message sign. Moving video shall not include animation as defined in this article. 
    Nits means a photometric unit defined as cd/m 2 (candelas per square meter). 
    Official sign means any sign erected by or at the direction of any governmental body. 
    Off-premises sign means a sign displaying advertising or information copy that refers to a business, person, organization, activity, event, place, service or product not principally located or primarily manufactured or sold on the premises on which the sign is located. 
    On-premises sign means a sign identifying or advertising a business, person, or activity and installed and maintained on the same premises as the business, person or activity, or displaying a noncommercial message on the premises of a business, person or activity. 
    Outdoor advertising sign. See the definition of "Advertising sign". 
    Political sign means a temporary sign announcing or supporting political candidates or issues in connection with any national, state or local election. 
    Portable sign means any sign which is designed or constructed to be easily moved from one location to another, including signs mounted upon, or designed to be mounted upon, a trailer, wheeled carrier or other nonmotorized mobile structure. 
    Portable sign, small, means any portable sign, as defined herein, that does not exceed 64 square feet in area and/or ten feet in height. 
    Premises means any lot or unplatted tract, or any combination of contiguous lots or unplatted tracts, held under single ownership. 
    Projecting sign means a sign affixed to any building, wall, roof, marquee or other structural element which extends or projects more than 12 inches from the wall, roof, marquee or other structural element. 
    Public information sign means any sign which is intended to identify community, civic or social events and is not a commercial, political, official or real estate sign. 
    Real estate sign means a temporary sign displayed during, and in connection with, construction operations, pertaining to the lease or sale of a lot or building upon which the sign is placed, and not exceeding 64 square feet, and pertaining to the sale of an addition or a subdivision, the area of which subdivision exceeds one acre of land for a period not to exceed two years. 
    Residential nameplate sign means a sign permitted for the sole purpose of identifying the inhabitant residing in the house, the house name or the address of the house. The sign may contain no advertising of any kind and may not exceed two square feet in area. 
    Roof sign means a sign attached to a roof, and extending more than three feet above the ridge line. 
    Scroll/travel means a mode of message transition on an electronic sign where the message appears to move vertically or horizontally across the display surface. 
    Setback means a line parallel to and the required distance from the lot frontage adjacent to any street abutting the lot or tract in question, or a line parallel to and the required distance from any lot abutting the side of the lot or tract in question. For purposes of determining the requirements for this definition, no portion of any sign or its support shall project or extend beyond the required setback line. 
    Sign means any structure or combination of structure and/or message in the form of a display, device, figure, painting, drawing, placard, poster, billboard, advertising structure, advertisement, logo, symbol or other form designed to advertise or to inform the public. The term "sign" does not include an official traffic control sign, an official governmental marker, a national, state, city, or educational institution flag, or governmental signs and announcements. 
    Sloping roof sign means a sign affixed to the wall, roof, marquee or other structural element of any building, which does not project more than 12 inches from the wall, roof, marquee or other structural element or extend more than three feet above the wall to which the sign is attached. 
    Spectacular sign means any sign that physically rotates, oscillates, contains any moving parts, or contains flashing lights, including lights flashing in sequence. 
    Temporary sign means a sign not permanently affixed to a building, structure or the ground. 
    Traffic control sign means a permitted sign for the purpose of identifying parking areas and directing the flow of traffic on private property. 
    Transition means a visual effect used on an electronic billboard or electronic message sign to change from one message to another. 
    Wall sign. See the definition of "Sloping roof sign". 
(Code 1995, § 154.04; Ord. No. 02-31, § 3, 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 04-10, § I, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 08-36, § I, 10-14-2008) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-3. - Findings; purpose. 
(a)  In order to promote a positive city image reflecting harmony and order, the city council finds that it is appropriate to regulate signs and provide uniform sign standards. 
(b)  New businesses and industries are increasingly basing their decisions to locate in a particular area on the quality of life in that area, and the regulation of visual clutter can help to preserve such quality and promote the steady growth that is vital to continued economic health and prosperity of the city. 
(c)  The city council further recognizes that the proliferation of signs without reasonable regulation and control can create a hazardous driving condition by distracting the motoring public. 
(d)  In enacting the regulations set forth in this chapter, special notice has been taken of the often competing viewpoints of citizens and the sign industry, particularly the part of the industry engaged in billboard operations. This chapter has been designed to protect and accommodate both concerns. 
(e)  Therefore, the general objectives of this chapter are to promote health, safety, welfare, convenience and enjoyment of the public, while recognizing that the reasonable and orderly display of signs is a necessary public service and a necessity for the conduct of commerce and industry in the continuing quest to inform, direct and attract shoppers and prospective clients. 
(Code 1995, § 154.02) 
Sec. 90-4. - Compliance required. 
    All signs shall be erected, displayed and maintained in compliance with the requirements of this chapter and all other applicable state laws and city ordinances. If there is a conflict between the regulations of this chapter and a state law or city ordinance, the most restrictive standard applies and controls. 
(Ord. No. 02-31, § 1(154.021), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-5. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to the entire area within the corporate limits of the city and those areas within the extraterritorial jurisdiction (ETJ) of the city. For those areas within the ETJ, the allowable signage shall be determined by the regulations from the most restrictive zoning district in which the use would be allowed as if the signage was within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 154.03; Ord. No. 02-31, § 2, 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-6. - Nonconforming signs. 
    Any sign which existed and/or was erected prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, and which does not conform to the intent and specifications of this chapter, is considered to be a nonconforming sign. A nonconforming sign may remain in place as long as it is kept in good repair and maintained in a safe condition. Loss of legal nonconforming status will result if the nonconforming sign is part of an establishment that discontinues its operation for a continuous period of one year. 
(Code 1995, § 154.35) 
Secs. 90-7-90-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 90-41. - Authority for enforcement and administration. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the city building official/electrical inspector and administered by the zoning administrator. The building official/electrical inspector shall have the authority to order the painting, repair or removal of a sign. 
(Code 1995, § 154.45) 
Sec. 90-42. - Removal of signs. 
(a)  The building official may order the removal of any sign that is not maintained in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. If any sign is installed, erected or constructed in violation of the terms of this chapter, the building official shall notify, by registered mail or written notice served personally, the owner or lessee thereof to alter such sign so as to comply with this chapter and to secure the necessary permit therefor, or to remove the sign. If such order is not complied with within ten days, the building official shall remove the sign at the expense of the owner or lessee thereof. 
(b)  All abandoned signs and their supports shall be removed within 90 days from the date of abandonment. 
(c)  All damaged signs shall be removed within 90 days from the date of such damage, except in times of natural disaster. The building official shall have the authority to grant a one-time extension, not to exceed 90 days, for abandoned, nondamaged signs, provided that the extension is requested in writing. 
(Code 1995, § 154.36(B)) 
Sec. 90-43. - Variance procedures. 
(a)  An applicant for a sign permit may include with the sign permit application an application for a variance from the requirements of this chapter on forms approved by the board of adjustment for use. The application shall state the reasons why the applicant requests a variance. 
(b)  The procedures for consideration of the variance are set forth in section 98-64. 
(c)  The board, subject to appropriate conditions, may authorize only the following variances from the requirements of this section if it finds that the public convenience and welfare will substantially be served, that the appropriate use of the neighboring area will not be substantially affected and that the variance is the minimum necessary to prevent an unnecessary hardship not created by the applicant: 
(1)  A variance from the front or side yard setbacks. 
(2)  A variance from the height restrictions. 
The board may not grant a variance from the size or spacing requirements for signs. 
(d)  The board, as authorized by section 98-65, may hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order, requirements, decision or determination made by the building official in the administration of this section. 
(Code 1995, § 154.46; Ord. No. 02-31, § 11, 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 12-18, § I, 10-9-2012) 
Sec. 90-44. - Board on sign control. 
(a)  Pursuant to V.C.T.A., Local Government Code § 216.001 et seq., there is hereby created a city board on sign control to consist of five members. 
(b)  The city board on sign control shall have all powers and perform all duties vested in the board by or under V.C.T.A., Local Government Code § 216.004 et seq. 
(c)  The code administrator of the city or his designee shall be an ex officio member of the board without the power to vote and in such capacity shall act as secretary to the board and shall set up and maintain the minutes and record of all board activities, actions, notices, attendance, orders and proceedings. 
(d)  The members of the board on sign control shall be appointed by the mayor as the presiding officer of the city council. 
(e)  Members of the board shall be appointed for terms of two years. 
(f)  The membership of the board shall be composed of the following persons: 
(1)  Two persons who must be real estate appraisers, each of whom must be a member in good standing of a nationally recognized professional appraiser society or trade organization that has an established code of ethics, educational program, and professional certification program; 
(2)  One person who must be engaged in the sign business in the city; 
(3)  One person who must be an employee of the state department of transportation and must be familiar with real estate valuations in eminent domain proceedings; and 
(4)  One person who must be an architect or a landscape architect licensed by the state. 
(Ord. No. 02-31, § 10(154.47), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-45. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person found in violation of this chapter shall be subject to the penalties found in section 1-14 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 08-36, § II, 10-14-2008) 
Secs. 90-46-90-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LICENSES AND PERMITS 

Sec. 90-71. - License required. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation engaged in the commercial sign business, including, without limitation, constructing, erecting, installing, or relocating commercial signs within the corporate limits of the city shall obtain a commercial sign contractor's license and such license shall require annual renewal. 
(Code 1995, § 154.15; Ord. No. 02-31, § 4, 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-72. - Bond required. 
    Before any person shall be issued a commercial sign contractor's license to engage in the sign business in the city and a permit for the installation, erection, and maintenance of signs, such person shall first file with the city a performance bond guaranteeing performance and compliance with all applicable laws of the city, including, without limitation, this chapter. The performance bond shall be issued by a corporate surety licensed to do business in the state in the sum of $3,000.00. The performance bond shall insure that the licensee and permittee shall install, erect, repair, maintain, remove and/or demolish signs in accordance with the prevailing standards of the trade and with this chapter. The performance bond shall remain in place for as long as the licensee and permittee has signs permitted in the city and/or the city's ETJ. Notwithstanding the foregoing, wall signs shall be exempted from bonding requirements. 
(Code 1995, § 154.16; Ord. No. 02-31, § 5, 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-73. - Permits required. 
(a)  Requirement. Except as set forth in subsection 90-101(2), a permit shall be obtained from the city for a proposed sign. 
(b)  Applications for permits. An application for a permit shall contain information concerning the location and size of the sign, date to be erected, value, name, address and telephone number of the sign owner, name, address and telephone number of the sign lessee, if any, and the name, address and telephone number of the owner of the property where the sign is to be located. An application for a permit shall also include a drawing to scale of the proposed sign, including a list indicating the size of all existing signs maintained on the premises and visible from the right-of-way, a drawing of the lot plan or building facade indicating the proposed location of the sign, and specifications for its construction, lighting, motion and wiring, if any. If the ownership or leasehold interest of any sign for which a permit has been issued changes, the permit holder shall provide this information to the city within 30 days. 
(c)  Structural. For the purposes of the structural design of signs, the building code of the city adopted in section 78-31 shall be utilized. All signs 35 feet and higher shall have a professional engineer's seal. 
(d)  Electrical. All illuminated signs or signs utilizing any electrical devices shall require an electrical permit and shall be wired in accordance with the electrical code of the city. 
(e)  Permit to enlarge, alter, repair, etc. No sign shall be altered, rebuilt, enlarged, extended, replaced or relocated, nor shall sign faces be renewed or neon tubing be rearranged when the values of such work exceeds 50 percent of the cost of erecting a new sign of the same type at the same location, except upon the issuance of a permit, and all work done under such permit shall be in conformity with the requirements of all applicable laws of the city, including all sign location requirements of the city. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a sign owner who desires to repair or rebuild a sign where the value of such work exceeds 50 percent of the cost of erecting a new sign of the same type at the same location may seek a variance to the location requirements of applicable city laws from the board of adjustment, pursuant to sections 90-43 and 98-64, if the owner can establish by a preponderance of the evidence that the following has occurred: 
(1)  A sign was located in a conforming location when it was originally permitted and constructed, but such sign would no longer be allowed to be constructed, repaired or rebuilt in such location pursuant to the applicable laws of the city; 
(2)  The sign was damaged or destroyed by a natural disaster, vandalism or the negligence of a third party and due to no fault of the sign owner, its agents, employees, contractors or assigns, and the sign was in good condition and being maintained in accordance with all applicable laws; and 
(3)  The sign owner makes a written request for a variance to the city no later than 30 days following such damage or destruction of the sign. 
(f)  Construction time limitations. Construction activities pertaining to permanent off-premises signs must commence within 30 days of the date the sign permit is issued by the city. Construction will be completed within 45 days of such date. Failure to comply with these provisions will result in the revocation of the sign permit. In addition, the same applicant may not reapply for another sign permit for the location concerned for a period of six months. 
(g)  Fees. No permit shall be issued until the applicant has paid a sign permit and inspection fee. A fee shall be paid on all signs requiring a permit in accordance with the schedule of permit fees, pursuant to the International Building Code, as amended, and kept on file in the office of the zoning administrator, or as established by the city council by ordinance and placed on file in the office of the city secretary. No permit fee shall be required for a sign 15 square feet or less over a show window or door of a store or business establishment which contains only the name of the proprietor and nature of the business. No permit shall be required for ground signs; provided that such signs are not over four square feet in area; and provided further that no business or location shall have more than 12 square feet of ground signs cumulative on any one location without a permit. 
(Code 1995, § 154.17; Ord. No. 02-31, § 6, 7-9-2002) 
Secs. 90-74-90-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-101. - Sign requiring permits; exceptions. 
    This section sets forth the categories of permanent and temporary signs governed by the provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  Signs requiring a permit under the provisions of this chapter are as follows: 
a.  Back-to-back signs. 
b.  Billboard signs. 
c.  Canopy signs. 
d.  Hanging signs. 
e.  Marquee signs. 
f.  Portable signs. 
g.  Projecting signs. 
h.  Roof signs. 
i.  Sloping roof signs. 
j.  Wall signs. 
k.  Electronic billboards. 
1.  Electronic message signs. 
(2)  Signs not requiring a permit under the provisions of this chapter are as follows: 
a.  A-frame signs. 
b.  Community service signs. 
c.  Home occupation signs. 
d.  Official signs. 
e.  Political signs, temporary. 
f.  Public information signs, temporary. 
g.  Real estate signs, temporary. 
h.  Residential nameplate signs. 
i.  Traffic control signs on private property. 
j.  Portable signs, small. 
(Code 1995, § 154.30; Ord. No. 04-10, § II, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 08-36, § III, 10-14-2008) 
Sec. 90-102. - Prohibited signs. 
    The following signs shall be prohibited in all districts: 
(1)  Searchlights, except they may be permitted for a period not to exceed ten days for grand openings or other special occasions. 
(2)  Any sign which resembles official traffic signs or signals, or which bear the term "stop", "go slow", "caution", "danger", "warning" or similar words, or any sign which, by reason of its size, color, location, movement or manner of illumination, may be confused with a traffic control sign, signal or device. 
(3)  Lighted signs within 100 feet of a residential district, unless lighting is shielded from view in the direction of the residential district. 
(4)  Signs erected closer than six feet to any telephone cable, power line or streetlight standard. 
(5)  Signs containing statements, words or pictures of an obscene, indecent or immoral nature. 
(6)  Spectacular signs and signs which emit audible sound, odor or visible matter. 
(Code 1995, § 154.33; Ord. No. 08-36, § III, 10-14-2008) 
Sec. 90-103. - Signs not requiring a license, bond or permit. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the following signs, except that no license, bond or permit will be required for such signs: 
(1)  Prior existing signs. A legal sign in existence before the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. 
(2)  Holiday displays. Temporary displays, commonly associated with any national, local or religious holiday or celebration. 
(3)  Home occupation signs. One nonilluminated nameplate, not exceeding one square foot in area, which is used to identify legal home occupations. 
(4)  Official signs. Federal, state or local government traffic, directional and informational signs and notices issued by any court, person or officer in the performance of a public duty. 
(5)  Political signs. See section 90-168. 
(6)  Public utility signs. Signs giving information regarding the location of underground electric transmission lines, telegraph or telephone properties and facilities, pipelines, public sewers or water lines. 
(7)  Real estate signs. Temporary signs advertising the sale, lease or development of the property on which the signs are located. Such signs shall not exceed 64 square feet. 
(8)  Residential nameplate signs. Signs indicating the name and/or address of the occupants of the residence, not to exceed two square feet in area. 
(9)  Safety, warning and directional signs. Signs warning of construction, excavation or similar hazards, and parking lot and other private traffic directional signs, each not to exceed the uniform sizes recommended in the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways. Such signs are limited to directing pedestrian and vehicular traffic within the premises on which they are located and are not intended to advertise a product or service. 
(10)  Portable signs (small). A portable sign that does not exceed 64 square feet in area and/or ten feet in height. 
(Code 1995, § 154.34; Ord. No. 04-10, § III, 3-9-2004) 
Sec. 90-104. - Maintenance. 
    All signs shall be maintained in a safe, presentable or structurally sound condition, at all times, including replacement of defective parts. All pennants, banners, streamers, spinning or similar moving devices shall be kept in a presentable condition, at all times. The owner of any property on which a sign is located and the persons responsible for maintenance of the sign shall be equally responsible for the condition of the sign and the area in the immediate vicinity of the sign, and shall be required to keep the area clean, sanitary and free from noxious or offensive substances, rubbish and flammable waste materials. 
(Code 1995, § 154.36(A)) 
Secs. 90-105-90-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GENERAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 90-131. - Contents. 
    This division contains the general regulations pertaining to the location, size, number, height, setback and spacing of signs. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31) 
Sec. 90-132. - Identification of outdoor advertising display signs. 
    Every outdoor advertising display sign erected, constructed or maintained, for which a permit is required, shall be plainly marked with the name of the person erecting and maintaining such sign. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(A)) 
Sec. 90-133. - Location restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, erect, construct, or use any signs in any residential district, including, without limitation, R-1, R-1A, R-1B, R-2, R-3 or MH residential districts, except residential name plate signs, home occupation signs, lease or sale signs, temporary signs displayed during construction and in connection with construction operations, temporary signs pertaining to the sale of an addition or subdivision, freestanding institutional signs, as described herein and political signs. 
(b)  No sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained so as to obstruct any fire escape, window, door or opening used as a means of egress. 
(c)  No sign shall be attached to a fire escape, nor be placed in a manner so as to interfere with any opening required for legal ventilation. 
(d)  No sign shall be erected on or over public property in a manner which interferes with any fire hydrant, traffic light or streetlight, or which hampers the functions of the fire department. 
(e)  No person shall place or maintain a flashing light or flashing electric light of any kind or color within 1,000 feet of any state maintained street or highway intersection, unless a permit is granted by the state highway commission for such sign. All lighting shall be shielded so as to prevent intensive light or glare on adjacent property and roadways. 
(f)  V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code §§ 752.004 and 752.006 make it unlawful to operate or erect any object within six feet of high voltage overhead electric lines and to operate machinery or equipment within ten feet of high voltage electric lines. All signs which are erected, constructed, installed or relocated shall comply with such statute and the minimum clearance restrictions set out in the National Electrical Safety Code and OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.1807. 
(g)  No sign will be permitted in areas identified as floodways or the 100-year floodplain without compliance with the requirements for a special development permit. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(B); Ord. No. 02-31, § 7(B), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-134. - Fastening and anchoring. 
    All signs shall be securely fastened or anchored to a building wall, structural framing or other foundation with a sufficient number of bolts or anchors to resist stress resulting from the dead weight of the sign and wind loads. (See the building code adopted in section 78-31 for allowable working stresses.) Trees, rocks, bridges, fences, windmills, towers, utility poles and dilapidated buildings shall not be used for sign supports. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(C)) 
Sec. 90-135. - Construction materials. 
    All signs shall be constructed of durable materials and securely attached to framework and supports made of wood, metal or other material of an equivalent strength. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(D)) 
Sec. 90-136. - Electrically illuminated signs. 
(a)  Electrically illuminated signs (including electronic billboards and electronic message signs), or signs which are equipped in any way with electrical devices or appliances, shall conform to the provisions of chapter 78, article X. 
(b)  Light from any exterior source intended to illuminate a sign: 
(1)  Shall be shaded, shielded or directed in such a way so that the light intensity or brightness shall not adversely affect the vision of pedestrians or vehicle operators on public or private streets, driveways or parking areas, or operators of aircraft in the approach path to any airport runway; 
(2)  Shall not be flashing. 
(c)  Illumination from any sign: 
(1)  Shall not interfere with the effectiveness of any official traffic sign, signal or device. 
(2)  Shall not be flashing. 
(3)  Shall not exceed 5,000 nits (candelas per square meter) during the daylight hours or 500 nits between dusk and dawn, as measured from the sign's face. 
(d)  Electronic message signs and electronic billboards must have an electronic control to produce the required illumination change required in subsection (c). 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(E); Ord. No. 08-36, § IV, 10-14-2008) 
Sec. 90-137. - Right of entry for inspection. 
    The city building official/electrical inspector shall have the right to visit any site where a sign is being erected, or enter any building where a sign is being constructed for installation within the city, for the purpose of making any necessary inspection. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(F)) 
Sec. 90-138. - Public rights-of-way. 
(a)  No sign may be placed on or over a public right-of-way, whether used or unused, across the public right-of-way extended across a railroad right-of-way, on utility poles or in such a manner as to create a hazard to traffic, except as set forth below in the commercial areas located in the development area created by the city in Ordinance No. 99-37. Signs projecting from a building or extending over a public right-of-way in the development area shall maintain a clear height of nine feet above the sidewalk grade, and all such signs shall not extend into the public right-of-way for a distance of more than two feet of the curbline. Bench signs located on public property are exempt from this provision if approval has been granted pursuant to a contract with the city for the location of such bench signs. 
(b)  In no instance shall a sign extend into the right-of-way of any state maintained street or highway. 
(c)  No pole, post or standard used to support any sign or floodlight shall be set in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public property. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(G); Ord. No. 02-31, § 7(G), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-139. - Area beneath freestanding signs. 
    A 100 square foot area beneath freestanding signs shall be mowed and maintained in a neat and clean condition. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(H)) 
Sec. 90-140. - Area calculation. 
    In calculating the area of a sign, the perimeter of the area shall be a line including the outer extremities of all letters, figures, characters and delineations, or a line including the outer extremities or the framework of the background upon which the sign is placed, whichever line includes the larger area. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(I)) 
Sec. 90-141. - Freestanding billboard signs prohibited in certain areas. 
    Freestanding billboard signs are prohibited in the following areas: 
(1)  The development area created by the city in Ordinance No. 99-37; 
(2)  The entire length of Austin Avenue; and 
(3)  The entire length of Coggin Avenue. 
(Code 1995, § 154.31(J); Ord. No. 02-31, § 7(J), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-142. - Height of signs. 
(a)  Except as set forth in this section, no sign shall exceed a height of 35 feet unless located along an interstate highway or a state highway, whereupon the maximum height shall not exceed 42 feet. 
(b)  Signs located in an area 660 feet from state highways and bound by West Austin Avenue, the slough of the Pecan Bayou, Commerce Street and Belle Plain Avenue shall not exceed 60 feet in height. 
(Ord. No. 02-31, § 7(154.31(K)), 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 04-27, § I, 9-14-2004) 
Sec. 90-143. - Off-premises signs in agricultural districts. 
    In A-1 districts, off-premises signs may be permitted upon issuance of a special exception by the zoning board of adjustment after a public hearing. In determining the suitability of a site for placement of an off-site advertising sign, the board shall consider the proximity of the proposed location to existing or proposed residential uses as may be indicated on the zoning map of the city or any land use plans that have been approved by either the planning and zoning commission or the city council. 
(Ord. No. 02-31, § 7(154.31(L)), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-144. - Freestanding institutional signs in residential districts. 
    Freestanding institutional signs (identifying churches and other public service nonprofit institutions) located within residential districts are permitted to be up to 80 square feet in area and up to 25 feet in height. Such institutions are permitted only one freestanding sign per street front. In addition, such institutions shall be permitted one wall sign (for identification purposes) per street frontage, so long as such sign exceeds no more than 100 square feet in area. A permit from the city shall be required for installation of all signs identifying churches and other institutions within residential districts. 
(Ord. No. 02-31, § 7(154.31(M)), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-145. - Signs on or over buildings restricted. 
    No sign shall be located on or project over a building, except for roof signs, as provided in section 90-173. 
(Ord. No. 02-31, § 7(154.31(N)), 7-9-2002) 
Sec. 90-146. - Freestanding on-premises signs. 
    Freestanding on-premises signs shall maintain a ten-foot front setback from the property line and a ten-foot side setback from any side abutting an A-1, R-1, R-1A, R-1B, R-2, R-3 or MH district. In all other cases, there shall be no side setback requirement for freestanding on-premises signs. Freestanding on-premises signs shall maintain a clearance from grade of nine feet, except if the sign is set back a minimum of ten feet from all front and side property lines and is not within the prohibited corner clearance triangle as set forth in article IV of chapter 58. A sign so situated does not need a minimum grade clearance. 
(Ord. No. 02-31, § 7(154.31(O)), 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 03-44, § I, 11-11-2003) 
Sec. 90-147. - Number of signs. 
    There shall be a maximum of two freestanding signs per 100 feet of frontage. 
(Ord. No. 02-31, § 7(154.31(P)), 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 03-44, § II, 11-11-2003) 
Secs. 90-148-90-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SPECIFIC REGULATIONS 

Sec. 90-161. - Contents. 
    This division contains the specific regulations pertaining to location, size, number, height, setback and spacing of signs. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32) 
Sec. 90-162. - A-frame signs. 
(a)  Location. A-frame signs shall be allowed in commercial and industrial districts. 
(b)  Size. A-frame signs shall be eight square feet per sign. 
(c)  Number. One A-frame sign shall be permitted per location, except two such signs shall be permitted per each corner location. 
(d)  Setback. A-frame signs shall be located behind the property line, a minimum of six feet behind the curb. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(A)) 
Sec. 90-163. - Back-to-back signs. 
    Back-to-back signs shall have the same regulations as set forth in section 90-164 for billboard signs. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(B)) 
Sec. 90-164. - Billboard signs. 
(a)  Location. Billboard signs shall be allowed in all commercial and industrial districts, unless specifically prohibited elsewhere in this chapter. 
(b)  Size. The maximum size of billboards shall not exceed 300 square feet unless the billboard is located along an interstate highway or state highway, whereupon the maximum size shall not exceed 400 square feet. 
(c)  Height. Billboard signs shall maintain a clearance from grade of nine feet, except for ground signs with the base of the sign within three feet of average grade. The maximum height of billboards shall not exceed 35 feet unless the billboard is located along an interstate highway or state highway, whereupon the maximum height shall not exceed 42 feet. 
(d)  Setback. 
(1)  Billboards shall have a front setback of not less than the greater of 35 feet from the property line or the greatest setback of all the front buildings on the lot on which the billboard is located, or if none, then that of the lots contiguous to the lot upon which the billboard is located. Billboards shall have a side setback of at least ten feet. 
(2)  No part of a billboard or its support structure may overhang the setback line. 
(3)  All billboards shall maintain a minimum setback distance of 150 feet from any residential district or agriculture district. 
(4)  Additionally, all billboards shall be setback from the following facilities as specified: 
a.  City parks: 1,000 feet from the park boundary; 
b.  Cultural facilities: 1,000 feet from the facility boundary; 
c.  Historic building or structure: 1,000 feet from the building or structure; 
d.  Universities: 1,000 feet from the campus area. 
(e)  Spacing. 
(1)  Billboard signs shall not be erected along designated major thoroughfares closer than 1,000 feet apart along the same side of the street or road. 
(2)  A billboard will be considered to be "along" a street or road if the sign face is oriented so that the message can be read by drivers using the street or road, regardless of how far from the public right-of-way the sign is physically located. 
(f)  Electronic billboards. 
(1)  Electronic billboards shall be allowed subject to all the regulatory provisions contained herein governing signs and billboards in general. Should any provisions be in conflict, the more stringent provision shall control. 
(2)  A sign permit shall be required prior to constructing any new electronic billboard or modifying any legally conforming billboard to an electronic billboard, either of which shall be in compliance with the requirements set forth herein. A nonconforming billboard may not be modified to an electronic billboard. Prior to the issuance of a permit for an electronic message sign, the applicant shall provide written certification from the sign manufacturer that the light intensity has been factory preset not to exceed the levels specified in this division. 
(3)  In no case shall an electronic billboard be allowed in an area in which billboards are prohibited by current sign regulations. 
(4)  Electronic billboards shall not be erected within 1,000 feet of an existing billboard on the same side of the street or road; or within 1,500 feet of any other electronic billboard facing the same direction of travel. 
(5)  An electronic billboard shall be limited to a single-face viewed from any one direction. The use of a double-faced electronic billboard (either side-by-side or stacked) is prohibited. 
(6)  No external lighting shall be used to illuminate an electronic billboard. 
(7)  An electronic billboard: 
a.  Shall not contain, display, or be illuminated by flashing, intermittent or moving lights; 
b.  Shall not contain or display animated, moving video or scrolling advertising; 
c.  Shall not consist of a static image projected upon a stationary object; 
d.  Shall not be a portable sign. 
(8)  An electronic billboard shall display static messages only. 
a.  The dwell or hold time of each message, defined as the interval between each message change, shall be at least eight seconds. 
b.  Each message change must be accomplished within two seconds or less and must occur simultaneously on the entire sign face. 
(9)  An electronic billboard shall not be configured to resemble or simulate a warning or danger signal or any official lights or signage used to control traffic. 
(10)  An electronic billboard may not display light of such intensity to cause glare, impair vision or otherwise result in a nuisance to the public. 
a.  The maximum luminous intensity of a billboard shall not exceed 5,000 nits during daylight hours or 500 nits between dusk and dawn, as measured from the billboard's face. 
b.  The billboard must be equipped with both a dimmer control or other such electronic control and a photocell or other such automatic control, which will produce the required illumination change according to natural ambient conditions as provided in subsection (10)a., above. 
(11)  The city may order a sign's brightness reduced and/or its minimum display time increased if the city's division director of public works, or his designee, finds that it interferes with or poses a traffic safety hazard to the operation of vehicles. 
(12)  An electronic billboard shall contain a default mechanism that will freeze the sign in one position if a malfunction occurs. 
(13)  The City of Brownwood, through appropriate personnel, may protect public health, safety and welfare by requiring emergency information to be displayed on electronic billboards. 
a.  Upon notification by the city, the billboard operators shall display emergency information such as "Amber Alert Notices" or other public safety alerts. 
b.  Emergency information messages are to remain in rotation according to the protocols of the designated issuing agency. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(C); Ord. No. 02-31, § 8, 7-9-2002; Ord. No. 03-44, § III, 11-11-2003; Ord. No. 08-36, § V, 10-14-2008) 
Sec. 90-165. - Canopy signs. 
    Signs on a freestanding canopy or detached accessory island canopy may be placed at any location on the canopy, provided that such signs shall not project beyond the width or length of the canopy. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(D)) 
Sec. 90-166. - Hanging signs. 
    All permanent signs shall be erected so as not to overhang any street or alley. 
(1)  Location. Signs may be hung perpendicular to, suspended from or attached to any building, wall or canopy in the area defined under section 90-140. Signs may also be suspended under a marquee. 
(2)  Height. Signs shall maintain a clear height of nine feet above the sidewalk grade and shall not extend more than two feet of the curbline. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(E)) 
Sec. 90-167. - Marquee signs. 
    Marquee signs not more than four feet tall, excluding any top ornament supported directly by the marquee or awning, may extend around three sides of a marquee or awning. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(F)) 
Sec. 90-168. - Political signs. 
    Political signs shall be subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Size . Political signs in residential districts shall not exceed 36 square feet in area and shall not exceed eight feet in height. 
(2)  Location . Political signs shall not be placed on a right-of-way, traffic sign or signal, utility pole, or city-owned public property in any district. Such signs may be placed on private real property only with the permission of the property owner. Political signs shall not be installed on private real property in any manner that create a potential safety hazard by restricting the line of sight for approaching traffic. 
(3)  Removal . Political signs shall be removed from all zoning districts within seven days following the election to which the sign pertains. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(G); Ord. No. 08-15, § I, 6-10-2008; Ord. No. 18-04 , § I, 2-27-2018) 
Sec. 90-169. - Portable signs. 
    Portable (wheeled) signs shall be permitted in commercial and industrial districts, subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  Portable signs shall be secured to the ground at a minimum of four separate points. 
(2)  Illuminated portable signs may be white or yellow, with a maximum illumination of 60 watts, and shall meet all requirements of chapter 78, article IX. 
(3)  Portable signs shall be set back ten feet from the curb or zero feet from the property line, whichever is greater. Any location not meeting such setback requirement will not be allowed to use a portable sign. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(H)) 
Sec. 90-170. - Projecting signs. 
    Projecting signs shall have the same requirements as set forth in section 9-166 for hanging signs. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(I)) 
Sec. 90-171. - Public information signs. 
(a)  Location. Public information signs shall be located subject to the approval of the city council. 
(b)  Number. The number of public information signs allowed shall be subject to the approval of the city council. 
(c)  Size. Public information signs shall be a maximum of six square feet. 
(d)  Height. The bottom of a public information sign shall not exceed nine feet above the average grade. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(J)) 
Sec. 90-172. - Residential nameplate signs. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of residential nameplate signs are to indicate the address and/or name of occupants. 
(b)  Size. Residential nameplate signs shall not exceed two square feet per single-family and duplex structure, or one-half foot per each multifamily unit. 
(c)  Height. No part of a residential nameplate sign shall extend above eight feet from the average grade. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(K)) 
Sec. 90-173. - Roof signs. 
    Roof signs shall be subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Roof signs shall be used for on-premises advertising only. 
(2)  Roof signs shall not exceed 32 feet in total height above the portion of the roof over which such signs are erected. 
(3)  All roof signs shall be constructed entirely of steel, including the upright supports and braces, except that only the ornamental molding and battens behind the steel facing and the decorative lattice work may be of wood construction, as provided in the building code adopted in section 78-31. 
(4)  All roof signs shall be set back a minimum of seven feet from the inside line of the exterior wall of the building, and such distance shall be measured at right angles to the line of the wall. 
(5)  An open space of not less than six feet shall be maintained below the bottom of the roof sign and the roof, except for necessary vertical supports. 
(6)  All metal parts of a roof sign shall be grounded as a protection against lightning. 
(7)  No roof sign shall be allowed to extend over a sidewalk, street or other public property. 
(8)  Sloping roof signs shall not project horizontally or vertically beyond the perimeters of the roof. Not more than 25 percent of any sloping roof area shall be devoted to such sign. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(L)) 
Sec. 90-174. - Traffic control signs. 
    All traffic control signs on private property shall be of a uniform design and shall conform to the overall sign program for the entire site. No traffic control sign shall contain advertising. Such signs may be freestanding or wall mounted, and if lighted, shall be indirect. 
(1)  Height. No part of a traffic control sign on private property shall extend above seven feet from the average grade. 
(2)  Size. Traffic control signs on private property shall be of uniform sizes as recommended in the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(M)) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 66. 
Sec. 90-175. - Wall signs. 
    Wall signs shall: 
(1)  Be attached, on-premises signs; 
(2)  Not project horizontally beyond the perimeters of the wall or extend more than three feet above the wall to which such signs are attached; 
(3)  Not project more than 12 inches from the wall. 
(Code 1995, § 154.32(N)) 
Sec. 90-176. - Electronic message sign. 
(a)  Electronic message signs shall be allowed subject to all the regulatory provisions contained herein governing signs and billboards in general, in addition to the specific provisions contained in this section. An electronic message sign, depending on what type of sign it is, i.e, freestanding, hanging, wall, portable or other type of sign, must meet all requirements applicable for that sign. Should any provisions be in conflict, the more stringent provision shall control. 
(b)  Electronic message signs shall have the following operational limitations: 
(1)  The display of a static message or image and the use of scroll/travel to display a message or image shall be permitted on all electronic message signs. 
(2)  The use of flashing and moving video shall be prohibited on all electronic message signs. 
(3)  The use of animation shall be prohibited on electronic message signs/large. 
(4)  The use of any other type of transition, such as dissolve/fade and frame effects, shall be prohibited on electronic message signs/large except in accordance with the following: 
a.  Each message or image must be displayed for a minimum of three seconds; and 
b.  The change of message or image must be accomplished within two seconds or less and must occur simultaneously on the entire sign face. 
(5)  The use of animation and other types of transition, such as dissolve/fade and frame effects shall be permitted on electronic message signs/small. 
(6)  An electronic message sign must be equipped with both a dimmer control or other such electronic control and a photocell or other such automatic control, which will produce the required illumination change according to natural ambient conditions as provided in subsection 90-136(c)(3). 
(c)  Each electronic message sign structure is limited to not more than two sides with one sign face per side. An electronic message sign shall be limited to a single-face viewed from any one direction. The use of a double-faced electronic message sign (either side-by-side or stacked) is prohibited. 
(d)  Only one electronic message sign structure shall be allowed per property, including properties that have multiple tenants. The maximum size of an electronic message sign face shall not exceed 100 square feet. 
(e)  An electronic message sign shall not be located in any residential district, including, without limitation, MH districts. If an electronic message sign is located within 100 feet of a property with residential zoning, the sign must be oriented such that no portion of the electronic sign face is visible from a residentially zoned property or the brightness is reduced to no more than 250 nits from dusk to dawn. 
(f)  The city may order a sign's brightness reduced, its minimum display time increased or its use of animation and other transition effects decreased if the city's division director of public works, or his designee, finds that it interferes with or poses a traffic safety hazard to the operation of vehicles. 
(g)  Prior to the issuance of a permit for an electronic message sign, the applicant shall provide written certification from the sign manufacturer that the light intensity has been factory preset not to exceed the levels specified in this division. 
(Ord. No. 08-36, § V, 10-14-2008) 
Chapter 94 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Platting, § 9. 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34; natural resources, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58; utilities, ch. 70; buildings and building regulations, ch. 78; floods, ch. 82; manufactured homes and parks, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of subdivisions and property development, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a minor public right-of-way, not intended to provide the primary means of access to abutting lots, which is used primarily for vehicular service access to the back or sides of properties otherwise abutting on a public street. 
    Building line means a line beyond which buildings must be set back from the street line. 
    Commission means the planning and zoning commission of the city. 
    Comprehensive master plan means the comprehensive plan of the city, including any unit or part of such plan separately adopted, and any amendments to such plan, or parts thereof. 
    Crosswalk means a public right-of-way, six feet or more in width between property lines, which provides pedestrian circulation. 
    Easement means a right granted for the purpose of limited public or semipublic use across, over or under private land. 
    Engineer means the city engineer or his duly authorized representative. 
    Floodprone area means a land area adjoining a river, stream, watercourse, ocean, bay or lake, which is likely to be flooded. 
    Floodproofing means any combination of structural and nonstructural additions, changes or adjustments to properties and structures which reduce or eliminate flood damage to lands, water and sanitary facilities, structures and contents of buildings. 
    Lot means an undivided tract or parcel of land having frontage on a public street, and which is, or in the future may be, offered for sale, conveyance, transfer or improvement; which is designated as a distinct and separate tract; and which is identified by a tract or lot number or symbol in a duly approved subdivision plat which has been properly filed on record. 
    Major thoroughfare plan means the part of the comprehensive master plan showing the location and dimensions of principal and secondary thoroughfares. 
    National Flood Insurance Program means the program established by the National Flood Insurance Act of 1968, as amended, 42 USC 4001-4127, which is administrated by the Federal Insurance Administrator. The provisions of such program have been adopted by the city. The definitions listed in the general provisions of the National Flood Insurance Program shall apply in like manner to this chapter. 
    Neighborhood means a complete distinct residential development designated in the comprehensive plan as a neighborhood unit. 
    Plat means the map, drawing or chart on which a subdivider's plan of a subdivision is presented, which he submits for approval and a copy of which he intends to record in final form. 
    Street means a public right-of-way which provides primary vehicular access to adjacent land, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, throughway, avenue, land, boulevard, road, place, drive, or however otherwise designated. 
(1)  Cul-de-sac means a short minor street having only one vehicular access to another street and terminated by a vehicular turnaround. 
(2)  Dead-end street means a street, other than a cul-de-sac, with only one outlet. 
(3)  Major street means a principal traffic artery, more or less continuous across the city, which is intended to connect remote parts of the city, or areas adjacent thereto, and acts as a principal connecting street with state and federal highways, and shall include each street designated as a thoroughfare on the thoroughfare plan, including all existing and proposed major streets shown on the major street plan adopted by the commission. 
(4)  Minor street and local street mean a street which is primarily intended to serve traffic within a neighborhood or limited residential district, and is not necessarily continuous through several residential districts. 
(5)  Roadway and paving width mean the portion of a street available for vehicular traffic, and when curbs are laid, the portion between the face of the curbs. 
(6)  Secondary street and collector street mean a street which carries traffic from minor streets to the major system or arterial streets and highways, including the principal entrance streets of a residential development and principal streets for circulation to schools, parks and other community facilities within a neighborhood. 
    Street width means the shortest horizontal distance between the lines which delineate the right-of-way of a street. 
    Subdivider means any individual, firm, association, syndicate or partnership, or any agent thereof, dividing, or proposing to divide, land so as to constitute a "subdivision," as such term is defined in this section. In any event, the term "subdivider" shall be restricted to include only the owner, equitable owner, or authorized agent of such owner or equitable owner, or land sought to be subdivided. 
    Subdivision means the division of any lot, tract or parcel of land, whether described as lots and blocks or by metes and bounds, into two or more lots or sites for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale or building development. Such term also includes resubdivision of land or lots. 
(Code 1995, § 156.06) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 94-2. - Interpretation; purpose. 
(a)  In the interpretation and application of the provisions of this chapter, such provisions shall be deemed to be minimal in nature, and whenever the principles, standards or requirements of any other applicable provision of ordinances of the city are higher or more restrictive, the latter shall control. 
(b)  The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(1)  Achieve orderly urban development through land subdivision; 
(2)  Promote and develop the utilization of land to assure the best possible community environment in accordance with the comprehensive master plan of the city; 
(3)  Provide for adequate municipal services and safe streets; 
(4)  Allow freedom of creative expression on the part of developers; and 
(5)  Protect and promote the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(Code 1995, § 156.02) 
Sec. 94-3. - Adoption of legislative grant of power. 
    V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.001 et seq. is adopted, and the provisions of this chapter are adopted in the exercise of the power granted to municipalities by such statute, as provided in section 9 of the city Charter. 
(Code 1995, § 156.03) 
Sec. 94-4. - Compliance required. 
    No person shall create a subdivision of land within the corporate limits of the city, or within one mile thereof, without complying with the provisions of this chapter. All plats and subdivisions of any such land shall conform to the rules and regulations set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 156.04) 
Sec. 94-5. - Application. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any lot forming a part of a subdivision, a plat of which has been duly recorded in the office of the county clerk, prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, unless such lot is to be divided or replatted. 
(Code 1995, § 156.05) 
Secs. 94-6-94-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 94-41. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Permits shall not be issued for the building or repair of any structure on a lot in a subdivision for which a final plat has not been approved by the planning and zoning commission and duly recorded in the office of the county clerk. 
(b)  The city shall withhold all public improvements and services of any nature, including the maintenance of streets, sewerage facilities and water, gas and electric service, from all subdivisions which have not been approved in the manner prescribed in this chapter, and from all areas dedicated to the public which have not been accepted by the city council. 
(c)  Any subdivision of land in violation of the terms and provisions of this chapter is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and appropriate officers of the city are hereby authorized to institute any action which may be necessary to restrain or abate such violation. 
(d)  No changes, erasures, modifications or revisions shall be made in any plat of a subdivision after approval has been given by the planning and zoning commission and endorsed on the plat, in writing, unless such change, modification or revision is first submitted to and approved by the planning and zoning commission. 
(Code 1995, § 156.08) 
Sec. 94-42. - Serving and connecting utilities. 
    Unless and until a plat of a subdivision has been approved, and the subdivider has constructed the streets, curbs, paving, utilities and drainage facilities in the subdivision in the manner prescribed by this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any official of the city to serve or connect any public utilities to any land, or part thereof, covered by such plat, or the owners or purchasers of such land, or any part thereof. 
(Code 1995, § 156.09) 
Sec. 94-43. - Dedication and maintenance of streets and alleys. 
    Disapproval of a plat shall be deemed a refusal to accept the offered dedications shown on such plat. Approval of a plat shall not be deemed an acceptance of the proposed dedication. It shall be unlawful for any officer or employee of the city to enter upon the streets and alleys in a subdivision for maintenance purposes, and the city will not accept or maintain such streets and alleys unless and until such streets and alleys have been constructed according to the requirements of this chapter, and the required utilities and drainage facilities have been installed, and such improvements have been accepted by the city as evidenced by the written certificate of the city engineer. 
(Code 1995, § 156.10) 
Sec. 94-44. - Large scale or neighborhood development. 
    The standards and requirements of the regulations set forth in this chapter may be modified by the planning and zoning commission, in the case of a plan and program for a new complete community or neighborhood unit or a mass housing project, which contains adequate provisions for circulation, recreation, light, air and service needs of the tract when fully developed and populated and equal to or better than the detailed requirements of this chapter, and which also provides such covenants or other legal provisions as will assure conformity to the plan. 
(Code 1995, § 156.11) 
Sec. 94-45. - Variances. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission may authorize a variance from this chapter, without direct notice of a public hearing, when, in the opinion of the planning and zoning commission, undue hardship will result from requiring strict compliance with this chapter. In granting a variance, the planning and zoning commission shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary or desirable to the public interest. In making the findings required in subsection (b) of this section, the planning and zoning commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of the land involved and existing uses of the land in the vicinity, the number of persons who will reside or work in the proposed subdivision, and the probable effect of such variance upon traffic conditions and public health, safety, convenience and welfare in the vicinity. 
(b)  No variance shall be granted unless the planning and zoning commission finds that: 
(1)  There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the land involved such that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his land. 
(2)  The variance is necessary for the presentation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the applicant. 
(3)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare, or injurious to other property in the area. 
(4)  The granting of the variance will not have the effect of preventing the orderly subdivision of other land in the area in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Such findings of the planning and zoning commission, together with the specific facts upon which such findings are based, shall be incorporated into the official minutes of the planning and zoning commission's meeting at which such variance is granted. Variances may be granted only when in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this chapter so that the public health, safety and welfare may be secured and substantial justice done. Pecuniary hardship to the subdivider, standing alone, shall not be deemed to constitute an undue hardship. 
(Code 1995, § 156.07) 
Sec. 94-46. - Appeals. 
    Any subdivision aggrieved by a finding or action of the planning and zoning commission which is lawfully subject to review by the city council shall appeal to the city council within 90 days from the date of such finding or action, and not thereafter. Nothing in this section shall prevent a right of review by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1995, § 156.12) 
Sec. 94-47. - Cost of public works improvements. 
(a)  The developer shall furnish all public works improvements required for normal neighborhood development within his subdivision, including minor and secondary streets and alleys and all utilities, sanitary sewer and drainage facilities required to serve the area within the subdivision. The city will participate in the construction of major thoroughfares and the cost of installing larger utility, sanitary sewer and drainage facilities designed to serve a contributing area larger than the subdivision under consideration, in accordance with policies established by the city council. 
(b)  In order to provide water and sewer services to land being developed, if the developer shall extend water and/or sewer lines from existing lines to his development, and in so doing, shall lay such lines on, over, across or in the general vicinity of land not owned by him, such developer may, at his option, enter into an agreement with the city whereby the developer will be able, in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter, to recover a portion of the cost of the laying of such lines, if other persons or entities seek to tap into such lines to provide service to an area not owned by the developer. For the purposes of this chapter, the term "developer" means any person or entity other than the city. 
(c)  In order to enter into such an agreement with the city, the developer shall provide the city with a sworn certification, signed and sworn to both by the developer, if the developer is an individual, or by a duly authorized officer or agent of the developer, in the case of a partnership or corporate developer, and by the contractor who installed the lines. Such sworn document shall state the actual cost, per linear foot, for the installation of the water and/or sewer lines. If the cost shown on the sworn statement is, in the opinion of the staff of the city, in excess of the then current market cost for laying such lines then, and in such event, the city, acting by its duly authorized officials, and the developer, shall seek to negotiate a mutually acceptable figure for the fair market cost of such installation. If the city and the developer cannot arrive at a mutually acceptable figure, the developer may, at his option, request that determination of such figure be submitted to binding arbitration. 
(d)  If the agreement contemplated in subsection (c) of this section is entered into by and between the city and developer, thereafter, any person who, within ten years from the date of the completion of the water and/or sewer lines as certified to by the developer and accepted by the city, desires to receive service from the sewer and/or water lines by tapping into such lines, shall reimburse the developer, or his assigns, for the cost of laying such line in accordance with the following: 
(1)  If the person seeking to receive service from such sewer and/or water lines desires to tap into the sewer and/or water line to provide service on lands located on both sides of the sewer and/or water line, such person desiring to tap into the lines shall repay the developer by paying to the city a sum equal to 25 percent of the cost, per linear foot, for the laying of such line for each linear foot of the line fronting upon property owned by the person seeking to tap into the lines. The 25 percent figure shall be applicable to the linear footage on each side of the line. 
(2)  If the person seeking to tap into the line shall only desire for the tap-in to serve an area located on one side of the line, such person shall reimburse the developer for the cost of the line by paying to the city a sum equal to 50 percent of the cost, per linear foot, for each linear foot of such line fronting along the property owned by the person seeking to tap into the line. 
(3)  The fees provided for in subsections (d)(1) and (2) of this section shall be assessed by the city and collected at the time a tap fee is collected from the person seeking to utilize such lines, and the city shall remit the fee collected to the original developer, or his assigns, within 30 days from the date of collection thereof by the city. The city shall not knowingly permit a tap of such line by any person other than the original developer unless the fees provided for in this subsection (d) to reimburse the developer for the cost of construction of such lines are paid to the city by the person seeking to tap the lines. 
(4)  If the person seeking to receive service from such water or sewer line to property which does not front such utility line, but is beyond or separated by other property from the line, such person shall reimburse the developer by paying to the city a sum equal to a pro rata percent of the cost, per linear foot, for the laying of such line to the point where such person taps the line, between the city main and end of the line extension. 
(Code 1995, § 156.13) 
Secs. 94-48-94-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PLATS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Plat required, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.004. 

Sec. 94-81. - Preapplication conference. 
(a)  Planning and zoning commission suggestions. Prior to the preparation of the preliminary plat, the subdivider may seek the advice of the planning and zoning commission as set forth in this chapter. Such step does not require formal application, fee or filing of any plat with the planning and zoning commission. At such meeting, the planning and zoning commission will be able to make any suggestions that would direct the proposed subdivision toward desirable objectives and possibly prevent unnecessary work if such objectives are not met. 
(b)  Forms and maps. Forms or maps needed for such planning and zoning commission meeting are described and shown in appendix B to this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 156.30) 
Sec. 94-82. - Preliminary plat conditional approval. 
(a)  Filing procedure. 
(1)  After reaching conclusions informally regarding his program and objectives, as described in section 94-81, the subdivider shall cause a preliminary plat to be prepared, together with other supplementary data as specified and shown in appendix B to this chapter, for formal submission to the planning and zoning commission. 
(2)  Four prints of the preliminary plat shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission and filed with the city engineer not less than five days prior to the next meeting of the planning and zoning commission at which the preliminary plat is to be considered. A certificate of filing shall be maintained by the city engineer and a copy of such certificate shall be given to the party filing the plat. 
(3)  A filing fee, per subdivision, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, plus a fee, per residential lot, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office, shall be paid by the subdivider. Where acreage is involved, such as, but not limited to, sites for industrial or commercial use, housing projects and shopping centers, the subdivider shall pay a filing fee, per acre, as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. In no case shall the filing fee involving acreage exceed $100.00. 
(b)  Approval or disapproval. The planning and zoning commission shall approve or disapprove any preliminary plat within 30 days from the date the preliminary plat is filed. Approval of the preliminary plat as such shall not constitute final acceptance or approval of the subdivision. If no action by the planning and zoning commission to disapprove a preliminary plat is taken within the 30-day period from the date of filing, the preliminary plat is deemed to have been approved and a certificate showing such filing date and the failure to take action within 30 days from the filing date shall, on demand, be issued by the planning and zoning commission, and the certificate shall be sufficient in lieu of a written endorsement or other evidence of approval. 
(c)  Master preliminary of larger tract. Where the proposed subdivision constitutes a unit of a larger tract owned by the subdivider which he intends to subsequently divide as additional units of the same subdivision, the subdivision plat shall be accompanied by a layout of the entire area, showing the tentative proposed layout of streets, blocks and drainage for such area. The overall layout, if approved by the planning and zoning commission, shall be attached to and filed with a copy of the approved subdivision plat in the permanent files of the city engineer and the planning and zoning commission. Thereafter, fractional final plats of subsequent units of such subdivision may be submitted without additional preliminary plat approval, and shall conform to such approved overall layout, unless changed by the planning and zoning commission. Where the subdivider does not agree to such change, the planning and zoning commission may change such approved overall layout only when it finds that adherence to the previously approved overall layout will: 
(1)  Hinder the orderly subdivision of other land in the area in accordance with the provisions of this chapter; or 
(2)  Be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare, or will be injurious to other property in the area.
