Each subsequent fractional plat submitted for approval shall be adjacent to a unit previously developed. 
(Code 1995, § 156.31) 
Sec. 94-83. - Final plat approval. 
(a)  After conditional approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall cause a final plat to be prepared, together with supplementary data as specified and shown in appendix B to this chapter, and referenced in subsection (c)(3) of this section, for formal submission to the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)  Six prints of the final plat shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission under the same procedure as set forth in section 94-82(a)(2). 
(c)  The subdivider shall submit the following data at the time of filing the preliminary plat: 
(1)  A tax certificate from the city, and other officials of taxing agencies within whose jurisdiction the proposed subdivision lies, to the effect that all ad valorem taxes have been paid on the land included within the subdivision. 
(2)  An utility certificate from the superintendent of the water and sewer departments approving the proposed utilities layout and indicating that adequate service is available to the subdivision. 
(3)  The following data, in duplicate, prepared and stamped by a registered engineer, which shall be presented to and approved by the city engineer before any subdivision, shall be approved by the planning and zoning commission: 
a.  Streets, alleys, sidewalks, crosswalks and monuments (plans and profiles, with the data outlined in appendix A to this chapter); 
b.  Storm drainage data and proposed drainage structures (calculation, plans and profile using design data outlined in appendix A to this chapter); 
c.  Water and sewer data and proposed structures (calculation, plans and profile using design data outlined in appendix A to this chapter). 
(d)  All subdividers doing business in the city or its extraterritorial jurisdiction shall be required to file with the city secretary a corporate surety bond, payable to the city, in the amount as established by the city council and on file in the city secretary's office. The bond will be kept current while any subdivision work is being pursued by the subdivider and until improvements on areas submitted by the subdivider as offered to the general public for sale are certified complete by the city engineer and utility superintendent. Certification by the city engineer or utility superintendent of failure to execute improvements on areas identified by the subdivider as offered for sale to the general public to the standards required in this chapter shall constitute grounds to call on the bonding company for payment of the bond. No final plat shall be approved or recorded until the bond has been filed with the city secretary. When the bond is filed with the city, the city secretary shall issue a certificate to the subdivider identifying him as a bonded subdivider. 
(Code 1995, § 156.32) 
State Law reference- Requirements for recording the plat, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.004. 
Sec. 94-84. - New subdivision short form procedure. 
    A short form procedure, omitting the filing of the preliminary plat, may be followed when the proposed subdivision or resubdivision meets the following requirements: 
(1)  The proposed subdivision contains four lots or less, all fronting on a previously dedicated street of an adequate width, and situated so that no additional streets, alleys, easements or other public property are required in order to meet the requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  The utilities and drainage facilities, as required in this chapter, are in place to serve each lot in the proposed subdivision and require no alterations, or satisfactory arrangements have been made to effect any necessary alterations. 
(3)  The proposed subdivision abuts property which has previously been subdivided. 
(Code 1995, § 156.33; Ord. No. 13-10, § 1, 3-12-2013) 
Sec. 94-85. - Resubdivision short form procedure. 
    A short form procedure for resubdivisions of existing platted and approved subdivisions, omitting the requirements for filing a preliminary plat, supporting data and exhibits, may be submitted to the planning and zoning commission for its approval, when: 
(1)  The proposed resubdivision has been prepared by a registered engineer or a licensed surveyor; 
(2)  Staff review by the appropriate city departments confirms all engineering data remains accurate and that any other requirement of this chapter shall otherwise be complied with; 
(3)  The proposed resubdivision constitutes no change in the exterior configuration of more than one side of any block in the subdivision, as previously submitted; and 
(4)  The proposed resubdivision does not propose to change the existing zoning classification from a more restrictive classification to a less restrictive classification. 
(Code 1995, § 156.34) 
Sec. 94-86. - Administrative approval of certain plats or replats. 
(a)  Pursuant to V.T.C.A. Local Government Code § 212.0065, the City Council hereby delegates the approval of the following plats or replats to the City Engineer: 
(1)  Amending plats described by V.T.C.A. Local Government Code § 212.016; 
(2)  Minor plats or replats involving four or fewer lots fronting on an existing street and not requiring the creation of any new street or the extension of municipal facilities; and 
(3)  A replat under V.T.C.A. Local Government Code § 212.0145 that does not require the creation of any new street or the extension of municipal facilities. 
(b)  Submittal requirements. All requirements of section 94-83 of the Code of Ordinances regarding final plats submittal requirements shall be applicable to plats submitted to the city engineer for administrative approval. 
(c)  Administrative approval of plats or replats. If the city engineer determines that the plat or replat complies with the requirements of this section, the plat or replat shall be certified by the required parties and filed of record. The city engineer shall act on a plat within 30 days after the date the plat or replat is filed with the city and has met all submittal requirements required by this section, including all applicable fees. 
(d)  Denial of plats or replats. If the city engineer determines that the plat or replat submitted to him for administrative approval does not comply with the requirements of this section, then the city engineer shall refer the plat or replat to the planning and zoning commission within 30 days after the plat or replat is filed and has met all submittal requirements required by this section, including all applicable fees. If the city engineer determines that he cannot approve the plat or replat and refers the plat or replat to the planning and zoning commission, the planning and zoning commission shall take action on the plat or replat within the time period specified in V.T.C.A. Local Government Code § 212.009, such time period to commence upon the City Engineer filing a written referral of the plat or replat to the Planning and Zoning Commission. 
(e)  Right to refer to planning and zoning commission. The city engineer may, for any reason, elect to present the plat or replat for approval to the planning and zoning commission within 30 days after the plat or replat is filed and has met all submittal requirements required by this section, including all applicable fees. Once the city engineer so elects and refers the plat or replat to the planning and zoning commission, the planning and zoning commission shall take action on the plat or replat within the time period specified in V.T.C.A. Local Government Code § 212.009, such time period to commence upon the city engineer filing a written referral of the plat or replat to the planning and zoning commission. 
(Ord. No. 13-10, § 1, 3-12-2013) 
Secs. 94-87-94-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 94-121. - General principles and objectives. 
(a)  Conformity with the comprehensive master plan. All subdivisions shall conform to the comprehensive master plan for orderly and unified development of streets, utilities, neighborhood design and public land facilities. 
(b)  Achieving desirable neighborhood development. Residential subdivisions shall be designed to take advantage of the principles and general designs for neighborhood development as established by the comprehensive master plan and the planning and zoning commission in order to achieve the most advantageous development of the entire neighborhood unit in which the subdivision is located. 
(c)  Provision for future subdivision. If a tract is subdivided into parcels larger than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged to allow logical further subdivision and the opening of future streets. 
(d)  Standards for site improvements. All streets, alleys, sidewalks, utility installations and other site improvements required to be installed by the subdivider under the provisions of this article shall conform to the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 156.50) 
Sec. 94-122. - Streets. 
(a)  Layout. The arrangement, extent, character, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the major thoroughfare plan and comprehensive master plan. Minor residential streets shall provide adequate circulation within the neighborhood, but shall discourage excessive through traffic. The street layout shall be arranged to achieve the most desirable development of the entire neighborhood unit, with appropriate consideration of creeks, drainage channels, wooded areas and other topographical features which lend themselves to special treatment. Streets forming the boundary line of a subdivision shall permit no setback from the property line. 
(b)  Relation to adjoining streets. Where appropriate to the neighborhood pattern, existing streets in adjoining areas shall be continued and tied into the proposed street layout. The width and alignment of such streets shall be as determined by the planning and zoning commission. 
(c)  Projection. When adjoining areas are not subdivided, the arrangement of streets shall provide for the proper projection of streets into the adjoining unsubdivided areas as will be required to complete the neighborhood pattern or conform to the comprehensive plan. 
(d)  Partial or half streets. In the case of minor streets, no new half streets shall be platted. Where the proposed subdivision abuts upon an existing half street, the remaining half of the street shall be platted. In the case of secondary streets and major thoroughfares, half streets may be platted, if necessary, in conformance with the comprehensive master plan. 
(e)  Dead-end streets and culs-de-sac. 
(1)  Dead-end streets shall be prohibited, except as short stubs which are projected to be continued in future subdivisions in conformance with subsection (c) of this section, or when designed as culs-de-sac. Temporary turnarounds shall be provided on projected streets until such time as such streets are extended. 
(2)  Culs-de-sac shall not exceed 400 feet in length and shall have a turnaround of not less than 80 feet in diameter in single-family residential areas, 120 feet in multifamily areas and not less than 200 feet in diameter in commercial and industrial areas. 
(f)  Alignment. The alignment of all major thoroughfares and secondary streets shall conform to the comprehensive master plan and the requirements of appendix A to this chapter. Minor street alignment shall meet the requirements of appendix A to this chapter, and in no case shall street jogs be offset more than 120 feet on the centerline. 
(g)  Intersections. All intersections on major thoroughfares and secondary streets shall be at least 90 degrees, except as shown on the comprehensive master plan or approved by the planning and zoning commission. The intersections of minor streets shall be as nearly to 90 degrees as practicable. The curb radii at street intersections in urban subdivisions shall conform to table 1 as set forth in appendix A to this chapter. 
(h)  Right-of-way and pavement widths. All street and pavement widths shall conform to the comprehensive master plan and the requirements of appendix A to this chapter, but in no case shall the right-of-way widths be less than the following: 
(1)  Major thoroughfares, 80 feet; 
(2)  Minor streets, 50 feet; 
(3)  Secondary streets, 60 feet. 
(i)  Names. Names of new streets shall not duplicate the names of existing streets within the county unless the new street is a continuation of such existing street. Street names shall be chosen to avoid similarity or confusion with existing street names. Names of all new streets shall be subject to approval by the planning and zoning commission, and coordinated on an areawide basis. 
(j)  Additional improvements. Additional improvements, such as streetlights and street signs, shall be installed at no cost to the developer. 
(k)  Construction. All street bases, surfacing, curbs, grades, horizontal curves and intersection curve radii shall be constructed in accordance with the standards prescribed in appendix A to this chapter. 
(l)  Temporary rights-of-way. When deemed necessary by the planning and zoning commission, temporary rights-of-way shall be provided for certain uses or locations, such as the provision of turnarounds on projected streets. Such temporary rights-of-way shall revert to the abutting property owners when no longer required for its original purpose. 
(Code 1995, § 156.51) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58. 
Sec. 94-123. - Alleys. 
(a)  Layout. Alleys shall be as nearly parallel to the street frontage as reasonably possible. Alleys forming the boundary of a subdivision shall permit no setback from the property line. 
(b)  Commercial and industrial districts. Paved alleys not less than 20 feet wide shall be provided in all commercial or industrial districts, except that the planning and zoning commission may waive such requirement where other definite and assured provision is made for service access, such as off-street loading and parking, consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(c)  Residential areas. Alleys shall be provided in all residential areas. Such alleys shall not be less than 20 feet wide, with at least 16 feet of six-inch washing plant base material. The planning and zoning commission may waive such requirement when topography would dictate the loss of usable property, but the developer shall be required to make provisions for the current method of solid waste collection. 
(d)  Intersections and turns. Alley intersections and sharp changes in alignment shall be avoided, but where two alleys intersect, or any alley turns at an angle sharper than 100 degrees, a cutoff shall be provided. The degree of the angle will determine the depth of the cutoff required. 
(e)  Dead ends. Dead-end alleys shall be avoided where possible, but if they are unavoidable, they shall be provided with adequate turnaround facilities, as determined by the planning and zoning commission, and have no less than 32 feet improved width. 
(f)  Construction. All alleys shall be constructed in accordance with the standards prescribed in appendix A to this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 156.52) 
Sec. 94-124. - Easements. 
(a)  Public utilities. Utility easements shall be provided for installation of utilities or appurtenances where alleys are not feasible. In general, the rear easement shall be 20 feet wide, all from one tier of lots. Covenants shall be written into all deeds requiring 15-foot gates in all fences crossing easements. Additional requirements for public utility easements shall be determined by the engineer. 
(b)  Drainage. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse, and of sufficient width, as determined by the engineer, to accommodate further width or construction and allow access for maintenance. 
(Code 1995, § 156.53) 
Sec. 94-125. - Blocks. 
(a)  General layout. The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: 
(1)  Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated; 
(2)  Zoning requirements for lot sizes and dimensions; 
(3)  Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic; 
(4)  Limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(b)  Length. In general, block lengths along minor or secondary streets shall not exceed 1,400 feet or be less than 500 feet, and along major thoroughfares, block lengths shall not exceed 1,800 feet or be less than 900 feet. 
(c)  Width. In general, blocks shall be platted of a sufficient width to contain two tiers of lots with an alley between them, except where lots are double fronted on major thoroughfares, railroads or drainage channels, or where overall neighborhood design justifies a different layout, or where a single tier of lots is platted to adjoin the rear of existing lots of unplatted tracts. 
(Code 1995, § 156.54) 
Sec. 94-126. - Lots. 
(a)  General layout. The size, width, depth, shape and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the neighborhood in which the subdivision is located, and for the type of development and use contemplated in order to assure provision of proper open space and prevent overcrowding. 
(b)  Dimensions. Lot dimensions shall conform to chapter 98 of this Code, or the following requirements, if more restrictive: 
(1)  Residential lots, where not served by public or approved off-lot sewer, shall be at least 70 feet wide, 120 feet deep and have an area of at least 9,000 square feet. In addition, the planning and zoning commission shall request the city or county health office to cause a percolation test to be made, and shall require such lot areas as recommended by the health officer, but in no case less than 9,000 square feet. 
(2)  Where a residential lot backs up to a railroad right-of-way, high pressure gas line, industrial area or any other land use which may have a depreciating effect on residential property, and where no marginal access street or other street is provided at the rear of such lot, additional depth shall be required, not to exceed a total of 150 feet. Where a lot sides to any such traffic artery or other disadvantageous land use, an appropriate additional width shall be required. A planting screen, no-access easement, of at least ten feet shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such traffic artery or other disadvantageous land use. 
(c)  Orientation. Residential lots may be oriented to take advantage of topography and the best relationship to the overall design of the neighborhood, and to minimize the effects of any surrounding depreciating land uses. 
(1)  The placing of residential lots facing directly upon a major thoroughfare shall be avoided, unless lots face a marginal access street parallel to such major thoroughfare. Lots should side or back to major thoroughfares and other depreciating land uses. 
(2)  The placing of lots at right angles to each other, with rear and side lot lines adjacent, shall be avoided, when possible. 
(3)  Side lot lines shall be as nearly perpendicular as practicable to the street the lot faces, or radial to curved streets. 
(d)  Access. Every lot shall be provided with adequate access to a public street, either by direct frontage on such street or by a public pedestrian accessway approved by the planning and zoning commission. Rear and/or side driveway access to major thoroughfares shall be prohibited. 
(Code 1995, § 156.55) 
Sec. 94-127. - Public sites and open spaces. 
(a)  If a proposed park, school, playground or other public facility shown in the comprehensive master plan or official neighborhood plan is located, in whole or in part, in a subdivision, the subdivider may dedicate such land to public use, or shall cause such land to be held in reserve for a period of six months from the date the plat is recorded for purchase by the appropriate public agency. 
(b)  Where deemed essential by the planning and zoning commission, upon consideration of the particular type of development proposed in the subdivision, and especially in large scale neighborhood unit developments not anticipated in the comprehensive master plan, the planning and zoning commission may require the reservation of such other areas or sites of a character, extent and location suitable to the needs created by subdevelopment for schools, parks and other neighborhood purposes. Such requirement shall be made by the appropriate public agency within six months, and, within 60 days of such notification, the public agency shall compensate the developer at a price mutually agreeable to both parties; however, such price shall not exceed the square foot price being asked for adjacent speculative lots. 
(Code 1995, § 156.56) 
Secs. 94-128-94-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 94-161. - Monuments. 
    There shall be one concrete monument per subdivision, inscribed with the elevation, and iron pins encased in concrete placed at angle points, points of curve, lot lines and all corners of boundary lines of the subdivision. 
(Code 1995, § 156.70) 
Sec. 94-162. - Street improvements. 
    All street improvements shall meet the requirements of the comprehensive master plan and appendix A to this article, but, in no case, shall such improvements be more minimal than specifications set forth in the following table: 
SCHEDULE OF MINIMUM STREET IMPROVEMENTS

(feet) Pavement Standard

(Code 1995, § 156.71) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 58. 
Sec. 94-163. - Water system. 
(a)  Furnishing and installing facilities. All water supply, treatment, storage and distribution facilities shall be furnished and installed in compliance with the requirements of appendix A of this article, the state department of health, state water development board and the Environmental Protection Agency. 
(b)  Provision required. Every lot in a subdivision shall be provided with an approved supply of water, either by the construction of a distribution system connected to an adequate approved public water system or, if such public source is not available, by construction of a complete water system, including a safe, adequate water source, proper treatment facilities, pumps, storage facilities and distribution system, approved by the appropriate state and federal agencies. 
(c)  Fire hydrants. 
(1)  Fire hydrants must be approved by the American Water Works Association. Brands other than Mueller, Draling and M & H must meet the city's measuring requirements and be approved by the city engineer, fire chief and utility superintendent. 
(2)  Fire hydrants must have a tested working pressure of not less than 150 pounds hydrostatic test and must open against the water pressure. The diameter of the main valve seat should be 51/4 inches, and the length should be determined by the depth of the trench. All working parts, including the main valve assembly, shall be removable through the barrel, without excavation. Hydrant shoes must be a mechanical joint and must have automatically opening drains to dry up the barrel. The stuffing box must have O-ring seals and an oil bath holding no less than eight ounces of oil. All fire hydrants must be traffic model or breakaway. Fire plugs shall be located no further than 500 feet from any structure and such locations shall be submitted on the water map for approval by the developer. All water mains shall be looped in a manner to assure adequate water pressure at the fire hydrant. The fire chief and utility superintendent shall have approval of fireplug placement. 
(3)  Every urban subdivision shall be provided with standard fire hydrants as part of the water distribution system so that every lot is within 500 feet of a fire hydrant. 
(Code 1995, § 156.72) 
Sec. 94-164. - Sewerage systems. 
(a)  Furnishing and installing facilities. All facilities for the collection and disposal of sewage shall be furnished and installed in compliance with the requirements of appendix A of this article, the state department of health, state water development board and the Environmental Protection Agency. 
(b)  Sanitary sewers. Sanitary sewers shall be installed to serve each lot in all subdivisions where connection is to be made immediately to a community disposal system or to a public sewerage system. The parts of such systems which will lie in the portion of streets and alleys intended for vehicular traffic shall be installed before such street or alley is paved. 
(c)  Septic tanks. In any subdivision in which immediate connection to a sewerage system cannot be made, a septic tank of at least 500 gallons' capacity, with a drain field of at least 150 feet, shall be installed on a lot in accordance with the regulations of the appropriate health authorities. 
(Code 1995, § 156.73) 
Sec. 94-165. - Drainage. 
(a)  Adequate facilities required. No lot in any subdivision which is subject to flooding by rainfall shall be approved until drainage facilities which are adequate to carry off such rainfall have been provided, as determined by computations by the engineer. The system shall ensure drainage at all points along streets and provide positive drainage away from buildings and on solid waste disposal sites. 
(b)  Installation. All necessary storm drainage facilities, including enclosed storm sewers, bridges, culverts and watercourse improvements, to carry off stormwater within the subdivision and to integrate such subdivision drainage with the overall urban drainage system shall be installed in accordance with appendix A of this article and official urban and county drainage plans. The planning and zoning commission may require a primarily underground system to accommodate larger, less frequent floods. 
(c)  Roof drainage in commercial areas. In commercial areas, all roof drainage shall be piped directly into an underground storm sewer, where a storm sewer exists. 
(d)  Floodprone areas. If a section of a lot is in the floodprone areas, as designated by the National Flood Insurance Program, an approved type of floodproofing must be installed. 
(e)  Uses in floodplain areas. No use, including landfill, may be permitted within a floodplain area having special flood hazards unless the subdivider has demonstrated that the proposed use, when combined with all other existing and anticipated uses, will not increase the water surface elevation of the 100-year flood more than one foot at any point. 
(Code 1995, § 156.74) 
Secs. 94-166-94-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SUPPLEMENTAL REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 94-201-94-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RANCHETTE SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 94-221. - Title. 
    This division shall be known and cited as the "City of Brownwood Ranchette Subdivision Ordinance." 
(Code 1995, § 157.01) 
Sec. 94-222. - Definitions. 
    The definitions adopted in this division shall be the definitions set forth in chapter 98 and section 94-1, and such definitions shall be made a part of this section, where applicable. In addition, the following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ranchette subdivision means a tract or parcel of land to be subdivided into smaller tracts of land upon which certain uses and activities described in this division may be permitted which would not otherwise be permissible under existing zoning laws and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 157.02) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 94-223. - Establishment. 
(a)  Prohibited classification. For the purpose of this division, ranchettes and ranchette subdivisions shall not be included in any of the existing land use classifications as set forth in chapter 98. 
(b)  Official zoning map. The location of ranchette subdivisions shall be noted upon the official zoning map as "ranchette subdivisions," together with any and all notations, references and other information, and any and all amendments to such map, and shall be kept on file in the office of the city secretary. 
(c)  Approval procedure. The procedures of approving ranchette subdivision tracts shall be the same as pertains to appearance before the planning and zoning commission, rights of appeal and approval of the city council as set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1995, § 157.03) 
Sec. 94-224. - Rentals and provisions of chapter applicable; exceptions; livestock. 
(a)  Applicability. The rentals and provisions of this chapter, adopted by the city, shall be applicable to ranchette subdivisions, except as provided in this section. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Each ranchette lot shall not be less than 21/2 acres in size, with a minimum width of 200 feet. 
(2)  Each developer of a ranchette subdivision shall provide water and sewer to each ranchette lot at no cost to the city. Additional utilities may be installed at the option of the developer. Developers or owners of ranchettes may provide such lots or tracts of land with septic tanks until sewer is available to the subdivision, the installation of which shall meet the minimum standards of the city, state and federal health authorities and regulations pertaining to the installation of such septic tanks. 
(3)  The developer shall install paved roads to serve each tract, at no cost to the city, and such paved roads shall be constructed according to the provisions of this chapter as to grade and curve, but no cement curbs or gutters shall be required in such areas. Bar-ditches must provide proper drainage in accordance with good engineering practices, and be approved by the city engineers. Driveways providing access shall have drainage horns installed which shall be sufficient to provide proper drainage as set forth in this subsection. 
(4)  Butane tanks shall only be allowed as a source of fuel if located outside the city limits, and all installations of service lines shall be installed to city and state codes as they pertain to liquefied gas. 
(5)  No more than two residences may be erected upon any 21/2-acre ranchette tract, and both residences must be served by the same water meter and be owned by one party, and no lot or tract in any ranchette subdivision may be further subdivided. 
(6)  Owners of ranchettes shall be allowed to keep domesticated livestock, including, but not limited to, horses, cattle, sheep and goats. The number of animals shall not exceed three adult animals, excluding offspring, per acre. Offspring shall be classified as adults upon obtaining the age of one year. No swine shall be allowed or permitted as domesticated livestock. No commercial livestock feeding or breeding operations shall be conducted on the ranchette. 
(Code 1995, § 157.04) 
Sec. 94-225. - Restrictive covenants. 
    Prior to approval of a ranchette subdivision, the planning and zoning commission may require restrictive covenants to be placed upon any of the land sought to be subdivided as a ranchette, and in conformance and harmony with the covenants set forth in this division. 
(Code 1995, § 157.05) 
Sec. 94-226. - Applicability of city codes. 
    All buildings built on ranchettes within the city limits shall meet all city electrical and plumbing codes and other requirements required by the city as to new buildings, and all necessary building permits must be obtained on new buildings, as required by the city. If the ranchette is outside the city limits and within one mile thereof, city plumbing codes are applicable when the ranchette is connected to city water and/or sewer system. 
(Code 1995, § 157.06) 
Sec. 94-227. - Height and area requirements. 
    Height and area requirements shall be in conformance with the zoning requirements set forth in chapter 98 for the R-1 district, except that the rear yard requirement shall be 25 feet. 
(Code 1995, § 157.07) 
Sec. 94-228. - Location restrictions. 
    Ranchette subdivisions may not be adopted contiguous to existing conventional city lots and in common with a property line on conventional city lots, unless separated by an alley, street, drainage easement or public utility easement. 
(Code 1995, § 157.08) 
Secs. 94-229-94-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INDUSTRIAL PARK DISTRICT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- M-1 restricted industrial district, § 98-451 et seq.; M-2 industrial district, § 98-471 et seq. 

Sec. 94-251. - Established; conflicts. 
    There is hereby established for the city the Brownwood Industrial Park District Subdivision, Phase I, which shall consist of the area described in the legal description on file in the office of the city secretary and designated by the plat of Roy Pfingsten, registered public land surveyor, as approved by the planning and zoning commission. In addition to the regulations set out in this division, areas in the industrial park district shall be subject to the zoning regulations of chapter 98. In the event of conflict between the chapter 98 and the regulations and rules established by this division, the latter shall govern and prevail. 
(Code 1995, § 157.20) 
Sec. 94-252. - District map. 
    The industrial park district map shall be prepared by the city engineer or his designee. The map shall include all of the area designated by this division as a part of the official industrial park district, but the map or plat may be prepared for phases of development of the subdivision, i.e., phase I, phase II, etc., and the city reserves the right to officially adopt plats or maps of the phased development, one phase at a time. Where a street is designated as the boundary of the district, the centerline of the street shall be taken as such boundary, in the absence of a provision to the contrary. Metes and bounds descriptions shall be clearly designated where no other designation if used. 
(Code 1995, § 157.21) 
Sec. 94-253. - Prohibited uses. 
    No part of the industrial park district, or any building or improvement located in such district, shall be used for any purpose, other than industrial, warehouse or commercial nonretail sales purposes. 
(Code 1995, § 157.28) 
Sec. 94-254. - Exterior of buildings and structures. 
    No building or structure shall be erected, permitted or placed within the industrial park district unless the exterior of the building or structure is of stone, brick, reinforced concrete, glass, equivalent masonry construction or a combination of such materials. Metal buildings are acceptable as long as the front (street-facing) of the building is faced to a level of not less than four feet from the ground elevation with the materials listed as acceptable in this section. 
(Code 1995, § 157.30) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 78. 
Sec. 94-255. - Dangerous or objectionable elements. 
(a)  No part of the industrial park district, or any building or improvement within the district, shall be used or occupied in any manner so as to create any dangerous, injurious, noxious or otherwise objectionable fire, explosive or other hazard, including a possible potential hazard, noise or vibration, smoke, dust, odor or other form of air pollution, heat, cold, dampness, electrical or other substance, condition or element (referred to in this section as "dangerous or objectionable elements"), in such a manner or amount as to adversely affect the surrounding area or adjoining premises, provided that any use permitted or not expressly prohibited by this division may be undertaken and maintained if the use conforms to the regulations of this division limiting dangerous and objectionable elements at the point of the determination of their existence. 
(b)  The determination of the existence of any dangerous and objectionable elements shall be made at the location of the use creating the elements and at any points where the existence of such elements may be more apparent. 
(Code 1995, § 157.22) 
Sec. 94-256. - Storage of inflammable and explosive materials; open burning prohibited; fire zone. 
    All activities involving, and all storage of, inflammable and explosive materials shall be provided, at any point, with adequate firefighting and fire-suppression equipment and devices which are standard in the industry. Burning of waste materials and open fires shall be prohibited at any point. An adequate fire clear zone of 15-30 feet shall be maintained on at least two sides of the structure. The fire zone shall be maintained free and clear of any stored properties or vehicles for the utilization of fire equipment in the event of an emergency. 
(Code 1995, § 157.23) 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34; fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
Sec. 94-257. - Prohibited activities. 
(a)  Radiation. No activities shall be permitted which violate the requirements and standards of the radiation protection regulations of the state. 
(b)  Electrical disturbance. No electrical disturbance or any disturbance resulting from radio or television transmission shall be tolerated which adversely affects the operation, at any point, of any equipment, other than the equipment of the creator of such disturbance. 
(c)  Vibration. No vibration shall be permitted which is discernible without instruments at the points of measurement. 
(d)  Emissions. 
(1)  No emission of any smoke or other products of combustion violating any city, federal or state law shall be permitted. 
(2)  No emission of odorous gases or other odorous matter shall be permitted in such quantities as to be offensive at the points of measurement. 
(e)  Discharge into the sewage system. No discharge, at any point, into the sewage system serving the property shall be made, except in accordance with standards approved by the city or other applicable regulatory authority. 
(Code 1995, § 157.24) 
Sec. 94-258. - Pavement of parking and loading areas. 
    All parking and loading areas, whether public or private, shall be surfaced with a pavement of sufficient strength to support the vehicular loads on such areas and to provide a durable and dustless surface, graded and drained, to dispose of surface water, and properly marked and arranged to provide for orderly and safe maneuvering and storage of automobiles and trucks. 
(Code 1995, § 157.26) 
Sec. 94-259. - Lighting. 
    All public areas shall be appropriately lighted to provide for safe and orderly usage of such areas. 
(Code 1995, § 157.27) 
Sec. 94-260. - Building setback. 
    No building or other structure shall be erected, permitted or placed within the industrial park district which shall have any part of such building or structure, including, but not limited to, any windows, eaves, steps, chimneys or other projections, closer than 30 feet from the nearest boundary line of any street or closer than 15 feet from any boundary line of such tract which does not border a street. 
(Code 1995, § 157.29) 
Sec. 94-261. - Excavations. 
    No excavations or excavating work shall be permitted on any part or portion of the industrial park district property, except excavations for the purpose of constructing buildings and tangible improvements within the district immediately prior to and during the construction of such buildings and tangible improvements. No soil, sand, gravel, minerals, aggregate or earth materials shall be removed from the district property, except as a part of such excavations made for the purpose of constructing buildings and tangible improvements on the real estate. 
(Code 1995, § 157.31) 
Sec. 94-262. - Landscaping. 
    All property within the industrial park district, and all buildings, structures, improvements and appurtenances relative to such district, shall be attractively landscaped, and all portions of the real estate not used for buildings, structures, parking areas, loading areas, driveways, streets and other landscaping shall be mowed and trimmed and maintained in an attractive and neat condition. Grass or other suitable ground cover may be planted. 
(Code 1995, § 157.32) 
Sec. 94-263. - Outside property maintenance. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner or tenant to maintain the outside property in a manner consistent with other adjacent property in the industrial park. Items of any nature which are permanently placed outside shall be properly stored and screened in a manner to make the storage area conform with other properties in the industrial park. 
(Code 1995, § 157.33) 
Sec. 94-264. - Fences. 
    No fences or other obstructions or restrictions shall be placed in any utility easement located on the industrial park property without the express written consent of the city. 
(Code 1995, § 157.34) 
Sec. 94-265. - Drainage. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the industrial park property to provide for adequate drainage to the industrial park's drainage facilities located within the industrial park district. 
(Code 1995, § 157.35) 
Sec. 94-266. - Signs. 
(a)  A maximum of three signs will be allowed zero feet from the property line. The allowed signs will be an entrance designation sign and exit designation sign. The two allowed signs shall be a maximum of six square feet in size. The third designated sign, which will be the company identification, will be a maximum of 36 square feet in size. All three signs may be lighted. 
(b)  There will be no other freestanding signs in the industrial park district. Signs on buildings will be no larger than 36 square feet, and the sign may be lighted. 
(c)  All signs within the industrial park will be common. The city will provide design specifications. 
(Code 1995, § 157.36) 
Sec. 94-267. - Utility easements. 
    Utility easements shown on the map or plat are reserved for the use of the grantor, its successors and assigns. Streets shown on the plat are dedicated to the use of owners of tracts of land in the subdivision, but shall be maintained by the city. 
(Code 1995, § 157.39) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 70. 
Sec. 94-268. - Building limitation within 100-year floodplain. 
    No building or structure shall be erected, permitted or placed upon any part of the industrial park district which is located within the 100-year floodplain. All properties sold which contain any part of the 100-year floodplain shall be subject to deed restrictions enforcing such building limitations. The city hereby creates a natural drainage easement within the district which shall be the portion of the 100-year floodplain located within the district. The 100-year floodplain shall be designated on all current and future subdivision plats of the district. 
(Code 1995, § 157.40) 
Sec. 94-269. - Restrictions and covenants. 
(a)  The restrictions and covenants set forth in this division are hereby declared to be covenants running with the land and shall be fully binding upon all persons acquiring property in the industrial park district, whether by descent, devise, purchase or otherwise, and any person, by the acceptance of title to any lot of the subdivision, shall thereby agree and covenant to abide by and fully perform the restrictions and covenants set forth in this division. 
(b)  The covenants set forth in this division are to run with the land and shall be binding for a period of 25 years from the date of such covenants. At the end of such period, the restrictions and covenants shall automatically be extended for a successive period of ten years unless, by a vote of a three-fourths majority of the owners of the lots in the subdivision (each lot having one vote), taken prior to the expiration of the 25-year period and filed of record in the county, it is agreed to amend or release the restrictions and covenants. 
(Code 1995, § 157.37) 
Sec. 94-270. - Rights of city. 
    The city expressly reserves the sole right to further dedicate, plat and adopt phase III of the industrial park district and to amend the rules, regulations and restrictions set forth in this division as to phase III without the joinder or acquiescence of any owner of other property within the subdivision. 
(Code 1995, § 157.38) 
Sec. 94-271. - Violations. 
(a)  If any person shall violate, or attempt to violate, any of the restrictions and covenants set forth in this division, it shall be lawful for any person owning any lot in the industrial park district to prosecute proceedings at law or in equity against the person violating, or attempting to violate, any such restriction and covenant, either to prevent such person from committing such violation or to correct such violation or to recover damages or other relief for such violation. 
(b)  Invalidation of any one or part of the restrictions set forth in this division by judgment or court order shall in no way affect any of the other provisions, or parts thereof, which shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Code 1995, § 157.98) 
Secs. 94-272-94-300. - Reserved. 
APPENDIX A. - SPECIFICATIONS AND DESIGN STANDARDS FOR PUBLIC WORKS IMPROVEMENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 70. 

§ 1. - General. 
(a)  All subdivisions shall comply with the specifications and design standards as outlined in this appendix A. 
(b)  Three copies of plans and profiles for streets, alleys, sidewalks and drainage easements, including the information required in this appendix A, shall be submitted within each subdivision plat. 
(Code 1995, ch. 156, app. A, § 1) 
§ 2. - Streets, alleys and sidewalks. 
(a)  Plans. Plans shall include the following: 
(1)  Typical sections showing the proposed pavement width, type, thickness and growth; the proposed curb or curb and gutter type, as required, location in relation to centerline and exposure; the proposed sidewalk dimensions and location in relation to curbs and property lines; the proposed street grading slopes for each of the different types of streets and alleys in the subdivision. 
(2)  Alignment of each street, alley, sidewalk and crosswalkway, showing a beginning and ending station; each deflection angle of the centerline and the point of intersection; the station of the point of curvature and the point of tangency of each curve; the station and angle of intersection of each intersection with another street, alley or drainage easement; the station and radius of each curb return; the location of adjacent right-of-way lines; the location and limits of sidewalks and curbs of each street; the location of monuments. 
(3)  Location, description and elevation of benchmarks; the top of curb grade at each curb end, 50-foot station and the end of curb return; the centerline grade at each end and each 50-foot station of alleys; the gradient of each tangent grade and the location and length of each vertical curve; the direction of storm drainage flow at each intersection; the profiles of streets, alleys and drainage ditches shall show the natural ground at adjacent property lines and the proposed centerline. 
(4)  Scale, north arrow and date. The plan and profile shall be drawn to a scale of one inch equals 50 feet horizontally, and one inch equals five feet vertically. 
(b)  Design standards. Design standards shall include the following: 
(1)  At each street intersection, the curb shall be rounded with an R curve or radius, varying with the interior angle as specified in table 1 in § 6(a) of this appendix A. 
(2)  At each intersection, the property lines at each block corner shall be rounded with an R curve or radius, varying with the interior angle as specified in table 1 in § 6(a) of this appendix A. 
(3)  Street and alley grades shall, in general, conform to the terrain, and shall not exceed the grades specified in table 2 in § 6(b) of this appendix A. No street or alley grade shall be less than three-tenths of one percent unless otherwise specified by the engineer. 
(4)  Horizontal curve radii shall not be less than the radii specified in table 2 in § 6(b) of this appendix A. 
(c)  Construction requirements. The subdivider shall excavate, fill and grade all alleys and new streets within the subdivision, including sidewalk areas where required, so that pavements and sidewalks may be constructed along lines and grades approved by the engineer. In general, the grades of sidewalk areas shall be established so that no extreme or abrupt changes in grade are encountered within blocks, but variations may be allowed where, because of soil conditions, topography or valuable trees, the establishment of such grades would result in undue hardship. New streets and alleys shall be surfaced in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the engineer and constructed under his supervision. No street shall be surfaced or alley finished to specifications of this appendix A until the underground utilities which are to be installed in the portions of the streets or alleys intended for vehicular traffic have been installed and taps completed. New streets, including previously dedicated rights-of-way, and existing unpaved streets abutting both sides to a new subdivision shall be constructed in accordance with the standards of table 3 in § 6(c) of this appendix A and the following requirements: 
(1)  Subgrade preparation. Subgrade shall be prepared in accordance with the specifications of the engineer, and compacted to a standard proctor dry density of not less than 90 percent. When fill is required, it shall be placed in uniform lifts not to exceed six inches in depth prior with pneumatic rollers or eight inches prior to compaction with other types of rollers. Each lift shall be compacted to 90 percent standard proctor density before succeeding lifts are placed. Density tests shall be taken a minimum of one per city block or one every 600 feet if the block exceeds 600 feet in length. Developers shall provide proctor tests upon request of the engineer. 
(2)  Flexible base. When asphaltic pavement surfaces are used, the base shall be a compacted flexible base constructed to the specification of the engineer to the depth shown in table 3 in § 6(c) of this appendix A, with a standard proctor density of not less than 95 percent. 
(3)  Stabilized base. As alternate to the flexible base set forth in subsection (c)(2) of this section, a compacted soil-cement base, with a standard proctor density of 95 percent, may be used, with a soil-cement ratio and thickness as approved by the engineer. 
(4)  Asphaltic pavement. The compacted surface course shall be applied at the rates specified in table 3 in § 6(c) of this appendix A. The paving mixture and construction methods shall conform to the specifications of the engineer for hot mix, hot laid asphaltic concrete, hot mix fold laid asphaltic concrete or cold mix limestone rock asphalt. 
(5)  Concrete pavement. All concrete pavement shall be Portland cement concrete of a depth and compressive strength specified in table 3 in § 6(c) of this appendix A, and constructed in accordance with the specifications of the engineer. Reinforcing steel shall be a six by six wire mesh or No. 3 round steel, 18 inches on center, both ways. 
(6)  Curbs and combined curb and gutter. Curbs or combined curb and gutter sections shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete and installed in accordance with the specifications of the engineer on all streets within the subdivision along the lines and grades approved by the engineer. Curbs or combined curb and gutter shall be provided on both sides of all streets within subdivisions and on the side of boundary streets adjacent to the subdivision. Base material shall be placed and compacted beginning three inches behind the curb. 
(7)  Sidewalks and crosswalks. All sidewalks and crosswalks shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete at least four inches thick and at least four feet wide, according to specifications of the engineer, and along the lines and grades approved by the engineer. 
(8)  Aggregate specifications. See table 12 in § 6(l) of this appendix A for aggregate specifications. 
(9)  Rear/alley drives/entrances. New subdivisions and replats of subdivisions with rear/alley drives/entrances will require the developer to have paved alleys included in the plans submitted for approval. Developers of new subdivisions abutting an existing subdivision will be required to pave the entire width of any alley being affected in existing subdivisions. 
(Code 1995, ch. 156, app. A, § 2) 
§ 3. - Drainage and drainage structures. 
(a)  Plans. The required drainage and drainage structure plans shall show the following information: 
(1)  Construction details of all drainage structures, including dimensions, reinforcement and components such as grades and manhole covers. 
(2)  Alignment of drainage easements, showing a beginning and ending station; each deflection angle of the centerline and the station of the point of intersection; the station of the point of curvature and the point of tangency of each curve; the station and angle of intersection of each intersection with another drainage easement; the location of each drainage structure; and the location and size of all storm sewers. 
(3)  The centerline grade at each end and each 50-foot station of drainage ditches; the direction of the storm drainage flow at each intersection; the flow line elevations of each drainage structure; the flow line elevation of each storm sewer at each point of change, each end and at the intervening gradients. 
(4)  All construction in floodprone areas require evidence of floodproofing as required by National Flood Insurance Law. 
(b)  Drainage computations. 
(1)  Runoff rates shall be computed as determined by the engineer. In all cases, runoff rates shall be computed on the basis of ultimate development of the entire watershed contributing runoff water to the proposed subdivision on the basis of concrete lined channels and streets carrying stormwater in the contributing area. 
(2)  Streets may be used to carry stormwater if the calculated flow does not exceed that required by the engineer, or the velocity does not exceed ten feet per second. Minor streets shall be designed on a five-year frequency. Where streets are not capable of meeting the requirements of this subsection, drainage structures shall be provided. Street widths shall not be widened beyond the width determined by street classification. 
(3)  Concrete and earth lined channels and storm sewers shall be designed on the basis of a 25-year frequency. 
(4)  Alleys shall be designed on the basis of a five-year frequency to carry stormwater only from the lots within the blocks abutting the alleys. 
(c)  Construction standards. 
(1)  All drainage structures shall be constructed in accordance with the plans and specifications and to the lines and grades approved by the engineer. 
(2)  All concrete used in drainage structures shall develop a compressive strength of 3,000 pounds per square inch (psi) in 28 days. All castings shall conform to the standard specifications for gray iron castings, ASTM Designation A-48, for class 2 gray cast iron. 
(d)  Drainage ditches. In concrete lined ditches, the lining shall extend one foot beyond the height of the design flow line. Between the top of the lining and the top of the ditch an earth sodded side slope, not steeper than two horizontal to one vertical, may be used. Vertical concrete walls shall not exceed two feet in height unless such walls are properly fenced or enclosed. Earth sodded channels shall be mulch sodded over the entire surface area of the channel, and the side slope shall not be steeper than three horizontal to one vertical. 
(Code 1995, ch. 156, app. A, § 3) 
§ 4. - Sanitary sewers. 
(a)  All gravity sewers shall be vitrified clay, asbestos cement, cast iron, PVC SDR 35 with rubber gaskets and pushed together joints, or concrete sewer pipe with delta seal or equal coupling conforming to American Society for Testing Materials (ASTM) standard, and installed in conformance with the specifications of the water and sewer superintendent. 
(b)  The minimum size of lateral sewer mains in residential areas shall be six inches in diameter. Minimum grades shall be sufficient to produce a velocity of two feet per second. 
(c)  All outfall mains shall be of a sufficient size to accommodate the maximum anticipated flow from the entire tributary to the line, as approved by the water and sewer superintendent. 
(d)  Lift stations shall be furnished, where necessary, and shall be of such size and design as determined by the water and sewer superintendent or engineer. 
(e)  All sewer lines must be bedded as follows: 
(1)  Soils without rock are to be bedded with No. 6 sand, pea gravel or crushed rock over the pipe and on top of the pipe. 
(2)  Where the soil in the trenches is wet, No. 6 crushed rock one inch to 11/2 inches in size over the pipe and No. 6 sand on top of the pipe shall be used. 
(3)  When trenches are rocky, No. 6 sand, pea gravel or small crushed rock over the pipe and No. 12 sand, pea gravel or crushed rock on top of pipe shall be used. 
(f)  All sewer lines, when completed, must be tested with water or air so that no water will infiltrate into the sewer system. 
(g)  All sewer lines installed in a subdivision or any sewer line that connects to the city sewer system must be inspected by a city inspector. 
(h)  When the sewer line is completed, all manholes and cleanouts must be set flush with the finished grade or paving. 
(i)  All sewer lines in a subdivision must have a manhole every 500 feet and at each change of direction of 45 degrees or greater. All cement work in the bottom of a manhole must be finished so there is no obstruction to the water flow. Joints and connections in the manhole must be watertight so that no water will infiltrate into the sewer system. 
(Code 1995, ch. 156, app. A, § 4) 
§ 5. - Water mains. 
(a)  All water distribution mains shall be installed in conformance with the specifications of the water and sewer superintendent or engineer. 
(b)  The minimum size of lateral water mains shall be six inches in diameter. 
(c)  All principal mains shall be of a sufficient size to meet all anticipated requirements of the system, as determined by the water and sewer superintendent or engineer. 
(d)  The layout of mains shall assure two-way flow at all points in the system, with the exception of extensions on culs-de-sac and other dead ends approved by the water and sewer superintendent or engineer. 
(e)  Water mains will be located in alleys, when at all possible. 
(f)  All water lines must be bedded as follows: 
(1)  Soils without rock shall be bedded with No. 6 sand, pea gravel or crushed rock over the pipe and on top of the pipe. 
(2)  Where the soil in the trenches is wet, No. 6 crushed rock one inch to 11/2 inches in size over the pipe and No. 6 sand on top of the pipe shall be used. 
(3)  When trenches are rocky, No. 6 sand, pea gravel or small crushed rock over the pipe and No. 12 sand, pea gravel or crushed rock on top of the pipe shall be used. 
(g)  Water mains must be pressure tested at a minimum of 100 pounds working pressure, and found to be tight. 
(h)  All water mains, when installed in a subdivision, must be inspected by a city inspector. 
(i)  When water mains are completed, all valves and valve boxes must be set flush with the finished grade or paving. 
(j)  All water mains size six inches and larger must be cement asbestos, class 150 SDR 18 AWWA C-900 PVC, with rubber gaskets and pushed together joints, or cast iron, cement lined. All joints must be mechanical or fluidtight. 
(k)  All water mains four inches or smaller must be cement asbestos, PVC class 160 or cast iron, cement lined, and be fluidtight or mechanical joint. 
(l)  All water fittings must be cement lined and fluidtight or mechanical joint. 
(m)  Before water mains are put into service, they must be treated with chlorine for 24 hours. After 24 hours of treatment, such water mains must have a chlorine residual of 50 parts per million (ppm). After the city inspector has approved the 50 ppm test, the water mains must be flushed out until the chlorine residual is down to a maximum of five ppm. 
(n)  All change of direction fittings, such as tees, bends and valves, must be blocked by pouring concrete between the fitting and a solid bank. 
(o)  Water mains and sewer mains must not be laid less than nine feet apart horizontally. 
(Code 1995, ch. 156, app. A, § 5) 
§ 6. - Tables. 
(a)  Table 1. Curb and block corner returns. See the city engineer for curb and block corner return specifications. 
(b)  Table 2. Grades and horizontal curves. See the city engineer for grade and horizontal curve specifications.

(e)  Table 5. Texas Department of Highways 1972 Standard Specifications For Construction of Highways, Streets and Bridges; Item No. 242; Flexible Base (Class 1). 
(1)  Description. Flexible base (class 1) shall consist of a foundation course for the surface course or other base course; be composed of crusher-run broken stone; and be constructed in one or more courses as specified in this subsection (e). 
(2)  Material. The material shall be crushed, and shall consist of durable particles of stone mixed with approved binding materials. The material shall be stockpiled and must be approved by the engineer. 
(3)  Types. Types of flexible base material are identified as follows: 
a.  Type A. Type A flexible base shall consist of crushed material as described in subsection (e)(2) of this section. 
b.  Type B. Type B flexible base shall consist of crushed material as described in subsection (e)(2) of this section, and, prior to crushing, shall be screened, partially screened or otherwise manipulated in a manner satisfactory to the engineer, in order that all soil, clay and other objectionable material will be removed. 
(4)  Grades. The material shall conform to the requirements of either grade 1 or grade 2 as follows: 
a.  Grade 1. 
1.  After placement on the road, the base material shall be wetted and windrowed. Job control samples for testing gradation shall be taken prior to compaction operations. The flexible base material shall meet the following requirements: 
Retained on 13/4 sieve      0% Retained on 7/8 sieve  8-30% Retained on 3/8 sieve 30-50% Retained on No. 4 sieve 45-65% Retained on No. 40 sieve 70-85  
2.  Material passing the No. 40 sieve shall be known as soil binder, and shall meet the following requirements when prepared in accordance with the Tex-101-E test method procedure: 
The liquid limit shall not exceed 40 The plasticity index shall not exceed 12  
3.  The processed material shall be of such soundness that when it is tested in accordance with the Tex-116-E test method, the resulting soil binder content (material passing the No. 40 sieve) shall not exceed 40 percent by weight of the total sample tested and the increase in soil binder shall not exceed 20. 
4.  When tested in accordance with the Tex-117-E test method, the material shall conform to the requirements for a class 1 base material. 
5.  With the written permission of the engineer, additives may be used in order to meet the requirements of this subsection (e)(4)a. 
b.  Grade 2. The grading, soil constants and/or triaxial requirements and other specification data for grade 2 flexible base material shall be shown on the plans. 
(5)  Construction methods. 
a.  Preparation of subgrade. The roadbed shall be excavated and shaped in conformity with the typical sections shown on plans and to the lines and grades as established by the engineer. All unstable or otherwise objectionable material shall be removed from the subgrade and replaced with approved material. All holes, ruts and depressions shall be filled with approved material, and if required, the subgrade shall be thoroughly wetted with water and reshaped and rolled to the extent directed in order to place the subgrade in an acceptable condition to receive the base material. The surface of the subgrade shall be finished to line and grade as established and in conformity with the typical section shown on the plans, and any deviation in excess of one-half inch in cross section and a length of 16 feet measured longitudinally shall be corrected by loosening, adding or removing material, reshaping and recompacting by sprinkling and rolling. Sufficient subgrade shall be prepared in advance to ensure satisfactory prosecution of the work. Subgrade shall be density controlled. 
b.  First course. 
1.  Immediately before placing the base material, the subgrade shall be checked as to conformity with the grade and section. The material shall be delivered in approved vehicles of a uniform capacity, and it shall be the charge of the contractor that the required amount of specified material shall be delivered in each 100-foot station. Material deposited upon the subgrade shall be spread and shaped the same day unless otherwise directed, in writing, by the engineer. If inclement weather or other unforeseen circumstances render the spreading of the material impractical during the first 24-hour period, the material shall be scarified and spread as directed by the engineer. 
2.  The material shall be sprinkled, if required, and shall then be shaped to conform to typical sections as shown on the plans in such a manner that a uniformity in grading of the material in place will be obtained that will not vary at any point on the road on any of the screen sizes from the grading of the material as set forth in subsection (e)(4) of this section. All areas and nests of segregated coarse or fine material not meeting such requirement shall be corrected or removed if directed by the engineer, and replaced with material meeting such requirement. The course shall then be sprinkled as required and compacted to the extent necessary to provide not less than the percent density as specified under subsection (e)(5)d. of this section. In addition to the requirements specified for density in subsection (e)(5)d. of this section, the full depth of flexible base shown on the plans shall be compacted to the extent necessary to remain firm and stable under construction equipment. After each section of flexible base is completed, tests will be made by the engineer, as necessary. If the material fails to meet the density requirements, it shall be reworked, as necessary, to meet such requirements. Throughout the entire operation, the shape of the course shall be maintained by blading, and the surface, upon completion, shall be smooth and in conformity with the typical section shown on the plans and to the established lines and grades. In the area on which pavement is to be placed, any deviation in excess of one-fourth inch in cross section and a length of 16 feet measured longitudinally shall be corrected by loosening, adding or removing material, reshaping and recompacting by sprinkling and rolling. All irregularities, depressions or weak spots which develop shall be immediately corrected by scarifying the areas affected, adding suitable materials, as required, reshaping and recompacting by sprinkling and rolling. 
3.  Due to any reason or cause, should the base course lose the required stability, density or finish before the surfacing is complete, it shall be recompacted and refinished at the sole expense of the contractor. Excessive loss of moisture in the completed base shall be prevented by sprinkling. 
4.  Traffic shall be controlled so that the repetitious application of heavy loads on unfinished base will be held to the absolute minimum. 
5.  During the period traffic is being directed over the course, the surface shall be satisfactorily maintained by the use of a sufficient number of approved blades, drags and such other equipment as is required. 
c.  Succeeding courses. Construction methods for succeeding courses shall be the same as prescribed for the first course. Prior to placing the surfacing on the completed base, the final course of the base shall be dry cured to the extent directed by the engineer. 
d.  Density. Each course of flexible base shall be compacted to the percent density stated in the requirements. The testing will be as outlined in the Tex-114-E test method. Field density determination shall be made in accordance with approved methods.
